input: Axionlike-particles (ALPs) are one promising type of dark matter candidate particle that may generate detectable effects on -ray spectra other than the canonical weakly interacting massive particles. In this work we search for such oscillation effects in the spectra of supernova remnants caused by the photon-ALP conversion, using the Fermi Large Area Telescope data. Three bright supernova remnants, IC443, W44, and W51C, are analyzed. The inclusion of photon-ALP oscillations yields an improved fit to the -ray spectrum of IC443, which gives a statistical significance of in favor of such spectral oscillation. However, the best-fit parameters of ALPs ( , ) are in tension with the upper bound ( ) set by the CAST experiment. It is difficult to explain the results using the systematic uncertainties of the flux measurements. We speculate that the "irregularity" displayed in the spectrum of IC443 may be due to the superposition of the emission from different parts of the remnant.

output.explanation:
The universe is composed of various forms of matter and energy, including dark matter, which can be influenced by particles such as axionlike-particles (ALPs). ALPs are hypothetical particles that may interact with photons through a process called photon-ALP conversion.

Axionlike-particle refers to the hypothetical particle's property of having a very weak interaction with normal matter. Dark matter is a type of matter that does not emit, absorb, or reflect light and thus remains invisible to our telescopes. Supernova remnants are the leftover material from massive stars that have exploded in supernovae events.

When photons interact with ALPs through photon-ALP conversion, it can lead to oscillations in the energy spectra of celestial objects like supernova remnants. These oscillations occur due to the change in frequency and wavelength of the emitted radiation as a result of the interaction between photons and ALPs.

The analysis revealed that accounting for photon-ALP oscillations yields an improved fit to the spectrum of IC443, indicating a statistical significance in favor of this phenomenon. However, the best-fit parameters obtained for ALPs are inconsistent with upper bounds set by other experiments.

title: Solar polarimetry in the K I line: A novel possibility for a stratospheric balloon
input: Of the two solar lines, K I and , almost all attention so far has been devoted to the line, as is severely affected by an O atmospheric band. This, however, makes the latter appealing for balloon and space observations from above (most of) the Earth's atmosphere. We estimate the residual effect of the O band on the K I line at altitudes typical for stratospheric balloons. Our aim is to study the feasibility of observing the 770 nm window. Specifically, this paper serves as a preparation for the third flight of the Sunrise balloon-borne observatory. The results indicate that the absorption by O is still present, albeit much weaker, at the expected balloon altitude. We applied the obtained O transmittance to K I synthetic polarimetric spectra and found that in the absence of line-of-sight motions, the residual O has a negligible effect on the K I line. On the other hand, for Doppler-shifted K I data, the residual O might alter the shape of the Stokes profiles. However, the residual O absorption is sufficiently weak at stratospheric levels that it can be divided out if appropriate measurements are made, something that is impossible at ground level. Therefore, for the first time with Sunrise III, we will be able to perform polarimetric observations of the K I line and, consequently, we will have improved access to the thermodynamics and magnetic properties of the upper photosphere from observations of the K I lines.

output.explanation:
The Earth's atmosphere is a complex system that affects various solar lines, including K I and O. The latter is particularly interesting for observations from above the atmospheric layers due to its reduced impact compared to the former.

The stratosphere, where balloons typically operate, has distinct characteristics that influence the behavior of these solar lines. At high altitudes, the residual effect of the O band on K I is still present but significantly weaker than at ground level. This residual absorption can be divided out if precise measurements are made, allowing for polarimetric observations of the K I line.

The key to understanding this phenomenon lies in the concept of transmittance and its application to synthetic spectra. Transmittance refers to the measure of light that passes through a medium without being absorbed or scattered. In this context, it's essential to consider the effects of Doppler shifts on the K I line, which can alter the shape of Stokes profiles under certain conditions.

The feasibility of observing the 770 nm window is crucial for studying thermodynamics and magnetic properties in the upper photosphere. By performing polarimetric observations with Sunrise III, researchers will gain improved access to this information through the analysis of K I lines.

title: The Størmer problem for an aligned rotator
input: The effective potential energy of the particles in the field of rotating uniformly magnetized celestial body is investigated. The axis of rotation coincides with the axis of the magnetic field. Electromagnetic field of the body is composed of a dipole magnetic and quadrupole electric fields. The geometry of the trapping regions is studied as a function of the magnetic field magnitude and the rotation speed of the body. Examples of the potential energy topology for different values of these parameters are given. The main difference from the classical Størmer problem is that the single toroidal trapping region predicted by Størmer is divided into equatorial and off-equatorial trapping regions. Applicability of the idealized model of a rotating uniformly magnetized sphere with a vacuum magnetosphere to real celestial bodies is discussed.

output.explanation:
A rotating, uniformly magnetized celestial body is the focus of this investigation. The alignment of its axis of rotation with the magnetic field axis creates an environment where electromagnetic forces are at play.

The key terms in this context include a dipole, which refers to a pair of equal but opposite charges separated by a distance, resulting in a defined direction for its associated field; and angular velocity, or the rate at which an object rotates around a central axis. The interaction between rotation and magnetization gives rise to distinct trapping regions within the electromagnetic field.

The geometry of these trapping regions is influenced by both the strength of the magnetic field and the rate at which the celestial body rotates. As these parameters change, so too does the topology of potential energy within these regions. This scenario differs from classical models like Størmer's problem in that a single toroidal region is divided into equatorial and off-equatorial trapping areas.

The behavior of particles within this environment depends on both the magnetic field magnitude and rotation speed of the body, leading to distinct trapping regions with varying potential energy topologies. The applicability of an idealized model featuring a rotating sphere with a vacuum magnetosphere to real celestial bodies is also considered.

title: Spatial Inhomogeneity In Solar Faculae
input: In this paper, we investigate the inhomogeneous spatial distribution of solar faculae. The focus is on the latitudinal and longitudinal distributions of these highly localised features covering ubiquitously the solar surface. The statistical analysis is based on white light observations of the Solar and Heliospheric Observatory (SOHO) and Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO) between 1996 and 2014. We found that the fine structure of the latitudinal distribution of faculae displays a quasi-biennial oscillatory pattern. Furthermore, the longitudinal distribution of photospheric solar faculae does not show homogeneous behaviour either. In particular, the non-axisymmetric behaviour of these events show similar properties as that of the active longitude (AL) found in the distribution of sunspots. Our results, preliminary though, may provide a valuable observational constrain for developing the next-generation solar dynamo model.

output.explanation:
The Sun's surface is a complex environment with various features, including solar faculae, which are highly localised and cover the entire surface ubiquitously.

Solar faculae refer to bright regions on the Sun's photosphere, while active longitude (AL) refers to a specific region of high activity near the Sun's equator. The longitudinal distribution of these features does not display homogeneous behaviour.

The fine structure of solar faculae's latitudinal distribution exhibits a quasi-biennial oscillatory pattern due to periodic changes in their organisation and magnetic field interactions within the Sun's interior. This complex interplay between different processes leads to non-axisymmetric properties similar to those found in sunspots' active longitude.

The spatial organisation of solar faculae displays a quasi-biennial oscillation, which may be a key aspect of these dynamics, providing valuable insights for developing next-generation solar dynamo models.

title: Artificial Neural Network for Constructing Type Ia Supernovae Spectrum Evolution Model
input: We construct and train an artificial neural network called the back-propagation neural network to describe the evolution of the type Ia supernova spectrum by using the data from the CfA Supernova Program. This network method has many attractive features, and one of them is that the constructed model is differentiable. Benefitting from this, we calculate the absorption velocity and its variation. The model we constructed can well describe not only the spectrum of SNe Ia with wavelength range from to , but also the light-curve evolution with phase time from to with different colors. Moreover, the number of parameters needed during the training process is much less than the usual methods.

output.explanation:
The universe's vast expanse hosts a variety of celestial events, including supernovae type Ia, which are characterized by their distinct spectral signatures and light-curve evolution patterns.

In astrophysics, differentiability refers to the property of a function that can be expressed as an infinite series of terms involving derivatives. A neural network is a computational tool used for modeling complex phenomena like type Ia supernovae spectra. Type Ia supernova spectrum describes the distribution of light across various wavelengths.

The back-propagation method enables precise calculations of physical properties due to its differentiable nature. This property allows researchers to effectively describe the spectral characteristics of SNe Ia within specific wavelength ranges and their light-curve evolution over time with varying colors.

The constructed model's ability to accurately predict these phenomena is attributed to its capacity for describing both the spectrum and light-curve evolution of type Ia supernovae. The model can well describe not only the spectrum but also the light-curve evolution, which are essential for understanding these events.

title: Weak lensing probe of cubic Galileon model
input: The cubic Galileon model containing the lowest non-trivial order action of the full Galileon action can produce the stable late-time cosmic acceleration. This model can have a significant role in the growth of structures. The signatures of the cubic Galileon model in the structure formation can be probed by the weak lensing statistics. Weak lensing convergence statistics is one of the strongest probes to the structure formation and hence it can probe the dark energy or modified theories of gravity models. In this work, we investigate the detectability of the cubic Galileon model from the CDM model or from the canonical quintessence model through the convergence power spectrum and bi-spectrum.

output.explanation:
The universe's late-time acceleration is a phenomenon where the expansion of space accelerates over time, and it can be described by modified theories of gravity or dark energy models. The cubic Galileon model proposes an action with non-trivial order to explain this acceleration.

In cosmology, structure formation refers to how matter clumps together under gravitational forces. Key terms like 'Galileon' and 'structure growth' are related to the way galaxies and galaxy clusters form in the universe. The cubic Galion model can affect these processes by modifying gravity's behavior on large scales.

The mechanism behind this modification involves a complex interplay between gravity, matter distribution, and the expansion of space. When considering modified theories like the cubic Galileon model, researchers must account for how changes to gravity impact structure formation and late-time acceleration.

In particular, the detectability of the cubic Galileon model from other theories such as CDM or canonical quintessence models can be probed through statistical tools like the convergence power spectrum and bi-spectrum. These methods allow researchers to quantify matter distribution and its fluctuations in different regions of the universe.

title: Ghost Images in Helioseismic Holography? Toy Models in a Uniform Medium
input: Helioseismic holography is a powerful technique used to probe the solar interior based on estimations of the 3D wavefield. Porter--Bojarski holography, which is a well-established method used in acoustics to recover sources and scatterers in 3D, is also an estimation of the wavefield, and hence it has the potential to be applied to helioseismology. Here we present a proof of concept study, where we compare helioseismic holography and Porter--Bojarski holography under the assumption that the waves propagate in a homogeneous medium. We consider the problem of locating a point source of wave excitation inside a sphere. Under these assumptions, we find that the two imaging methods have the same capability of locating the source, with the exception that helioseismic holography suffers from "ghost images" (i.e., artificial peaks away from the source location). We conclude that Porter--Bojarski holography may improve the current method used in helioseismology.

output.explanation:
The solar interior is a region where waves propagate through the plasma, carrying information about its internal structure and dynamics. A homogeneous medium is characterized by uniform density or composition throughout space.

In this context, helioseismology refers to the study of wave propagation in the Sun's interior, while Porter--Bojarski holography is a method for recovering sources within three-dimensional spaces. This technique relies on estimations of the 3D wavefield and has been applied effectively in acoustics.

The process involves waves propagating through a homogeneous medium without spatial variations in density or composition. Under these conditions, both imaging methods have equal capability to locate point sources inside a sphere. However, helioseismic holography suffers from 'ghost images,' artificial peaks away from the source location.

In a homogeneous medium with no spatial variations, Porter--Bojarski holography may offer an improvement over current helioseismology methods by reducing or eliminating these ghost images.

title: Exploring the constraints on cosmological models with CosmoEJS
input: We introduce new CosmoEJS modules to improve the investigation of the consequences of constraints on the parameter values of cosmological models. We use CosmoMC to fit dark energy models and modified gravity models to recent data from the cosmic microwave background measurements of the Planck satellite, baryon acoustic oscillations, supernovae type Ia, Hubble Parameter H(z) measurements, and redshift space distortions. While the results are in agreement with previous constraints for these models, here, we add an investigation into the statistical fits with CosmoEJS, an interactive Java package of simulations that allow the user to explore the ramifications of choosing various values for the cosmological parameters of a particular model. We visually inspect the plots of the simulated theoretical values for comparisons to the observational values, calculate derived cosmological values, and finally plot the expansion history of cosmological models. These new simulations now include modified gravity cosmological models as well as observations of the growth of structures of galaxies for a more accurate description of the universe's dynamics. The latest version of CosmoEJS is available from http://www.compadre.org/osp/items/detail.cfm?ID=12406.

output.explanation:
The universe's evolution is shaped by the interplay between its expansion and various physical processes. Cosmological models describe this complex behavior, relying on a set of parameters that need to be constrained through observations.

In cosmology, dark energy refers to the mysterious force driving the acceleration of the universe's expansion. Modified gravity models attempt to explain this phenomenon by altering how matter interacts with gravity. Baryon acoustic oscillations and supernovae type Ia are key observational tools for understanding these processes.

CosmoEJS modules facilitate the investigation of constraints on cosmological parameters, enabling users to explore the consequences of different parameter values through interactive simulations. These simulations allow for comparisons between simulated theoretical values and observational data, ultimately informing our understanding of the universe's dynamics.

The new CosmoEJS modules include modified gravity models and observations of galaxy structure growth, providing a more accurate description of the universe's behavior. By analyzing these simulations, researchers can derive cosmological parameters and plot the expansion history of various models.

title: Time's arrow and life's origin
input: The thermodynamic arrow-of-time problem is thought to be resolved by the observation that our universe initially was---and still is---far from equilibrium. The psychological arrow-of-time problem is often attributed the same resolution, but the connection has not been thoroughly established. I argue that a compelling explanation of the psychological arrow requires an understanding of the physical conditions necessary for life to emerge from a prebiotic environment. A simple calculation illustrates how life-sustaining energy fluxes from the Sun and the Earth's interior bias the development of life in the direction of the arrow inherited from cosmic initial conditions.

output.explanation:
The universe's thermodynamic properties are characterized by its initial and ongoing state far from equilibrium, a condition that has persisted since the beginning of time. This persistent disequilibrium sets the stage for understanding various phenomena related to life's emergence in a prebiotic environment.

To grasp this phenomenon, it's essential to define key terms: 'prebiotic' refers to the period before life existed on Earth; 'equilibrium' describes a system where energy is evenly distributed with no net flow. The concept of equilibrium is crucial here because living organisms rely on gradients and fluxes to sustain themselves.

The emergence of life in such an environment involves complex interactions between various energy sources, including those from the Sun and the Earth's interior. These energy fluxes create imbalances that allow for life development towards a particular direction, influenced by cosmic initial conditions.

A simple calculation illustrates how these life-sustaining energy fluxes bias the development of life in the direction inherited from cosmic initial conditions.

title: Black hole perturbations in vector-tensor theories: The odd-mode analysis
input: In generalized Proca theories with vector-field derivative couplings, a bunch of hairy black hole solutions have been derived on a static and spherically symmetric background. In this paper, we formulate the odd-parity black hole perturbations in generalized Proca theories by expanding the corresponding action up to second order and investigate whether or not black holes with vector hair suffer ghost or Laplacian instabilities. We show that the models with cubic couplings , where with a vector field , do not provide any additional stability condition as in General Relativity. On the other hand, the exact charged stealth Schwarzschild solution with a nonvanishing longitudinal vector component , which originates from the coupling to the Einstein tensor equivalent to the quartic coupling containing a linear function of , is unstable in the vicinity of the event horizon. The same instability problem also persists for hairy black holes arising from general quartic power-law couplings with the nonvanishing , while the other branch with can be consistent with conditions for the absence of ghost and Laplacian instabilities. We also discuss the case of other exact and numerical black hole solutions associated with intrinsic vector-field derivative couplings and show that there exists a wide range of parameter spaces in which the solutions suffer neither ghost nor Laplacian instabilities against odd-parity perturbations.

output.explanation:
Black holes with vector hair exist in a specific type of physical setting, where gravity is described by General Relativity and an additional vector field interacts with matter through derivative couplings. In this context, the term 'vector hair' refers to the presence of a nonvanishing longitudinal component of the vector field near the event horizon of a black hole. The key concept in understanding these systems is that of generalized Proca theories, which involve vector-field derivative couplings and can be formulated using an action that includes terms up to second order.

To analyze stability, we need to understand what 'ghost' or 'Laplacian instabilities' mean: a ghost instability occurs when the system has negative energy density, while Laplacian instability arises from unbounded growth of perturbations. In generalized Proca theories with cubic couplings, no additional stability conditions are required beyond those in General Relativity.

However, for certain types of quartic power-law couplings, black holes can suffer instabilities near the event horizon. Specifically, when a nonvanishing longitudinal vector component is present, the system becomes unstable. Nevertheless, there exists a range of parameter spaces where these solutions are stable against odd-parity perturbations.

The exact charged stealth Schwarzschild solution and other numerical black hole solutions associated with intrinsic vector-field derivative couplings also exhibit instability problems in certain regimes.

title: Understanding Type Ia supernovae through their U-band spectra
input: Context. Observations of Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) can be used to derive accurate cosmological distances through empirical standardization techniques. Despite this success neither the progenitors of SNe Ia nor the explosion process are fully understood. The U-band region has been less well observed for nearby SNe, due to technical challenges, but is the most readily accessible band for high-redshift SNe. Aims. Using spectrophotometry from the Nearby Supernova Factory, we study the origin and extent of U-band spectroscopic variations in SNe Ia and explore consequences for their standardization and the potential for providing new insights into the explosion process. Methods. We divide the U-band spectrum into four wavelength regions λ(uNi), λ(uTi), λ(uSi) and λ(uCa). Two of these span the Ca H&K λλ 3934, 3969 complex. We employ spectral synthesis using SYNAPPS to associate the two bluer regions with Ni/Co and Ti. Results. (1) The flux of the uTi feature is an extremely sensitive temperature/luminosity indicator, standardizing the SN peak luminosity to 0.116 0.011 mag RMS. A traditional SALT2.4 fit on the same sample yields a 0.135 mag RMS. Standardization using uTi also reduces the difference in corrected magnitude between SNe originating from different host galaxy environments. (2) Early U-band spectra can be used to probe the Ni+Co distribution in the ejecta, thus offering a rare window into the source of lightcurve power. (3) The uCa flux further improves standardization, yielding a 0.086 0.010 mag RMS without the need to include an additional intrinsic dispersion to reach χ /dof 1. This reduction in RMS is partially driven by an improved standardization of Shallow Silicon and 91T-like SNe.

output.explanation:
The universe's expansion is measured using Type Ia supernovae, which are incredibly powerful explosions of stars. These events can be used to derive accurate distances in the cosmos. However, scientists still don't fully understand what triggers these explosions or how they work.

Key terms like spectrophotometry and SYNAPPS refer to advanced techniques for analyzing light from distant objects. Spectrophotometry involves measuring the intensity of different wavelengths of light emitted by a source, while SYNAPPS is a software tool used for spectral synthesis. This process associates specific features in the U-band spectrum with elements such as nickel/cobalt and titanium.

The interaction between these processes occurs when scientists divide the U-band spectrum into four regions: λ(uNi), λ(uTi), λ(uSi), and λ(uCa). These regions are associated with distinct features, including those related to calcium. The flux of certain features in this spectrum can be used as a sensitive indicator of temperature and luminosity.

The system's behavior is characterized by the ability to standardize supernova peak luminosities using specific features in their U-band spectra. This allows for more accurate measurements of cosmological distances. For instance, the uTi feature has been shown to reduce the RMS (root mean square) error in these measurements from 0.135 mag to 0.116 mag.

title: Gamma-ray burst afterglow blast waves
input: The various stages of baryonic gamma-ray burst afterglow blast waves are reviewed. These are responsible for the afterglow emission from which much of our understanding of gamma-ray bursts derives. Initially, the blast waves are confined to the dense medium surrounding the burster (stellar envelope or dense wind), giving rise to a jet-cocoon structure. A massive ejecta is released and potentially fed by ongoing energy release from the burster and a forward-reverse shock system is set up between ejecta and ambient density. Ultimately the blast wave spreads sideways and slows down, and the dominant afterglow emission shifts from X-rays down to radio. Over the past years significant progress has been made both observationally and theoretically/numerically in our understanding of these blast waves, unique in the universe due to their often incredibly high initial Lorentz factors of 100-1000. The recent discovery of a short gamma-ray burst counterpart to a gravitational wave detection (GW 170817) brings the promise of a completely new avenue to explore and constrain the dynamics of gamma-ray burst blast waves.

output.explanation:
Gamma-ray bursts are intense explosions that occur in the dense environments surrounding massive stars, releasing enormous amounts of energy into space.

Key terms like **jet** refer to narrow beams of energetic particles emitted by these explosions, while a **cocoon** describes the denser material surrounding the jet. The interaction between the fast-moving ejecta and ambient density sets up a forward-reverse shock system, creating strong shocks that accelerate particles to high energies.

The blast wave's behavior can be understood through its interactions with the environment: initially confined by the dense medium, it eventually spreads sideways and slows down, causing the dominant afterglow emission to shift from X-rays to radio frequencies. This process is unique in the universe due to the incredibly high initial Lorentz factors of 100-1000.

The blast wave's dynamics are characterized by its ability to spread sideways and slow down, leading to a shift in the dominant afterglow emission. The recent discovery of a short gamma-ray burst counterpart to a gravitational wave detection has opened up new avenues for exploring and constraining these complex astrophysical phenomena.

title: A closer look at the quadruply lensed quasar PSOJ0147: spectroscopic redshifts and microlensing effect
input: I present timely spectroscopic follow-up of the newly discovered, quadruply lensed quasar PSOJ0147 from the Pan-STARRS 1 survey. The newly acquired optical spectra with GMOS onboard the Gemini north telescope allow us to pin down the redshifts of both the foreground lensing galaxy and the background lensed quasar to be z=0.572 and 2.341, providing firm basis for cosmography with future high cadence photometric monitoring. I also inspect difference spectra from two of the quasar images, revealing the microlensing effect. Long-term spectroscopic follow-ups will shed lights on the structure of the AGN and its environment.

output.explanation:
The universe's large-scale structure is shaped by the distribution of matter and energy, which can bend light around massive objects like galaxies. In this context, a quadruply lensed quasar PSOJ0147 has been discovered in the Pan-STARRS 1 survey. Quasars are incredibly luminous objects powered by supermassive black holes at their centers.

A redshift is a measure of how much light from an object has been stretched due to expansion of space between the observer and that object. The foreground galaxy acts as a gravitational lens, distorting and magnifying the light from the background quasar into multiple images. This phenomenon is known as microlensing when caused by massive objects in the foreground.

The redshifts of both the foreground lensing galaxy and the background quasar have been determined to be z=0.572 and 2.341, respectively. These values provide a firm basis for cosmography with future high cadence photometric monitoring. The microlensing effect has also been observed in difference spectra from two quasar images.

The redshifts of the foreground galaxy and background quasar indicate that they are separated by vast distances within our universe. This information will be crucial for understanding the structure of active galactic nuclei (AGN) and their environments, which can only be achieved through long-term spectroscopic follow-ups.

title: The IceCube Neutrino Observatory, the Pierre Auger Observatory and the Telescope Array: Joint Contribution to the 35th International Cosmic Ray Conference (ICRC 2017)
input: Joint contributions of the IceCube Collaboration, the Telescope Array Collaboration, and the Pierre Auger Collaboration to the 35th International Cosmic Ray Conference (ICRC 2017), 12-20 July 2017, Bexco, Busan, Korea.

output.explanation:
High-energy cosmic rays interact with the Earth's atmosphere, producing extensive air showers that can be detected by observatories like IceCube and Telescope Array.

The core concepts in this context include 'cosmic ray', which refers to high-energy particles from outside the solar system; 'extensive air shower', a cascade of secondary particles produced when cosmic rays collide with atmospheric nuclei; and 'air fluorescence', the emission of light by excited nitrogen molecules as they return to their ground state.

The mechanism behind these observations involves the detection of Cherenkov radiation, which is emitted by charged particles moving through the atmosphere at relativistic speeds, and air fluorescence, which provides a more detailed picture of the shower's development.

The collaborations report on the joint analysis of data from multiple observatories to study cosmic ray properties such as energy spectra and composition.

title: Exotic energy injection with ExoCLASS: Application to the Higgs portal model and evaporating black holes
input: We devise a new user-friendly tool interfaced with the Boltzmann code CLASS to deal with any kind of exotic electromagnetic energy injection in the universe and its impact on anisotropies of the Cosmic Microwave Background. It makes use of the results from standard electromagnetic cascade calculations develop in the context of WIMP annihilation, generalized to incorporate any injection history. We first validate it on a specific WIMP scenario, the Higgs Portal model, confirming that the standard effective on-the-spot treatment is accurate enough. We then analyze the more involved example of evaporating Primordial Black Holes (PBHs) with masses in the range g, for which the standard approximations break down. We derive robust CMB bounds on the relic density of evaporating PBHs, ruling out the possibility for PBHs with a monochromatic distribution of masses in the range g to represent all of the Dark Matter in our Universe. Remarkably, we confirm with an accurate study that the CMB bounds are several orders of magnitude stronger than those from the galactic gamma-ray background in the range g. A future CMB experiment like CORE+, or an experiment attempting at measuring the 21 cm signal from the Dark Ages could greatly improve the sensitivity to these models.

output.explanation:
The universe's electromagnetic energy injection has a profound impact on the Cosmic Microwave Background's anisotropies, shaping our understanding of cosmology.

Exotic electromagnetic energy injection refers to unusual sources of radiation that deviate from standard models, often associated with WIMP annihilation and Primordial Black Holes (PBHs). The term 'exotic' in this context highlights the departure from conventional expectations. PBHs are small regions in space characterized by extremely high densities.

To grasp these processes, it's essential to understand key terms: the Boltzmann code CLASS is a computational tool used for simulating cosmic evolution; WIMP stands for Weakly Interacting Massive Particle. The interaction between exotic electromagnetic energy injection and PBHs can be complex, involving matter conversion into radiation through mechanisms like annihilation or evaporation.

The study reveals that standard approximations break down for PBHs with masses in the range g, leading to robust CMB bounds on their relic density. This rules out monochromatic distributions of masses within this range representing all Dark Matter in our universe. Furthermore, it is found that CMB bounds are several orders of magnitude stronger than those from galactic gamma-ray backgrounds for PBHs with masses in the specified range.

title: Suzaku Observations of Heavily Obscured (Compton-thick) Active Galactic Nuclei selected by Swift/BAT Hard X-ray Survey
input: We present a uniform broadband X-ray (0.5-100.0 keV) spectral analysis of 12 Swift/Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) selected Compton-thick ( ) Active Galactic Nuclei (CTAGNs) observed with Suzaku. The Suzaku data of 3 objects are published here for the first time. We fit the Suzaku and Swift spectra with models utilizing an analytic reflection code and those utilizing the Monte Carlo based model from an AGN torus by Ikeda et al. 2009. The main results are as follows. (1) The estimated intrinsic luminosity of a CTAGN strongly depends on the model; applying Compton scattering to the transmitted component in an analytic model may largely overestimates the intrinsic luminosity at large column densities. (2) Unabsorbed reflection components are commonly observed, suggesting that the tori are clumpy. (3) Most of CTAGNs show small scattering fractions (<0.5%) implying a buried AGN nature. (4) Comparison with the results obtained for Compton-thin AGNs (Kawamuro et al. 2016) suggests that the properties of these CTAGNs can be understood as a smooth extension from Compton-thin AGNs with heavier obscuration; we find no evidence that the bulk of the population of hard X-ray selected CTAGN is different from less obscured objects.

output.explanation:
Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) are incredibly luminous objects residing at the centers of galaxies, emitting energy across various wavelengths. Compton-thick AGNs have column densities so high that they block even X-rays from reaching us, making them difficult to study.

Compton scattering refers to a process where high-energy photons interact with free electrons in the interstellar medium, transferring some of their energy and changing direction. This phenomenon is crucial for understanding how X-rays are affected as they pass through dense clouds. Compton-thick AGNs have column densities so high that even X-rays from these objects can be blocked by surrounding material.

The AGN torus is a doughnut-shaped structure surrounding the central black hole, responsible for producing reflected light that we observe as X-rays. The Monte Carlo method simulates this process by modeling interactions between photons and matter in the torus. By comparing different models, researchers found significant discrepancies in estimated intrinsic luminosity.

The presence of unabsorbed reflection components indicates that AGN tori are clumpy, allowing some X-rays to escape without being absorbed by dense gas and dust. This is consistent with a buried AGN nature, where the central black hole is shrouded in obscuring material. Most CTAGNs show small scattering fractions (<0.5%), implying heavily obscured cores that can be understood as a smooth extension from Compton-thin AGNs with heavier obscuration.

title: The NuSTAR Extragalactic Surveys: source catalog and the Compton-thick fraction in the UDS field
input: We present the results and the source catalog of the NuSTAR survey in the UKIDSS Ultra Deep Survey (UDS) field, bridging the gap in depth and area between NuSTAR's ECDFS and COSMOS surveys. The survey covers a deg area of the field for a total observing time of 1.75 Ms, to a half-area depth of 155 ks corrected for vignetting at keV, and reaching sensitivity limits at half-area in the full ( keV), soft ( keV) and hard ( keV) bands of erg cm s , erg cm s , and erg cm s , respectively. A total of 67 sources are detected in at least one of the three bands, 56 of which have a robust optical redshift with a median of . Through a broadband ( keV) spectral analysis of the whole sample combined with the NuSTAR hardness ratios, we compute the observed Compton-thick (CT; cm ) fraction. Taking into account the uncertainties on each measurement, the final number of CT sources is . This corresponds to an observed CT fraction of , providing a robust lower limit to the intrinsic fraction of CT AGN and placing constraints on cosmic X-ray background synthesis models.

output.explanation:
The universe's X-ray emission is a complex phenomenon, with various sources contributing to its overall intensity. In the context of this study, an astrophysical source refers to any celestial object emitting X-rays.

A Compton-thick (CT) source is characterized by its dense gas and dust content, which blocks the passage of X-rays. This property is crucial in understanding the observed CT fraction.

The NuSTAR survey's mechanism involves collecting data from a significant area of the UKIDSS Ultra Deep Survey field using sensitive instruments. The observing time and depth achieved allow for sensitivity limits to be established across different energy bands, enabling the detection of various sources.

Through broadband spectral analysis combined with hardness ratios, the observed CT fraction is computed, providing a robust lower limit on the intrinsic fraction of CT Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) in the universe. The final number of Compton-thick sources estimated from this study corresponds to an observed CT fraction.

title: The 105 month Swift-BAT all-sky hard X-ray survey
input: We present a catalog of hard X-ray sources detected in the first 105 months of observations with the Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) coded mask imager on board the Swift observatory. The 105 month Swift-BAT survey is a uniform hard X-ray all-sky survey with a sensitivity of over 90% of the sky and over 50% of the sky in the 14-195 keV band. The Swift-BAT 105 month catalog provides 1632 (422 new detections) hard X-ray sources in the 14-195 keV band above the 4.8σ significance level. Adding to the previously known hard X-ray sources, 34% (144/422) of the new detections are identified as Seyfert AGN in nearby galaxies (z<0.2). The majority of the remaining identified sources are X-ray binaries (7%, 31) and blazars/BL Lac objects (10%, 43). As part of this new edition of the Swift-BAT catalog, we release eight-channel spectra and monthly sampled light curves for each object in the online journal and at the Swift-BAT 105 month Web site.

output.explanation:
The universe is filled with intense X-ray emissions from various astrophysical sources, such as black holes and neutron stars. These hard X-rays are produced when hot gas swirls around these compact objects, releasing energy in the form of radiation. The Swift-BAT observatory has been monitoring the sky for 105 months to detect and catalog these sources.

The resulting survey covers over 90% of the sky with high sensitivity, allowing researchers to study a vast number of hard X-ray emitters. A key term here is 'hard X-rays,' which refers to radiation in the energy range of 14-195 keV. This band is particularly useful for studying compact objects and their environments.

The Swift-BAT catalog contains 1632 sources above a certain significance level, including 422 new detections. These new sources are analyzed to determine their nature, with 34% identified as Seyfert Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) in nearby galaxies. The remaining sources are primarily X-ray binaries and blazars/BL Lac objects.

The catalog also includes eight-channel spectra and light curves for each object, providing valuable data for further research.

title: Evidence for radial variations in the stellar mass-to-light ratio of massive galaxies from weak and strong lensing
input: The Initial Mass Function (IMF) for massive galaxies can be constrained by combining stellar dynamics with strong gravitational lensing. However, this method is limited by degeneracies between the density profile of dark matter and the stellar mass-to-light ratio. In this work we reduce this degeneracy by combining weak lensing together with strong lensing and stellar kinematics. Our analysis is based on two galaxy samples: 45 strong lenses from the SLACS survey and 1,700 massive quiescent galaxies from the SDSS main spectroscopic sample with weak lensing measurements from the Hyper Suprime-Cam survey. We use a Bayesian hierarchical approach to jointly model all three observables. We fit the data with models of varying complexity and show that a model with a radial gradient in the stellar mass-to-light ratio is required to simultaneously describe both galaxy samples. This result is driven by a subset of strong lenses with very steep total density profile, that cannot be fitted by models with no gradient. Our measurements are unable to determine whether gradients are due to variations in stellar population parameters at fixed IMF, or to gradients in the IMF itself. The inclusion of gradients decreases dramatically the inferred IMF normalisation, compared to previous lensing-based studies, with the exact value depending on the assumed dark matter profile. The main effect of strong lensing selection is to shift the stellar mass distribution towards the high mass end, while the halo mass and stellar IMF distribution at fixed stellar mass are not significantly affected.

output.explanation:
Galaxies reside in a complex gravitational environment where stars and dark matter interact. A key concept is the Initial Mass Function (IMF), describing stellar mass distribution, but its determination for massive galaxies remains challenging due to degeneracies between dark matter and stellar properties.

The IMF can be constrained by combining stellar dynamics with strong gravitational lensing. However, this method is limited by density profile of dark matter and stellar mass-to-light ratio. To address this issue, researchers have combined multiple observational techniques: weak lensing together with strong lensing and stellar kinematics.

A crucial term to understand here is 'density profile,' which refers to the distribution of mass within an object or system. In the context of galaxies, a radial gradient in density profile indicates how mass changes with distance from the center. The IMF normalisation represents the overall amplitude of the stellar mass function.

By combining strong and weak lensing with stellar kinematics, researchers have shown that a model incorporating a radial gradient in the stellar mass-to-light ratio is necessary to accurately describe both galaxy samples. This finding suggests that gradients may be due to variations in stellar population parameters or IMF itself.

title: First Data Release of the All-sky NOAO Source Catalog
input: Most of the sky has been imaged with NOAO's telescopes from both hemispheres. While the large majority of these data were obtained for PI-led projects and almost all of the images are publicly available, only a small fraction have been released to the community via well-calibrated and easily accessible catalogs. We are remedying this by creating a catalog of sources from most of the public data taken on the CTIO-4m+DECam and the KPNO-4m+Mosaic3. This catalog, called the NOAO Source Catalog (NSC), contains over 2.9 billion unique objects, 34 billion individual source measurements, covers ~30,000 square degrees of the sky, has depths of ~23rd magnitude in most broadband filters with ~1-2% photometric precision, and astrometric accuracy of ~7 mas. In addition, ~2 billion objects and ~21,000 square degrees of sky have photometry in three or more bands. The NSC will be useful for exploring stellar streams, dwarf satellite galaxies, QSOs, high-proper motion stars, variable stars and other transients. The NSC catalog is publicly available via the NOAO Data Lab service.

output.explanation:
The vast majority of the sky has been imaged using telescopes from both hemispheres, primarily for projects led by principal investigators and resulting in publicly available images. However, only a small fraction of these data have been compiled into well-calibrated catalogs accessible to the community.

The NOAO Source Catalog (NSC) aims to address this issue by aggregating public data from two prominent telescopes: CTIO-4m+DECam and KPNO-4m+Mosaic3. This catalog contains over 2.9 billion unique objects, with approximately 34 billion individual source measurements spanning ~30,000 square degrees of the sky.

The NSC boasts photometric precision of ~1-2% in most broadband filters, reaching depths of ~23rd magnitude. Additionally, it achieves astrometric accuracy of ~7 mas. Notably, around 2 billion objects have photometry in three or more bands across approximately 21,000 square degrees of the sky.

The NSC is particularly valuable for studying various celestial phenomena, including stellar streams, dwarf satellite galaxies, quasars (QSOs), high-proper motion stars, and variable stars.

title: Weak Lensing Peaks in Simulated Light-Cones: Investigating the Coupling between Dark Matter and Dark Energy
input: In this paper, we study the statistical properties of weak lensing peaks in light-cones generated from cosmological simulations. In order to assess the prospects of such observable as a cosmological probe, we consider simulations that include interacting Dark Energy (hereafter DE) models with coupling term between DE and Dark Matter. Cosmological models that produce a larger population of massive clusters have more numerous high signal-to-noise peaks; among models with comparable numbers of clusters those with more concentrated haloes produce more peaks. The most extreme model under investigation shows a difference in peak counts of about with respect to the reference CDM model. We find that peak statistics can be used to distinguish a coupling DE model from a reference one with the same power spectrum normalisation. The differences in the expansion history and the growth rate of structure formation are reflected in their halo counts, non-linear scale features and, through them, in the properties of the lensing peaks. For a source redshift distribution consistent with the expectations of future space-based wide field surveys, we find that typically seventy percent of the cluster population contributes to weak-lensing peaks with signal-to-noise ratios larger than two, and that the fraction of clusters in peaks approaches one-hundred percent for haloes with redshift z 0.5. Our analysis demonstrates that peak statistics are an important tool for disentangling DE models by accurately tracing the structure formation processes as a function of the cosmic time.

output.explanation:
The universe's large-scale structure is shaped by the interplay between Dark Matter and Dark Energy, two mysterious components driving its evolution.

Dark Matter provides gravitational scaffolding for galaxy formation, while Dark Energy drives the accelerating expansion of the universe. The coupling term describes their interaction. Non-linear scale features are a key aspect of cosmological simulations.

The differences in behavior between these components are reflected in halo counts and growth rate of structure formation. These processes interact to produce lensing peaks with varying signal-to-noise ratios.

Cosmological models with more massive clusters exhibit higher peak counts compared to those without interacting Dark Energy. For future space-based surveys, a significant portion of the cluster population contributes to weak-lensing peaks. The fraction of clusters in peaks approaches one-hundred percent for haloes at redshift z 0.5.

title: Dark matter contraction and stellar-mass-to-light ratio gradients in massive early-type galaxies
input: We present models for the dark and luminous mass structure of 12 strong lensing early-type galaxies (ETGs). We combine pixel-based modelling of multiband HST/ACS imaging with Jeans modelling of kinematics obtained from Keck/ESI spectra to disentangle the dark and luminous contributions to the mass. Assuming a gNFW profile for the dark matter halo and a spatially constant stellar-mass-to-light ratio for the baryonic mass, we infer distributions for consistent with IMFs that are heavier than the Milky Way's (with a global mean mismatch parameter relative to a Chabrier IMF ) and halo inner density slopes which span a large range but are generally cuspier than the dark-matter-only prediction ( ). We investigate possible reasons for overestimating the halo slope, including the neglect of spatially varying stellar-mas-to-light ratios and/or stellar orbital anisotropy, and find that a quarter of the systems prefer radially declining stellar-mass-to-light ratio gradients, but that the overall effect on our inference on the halo slope is small. We suggest a coherent explanation of these results in the context of inside-out galaxy growth, and that the relative importance of different baryonic processes in shaping the dark halo may depend on halo environment.

output.explanation:
Galaxies with strong gravitational lensing effects reside in a vast, cosmological context where dark matter plays a crucial role in shaping their mass distributions. Dark matter is often described using the generalized Navarro-Frenk-White profile (gNFW), which assumes a specific density distribution for this invisible form of matter. In contrast, luminous matter refers to stars and other visible components that contribute to a galaxy's overall mass.

The analysis in question relies on combining imaging data from multiple bands with spectroscopic observations to disentangle the dark and luminous contributions to the mass. A key assumption is that stellar-mass-to-light ratios are constant across space, although this may not always be the case. The inferred mass distributions suggest heavier initial mass functions than those found in the Milky Way.

The mechanism at play involves a complex interplay between dark matter and baryonic processes within galaxies. Dark matter's influence on halo inner density slopes is particularly noteworthy, as these slopes are generally steeper than predicted by simulations without considering baryonic effects.

These findings have significant implications for our understanding of galaxy growth and evolution. The relative importance of different baryonic processes in shaping the dark halo may depend on the environment within which galaxies reside.

title: Polarization of K-shell dielectronic recombination satellite lines of Fe XIX-XXV and its application for diagnostics of anisotropies of hot plasmas
input: We present a systematic measurement of the X-ray emission asymmetries in the K-shell dielectronic, trielectronic, and quadruelectronic recombination of free electrons into highly charged ions. Iron ions in He-like through O-like charge states were produced in an electron beam ion trap, and the electron-ion collision energy was scanned over the recombination resonances. Two identical X-ray detectors mounted head-on and side-on with respect to the electron beam propagation recorded X-rays emitted in the decay of resonantly populated states. The degrees of linear polarization of X-rays inferred from observed emission asymmetries benchmark distorted-wave predictions of the Flexible Atomic Code (FAC) for several dielectronic recombination satellite lines. The present method also demonstrates its applicability for diagnostics of energy and direction of electron beams inside hot anisotropic plasmas. Both experimental and theoretical data can be used for modeling of hot astrophysical and fusion plasmas.

output.explanation:
Highly charged ions, such as iron in He-like through O-like charge states, are formed when free electrons collide with these ions. This process is known as dielectronic recombination. The X-ray emission from these collisions can be measured to understand the properties of highly charged ions and plasmas.

The experiment involves an electron beam ion trap that produces iron ions in various charge states. By scanning the energy of the electron-ion collision, researchers can observe the X-rays emitted when electrons recombine with highly charged ions. Two detectors record X-rays from different angles to measure the polarization of these emissions. The results are compared to theoretical predictions and demonstrate a new method for diagnosing plasmas in hot astrophysical objects and fusion reactors.

The key concept here is dielectronic recombination, where an electron combines with a highly charged ion to form a more stable state. This process can be described using the Flexible Atomic Code (FAC). The experiment also relies on the principle of linear polarization, which is related to the orientation of light waves in space.

The findings from this study have implications for understanding hot plasmas and their behavior in astrophysical objects and fusion reactors. By measuring X-ray emission asymmetries, researchers can gain insights into the energy and direction of electron beams within these plasmas.

title: Multiband counterparts of two eclipsing ultraluminous X-ray sources in M 51
input: We present the discovery and interpretation of ionized nebulae around two ultraluminous X-ray sources in M 51; both sources share the rare property of showing X-ray eclipses by their companion stars, and are therefore prime targets for follow-up studies. Using archival Hubble Space Telescope images, we found an elongated, 100-pc-long emission-line structure associated with one X-ray source (CXOM51 J132940.0+471237; ULX-1 for simplicity), and a more circular, ionized nebula at the location of the second source (CXOM51 J132939.5+471244; ULX-2 for simplicity). We observed both nebulae with the Large Binocular Telescope's Multi-Object Double Spectrograph. From our analysis of the optical spectra, we argue that the gas in the ULX-1 bubble is shock-ionized, consistent with the effect of a jet with a kinetic power of 2 erg s . Additional X-ray photo-ionization may also be present, to explain the strength of high-ionization lines such as He II and [Ne V] . On the other hand, the emission lines from the ULX-2 bubble are typical for photoionization by normal O stars suggesting that the nebula is actually an H II region not physically related to the ULX but is simply a chance alignment. From archival Very Large Array data, we also detect spatially extended, steep-spectrum radio emission at the location of the ULX-1 bubble (consistent with its jet origin), but no radio counterpart for ULX-2 (consistent with the lack of shock-ionized gas around that source).

output.explanation:
Galaxies like M 51 are vast, star-forming systems where new stars and planets emerge. Within these galaxies, ultraluminous X-ray sources (ULXs) stand out as rare objects emitting enormous amounts of energy in the form of X-rays.

Key terms such as ULX require clarification: an object that emits extremely high amounts of energy due to accretion onto a compact object like a black hole or neutron star. H II regions, on the other hand, are ionized by normal O stars and appear as nebulae in space.

The interaction between these objects and their surroundings is complex. The analysis of optical spectra reveals that gas around one ULX is shock-ionized due to its jet's kinetic power. This implies energy injection into the environment through a powerful outflow.

However, another bubble shows emission lines typical for photoionization by normal O stars. This suggests it might be an H II region unrelated to the ULX but coincidentally aligned with it. The detection of radio emission at one ULX location supports its jet origin.

title: The KBC Void: Consistency with Supernovae Type Ia and the Kinematic SZ Effect in a LTB Model
input: There is substantial and growing observational evidence from the normalized luminosity density in the near-infrared that the local universe is under-dense on scales of several hundred Megaparsecs. We test whether our parameterization of the observational data of such a "void" is compatible with the latest supernovae type Ia data and with constraints from line-of-sight peculiar velocity motions of galaxy clusters with respect to the cosmic microwave background rest frame, known as the linear kinematic Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (kSZ) effect. Our study is based on the large local void (LLV) radial profile observed by Keenan, Barger, and Cowie (KBC) and a theoretical void description based on the Lemaître-Tolman-Bondi model with a nonzero cosmological constant ( LTB). We find consistency with the measured luminosity distance-redshift relation on radial scales relevant to the KBC LLV through a comparison with 217 low-redshift supernovae type Ia over the redshift range . We assess the implications of the KBC LLV in light of the tension between "local" and "cosmic" measurements of the Hubble constant, . We find that when the existence of the KBC LLV is fully accounted for, this tension is reduced from to . We find that previous linear kSZ constraints, as well as new ones from the South Pole Telescope (SPT) and the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT), are fully compatible with the existence of the KBC LLV.

output.explanation:
The universe's large-scale structure is characterized by vast regions of space known as voids, which are under-dense compared to the surrounding areas. These voids can be several hundred Megaparsecs in size and have been observed using near-infrared luminosity density measurements.

A key aspect of these observations is the concept of luminosity density, referring to the amount of light emitted per unit volume in a given region. Additionally, the cosmological constant Λ represents a measure of the universe's energy density. The Lemaître-Tolman-Bondi model incorporates this nonzero value to describe the radial profile of voids.

The study examines how these large-scale structures interact with nearby galaxy clusters and their peculiar velocity motions relative to the cosmic microwave background rest frame, known as the linear kinematic Sunyaev-Zel'dovich effect. This interaction is crucial in understanding the behavior of light propagating through such regions.

The findings indicate that previous constraints on line-of-sight peculiar velocities are fully compatible with the existence of large local voids like the one described by Keenan, Barger, and Cowie's radial profile. Furthermore, accounting for this void reduces the tension between 'local' and 'cosmic' measurements of the Hubble constant.

title: Beacons into the Cosmic Dark Ages: Boosted transmission of Ly from UV bright galaxies at
input: Recent detections of Lyman alpha (Ly ) emission from galaxies were somewhat unexpected given a dearth of previous non-detections in this era when the intergalactic medium (IGM) is still highly neutral. But these detections were from UV bright galaxies, which preferentially live in overdensities which reionize early, and have significantly Doppler-shifted Ly line profiles emerging from their interstellar media (ISM), making them less affected by the global IGM state. Using a combination of reionization simulations and empirical ISM models we show, as a result of these two effects, UV bright galaxies in overdensities have higher transmission through the IGM than typical field galaxies, and this boosted transmission is enhanced as the neutral fraction increases. The boosted transmission is not sufficient to explain the observed high Ly fraction of galaxies (Stark et al. 2017), suggesting Ly emitted by these galaxies must be stronger than expected due to enhanced production and/or selection effects. Despite the bias of UV bright galaxies to reside in overdensities we show Ly observations of such galaxies can accurately measure the global neutral hydrogen fraction, particularly when Ly from UV faint galaxies is extinguished, making them ideal candidates for spectroscopic follow-up into the cosmic Dark Ages.

output.explanation:
The universe is in a state of transition, with the intergalactic medium (IGM) gradually becoming less neutral over time due to reionization processes.

Reionization refers to the gradual increase in ionized gas within the IGM, affecting how light interacts with it. The Lyman alpha emission from galaxies can be impacted by this interaction. Key terms include overdensities and interstellar media (ISM), which are regions of high density where stars form and emit light.

In these regions, UV bright galaxies reside preferentially due to their Doppler-shifted Ly line profiles emerging from the ISM. This results in higher transmission through the IGM for these galaxies compared to typical field galaxies. The boosted transmission is further enhanced as the neutral fraction increases within the IGM.

The increased transmission allows UV bright galaxies to serve as reliable indicators of the global neutral hydrogen fraction, particularly when Lyman alpha emission from fainter galaxies is extinguished.

title: CHANG-ES X: Spatially-resolved Separation of Thermal Contribution from Radio Continuum Emission in Edge-on Galaxies
input: We analyze the application of star formation rate (SFR) calibrations using H and 22 micron infrared imaging data in predicting the thermal radio component for a test sample of 3 edge-on galaxies (NGC 891, NGC 3044, and NGC 4631) in the Continuum Halos in Nearby Galaxies -- an EVLA Survey (CHANG-ES). We use a mixture of H and 24 micron calibration from Calzetti et al. (2007), and a linear 22 micron only calibration from Jarrett et al. (2013) on the test sample. We apply these relations on a pixel-to-pixel basis to create thermal prediction maps in the two CHANG-ES bands: L- and C-band (1.5 GHz and 6.0 GHz, respectively). We analyze the resulting non-thermal spectral index maps, and find a characteristic steepening of the non-thermal spectral index with vertical distance from the disk after application of all methods. We find possible evidence of extinction in the 22 micron data as compared to 70 micron Spitzer Multband Imaging Photometer (MIPS) imaging in NGC 891. We analyze a larger sample of edge-on and face-on galaxy 25 micron to 100 micron flux ratios, and find that the ratios for edge-ons are systematically lower by a factor of 1.36, a result we attribute to excess extinction in the mid-IR in edge-ons. We introduce a new calibration for correcting the H luminosity for dust when galaxies are edge-on or very dusty.

output.explanation:
Galaxies are vast, star-forming systems consisting of a central bulge and a surrounding disk.

The thermal radio component is an essential aspect of these systems, influenced by the emission from ionized gas in H II regions. Two key terms are relevant here: SFR refers to the rate at which new stars form within a galaxy, while extinction describes the blocking of light due to interstellar dust. The process begins with applying infrared imaging data to predict this component accurately.

The thermal radio component is predicted using two different calibrations: one combining H and 24 micron calibration from Calzetti et al., and another using linear 22 micron only calibration from Jarrett et al. These predictions are then used to analyze non-thermal spectral index maps, revealing a characteristic steepening of the non-thermal spectral index with vertical distance from the disk after applying all methods.

The analysis reveals that edge-on galaxies have systematically lower flux ratios by a factor of 1.36 compared to face-on galaxies in certain wavelength ranges, attributed to excess extinction in the mid-IR. This suggests that dust affects infrared imaging data and must be corrected for when analyzing galaxy properties.

title: The Stagger-grid: A grid of 3D stellar atmosphere models V. Synthetic stellar spectra and broad-band photometry
input: Context. The surface structures and dynamics of cool stars are characterized by the presence of convective motions and turbulent flows which shape the emergent spectrum. Aims. We used realistic three-dimensional radiative hydrodynamical simulations from the Stagger-grid to calculate synthetic spectra with the radiative transfer code Optim3D for stars with different stellar parameters to predict photometric colors and convective velocity shifts. Methods. We calculated spectra from 1000 to 200 000 A with a constant resolving power of 20 000 and from 8470 and 8710 A (Gaia Radial Velocity Spectrometer - RVS - spectral range), with a constant resolving power of 300 000. Results. We used synthetic spectra to compute theoretical colors in the Johnson-Cousins UBV(RI), SDSS, 2MASS, Gaia, SkyMapper, Stromgren systems, and HST-WFC3. We showed that 1D versus 3D differences are limited to a small percent except for the narrow filters that span the optical and UV region of the spectrum. In addition, we derived the effect of the convective velocity fields on selected Fe I lines. We found the overall convective shift for 3D simulations with respect to the reference 1D hydrostatic models, revealing line shifts of between -0.235 and +0.361 km/s. We showed a net correlation of the convective shifts with the effective temperature: lower effective temperatures denote redshifts and higher effective temperatures denote blueshifts. We conclude that the extraction of accurate radial velocities from RVS spectra need an appropriate wavelength correction from convection shifts. Conclusions. The use of realistic 3D hydrodynamical stellar atmosphere simulations has a small but significant impact on the predicted photometry compared with classical 1D hydrostatic models for late-type stars. We make all the spectra publicly available for the community through the POLLUX database.

output.explanation:
The atmospheres of cool stars are characterized by convective motions and turbulent flows, influencing the emergent spectrum. Convection refers to the movement of hot plasma from the interior towards the surface, while turbulence involves chaotic fluid motion within the atmosphere. The Stagger-grid simulations used in this study aim to replicate these complex processes accurately. 

The synthetic spectra generated by Optim3D code are crucial for predicting photometric colors and convective velocity shifts. Photometry is a measure of an object's brightness, typically expressed as magnitudes or fluxes. Convective velocity shift refers to the change in wavelength due to the Doppler effect caused by moving hot plasma along the line-of-sight. 

The simulations reveal that 1D versus 3D differences are limited except for narrow filters spanning the optical and UV region of the spectrum. This indicates a significant impact on predicted photometry when using realistic 3D hydrodynamical models compared to classical 1D hydrostatic models, particularly for late-type stars. 

The study also explores the effect of convective velocity fields on selected Fe I lines, revealing line shifts between -0.235 and +0.361 km/s. A net correlation is observed with effective temperature: lower temperatures result in redshifts, while higher temperatures produce blueshifts. This implies that accurate radial velocities from RVS spectra require wavelength correction for convection shifts.

title: Automated data processing architecture for the Gemini Planet Imager Exoplanet Survey
input: The Gemini Planet Imager Exoplanet Survey (GPIES) is a multi-year direct imaging survey of 600 stars to discover and characterize young Jovian exoplanets and their environments. We have developed an automated data architecture to process and index all data related to the survey uniformly. An automated and flexible data processing framework, which we term the Data Cruncher, combines multiple data reduction pipelines together to process all spectroscopic, polarimetric, and calibration data taken with GPIES. With no human intervention, fully reduced and calibrated data products are available less than an hour after the data are taken to expedite follow-up on potential objects of interest. The Data Cruncher can run on a supercomputer to reprocess all GPIES data in a single day as improvements are made to our data reduction pipelines. A backend MySQL database indexes all files, which are synced to the cloud, and a front-end web server allows for easy browsing of all files associated with GPIES. To help observers, quicklook displays show reduced data as they are processed in real-time, and chatbots on Slack post observing information as well as reduced data products. Together, the GPIES automated data processing architecture reduces our workload, provides real-time data reduction, optimizes our observing strategy, and maintains a homogeneously reduced dataset to study planet occurrence and instrument performance.

output.explanation:
Direct imaging surveys involve observing stars to discover and characterize young Jovian exoplanets and their environments.

Key terms include direct imaging, which is a method of observing stars directly rather than through their light curves or transit signals; spectroscopic data refers to the measurement of a star's spectrum to determine its composition and properties; polarimetric data measures the polarization state of light from a star. A database indexes files synced to the cloud.

The Data Cruncher framework combines multiple data reduction pipelines uniformly processing spectroscopic, polarimetric, and calibration data taken with GPIES. This automated system produces fully reduced and calibrated data products within an hour of acquisition without human intervention.

The automated architecture reduces workload by providing real-time data reduction, optimizing observing strategy, maintaining a homogeneously reduced dataset to study planet occurrence and instrument performance.

title: Gamma-ray Emitting Narrow Line Seyfert 1 Galaxies in The Sloan Digital Sky Survey
input: The detection of significant -ray emission from radio-loud narrow line Seyfert 1 (NLSy1s) galaxies enables us to study jets in environments different than those in blazars. However, due to the small number of known -ray emitting NLSy1 ( -NLSy1) galaxies, a comprehensive study could not be performed. Here we report the first detection of significant -ray emission from four active galactic nuclei (AGN), recently classified as NLSy1 from their Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) optical spectrum. Three flat spectrum radio quasars (FSRQs) present in the third Large Area Telescope AGN catalog (3LAC) are also found as -NLSy1 galaxies. Comparing the -ray properties of these objects with 3LAC blazars reveals their spectral shapes to be similar to FSRQs, however, with low -ray luminosity ( erg s ). In the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer color-color diagram, these objects occupy a region mainly populated by FSRQs. Using the H emission line parameters, we find that on average -NLSy1 have smaller black hole masses than FSRQs at similar redshifts. In the low-resolution SDSS image of one of the -NLSy1 source, we find the evidence of an extended structure. We conclude by noting that overall many observational properties of -NLSy1 sources are similar to FSRQs and therefore, these objects could be their low black hole mass counterparts, as predicted in the literature.

output.explanation:
Active galactic nuclei, which are incredibly luminous objects in the universe, often harbor supermassive black holes at their centers.

A key term to understand is that a Seyfert 1 galaxy is an active galactic nucleus with a bright, blue center and strong emission lines. Radio-loud narrow line Seyfert 1 galaxies have particularly high-energy jets of particles emanating from the vicinity of the supermassive black hole.

The interaction between these energetic jets and their surroundings plays a crucial role in shaping the observed gamma-ray spectra. The smaller black hole masses in NLSy1 galaxies may be attributed to differences in accretion rates or jet formation mechanisms, which can influence the overall energy output of the system.

NLSy1 sources have similar observational properties to FSRQs, such as spectral shapes and luminosity levels, suggesting they could be low-mass counterparts. This is consistent with predictions made by astrophysicists in the literature.

title: Particles co-orbital to Janus and Epimetheus: a firefly planetary ring
input: The Cassini spacecraft found a new and unique ring that shares the trajectory of Janus and Epimetheus, co-orbital satellites of Saturn. Performing image analysis, we found this to be a continuous ring. Its width is between 30% and 50% larger than previously announced. We also verified that the ring behaves like a firefly. It can only be seen from time to time, when Cassini, the ring and the Sun are arranged in a particular geometric configuration, in very high phase angles. Otherwise, it remains "in the dark", not visible to Cassini's cameras. Through numerical simulations, we found a very short lifetime for the ring particles, less than a couple of decades. Consequently, the ring needs to be constantly replenished. Using a model of particles production due to micrometeorites impacts on the surfaces of Janus and Epimetheus, we reproduce the ring, explaining its existence and the "firefly" behavior.

output.explanation:
Saturn's ring system is a vast, dynamic environment comprising numerous icy particles and moons. The term 'co-orbital' refers to the satellites Janus and Epimetheus, which share the same orbital trajectory as a newly discovered ring.

The concept of phase angles in astronomy pertains to the angle between an object, its illuminating light source, and the observer's line of sight. High phase angles are necessary for observing certain celestial phenomena.

In this context, the interaction between micrometeorites impacting Janus and Epimetheus, and the resulting production of ring particles, is crucial. The process can be likened to a firefly's intermittent glow, only visible under specific conditions. This phenomenon necessitates constant replenishment due to the short lifetime of individual ring particles.

The newly discovered ring exhibits unique behavior, being visible only when Cassini, the Sun, and the ring are aligned in a particular geometric configuration at high phase angles. Otherwise, it remains undetectable.

title: The gravitational wave signal from core-collapse supernovae
input: We study gravitational waves (GWs) from a set of two-dimensional multi-group neutrino radiation hydrodynamic simulations of core-collapse supernovae (CCSNe). Our goal is to systematize the current knowledge about the post-bounce CCSN GW signal and recognize the templatable features that could be used by the ground-based laser interferometers. We demonstrate that starting from ~400ms after core bounce the dominant GW signal represents the fundamental quadrupole (l=2) oscillation mode (f-mode) of the proto-neutron star (PNS), which can be accurately reproduced by a linear perturbation analysis of the angle-averaged PNS profile. Before that, in the time interval between ~200 and ~400ms after bounce, the dominant mode has two radial nodes and represents a g-mode. We associate the high-frequency noise in the GW spectrograms above the main signal with p-modes, while below the dominant frequency there is a region with very little power. The collection of models presented here summarizes the dependence of the CCSN GW signal on the progenitor mass, equation of state, many-body corrections to the neutrino opacity, and rotation. Weak dependence of the dominant GW frequency on the progenitor mass motivates us to provide a simple fit for it as a function of time, which can be used as a prior when looking for CCSN candidates in the LIGO data.

output.explanation:
The core of a massive star collapses, releasing an enormous amount of energy in the form of gravitational waves (GWs). This phenomenon is studied through two-dimensional multi-group neutrino radiation hydrodynamic simulations of core-collapse supernovae (CCSNe).

Key terms such as proto-neutron stars (PNS) and GW modes need clarification. A PNS forms after a massive star's core collapses, with its density profile playing a crucial role in the generation of gravitational waves. The fundamental quadrupole oscillation mode (f-mode), which has two radial nodes, is responsible for the dominant GW signal between ~200-400ms post-bounce.

The f-mode can be accurately reproduced by analyzing the angle-averaged PNS profile using linear perturbation theory. Before this time interval, a g-mode dominates the GW signal with two radial nodes. High-frequency noise above the main signal is attributed to p-modes, while below the dominant frequency lies an area of very low power.

The CCSN GW signal depends on various factors such as progenitor mass, equation of state, many-body corrections to neutrino opacity, and rotation. Notably, the dominant GW frequency shows a weak dependence on progenitor mass, prompting a simple fit that can be used as a prior when searching for CCSN candidates in LIGO data.

title: The global and radial stellar mass assembly of Milky Way-sized galaxies
input: We study the global and radial stellar mass assembly of eight zoomed-in MW-sized galaxies produced in Hydrodynamics cosmological simulations.
