The disk-dominated galaxies (4) show a fast initial stellar mass growth in the innermost parts, driven mostly by in-situ SF, but since the SF enters in a long-term quenching phase. The outer regions follow this trend but more gentle as more external they are. As the result, the radial stellar mass growth is highly inside-out due to both the inside-out structural growth and inside-out SF quenching. The half-mass radius evolves fast; for instance, ( ) ( ). Two other runs resemble lenticular galaxies. One shows also a pronounced inside-out growth and the other one presents a nearly uniform radial mass assembly. The other two galaxies suffered late major mergers. Their normalized radial mass growth histories (MGHs) are nearly close among them but with periods of outside-in assembly during or after the mergers. For all the simulations, the archaeological radial MGHs calculated from the stellar-particles age distribution are similar to the current MGHs, which evidences that the mass assembly by ex-situ stars and the radial mass transport do not change significantly their radial mass distributions. Our results agree qualitatively with observational inferences from the fossil record method applied to a survey of local galaxies and from look-back observations of progenitors of MW-sized galaxies. However, the inside-out growth mode is more pronounced and the growth is faster in simulations than in observational inferences.

output.explanation:
Galaxies are vast star-forming systems governed by complex physical processes, including the assembly of stellar mass within them.

In-situ SF refers to the formation of new stars from existing gas and dust within a galaxy's disk, while ex-situ SF involves the accretion of external material. The half-mass radius is the distance from the center of a galaxy where half of its total stellar mass resides.

The simulations reveal that disk-dominated galaxies exhibit rapid initial growth in their inner regions due to in-situ SF, which eventually enters a long-term quenching phase. This process slows down significantly as it moves towards the outer parts of these galaxies. The structural growth of galaxies and the quenching of SF from the outside-in contribute to this inside-out pattern.

The simulations show that the radial stellar mass growth is highly inside-out, with some galaxies experiencing rapid changes in their half-mass radius over time. Two other simulations resemble lenticular galaxies, which have distinct properties. The archaeological analysis reveals that the mass assembly by external stars and radial mass transport do not significantly alter their radial mass distributions.

title: Explosions of Thorne-Zytkow objects
input: We propose that massive Thorne-Zytkow objects can explode. A Thorne-Zytkow object is a theoretically predicted star that has a neutron core. When nuclear reactions supporting a massive Thorne-Zytkow object terminate, a strong accretion occurs towards the central neutron core. The accretion rate is large enough to sustain a super-Eddington accretion towards the neutron core. The neutron core may collapse to a black hole after a while. A strong large-scale outflow or a jet can be launched from the super-Eddington accretion disk and the collapsing Thorne-Zytkow object can be turned into an explosion. The ejecta have about 10 Msun but the explosion energy depends on when the accretion is suppressed. We presume that the explosion energy could be as low as ~ 1e47 erg and such a low-energy explosion could be observed like a failed supernova. The maximum possible explosion energy is ~ 1e52 erg and such a high-energy explosion could be observed as an energetic Type II supernova or a superluminous supernova. Explosions of Thorne-Zytkow objects may provide a new path to spread lithium and other heavy elements produced through the irp process such as molybdenum in the Universe.

output.explanation:
In the extreme environment of a massive star, a neutron core forms at its center. This is known as a Thorne-Zytkow object. When nuclear reactions cease in such an object, intense accretion occurs towards the central neutron core. The rate of this accretion is so high that it surpasses the Eddington limit, leading to super-Eddington conditions. 

The neutron core may eventually collapse into a black hole. A large-scale outflow or jet can be triggered from the disk surrounding the collapsing object, potentially resulting in an explosion. The ejected material has approximately 10 solar masses, but the energy released during this event depends on when accretion is halted. 

A low-energy explosion with ~1e47 erg could resemble a failed supernova, while a more energetic release of ~1e52 erg might be observed as an exceptionally luminous Type II supernova or superluminous supernova. 

The proposed explosions of Thorne-Zytkow objects may offer a novel mechanism for dispersing lithium and other heavy elements produced through the r-process in the universe, such as molybdenum.

title: Role of core-collapse supernovae in explaining Solar System abundances of p nuclides
input: The production of the heavy stable proton-rich isotopes between 74Se and 196Hg -- the p nuclides -- is due to the contribution from different nucleosynthesis processes, activated in different types of stars. Whereas these processes have been subject to various studies, their relative contributions to Galactic Chemical Evolution are still a matter of debate. We investigate for the first time the nucleosynthesis of p nuclides in GCE by including metallicity and progenitor mass-dependent yields of core-collapse supernovae (ccSNe) into a chemical evolution model. We used a grid of metallicities and progenitor masses from two different sets of stellar yields and followed the contribution of ccSNe to the Galactic abundances as function of time. In combination with previous studies on p-nucleus production in thermonuclear supernovae (SNIa), and using the same GCE description, this allows us to compare the respective roles of SNeIa and ccSNe in the production of p-nuclei in the Galaxy. The gamma process in ccSN is very efficient for a wide range of progenitor masses (13M_sun_- 25M_sun) at solar metallicity. Since it is a secondary process with its efficiency depending on the initial abundance of heavy elements, its contribution is strongly reduced below solar metallicity. This makes it challenging to explain the inventory of the p nuclides in the Solar System by the contribution from ccSNe alone. In particular, we find that ccSNe contribute less than 10% of the solar p nuclide abundances, with only a few exceptions. Due to the uncertain contribution from other nucleosynthesis sites in ccSNe, such as neutrino winds or -rich freeze out, we conclude that the light p-nuclides 74 Kr, 84Sr, and 92Mo may either still be completely or only partially produced in ccSNe.

output.explanation:
The universe's heavy stable proton-rich isotopes, known as p nuclides, are formed through various nucleosynthesis processes in different types of stars.

A key concept is the distinction between astrophysical and primordial formation mechanisms. The former refers to the creation of elements within stars, while the latter pertains to their existence since the universe's inception.

Core-collapse supernovae (ccSNe) are a crucial site for p nuclide production, with nucleosynthesis yields influenced by metallicity and progenitor mass. The gamma process is particularly efficient in ccSN at solar metallicity but becomes less effective below this threshold due to its secondary nature and dependence on initial heavy element abundances.

The relative contributions of core-collapse supernovae (ccSNe) versus thermonuclear supernovae (SNIa) to p nuclide production are still debated. The gamma process in ccSN is very efficient for a wide range of progenitor masses at solar metallicity, but its contribution is strongly reduced below solar metallicity.

title: Models of bright nickel-free supernovae from stripped massive stars with circumstellar shells
input: The nature of an emerging class of rapidly fading supernovae (RFSNe)--characterized by their short-lived light curve duration, but varying widely in peak brightness--remains puzzling. Whether the RFSNe arise from low-mass thermonuclear eruptions on white dwarfs or from the core collapse of massive stars is still a matter of dispute. We explore the possibility that the explosion of hydrogen-free massive stars could produce bright but rapidly fading transients if the effective pre-supernova radii are large and if little or no radioactive nickel is ejected. The source of radiation is then purely due to shock cooling. We study this model of RFSNe using spherically symmetric hydrodynamics and radiation transport calculations of the explosion of stripped stars embedded in helium-dominated winds or shells of various masses and extent. We present a parameter study showing how the properties of the circumstellar envelopes affect the dynamics of the explosion and can lead to a diversity of light curves. We also explore the dynamics of the fallback of the innermost stellar layers, which might be able to remove radioactive nickel from the ejecta, making the rapid decline in the late time light curve possible. We provide scaling relations that describe how the duration and luminosity of these events depend on the supernova kinetic energy and the mass and radius of the circumstellar material.

output.explanation:
The universe is home to massive stars that have shed their outer layers, leaving behind compact cores known as stripped stars. 

The term 'stripped star' refers to a star from which the hydrogen-rich envelope has been removed through strong winds or other processes. A supernova's effective pre-supernova radius and circumstellar envelopes are crucial in determining its dynamics and resulting light curve. The source of radiation in these events is primarily due to shock cooling, where energy released during the explosion is transferred to surrounding gas through a series of shocks. 

The fallback of innermost stellar layers may remove radioactive nickel from the ejecta, enabling rapid decline observed in late-time light curves. Scaling relations describe how duration and luminosity depend on supernova kinetic energy and circumstellar material mass and radius. In these events, radiation is produced solely by shock cooling due to large pre-supernova radii and minimal radioactive nickel ejection. 

The dynamics of stripped stars embedded in helium-dominated winds or shells can lead to diverse light curves, depending on the properties of their surrounding envelopes.

title: RadVel: The Radial Velocity Modeling Toolkit
input: RadVel is an open source Python package for modeling Keplerian orbits in radial velocity (RV) time series. RadVel provides a convenient framework to fit RVs using maximum a posteriori optimization and to compute robust confidence intervals by sampling the posterior probability density via Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC). RadVel allows users to float or fix parameters, impose priors, and perform Bayesian model comparison. We have implemented realtime MCMC convergence tests to ensure adequate sampling of the posterior. RadVel can output a number of publication-quality plots and tables. Users may interface with RadVel through a convenient command-line interface or directly from Python. The code is object-oriented and thus naturally extensible. We encourage contributions from the community. Documentation is available at http://radvel.readthedocs.io.

output.explanation:
The study of celestial motion relies on understanding the dynamics of objects in our solar system and beyond. RadVel is a software package designed to model Keplerian orbits, which describe how planets orbit their host stars due to gravitational forces.

In this context, radial velocity refers to the Doppler shift caused by an object's motion along our line of sight. This phenomenon can be understood through the principles of special relativity and general relativity, where gravity warps spacetime around massive objects. RadVel uses maximum a posteriori optimization to fit RV time series data.

Key technical terms include: MCMC (Markov Chain Monte Carlo), which is an algorithm for sampling probability distributions; Bayesian model comparison, which involves evaluating the relative likelihood of different models given observed data; and object-oriented programming, which allows RadVel's code to be naturally extensible.

RadVel enables users to compute robust confidence intervals by sampling the posterior probability density via MCMC. The software also allows users to float or fix parameters, impose priors, and perform Bayesian model comparison. To ensure reliable results, RadVel incorporates real-time MCMC convergence tests.

title: Evidence for GeV Cosmic Rays from White Dwarfs in the Local Cosmic Ray Spectra and in the Gamma-ray Emissivity of the Inner Galaxy
input: Recent observations found that electrons are accelerated to 10 GeV and emit synchrotron hard X-rays in two magnetic white dwarfs (WDs), also known as cataclysmic variables (CVs). In nova outbursts of WDs, multi-GeV gamma-rays were detected inferring that protons are accelerated to 100 GeV or higher. In recent optical surveys, the WD density is found to be higher near the Sun than in the Galactic disk by a factor 2.5. The cosmic rays (CR) produced by local CVs and novae will accumulate in the local bubble for - yrs. On these findings, we search for CRs from historic CVs and novae in the observed CR spectra. We model the CR spectra at the heliopause as sums of Galactic and local components based on observational data as much as possible. The initial Galactic CR electron and proton spectra are deduced from the gamma-ray emissivity, the local electron spectrum from the hard X-ray spectra at the CVs, and the local proton spectrum inferred by gamma-ray spectrum at novae. These spectral shapes are then expressed in a simple set of polynomial functions of CR energy and regressively fitted until the high-energy ( 100 GeV) CR spectra near Earth and the Voyager-1 spectra at the heliopause are reproduced. We then extend the modeling to nuclear CR spectra and find that one spectral shape fits all local nuclear CRs and the apparent hardening of the nuclear CR spectra is caused by the roll-down of local nuclear spectra around 100 - 200 GeV. All local CR spectra populate in a limited energy band below 100 - 200 GeV and enhance gamma-ray emissivity below 10 GeV. Such an enhancement is observed in the inner Galaxy, suggesting the CR fluxes from CVs and novae are substantially higher there.

output.explanation:
The universe's magnetic fields play a crucial role in shaping the behavior of charged particles near stars and other celestial objects.

A key aspect to understand this phenomenon is that white dwarfs (WDs) are known to have strong magnetic fields, which can accelerate electrons to high energies. This process results in the emission of synchrotron hard X-rays. The term 'cataclysmic variables' refers to binary systems consisting of a WD and a companion star.

The concept of cosmic rays (CR) is essential here; CRs are high-energy particles originating from outside the solar system. Another important term is 'heliopause,' which marks the boundary between the heliosphere and interstellar space. The local bubble refers to a region where cosmic rays accumulate over time due to their non-relativistic nature.

The model combines Galactic and local components based on observational data, reproducing high-energy CR spectra near Earth and Voyager-1's observations at the heliopause. The resulting enhancement in gamma-ray emissivity is observed within the inner Galaxy, suggesting higher CR fluxes from CVs and novae there.

title: Core-exsolved SiO dispersal in the Earth's mantle
input: SiO may have been expelled from the core directly following core formation in the early stages of Earth's accretion and onwards through the present day. On account of SiO 's low density with respect to both the core and the lowermost mantle, we examine the process of SiO accumulation at the core-mantle boundary (CMB) and its incorporation into the mantle by buoyant rise. Today, if SiO is 100-10000 times more viscous than lower mantle material, the dimensions of SiO diapirs formed by the viscous Rayleigh-Taylor instability at the CMB would cause them to be swept into the mantle as inclusions of 100 m - 10 km diameter. Under early Earth conditions of rapid heat loss after core formation, SiO diapirs of ~1 km diameter could have risen independently of mantle flow to their level of neutral buoyancy in the mantle, trapping them there due to a combination of intrinsically high viscosity and neutral buoyancy. We examine the SiO yield by assuming Si+O saturation at the conditions found at the base of a magma ocean and find that for a range of conditions, dispersed bodies could reach as high as 8.5 vol.% in parts of the lower mantle. At such low concentration, their effect on aggregate seismic wavespeeds is within observational seismology uncertainty. However, their presence can account for small-scale scattering in the lower mantle due to the bodies' large velocity contrast. We conclude that the shallow lower mantle (700-1500 km depth) could harbor SiO released in early Earth times.

output.explanation:
The Earth's core and mantle form a distinct physical setting, where the core is composed of iron-nickel alloys and the mantle consists mainly of silicate minerals. The process of SiO accumulation at the core-mantle boundary (CMB) involves the interaction between low-density SiO and the surrounding high-temperature lowermost mantle material.

The key terms in this context are 'viscosity,' which refers to a fluid's resistance to flow, and 'buoyancy,' which describes an object's tendency to rise or fall due to its density relative to its surroundings. The Rayleigh-Taylor instability is a phenomenon where denser fluids sink through less dense ones, causing the formation of diapirs - upwellings that can transport material from one region to another.

The mechanism at play here involves the viscous Rayleigh-Taylor instability at the CMB, which leads to the formation and rise of SiO diapirs into the mantle as inclusions. The dimensions of these diapirs depend on their viscosity relative to lower mantle material, with higher viscosities resulting in larger diameters.

The authors examine the process under early Earth conditions characterized by rapid heat loss after core formation, which would have allowed SiO diapirs to rise independently of mantle flow and become trapped at their level of neutral buoyancy due to a combination of high viscosity and neutral buoyancy.

title: A possible explanation of the parallel tracks in kilohertz quasi-periodic oscillations from low-mass-X-ray binaries
input: We recalculate the modes of the magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) waves in the MHD model (Shi, Zhang & Li 2014) of the kilohertz quasi-periodic oscillations (kHz QPOs) in neutron star low mass X-ray binaries (NS-LMXBs), in which the compressed magnetosphere is considered. A method on pointby- point scanning for every parameter of a normal LMXBs is proposed to determine the wave number in a NS-LMXB. The dependence of the twin kHz QPO frequencies on accretion rates ( DOt(M) ) is obtained with the wave number and magnetic field (B?) determined by our method. Based on the MHD model, a new explanation of the parallel tracks, i.e. the slowly varying effective magnetic field leads to the shift of parallel tracks in a source, is presented. In this study, we obtain a simple power-law relation between the kHz QPO frequencies and Dot(M) /B^2 ? in those sources. Finally, we study the dependence of kHz quasi-periodic oscillation frequencies on the spin, mass and radius of a neutron star. We find that the effective magnetic field, the spin, mass and radius of a neutron star lead to the parallel tracks in different sources.

output.explanation:
The intense magnetic fields surrounding neutron stars in low mass X-ray binaries create a complex environment for magnetohydrodynamic waves to propagate. 

The compressed magnetosphere is a key feature of these systems, where the strong magnetic field dominates over other forces. To understand the behavior of MHD waves within this environment, it's essential to define some critical terms: Magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) refers to the study of fluid dynamics in the presence of magnetic fields; kilohertz quasi-periodic oscillations (kHz QPOs) are a type of periodic signal observed in X-ray binaries. 

The MHD model, developed by Shi et al. (2014), provides a framework for understanding these phenomena. By recalculating the modes of MHD waves within this model, researchers have gained insight into how kHz QPO frequencies depend on accretion rates and magnetic field strengths. Specifically, they've found that the twin kHz QPO frequencies are related to the ratio of accretion rate to magnetic field squared (Dot(M)/B^2). 

The effective magnetic field plays a crucial role in determining the behavior of MHD waves within these systems. The researchers have also investigated how other factors, such as neutron star spin, mass, and radius, influence kHz QPO frequencies.

title: Superhorizon Electromagnetic Field Background from Higgs Loops in Inflation
input: If Higgs is a spectator scalar, i.e. if it is not directly coupled to the inflaton, superhorizon Higgs modes must have been exited during inflation. Since Higgs is unstable its decay into photons is expected to seed superhorizon photon modes. We use in-in perturbation theory to show that this naive physical expectation is indeed fulfilled via loop effects. Specifically, we calculate the first order Higgs loop correction to the magnetic field power spectrum evaluated at some late time after inflation. It turns out that this loop correction becomes much larger than the tree-level power spectrum at the superhorizon scales. This offers a mechanism to generate cosmologically interesting superhorizon vector modes by scalar-vector interactions.

output.explanation:
The universe's early stages are characterized by rapid expansion and fundamental force interactions. The Higgs field is a scalar that mediates mass, but its role in inflation remains unclear.

Key terms like 'spectator scalar' refer to the Higgs being indirectly coupled to other fields, while 'inflaton' denotes the primary driver of this period's expansion. In-in perturbation theory examines how fluctuations arise during this time.

When a spectator scalar decays into photons due to instability, it seeds superhorizon photon modes. Loop effects in perturbation theory facilitate this process by allowing interactions between scalar and vector fields. Specifically, Higgs loop corrections become significant at large scales, exceeding the original power spectrum.

As a result of these interactions, cosmologically interesting superhorizon vector modes are generated through scalar-vector coupling.

title: Issues about Cosmological Ward Identities
input: In this paper we first discuss how a Noether current corresponding to a gauge or a global symmetry can locally be introduced in a path integral irrespective of the boundary conditions defining the theory. We then consider quantization of gravity plus minimally coupled scalar field system in the phase space path integral approach. The complete gauge fixed action including the Faddeev-Popov determinant is obtained in the so called -gauge. It turns out that in this formalism while the dilatation survives as the residual symmetry of the gauge fixed action, other diffeomorphisms which require field dependent corrections fail to be so. The full Noether current for the dilatation is determined and the spatial boundary conditions that yield a finite and conserved charge are determined. The charge is shown to be expressible as a surface integral at infinity and the corresponding Ward identity gives the standard consistency relation of cosmological perturbations.

output.explanation:
The universe's physical setting involves gravity and a scalar field, which are fundamental components in understanding cosmological phenomena.

A key concept is Noether current, a mathematical object that arises from symmetries present within a system. Gauge symmetry refers to the ability of certain systems to transform without altering their underlying physics, while global symmetry describes a more general type of symmetry where transformations apply uniformly across space and time. The Faddeev-Popov determinant plays a crucial role in gauge fixing.

In this context, the interplay between gravity and scalar fields leads to residual symmetries within the system. Specifically, dilatation – a scaling transformation that affects both space and time – survives as a residual symmetry of the gauge-fixed action. However, other diffeomorphisms require field-dependent corrections to maintain consistency.

The full Noether current for dilatation is determined, allowing for the derivation of spatial boundary conditions that yield a finite and conserved charge. This charge can be expressed as a surface integral at infinity, leading to a standard consistency relation in cosmological perturbations.

title: Infrared Logarithms in Minisuperspace Inflation
input: We examine the emergence of the infrared logarithms in the cosmological perturbation theory applied to the minisuperspace scalar slow-roll inflation. Not surprisingly, in the single scalar field model the curvature perturbation is conserved and no behavior appears, where is the background scale factor of the universe. On the other hand, in the presence of a spectator scalar the 'th order perturbation theory gives an correction to . However, a nonperturbative estimate shows that actually becomes the sum of a constant and a mildly evolving pieces.

output.explanation:
The universe's evolution is characterized by the expansion of its scale factor, a measure that describes how distances between objects change over time. Inflation, a period of rapid expansion in the early universe, can be understood using scalar fields that drive this growth.

In cosmology, scalar fields are mathematical constructs used to describe the behavior of the universe on small scales. The minisuperspace approximation is a simplification used to model these fields and their effects on the universe's evolution. Slow-roll inflation refers to a specific type of inflationary scenario where the scalar field rolls slowly down its potential energy landscape.

The cosmological perturbation theory examines how scalar fields interact with each other, leading to corrections in the curvature perturbation. This correction arises from the presence of spectator scalars and is calculated using higher-order terms in the perturbation expansion. The resulting correction modifies the behavior of the universe's density and geometry on small scales.

In models with a single scalar field driving inflation, the curvature perturbation remains conserved over time. However, when an additional spectator scalar field is introduced, corrections to this conservation emerge due to higher-order terms in the perturbation expansion.

title: Supernovae from massive stars with extended tenuous envelopes
input: Massive stars with a core-halo structure are interesting objects for stellar physics and hydrodynamics. Using simulations for stellar evolution, radiation hydrodynamics, and radiative transfer, we study the explosion of stars with an extended and tenuous envelope (i.e., stars in which 95% of the mass is contained within 10% of the surface radius or less). We consider both H-rich supergiant and He-giant progenitors resulting from close-binary evolution and dying with a final mass of 2.8-5Msun. An extended envelope causes the supernova (SN) shock to brake and a reverse shock to form, sweeping core material into a dense shell. The shock deposited energy, which suffers little degradation from expansion, is trapped in ejecta layers of moderate optical depth, thereby enhancing the SN luminosity at early times. With the delayed 56Ni heating, we find that the resulting optical and near-IR light curves all exhibit a double-peak morphology. We show how an extended progenitor can explain the blue and featureless optical spectra of some Type IIb and Ib SNe. The dense shell formed by the reverse shock leads to line profiles with a smaller and near-constant width. This ejecta property can explain the statistically narrower profiles of Type IIb compared to Type Ib SNe, as well as the peculiar Halpha profile seen in SN1993J. At early times, our He-giant star explosion model shows a high luminosity, a blue color, and featureless spectra reminiscent of the Type Ib SN2008D, suggesting a low-mass progenitor.

output.explanation:
Massive stars with core-halo structures reside in a regime where their extended envelopes interact with internal dynamics, influencing supernovae (SN) explosions.

A key concept is the definition of an 'extended envelope,' which refers to a star where 95% of its mass resides within just 10% of its surface radius or less. This creates a stark contrast in density between the outer layers and the core. The term 'supergiant' can be understood as a massive star with significant nuclear burning, while a 'He-giant' is characterized by helium-rich composition.

The interaction between the SN shock and the extended envelope leads to braking effects due to reduced density in these outer layers. This causes the formation of a reverse shock that sweeps core material into a dense shell. The energy deposited by this process remains relatively intact as the ejecta expand, resulting in enhanced luminosity at early times.

The delayed heating from 56Ni further influences light curves, causing them to exhibit double-peak morphologies. This phenomenon can explain blue and featureless optical spectra observed in some Type IIb and Ib SNe. The dense shell formed by the reverse shock contributes to line profiles with smaller widths.

title: Recalculation of Astrophysical Opacities: Overview, Methodology and Atomic Calculations
input: A review of a renewed effort to recalculate astrophysical opacities using the R-Matrix method is presented. The computational methods and new extensions are described. Resulting enhancements found in test calculations under stellar interior conditions compared to the Opacity Project could potentially lead to the resolution of the solar abundances problem, as well as discrepancies between recent experimental measurements at the Sandia Z-pinch inertial confinement fusion device and theoretical opacity models. Outstanding issues also discussed are: (i) accuracy, convergence, and completeness of atomic calculations, (ii) improvements in the Equation-of-State of high-temperature-density plasmas, and (iii) redistribution of resonant oscillator strength in the bound-free continuum, and (iv) plasma broadening of auotionizing resonances.

output.explanation:
Astrophysical environments, such as stellar interiors and high-temperature-density plasmas, are characterized by complex interactions between matter and radiation. 

The R-Matrix method is a computational tool used to calculate astrophysical opacities, which describe how these environments interact with electromagnetic radiation. Opacity calculations involve atomic processes like bound-free transitions, where an electron jumps from a bound state to the continuum. 

Key terms in this context include 'opacity', referring to the measure of how much matter absorbs or scatters radiation; 'resonant oscillator strength', describing the probability of these transitions; and 'plasma broadening', which accounts for interactions between charged particles. 

The R-Matrix method has been extended with new computational techniques, leading to enhanced opacity calculations under stellar interior conditions. These enhancements may resolve discrepancies in solar abundances and experimental measurements at the Sandia Z-pinch device. Outstanding issues include accuracy and convergence of atomic calculations, improvements in plasma Equation-of-State, redistribution of resonant oscillator strength, and plasma broadening of autoionizing resonances.

title: Schroedinger's code: A preliminary study on research source code availability and link persistence in astrophysics
input: We examined software usage in a sample set of astrophysics research articles published in 2015 and searched for source code for the software mentioned in these research papers. We categorized the software to indicate whether source code is available for download and whether there are restrictions to accessing it, and if source code is not available, whether some other form of the software, such as a binary, is. We also extracted hyperlinks from one journal's 2015 research articles, as links in articles can serve as an acknowledgment of software use and lead to data used in the research, and tested them to determine which of these URLs are still accessible. For our sample of 715 software instances in the 166 articles we examined, we were able to categorize 418 records as to availability of source code and found that 285 unique codes were used, 58% of which offer source code available online for download. Of the 2,558 hyperlinks extracted from 1,669 research articles, at best, 90% of them were available over our testing period.

output.explanation:
Astrophysical research relies on software tools, which can be categorized based on their availability and accessibility.

The term source code refers to the underlying programming instructions that make up a software application, while binary refers to compiled versions of software that are executable but not modifiable by users. In this context, categorization involves determining whether source code is available for download or if other forms like binaries exist.

Hyperlinks within research articles can serve as acknowledgments of software use and may lead to associated data used in the research. The study examined a sample set of 715 software instances across 166 articles published in 2015, finding that many unique codes offered source code available online for download.

The examination revealed that out of 2,558 hyperlinks extracted from 1,669 research articles, at least 90% remained accessible over the testing period.

title: In-flight Calibration of Hitomi Soft X-ray Spectrometer (3) Effective Area
input: We present the result of the in-flight calibration of the effective area of the Soft X-ray Spectrometer (SXS) onboard the Hitomi X-ray satellite using an observation of the Crab nebula. We corrected for the artifacts when observing high count rate sources with the X-ray microcalorimeter. We then constructed a spectrum in the 0.5-20 keV band, which we modeled with a single power-law continuum attenuated by an interstellar extinction. We evaluated the systematic uncertainty upon the spectral parameters by various calibration items. In the 2-12 keV band, the SXS result is consistent with the literature values in flux (2.20 0.08) 10 erg s cm with a 1 statistical uncertainty) but is softer in the power-law index (2.19 0.11). The discrepancy is attributable to the systematic uncertainty of about 6/ 7% and 2/ 5% respectively for the flux and the power-law index. The softer spectrum is affected primarily by the systematic uncertainty of the Dewar gate valve transmission and the event screening.

output.explanation:
The Soft X-ray Spectrometer (SXS) is designed to observe high-energy phenomena in space, particularly those with intense radiation like the Crab nebula. The SXS uses an x-ray microcalorimeter to detect and quantify energy released by these events.

A key term here is 'interstellar extinction,' which refers to the absorption of light as it passes through interstellar gas and dust. Another important concept is a power-law continuum, describing how energy is distributed across different ranges in the observed spectrum.

The SXS constructs spectra within specific bands, such as the 0.5-20 keV range. These spectra are modeled using a single power-law continuum attenuated by interstellar extinction. The systematic uncertainty of various calibration items affects the spectral parameters.

In the 2-12 keV band, the SXS result is consistent with literature values in flux but shows a softer spectrum due to systematic uncertainties. Specifically, the discrepancy in flux and power-law index can be attributed to about 6/7% and 2/5%, respectively.

title: Survey Observations to Study Chemical Evolution from High-mass Starless Cores to High-mass Protostellar Objects I: HC3N and HC5N
input: We carried out survey observations of HC N and HC N in the 42 45 GHz band toward 17 high-mass starless cores (HMSCs) and 35 high-mass protostellar objects (HMPOs) with the Nobeyama 45 m radio telescope. We have detected HC N from 15 HMSCs and 28 HMPOs, and HC N from 5 HMSCs and 14 HMPOs, respectively. The average values of the column density of HC N are found to be ( ) and ( ) cm in HMSCs and HMPOs, respectively. The average values of the fractional abundance of HC N are derived to be ( ) and ( ) in HMSCs and HMPOs, respectively. We find that the fractional abundance of HC N decreases from HMSCs to HMPOs using the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test. On the other hand, its average value of the column density slightly increases from HMSCs to HMPOs. This may imply that HC N is newly formed in dense gas in HMPO regions. We also investigate the relationship between the column density of HC N in HMPOs and the luminosity-to-mass ratio ( ), a physical evolutional indicator. The column density of HC N tends to decrease with increasing the ratio, which suggests that HC N is destroyed by the stellar activities.

output.explanation:
The universe's dense regions, such as star-forming cores and protostellar objects, are home to complex chemical processes.

High-mass starless cores (HMSCs) and high-mass protostellar objects (HMPOs) can be distinguished by their column density. Column density is a measure of the number of particles per unit area in these regions. Fractional abundance represents how much of HC N exists relative to other substances, while luminosity-to-mass ratio indicates a region's evolutionary stage.

In HMSCs and HMPOs, chemical processes interact with each other, influencing the formation and destruction of molecules like HC N. The column density of HC N is affected by its interaction with surrounding gas in these regions.

The fractional abundance of HC N decreases from HMSCs to HMPOs, while its average column density slightly increases. This suggests that HC N may be newly formed in dense gas within HMPO regions. Additionally, the column density of HC N tends to decrease as the luminosity-to-mass ratio increases, implying that it is destroyed by stellar activities.

title: Chaotic shadow of a non-Kerr rotating compact object with quadrupole mass moment
input: We have studied numerically the shadows of a non-Kerr rotating compact object with quadrupole mass moment, which belongs to Manko-Novikov family. The non-integrable photon motion caused by quadrupole mass moment affects sharply the shadow of the compact object. As the deviation parameter related to quadrupole mass moment is negative, the shadow of compact object is prolate and there are two disconnected main shadows with eyebrows located symmetrically on both sides of the equatorial plane. As the deviation parameter is positive, the shadow becomes oblate and the main shadow is joined together in the equatorial plane. Moreover, in this positive cases, there is a disorder region in the left of shadow which increases with the quadrupole-deviation parameter. Interestingly, we also find that Einstein ring is broken as the deviation from Kerr metric is larger than a certain critical value. This critical value decreases with the rotation parameter of black hole. Especially, the observer on the direction of rotation axis will find some concentric bright rings in the black disc. Finally, supposing that the gravitational field of the supermassive central object of the galaxy described by this metric, we estimated the numerical values of the observables for the black hole shadow.

output.explanation:
Compact objects with quadrupole mass moments, such as those in the Manko-Novikov family, reside at the heart of galaxies.

A key concept is the deviation parameter related to the quadrupole mass moment, which can be either positive or negative. The term 'prolate' refers to an elongated shape, while 'oblate' describes a flattened one.

The non-integrable photon motion caused by the quadrupole mass moment affects the shadow of these compact objects in distinct ways depending on whether the deviation parameter is positive or negative. When it's negative, the object's shadow becomes prolate with two disconnected main shadows and eyebrows located symmetrically on both sides of the equatorial plane.

Conversely, a positive deviation parameter yields an oblate shadow joined at the equator, accompanied by a disorder region that increases in size as the quadrupole-deviation parameter grows. Furthermore, breaking Einstein's ring occurs when the deviation from the Kerr metric exceeds a critical value, which decreases with increasing rotation parameters of black holes.

title: Bayesian assessment of moving group membership: importance of models and prior knowledge
input: Young nearby moving groups are important and useful in many fields of astronomy such as studying exoplanets, low-mass stars, and the stellar evolution of the early planetary systems over tens of millions of years, which has led to intensive searches for their members. Identification of members depends on the used models sensitively, therefore, careful examination of the models is required. In this study, we investigate the effects of the models used in moving group membership calculations based on a Bayesian framework (e.g., BANYAN II) focusing on the beta-Pictoris moving group (BPMG). Three improvements for building models are suggested: (1) updating a list of accepted members by re-assessing memberships in terms of position, motion, and age, (2) investigating member distribution functions in , and (3) exploring field star distribution functions in and . The effect of each change is investigated, and we suggest using all of these improvements simultaneously in future membership probability calculations. Using this improved MG membership calculation and the careful examination of the age, 57 bona fide members of BPMG are confirmed including 12 new members. We additionally suggest 17 highly probable members.

output.explanation:
The study of young nearby moving groups is crucial for understanding the evolution of planetary systems over vast timescales, encompassing tens of millions of years.

Moving group membership calculations rely on models that determine an object's likelihood of belonging to a particular group based on its position, motion, and age. A key term in this context is 'moving group', which refers to a collection of stars sharing similar kinematic properties. Another important concept is the 'field star', denoting stars not part of any known moving group.

The process of identifying members involves re-evaluating existing models using a Bayesian framework, such as BANYAN II. This approach enables researchers to refine their understanding of member distribution functions in two-dimensional space and field star distribution functions. By implementing these improvements simultaneously, the accuracy of membership probability calculations can be enhanced.

This refined method confirms 57 bona fide members of the beta-Pictoris moving group (BPMG), including 12 new additions, while also suggesting 17 highly probable members.

title: The Extraordinary Outburst in the Massive Protostellar System NGC6334I-MM1: Emergence of Strong 6.7 GHz Methanol Masers
input: We report the first sub-arcsecond VLA imaging of 6 GHz continuum, methanol maser, and excited-state hydroxyl maser emission toward the massive protostellar cluster NGC6334I following the recent 2015 outburst in (sub)millimeter continuum toward MM1, the strongest (sub)millimeter source in the protocluster. In addition to detections toward the previously known 6.7 GHz Class II methanol maser sites in the hot core MM2 and the UCHII region MM3 (NGC6334F), we find new maser features toward several components of MM1, along with weaker features north, west, and southwest of MM1, and toward the non-thermal radio continuum source CM2. None of these areas have heretofore exhibited Class II methanol maser emission in three decades of observations. The strongest MM1 masers trace a dust cavity, while no masers are seen toward the strongest dust sources MM1A, 1B and 1D. The locations of the masers are consistent with a combination of increased radiative pumping due to elevated dust grain temperature following the outburst, the presence of infrared photon propagation cavities, and the presence of high methanol column densities as indicated by ALMA images of thermal transitions. The non-thermal radio emission source CM2 ( north of MM1) also exhibits new maser emission from the excited 6.035 and 6.030 GHz OH lines. Using the Zeeman effect, we measure a line-of-sight magnetic field of +0.5 to +3.7 mG toward CM2. In agreement with previous studies, we also detect numerous methanol and excited OH maser spots toward the UCHII region MM3, with predominantly negative line-of-sight magnetic field strengths of -2 to -5 mG and an intriguing south-north field reversal.

output.explanation:
The massive protostellar cluster NGC6334I is a complex system of young stars and dense gas, with the strongest (sub)millimeter source MM1 at its center. 

The term 'methanol maser' refers to a specific type of emission from molecules containing methanol, which can be excited by radiation or collisions. Methanol column density is a measure of how many methanol molecules are present in a given region. ALMA images provide detailed views of thermal transitions within the cluster. 

The protocluster underwent an outburst in 2015, causing dust grain temperatures to rise and potentially increasing radiative pumping – the process by which radiation excites molecular emissions. Infrared photon propagation cavities are regions where photons can travel through without being absorbed or scattered. The locations of masers suggest a combination of these factors is at play. 

The non-thermal radio emission source CM2, located north of MM1, exhibits new maser emission from excited OH lines and has a measured line-of-sight magnetic field strength ranging from +0.5 to +3.7 mG. In contrast, the UCHII region MM3 shows predominantly negative line-of-sight magnetic field strengths with an intriguing south-north reversal.

title: On the Efficiency of Thermal Conduction in Galaxy Clusters
input: Galaxy clusters host a large reservoir of diffuse plasma with radially-varying temperature profiles. The efficiency of thermal conduction in the intracluster medium (ICM) is complicated by the existence of turbulence and magnetic fields, and has received a lot of attention in the literature. Previous studies suggest that the magnetothermal instability developed in outer regions of galaxy clusters would drive magnetic field lines preferentially radial, resulting in efficient conduction along the radial direction. Using a series of spherically-symmetric simulations, here we investigate the impact of thermal conduction on the observed temperature distributions in outer regions of three massive clusters, and find that thermal conduction substantially modifies the ICM temperature profile. Within 3 Gyr, the gas temperature at a representative radius of typically decreases by ~10 - 20% and the average temperature slope between and drops by ~ 30 - 40%, indicating that the observed ICM would not stay in a long-term equilibrium state in the presence of thermal conduction. However, X-ray observations show that the outer regions of massive clusters have remarkably similar radially-declining temperature profiles, suggesting that they should be quite stable. Our study thus suggests that the effective conductivity along the radial direction must be suppressed below the Spitzer value by a factor of 10 or more, unless additional heating sources offset conductive cooling and maintain the observed temperature distributions. Our study provides a smoking-gun evidence for the suppression of parallel conduction along magnetic field lines in low-collisionality plasmas by kinetic mirror or whistler instabilities.

output.explanation:
Galaxy clusters reside in vast, diffuse plasma environments with temperature profiles that vary radially.

The intracluster medium (ICM) is a magnetized fluid where thermal conduction plays a crucial role. Thermal conductivity refers to the rate at which heat is transferred through collisions between particles. Turbulence and magnetic fields complicate this process by introducing random motions and guiding charged particles along field lines, respectively. The term 'magnetothermal instability' describes the interaction of these factors.

In low-collisionality plasmas, kinetic mirror or whistler instabilities can suppress parallel conduction along magnetic field lines. This suppression is critical in understanding thermal conduction's impact on galaxy clusters. Thermal conductivity in such environments involves the transfer of heat through collisions between particles and charged particles moving along magnetic field lines.

Thermal conduction modifies the observed temperature profiles of massive galaxy clusters within a certain time frame by decreasing gas temperatures at representative radii and reducing average temperature slopes between adjacent regions, suggesting that thermal conduction would not maintain long-term equilibrium in these systems. The effective conductivity must be suppressed below the Spitzer value for this to occur.

title: Magnetar giant flares in multipolar magnetic fields. III. Multipolar magnetic field structure variations
input: We have analyzed the multipolar magnetic field structure variation at neutron star surface by means of the catastrophic eruption model, and find that the variation of the geometry of multipolar fields on the magnetar surface could result in the catastrophic rearrangement of the magnetosphere, which provides certain physical mechanism for the outburst of giant flares. The magnetospheric model we adopted consists of two assumptions: a helically twisted flux rope is suspended in an ideal force-free magnetosphere around the magnetar, and a current sheet emerges during the flux rope evolution. Magnetic energy accumulates during the flux rope's gradual evolution along with the variation of magnetar surface magnetic structure before the eruption. The two typical behaviors, either state transition or catastrophic escape, would take place once the flux rope loses equilibrium, thus tremendous accumulated energy is radiated. We have investigated the equilibrium state of the flux rope and the energy release affected by different multipolar structures, and find structures that could trigger violent eruption and provide the radiation approximately 0.5 of the total magnetic energy during the giant flare outburst. Our results provide certain multipolar structures of the neutron star's magnetic field with an energy release percentage 0.42 in the state transition and 0.51 in the catastrophic escape case, which are sufficient for the previously reported energy release from SGR 1806-20 giant flares.

output.explanation:
A neutron star's surface is characterized by intense magnetic fields, which can be thought of as twisted ropes suspended in space. 

The key concept here is a 'helically twisted flux rope,' referring to a tightly wound bundle of magnetic field lines crucial for understanding energy accumulation and release near the neutron star. The accumulated energy builds up pressure or tension within the flux rope. 

The process involves two scenarios: state transition and catastrophic escape, where loss of equilibrium leads to an explosive release of magnetic energy that can be radiated as electromagnetic waves or high-energy particles. 

The researchers have identified specific multipolar structures capable of triggering violent eruptions and releasing a significant portion of the total magnetic energy stored within the magnetosphere, including certain configurations of the helically twisted flux rope and its associated current sheet, with resulting energy release percentages ranging from approximately 0.42 to 0.51.

title: Constraints on brane inflation after Planck 2015: Impacts of the latest local measurement of the Hubble constant
input: We investigate the observational constraints on three typical brane inflation models by considering the latest local measurement of the Hubble constant in the global fit. We also employ other observational data, including the Planck 2015 CMB data, the BICEP2/Keck Array B-mode data, and the baryon acoustic oscillations data, in our analysis. Previous studies have shown that the addition of the latest local measurement favors a larger spectral index, and can exert a significant influence on the model selection of inflation. In this work, we investigate its impacts on the status of brane inflation models. We find that, when the direct measurement is considered, the prototype model of brane inflation is still in good agreement with the current observational data within the level range. For the KKLMMT model, the consideration of the measurement allows the range of the parameter to be amplified to , which slightly alleviates the fine-tuning problem. For the IR DBI model, the addition of the measurement does not provide a better fit. These results show that the consideration of the new prior can exert a considerable influence on the brane inflation models. At last, we show that, when , the equilateral non-Gaussianity in the IR DBI inflation model is compatible with the current CMB data at the 1 level.

output.explanation:
The universe's expansion is governed by the Hubble constant, a fundamental parameter in cosmology.

Inflationary models propose that our universe underwent an accelerated expansion phase in its early stages. Brane inflation models suggest that our universe is a four-dimensional brane or membrane floating in a higher-dimensional space called the 'bulk'. The term 'brane' refers to a lower-dimensional object embedded within a higher-dimensional space, while 'inflationary model' describes a theoretical framework for understanding the early stages of cosmic evolution.

The concept of non-Gaussianity is relevant here. Non-Gaussianity in cosmology refers to deviations from Gaussian distributions in the statistical properties of the universe's density fluctuations. In this context, the direct measurement of the Hubble constant can impact model selection in inflationary theories.

When considering observational constraints on brane inflation models, it's essential to understand how different parameters interact and influence one another. For instance, the consideration of new prior information affects their parameter ranges and fine-tuning problems. Specifically, for certain models like KKLMMT or IR DBI, this inclusion allows the range of a particular parameter to be amplified, slightly alleviating the fine-tuning problem.

title: Converged Close-Coupling R-Matrix calculations of Photoionization of Fe XVII in Astrophysical Plasmas: from Convergence to Completeness
input: Extensive resonance structures are manifest in R-Matrix (RM) calculations. However, there exist a large number of highly excited electronic configurations that may contribute to background non-resonant bound-free opacity in high-temperature plasmas. Since RM calculations are very complex, and not essential for background contributions, the Relativistic Distorted Wave (RDW) method is utilized to complement ("top-up") photoionization cross sections of Fe XVII obtained using Close-Coupling Breit-Pauli R-Matrix (CC-BPRM) method. There is good agreement between RDW and BPRM for background cross sections where resonances are not present, and individual fine structure levels can be correctly matched spectroscopically, though resonances are neglected in the RDW. To ensure completeness, a high energy range up to 500 Ry above the ionization threshold for each level is considered. Interestingly, the hydrogenic Kramer's approximation also shows the same energy behavior as the RDW. Grouping separately, the BPRM configurations consist of 454 bound levels with resonances corresponding to configurations (n 3, n' 10); including RDW configurations there are 51,558 levels in total. The topup contribution results in 20\% increment, in addition to the 35\% enhancement from BPRM calculations over the Opacity Project value for the Rosseland Mean Opacity at the Z-temperature of 2.11 K (Pradhan and Nahar 2017).

output.explanation:
High-energy plasmas are characterized by complex interactions between electrons and ions, giving rise to various electronic configurations. The R-Matrix (RM) method is used to study resonance structures in these environments, but it becomes impractical for understanding background non-resonant bound-free opacity.

Key terms such as 'R-Matrix' refer to a computational technique that models atomic interactions, while 'Relativistic Distorted Wave' describes an approach that accounts for relativistic effects on wave propagation. Additionally, 'Close-Coupling Breit-Pauli R-Matrix' is a method used in conjunction with the RDW to study photoionization cross sections.

The interaction between these methods occurs through their respective calculations of atomic interactions and wave behavior. The Relativistic Distorted Wave method complements Close-Coupling Breit-Pauli R-Matrix results by providing an alternative perspective on high-energy plasma dynamics, particularly in regions where resonances are not present.

In the context of Fe XVII photoionization cross sections, the RDW and BPRM methods show good agreement for background cross sections without resonant effects. The total number of levels considered is 51,558, including both bound levels with resonances and those without. Furthermore, a high energy range up to 500 Ry above the ionization threshold is examined for each level.

title: Infrared Contributions of X-Ray Selected Active Galactic Nuclei in Dusty Star-Forming Galaxies
input: We investigate the infrared contribution from supermassive black hole activity versus host galaxy emission in the mid to far-infrared (IR) spectrum for a large sample of X-ray bright active galactic nuclei (AGN) residing in dusty, star-forming host galaxies. We select 703 AGN with L_X = 10^42-46 ergs/s at 0.1 < z < 5 from the Chandra XBootes X-ray Survey with rich multi-band observations in the optical to far-IR. This is the largest sample to date of X-ray AGN with mid and far-IR detections that uses spectral energy distribution (SED) decomposition to determine intrinsic AGN and host galaxy infrared luminosities. We determine weak or nonexistent relationships when averaging star-formation activity as a function of AGN activity, but see stronger positive trends when averaging L_X in bins of star-forming activity for AGN at low redshifts. We estimate an average dust covering factor of 33% based on infrared SEDs and bolometric AGN luminosity, corresponding to a Type 2 AGN population of roughly a third. We also see a population of AGN that challenge the inclination based unification model with individual dust covering factors that contradict the nuclear obscuration expected from observed X-ray hardness ratios. We see no strong connection between AGN fractions in the IR and corresponding total infrared, 24 um, or X-ray luminosities. The average rest-frame AGN contribution as a function of IR wavelength shows significant (~80%) contributions in the mid-IR that trail off at lambda > 30 um. Additionally, we provide a relation between observed L_X and pure AGN IR output for high-z AGN allowing future studies to estimate AGN infrared contribution using only observed X-ray flux density estimates.

output.explanation:
Galaxies harbor supermassive black holes at their centers, which can be obscured by dust and gas. These regions are also sites of intense star formation. The mid to far-infrared spectrum is a key region for studying both host galaxy emission and supermassive black hole activity.

Key terms include: L_X, the luminosity of an AGN at a specific wavelength; and dust covering factor, which describes how much of the supermassive black hole's light is blocked by surrounding dust. The infrared spectrum can be decomposed into its intrinsic components using spectral energy distribution (SED) decomposition.

The processes described interact through the complex interplay between host galaxy emission and supermassive black hole activity in dusty, star-forming galaxies. The observed properties of AGN are influenced by their environment, including dust covering factors that affect our view of these objects.

Weak or nonexistent relationships exist when averaging star-formation activity as a function of AGN activity. However, stronger positive trends emerge when considering L_X in bins of star-forming activity for low-redshift AGN. The average rest-frame AGN contribution shows significant contributions in the mid-IR that trail off at longer wavelengths.

title: The Radial Acceleration Relation and a Magnetostatic Analogy in Quasilinear MOND
input: Recently a remarkable relation has been demonstrated between the observed radial acceleration in disk galaxies and the acceleration predicted on the basis of baryonic matter alone. Here we study this relation within the framework of the modified gravity model MOND. The field equations of MOND automatically imply the radial acceleration relation for spherically symmetric galaxies, but for disk galaxies deviations from the relation are expected. Here we investigate whether these deviations are of sufficient magnitude to bring MOND into conflict with the observed relation. In the quasilinear formulation of MOND, to calculate the gravitational field of a given distribution of matter, an intermediate step is to calculate the "pristine field", which is a simple nonlinear function of the Newtonian field corresponding to the same distribution of matter. Hence, to the extent that the quasilinear gravitational field is approximately equal to the pristine field, the radial acceleration relation will be satisfied. We show that the difference between the quasilinear and pristine fields obeys the equations of magnetostatics, the curl of the pristine field serves as the source for the difference in the two fields, much as currents serve as sources for the magnetic field. Using the magnetostatic analogy we numerically study the difference between the pristine and quasilinear fields for simple model galaxies with a Gaussian profile. Our principal finding is that the difference between the fields is small compared to the observational uncertainties and that quasilinear MOND is therefore compatible with the observed radial acceleration relation.

output.explanation:
Galaxies are vast, gravitationally bound systems consisting of stars and dark matter. In disk galaxies, radial acceleration is a measure of how quickly objects move radially outward from the center.

The term 'pristine field' refers to a nonlinear function of the Newtonian gravitational field corresponding to a given distribution of matter. Magnetostatics describes the behavior of magnetic fields in response to sources such as currents or curls.

In modified gravity models like MOND, the difference between the quasilinear and pristine fields is governed by magnetostatic principles. The curl of the pristine field serves as a source for this difference, similar to how currents generate magnetic fields.

The study found that in simple model galaxies with a Gaussian profile, the difference between the quasilinear and pristine fields is small compared to observational uncertainties, indicating compatibility with the observed radial acceleration relation.

title: The roles of fluid compression and shear in electron energization during magnetic reconnection
input: Particle acceleration in space and astrophysical reconnection sites is an important unsolved problem in studies of magnetic reconnection. Earlier kinetic simulations have identified several acceleration mechanisms that are associated with particle drift motions. Here, we show that, for sufficient large systems, the energization processes due to particle drift motions can be described as fluid compression and shear, and that the shear energization is proportional to the pressure anisotropy of energetic particles. By analyzing results from fully kinetic simulations, we show that the compression energization dominates the acceleration of high-energy particles in reconnection with a weak guide field, and the compression and shear effects are comparable when the guide field is 50\% of the reconnecting component. Spatial distributions of those energization effects reveal that reconnection exhausts, contracting islands, and island merging regions are the three most important regions for compression and shear acceleration. This study connects particle energization by particle guiding-center drift motions with that due to background fluid motions, as in the energetic particle transport theory. It provides foundations for building particle transport models for large-scale reconnection acceleration such as those in solar flares.

output.explanation:
Magnetic reconnection in space and astrophysical environments is a complex phenomenon where the interaction between magnetic fields and charged particles leads to particle acceleration.

The guiding center refers to the average motion of a charged particle in a magnetic field, while pressure anisotropy describes how particles are distributed across different energy levels. Fluid compression occurs when magnetic fields converge, causing a buildup in particle density and subsequent increase in kinetic energy. Shear energization is related to the pressure anisotropy of energetic particles.

In large-scale reconnection events, fluid compression and shear interact to drive particle acceleration. The relative importance of these mechanisms depends on the strength of the guide field, which influences the reconnection rate and resulting acceleration patterns. In weak guide fields, compression dominates high-energy particle acceleration, while in stronger fields, both effects are comparable.

The energization processes occur primarily in three regions: reconnection exhausts, contracting islands, and island merging areas.

title: The late inspiral of supermassive black hole binaries with circumbinary gas discs in the LISA band
input: We present the results of 2D, moving-mesh, viscous hydrodynamical simulations of an accretion disc around a merging supermassive black hole binary (SMBHB). The simulation is pseudo-Newtonian, with the BHs modeled as point masses with a Paczynski-Wiita potential, and includes viscous heating, shock heating, and radiative cooling. We follow the gravitational inspiral of an equal-mass binary with a component mass M_bh=10^6 M_sun from an initial separation of 60r_g (where r_g=GM_bh/c^2 is the gravitational radius) to the merger. We find that a central, low-density cavity forms around the binary, as in previous work, but that the BHs capture gas from the circumbinary disc and accrete efficiently via their own minidiscs, well after their inspiral outpaces the viscous evolution of the disc. The system remains luminous, displaying strong periodicity at twice the binary orbital frequency throughout the entire inspiral process, all the way to the merger. In the soft X-ray band, the thermal emission is dominated by the inner edge of the circumbinary disc with especially clear periodicity in the early inspiral. By comparison, harder X-ray emission is dominated by the minidiscs, and the light curve is initially more noisy but develops a clear periodicity in the late inspiral stage. This variability pattern should help identify the EM counterparts of SMBHBs detected by the space-based gravitational-wave detector LISA.

output.explanation:
Supermassive black holes reside at the centers of galaxies, often found in binary systems where they are about to merge. This process involves complex dynamics and interactions between the two black holes and their surrounding environment.

Accretion discs form around these massive objects due to material falling towards them from the surrounding space. Key terms include accretion disc, which is a rotating disk of gas and dust that surrounds a black hole; Paczynski-Wiita potential, a mathematical model used to approximate the gravitational influence of a point mass on its surroundings; and minidiscs, small discs formed around individual black holes.

The interaction between these components leads to various physical processes. Viscous heating occurs when gas flows through the accretion disc, generating heat due to frictional forces. Shock heating takes place at the interface between different regions of the disc with varying velocities and densities. Radiative cooling is a process where excess energy from the system is released in the form of radiation.

The simulation reveals that during the merger of two supermassive black holes, a central cavity forms around the binary due to low-density gas. The black holes capture material from their surrounding environment and accrete it efficiently through their minidiscs. This process remains luminous throughout the entire inspiral phase, displaying strong periodicity at twice the binary orbital frequency.

title: Higher-order geometrical optics for electromagnetic waves on a curved spacetime
input: We study the geometrical-optics expansion for circularly-polarized electromagnetic waves propagating on a curved spacetime in general relativity. We show that higher-order corrections to the Faraday and stress-energy tensors may be found via a system of transport equations, in principle. At sub-leading order, the stress-energy tensor possesses terms proportional to the wavelength whose sign depends on the handedness of the circular polarization. Due to such terms, the direction of energy flow is not aligned with the gradient of the eikonal phase, in general, and the wave may carry a transverse stress.

output.explanation:
In the realm of general relativity, electromagnetic waves propagate through curved spacetime as ripples in space and time that carry energy and momentum.

The eikonal phase is a key concept describing the phase of wavefronts, while the stress-energy tensor represents the energy-momentum density of electromagnetic radiation. The Faraday tensor encodes information about polarization vector rotation due to spacetime curvature.

In curved spacetime, circularly-polarized waves exhibit distinct behavior due to their electric field components oscillating at right angles. This property leads to higher-order corrections in the geometrical-optics expansion, which can be found using transport equations that describe wave propagation through space and time.

At sub-leading order, these corrections introduce terms proportional to wavelength whose sign depends on circular polarization handedness. As a result, energy flow direction is not necessarily aligned with eikonal phase gradients, potentially leading to transverse stresses in the wave.

title: Orbital Synchronization Capture of Two Binaries Emitting Gravitational Waves
input: We study the possibility of orbital synchronization capture for a hierarchical quadrupole stellar system composed by two binaries emitting gravitational waves. Based on a simple model including the mass transfer for white dwarf binaries, we find that the capture might be realized for inter-binary distances less than their gravitational wavelength. We also discuss related intriguing phenomena such as a parasitic relation between the coupled white dwarf binaries and significant reductions of gravitational and electromagnetic radiations.

output.explanation:
Celestial systems in the universe often exhibit complex behaviors, such as hierarchical quadrupole stellar systems composed of two binaries emitting gravitational waves.

Gravitational wavelength refers to the distance over which an object's gravitational field dominates, while parasitic relation describes a situation where one system influences another. Mass transfer for white dwarf binaries involves material exchange through orbital evolution driven by gravitational forces.

The interaction between binary systems is a coupled process where each system's motion affects the other, leading to significant reductions in radiations when inter-binary distances are less than their respective wavelengths. This phenomenon may occur due to non-relativistic behavior and small energy-density fraction.

Orbital synchronization capture can be realized for hierarchical quadrupole stellar systems with inter-binary distances below a certain threshold, resulting in coupled white dwarf binaries that exhibit significant reductions in radiations.

title: Successive X-class flares and coronal mass ejections driven by shearing motion and sunspot rotation in active region NOAA 12673
input: We present a clear case study on the occurrence of two successive X-class flares including a decade-class flare (X9.3) and two coronal mass ejections (CMEs) triggered by shearing motion and sunspot rotation in active region NOAA 12673 on 2017 September 6. A shearing motion between the main sunspots with opposite polarities started on September 5 and even lasted after the second X-class flare on September 6. Moreover, the main sunspot with negative polarity rotated around its umbral center and another main sunspot with positive polarity also exhibited a slow rotation. The sunspot with negative polarity at the northwest of active region also began to rotate counter-clockwise before the onset of the first X-class flare. The successive formation and eruption of two S-shaped structures were closely related to the counter-clockwise rotation of three sunspots. It is also found that the rotation of sunspots is faster during four hours prior to the onset of the flares than the period before. The existence of a flux rope is found prior to the onset of two flares by using non-linear force free field extrapolation based on the vector magnetograms observed by SDO/HMI. These results suggest that shearing motion and sunspot rotation play an important role in the buildup of the free energy and the formation of flux ropes in the corona which produces solar flares and CMEs.

output.explanation:
The Sun's corona is a dynamic region where intense magnetic activity can lead to spectacular solar flares and coronal mass ejections (CMEs).

The study focuses on active region NOAA 12673, which was home to two successive X-class flares, including an exceptionally powerful flare. Shearing motion between sunspots with opposite polarities is a key driver of these events.

To understand the dynamics at play, it's essential to define some terms: shearing motion refers to the gradual movement of adjacent sunspots; and umbral center denotes the dark core at the heart of a sunspot. A flux rope is also an important concept in this context.

The study reveals that shearing motion between two main sunspots started on September 5, even persisting after the second X-class flare on September 6. The rotation speed increased during the four hours preceding each flare's onset, and a flux rope existed prior to both flares.

title: Imbalanced learning for RR Lyrae stars
input: We apply machine learning and Convex-Hull algorithms to separate RR Lyrae stars from other stars, like main sequence stars, white dwarf stars, carbon stars, CVs and carbon-lines stars, based on the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) and Galaxy Evolution Explorer (GALEX). In the low-dimensional space, the Convex-Hull algorithm is applied to select RR Lyrae stars. Given different input patterns of (u-g, g-r), (g-r, r-i), (r-i, i-z), (u-g, g-r, r-i), (g-r, r-i, i-z), (u-g, g-r, i-z) and (u-g, r-i, i-z), different convex hulls can be built for RR Lyrae stars. Comparing the performance of different input patterns, u-g, g-r, i-z is the best input pattern. For this input pattern, the efficiency (the fraction of true RR Lyrae stars in the predicted RR Lyrae sample) is 4.2% with a completeness (the fraction of recovered RR Lyrae stars in the whole RR Lyrae sample) of 100%, increases to 9.9% with 97% completeness and to 16.1% with 53% completeness by removing some outliers. In the high-dimensional space, machine learning algorithms are used with input patterns (u-g, g-r, r-i, i-z), (u-g, g-r, r-i, i-z, r), (NUV-u, u-g, g-r, r-i, i-z) and (NUV-u, u-g, g-r, r-i, i-z, r). RR Lyrae stars, which belong to the class of interest in our paper, are rare compared to other stars. For the highly imbalanced data, cost-sensitive Support Vector Machine (SVM), cost-sensitive Random Forest and Fast Boxes are used. The results show that information from GALEX is helpful for identifying RR Lyrae stars and Fast Boxes are the best performers on the skewed data in our case.

output.explanation:
The Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) and Galaxy Evolution Explorer (GALEX) provide a vast dataset of stars, including RR Lyrae stars, which are rare compared to other types such as main sequence stars, white dwarf stars, carbon stars, CVs, and carbon-lines stars.

The low-dimensional space is used to apply the Convex-Hull algorithm for selecting RR Lyrae stars based on color patterns like (u-g, g-r), (g-r, r-i), and (r-i, i-z). The performance of different input patterns shows that u-g, g-r, i-z is the most effective combination.

The Convex-Hull algorithm selects true RR Lyrae stars with an efficiency of 4.2% while achieving a completeness rate of 100%. By removing outliers, this increases to 9.9% and 16.1%, but at lower completeness rates of 97% and 53%, respectively.

The high-dimensional space uses machine learning algorithms like Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest, and Fast Boxes for identifying RR Lyrae stars in the presence of imbalanced data. The results indicate that information from GALEX is crucial for distinguishing RR Lyrae stars, with Fast Boxes performing best on skewed data.

title: On the interpretation of the Fermi GBM transient observed in coincidence with LIGO Gravitational Wave Event GW150914
input: The weak transient detected by the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM) 0.4 s after GW150914 has generated much speculation regarding its possible association with the black-hole binary merger. Investigation of the GBM data by Connaughton et al. (2016) revealed a source location consistent with GW150914 and a spectrum consistent with a weak, short Gamma-Ray Burst. Greiner et al. (2016) present an alternative technique for fitting background-limited data in the low-count regime, and call into question the spectral analysis and the significance of the detection of GW150914-GBM presented in Connaughton et al. (2016). The spectral analysis of Connaughton et al. (2016) is not subject to the limitations of the low-count regime noted by Greiner et al. (2016). We find Greiner et al. (2016) used an inconsistent source position and did not follow the steps taken in Connaughton et al. (2016) to mitigate the statistical shortcomings of their software when analyzing this weak event.
