The process involves using this information in conjunction with a metallicity-dependent evolutionary model to produce individual binary black holes, which are systems consisting of two black holes orbiting each other due to gravitational attraction. The resulting inventory reveals that approximately one million have merged within the simulated Milky Way, while three million binaries remain intact.

A notable trend observed is that half of the binary black hole progenitors reside in the stellar halo and satellites, with 40 percent having formed outside the main galaxy. This phenomenon becomes more pronounced as the masses of the black holes increase. The numbers and mass distribution of merged systems are found to be compatible with LIGO/Virgo detections.

title: Multi-timescale X-ray reverberation mapping of accreting black holes
input: Accreting black holes show characteristic reflection features in their X-ray spectrum, including an iron K line, resulting from hard X-ray continuum photons illuminating the accretion disk. The reverberation lag resulting from the path length difference between direct and reflected emission provides a powerful tool to probe the innermost regions around both stellar-mass and supermassive black holes. Here, we present for the first time a reverberation mapping formalism that enables modeling of energy dependent time lags and variability amplitude for a wide range of variability timescales, taking the complete information of the cross-spectrum into account. We use a pivoting power-law model to account for the spectral variability of the continuum that dominates over the reverberation lags for longer time scale variability. We use an analytic approximation to self-consistently account for the non-linear effects caused by this continuum spectral variability, which have been ignored by all previous reverberation studies. We find that ignoring these non-linear effects can bias measurements of the reverberation lags, particularly at low frequencies. Since our model is analytic, we are able to fit simultaneously for a wide range of Fourier frequencies without prohibitive computational expense. We also introduce a formalism of fitting to real and imaginary parts of our cross-spectrum statistic, which naturally avoids some mistakes/inaccuracies previously common in the literature. We perform proof-of-principle fits to Rossi X-ray Timing Explorer data of Cygnus X-1.

output.explanation:
Black holes at the centers of galaxies and stars are surrounded by an accretion disk, a swirling hot gas that emits X-rays.

The iron K line is a characteristic feature in X-ray spectra produced when hard photons from these regions interact with the accretion disk. This interaction creates reflected emission that can be used to study the innermost regions of black holes. The reverberation lag resulting from path length differences between direct and reflected emissions provides valuable information about the environment surrounding black holes.

Reverberation lags are influenced by energy-dependent time delays, which depend on how long it takes for X-rays to travel through the accretion disk. This is due to the fact that hotter regions of the disk emit more X-rays than cooler ones. The term 'pivoting power-law model' refers to a mathematical representation of this spectral variability.

The proposed formalism uses an analytic approximation to account for non-linear effects caused by continuum spectral variability, which previous studies have overlooked. This allows for simultaneous fitting across a wide range of Fourier frequencies without excessive computational costs.

title: Advanced Environmentally Resistant Lithium Fluoride Mirror Coatings for the Next-Generation of Broadband Space Observatories
input: Recent advances in the physical vapor deposition (PVD) of protective fluoride films have raised the far-ultraviolet (FUV: 912-1600 Å) reflectivity of aluminum-based mirrors closer to the theoretical limit. The greatest gains, at more than 20%, have come for lithium fluoride-protected aluminum, which has the shortest wavelength cutoff of any conventional overcoat. Despite the success of the NASA FUSE mission, the use of lithium fluoride (LiF)-based optics is rare, as LiF is hygroscopic and requires handling procedures that can drive risk. With NASA now studying two large mission concepts for astronomy, Large UV-Optical-IR Surveyor (LUVOIR) and the Habitable Exoplanet Imaging Mission (HabEx), which mandate throughput down to 1000 Å, the development of LiF-based coatings becomes crucial. This paper discusses steps that are being taken to qualify these new enhanced LiF-protected aluminum (eLiF) mirror coatings for flight. In addition to quantifying the hygroscopic degradation, we have developed a new method of protecting eLiF with an ultrathin (10-20 Å) capping layer of a non-hygroscopic material to increase durability. We report on the performance of eLiF-based optics and assess the steps that need to be taken to qualify such coatings for LUVOIR, HabEx, and other FUV-sensitive space missions.

output.explanation:
The far-ultraviolet region of the electromagnetic spectrum is crucial for astronomical observations, spanning wavelengths from 912 to 1600 Å. In this context, aluminum-based mirrors are reflective surfaces due to their high reflectivity in the FUV regime. Physical vapor deposition has improved mirror performance by developing protective fluoride films.

Protective fluoride film refers to a thin layer of material deposited on top of a surface using physical vapor deposition (PVD). Hygroscopic materials absorb moisture from their surroundings, making them prone to degradation when exposed to humidity. Non-hygroscopic materials, in contrast, have low water affinity and are less susceptible to damage.

The development of protective fluoride films involves depositing thin layers of material on top of aluminum-based mirrors using PVD techniques. This process improves mirror performance by reducing reflectivity losses due to surface roughness and contamination. However, lithium fluoride's hygroscopic nature poses a significant challenge for its adoption in space missions.

Enhanced LiF-protected aluminum (eLiF) coatings have been developed with an ultrathin capping layer of non-hygroscopic material to increase durability. This approach aims to mitigate the effects of humidity exposure and make eLiF-based optics suitable for high-throughput applications down to 1000 Å.

title: Physical properties and scaling relations of molecular clouds: the effect of stellar feedback
input: Using hydrodynamical simulations of entire galactic discs similar to the Milky Way, reaching 4.6pc resolution, we study the origins of observed physical properties of giant molecular clouds (GMCs). We find that efficient stellar feedback is a necessary ingredient in order to develop a realistic interstellar medium (ISM), leading to molecular cloud masses, sizes, velocity dispersions and virial parameters in excellent agreement with Milky Way observations. GMC scaling relations observed in the Milky Way, such as the mass-size ( -- ), velocity dispersion-size ( -- ), and the -- relations, are reproduced in a feedback driven ISM when observed in projection, with and . When analysed in 3D, GMC scaling relations steepen significantly, indicating potential limitations of our understanding of molecular cloud 3D structure from observations. Furthermore, we demonstrate how a GMC population's underlying distribution of virial parameters can strongly influence the scatter in derived scaling relations. Finally, we show that GMCs with nearly identical global properties exist in different evolutionary stages, where a majority of clouds being either gravitationally bound or expanding, but with a significant fraction being compressed by external ISM pressure, at all times.

output.explanation:
Galactic discs, similar to the Milky Way, are complex systems governed by hydrodynamics and stellar feedback.

Key terms in this context include GMCs (giant molecular clouds), which are massive cloud formations within galaxies; ISM (interstellar medium), a diffuse gas that fills intergalactic space; virial parameters, measures of an object's self-gravity relative to its internal motions; and scaling relations, mathematical connections between physical properties. 

In these simulations, stellar feedback drives the evolution of GMCs, influencing their masses, sizes, velocity dispersions, and virial parameters. This process leads to realistic interstellar medium properties that match observations in our galaxy.

The interaction between stellar feedback and GMCs is crucial for understanding how galaxies evolve over time. Stellar feedback compresses and disperses gas within the ISM, affecting the formation of new stars and planets. The distribution of virial parameters among a GMC population can also impact the accuracy of derived scaling relations.

title: Full-disc CO(1-0) mapping across nearby galaxies of the EMPIRE survey and the CO-to-H conversion factor
input: Carbon monoxide (CO) provides crucial information about the molecular gas properties of galaxies. While CO has been targeted extensively, isotopologues such as CO have the advantage of being less optically thick and observations have recently become accessible across full galaxy discs. We present a comprehensive new dataset of CO(1-0) observations with the IRAM 30-m telescope of the full discs of 9 nearby spiral galaxies from the EMPIRE survey at a spatial resolution of 1.5kpc. CO(1-0) is mapped out to and detected at high signal-to-noise throughout our maps. We analyse the CO(1-0)-to- CO(1-0) ratio ( ) as a function of galactocentric radius and other parameters such as the CO(2-1)-to- CO(1-0) intensity ratio, the 70-to-160 m flux density ratio, the star-formation rate surface density, the star-formation efficiency, and the CO-to-H conversion factor. We find that varies by a factor of 2 at most within and amongst galaxies, with a median value of 11 and larger variations in the galaxy centres than in the discs. We argue that optical depth effects, most likely due to changes in the mixture of diffuse/dense gas, are favored explanations for the observed variations, while abundance changes may also be at play. We calculate a spatially-resolved CO(1-0)-to-H conversion factor and find an average value of cm (K.km/s) over our sample with a standard deviation of a factor of 2. We find that CO(1-0) does not appear to be a good predictor of the bulk molecular gas mass in normal galaxy discs due to the presence of a large diffuse phase, but it may be a better tracer of the mass than CO(1-0) in the galaxy centres where the fraction of dense gas is larger.

output.explanation:
Galaxies are vast, star-forming systems comprising molecular gas and dust.

Key terms such as galactocentric radius refer to the distance from a galaxy's center, while optical depth effects arise when diffuse or dense gas mixtures alter CO emission properties. Optical thickness is a measure of how easily radiation passes through interstellar medium.

The interaction between molecular gas and radiation leads to variations in CO intensity ratios across different galactic regions. In particular, the ratio of 13CO(1-0) to 12CO(1-0) exhibits larger fluctuations near galaxy centers compared to disc regions.

The observed variations suggest that optical depth effects are favored explanations for these changes, while abundance differences may also contribute. Spatially-resolved calculations yield an average CO-to-H conversion factor with a standard deviation of approximately two-fold variations across the sample.

title: An excess of massive stars in the local 30 Doradus starburst
input: The 30 Doradus star-forming region in the Large Magellanic Cloud is a nearby analogue of large star-formation events in the distant Universe. We determine the recent formation history and the initial mass function (IMF) of massive stars in 30 Doradus based on spectroscopic observations of 247 stars more massive than 15 solar masses ( ). The main episode of massive star formation started about ago and the star-formation rate seems to have declined in the last . The IMF is densely sampled up to and contains more stars above than predicted by a standard Salpeter IMF. In the mass range , the IMF power-law exponent is , shallower than the Salpeter value of 2.35.

output.explanation:
The Large Magellanic Cloud is a satellite galaxy of the Milky Way, hosting various star-forming regions. 

The initial mass function (IMF) refers to the distribution of masses among newly formed stars. In astrophysics, it's often described using power-law exponents. The Salpeter IMF is a widely accepted model with an exponent of 2.35. However, recent studies suggest that this value may not hold for all massive stars. 

The process of star formation involves the collapse of giant molecular clouds into dense cores, which eventually give birth to new stars. In regions like 30 Doradus, intense star-forming activity is observed. The IMF power-law exponent can vary depending on the mass range considered. For masses above a certain threshold, recent observations indicate that this exponent may be shallower than expected. 

The main episode of massive star formation in 30 Doradus started about ago and has since declined. This region's IMF is densely sampled up to these high-mass stars, revealing more instances than predicted by the standard Salpeter model.

title: Enforcing the Courant-Friedrichs-Lewy Condition in Explicitly Conservative Local Time Stepping Schemes
input: An optimally efficient explicit numerical scheme for solving fluid dynamics equations, or any other parabolic or hyperbolic system of partial differential equations, should allow local regions to advance in time with their own, locally constrained time steps. However, such a scheme can result in violation of the Courant-Friedrichs-Lewy (CFL) condition, which is manifestly non-local. Although the violations can be considered to be "weak" in a certain sense and the corresponding numerical solution may be stable, such calculation does not guarantee the correct propagation speed for arbitrary waves. We use an experimental fluid dynamics code that allows cubic "patches" of grid cells to step with independent, locally constrained time steps to demonstrate how the CFL condition can be enforced by imposing a condition on the time steps of neighboring patches. We perform several numerical tests that illustrate errors introduced in the numerical solutions by weak CFL condition violations and show how strict enforcement of the CFL condition eliminates these errors. In all our tests the strict enforcement of the CFL condition does not impose a significant performance penalty.

output.explanation:
Fluid dynamics equations describe the behavior of fluids in motion, which can be modeled using parabolic or hyperbolic systems of partial differential equations. These systems often require numerical solutions to simulate complex fluid flows.

The CFL condition is a fundamental constraint that ensures stability and accuracy in these simulations by limiting the time step for each grid cell. The Courant number represents the ratio of the wave speed to the maximum allowed time step, while the Friedrichs-Lewy condition considers spatial location when determining this limit. Partial differential equations describe how physical quantities change over space and time in a continuous manner.

Enforcing the CFL condition involves ensuring that neighboring patches of grid cells advance in time with their own locally constrained time steps while maintaining global stability. This can be achieved by imposing conditions on the time steps of these patches to prevent weak violations of the CFL condition, which may lead to errors in numerical solutions due to incorrect propagation speeds for arbitrary waves.

The proposed approach demonstrates that strict enforcement of the CFL condition does not impose a significant performance penalty while ensuring correct simulation results and accurate wave propagation.

title: Merging massive black holes: the right place and the right time
input: The LIGO/Virgo detections of gravitational waves from merging black holes of 30 solar mass suggest progenitor stars of low metallicity (Z/Z ). In this talk I will provide constrains on where the progenitors of GW150914 and GW170104 may have formed, based on advanced models of galaxy formation and evolution combined with binary population synthesis models. First I will combine estimates of galaxy properties (star-forming gas metallicity, star formation rate and merger rate) across cosmic time to predict the low redshift BBH merger rate as a function of present day host galaxy mass, formation redshift of the progenitor system and different progenitor metallicities. I will show that the signal is dominated by binaries formed at the peak of star formation in massive galaxies with and binaries formed recently in dwarf galaxies. Then, I will present what very high resolution hydrodynamic simulations of different galaxy types can learn us about their black hole populations.

output.explanation:
Galaxies are vast, gravitationally bound systems comprising stars, gas, and dust. 

The term 'metallicity' refers to the abundance of elements heavier than hydrogen and helium within a galaxy's interstellar medium. Low metallicity indicates fewer elements forged in older stars. Metallicity is often used as an indicator of a galaxy's age. 

The process of star formation is closely tied to gravitational collapse of gas within galaxies. As this gas heats up, it eventually ignites nuclear fusion, marking the birth of new stars. The rate at which stars form can vary across different galaxy types. Star-forming gas metallicity and merger rates are key factors in determining a galaxy's properties. 

The merging black holes detected by LIGO/Virgo suggest that progenitor stars were formed under low-metallicity conditions. This implies that the signal is dominated by binaries formed at the peak of star formation in massive galaxies with high star-forming gas metallicity and those formed recently in dwarf galaxies, where merger rates are lower.

title: Is 4C+29.48 a gamma-ray source?
input: The Fermi Large Area Telescope revealed that the extragalactic gamma-ray sky is dominated by blazars, active galactic nuclei (AGN) whose jet is seen at very small angle to the line of sight. To associate and then classify the gamma-ray sources, data have been collected from lower frequency surveys and observations. The gamma-ray source 3FGL J1323.0+2942 is associated with the radio source 4C+29.48 and classified as a blazar of unknown type, lacking optical spectrum and redshift. The higher-resolution radio data showed that 4C+29.48 comprises three bright radio-emitting features located within a ~1'-diameter area. We (re-)analyzed archival Very Large Array and unpublished very long baseline interferometry (VLBI) observations conducted by the Very Long Baseline Array and the European VLBI Network of 4C+29.48. We also collected data form optical, infrared and X-ray surveys. The northernmost complex of 4C+29.48 contains a blazar with a high brightness temperature compact core and a steep-spectrum jet feature. The blazar is positionally coincident with an optical source at a redshift of 1.142. Its mid-infrared colors also support its association with a gamma-ray emitting blazar. The two other radio complexes have steep radio spectra and do not have optical or infrared counterparts in currently available surveys. Based on the radio morphology, they are unlikely to be related to the blazar. We discuss the possibilities whether the two radio features are lobes of a radio galaxy, or gravitationally lensed images of a background source. We propose to associate 3FGL J1323.0+2942 in subsequent versions of the Fermi catalog with the blazar residing in northernmost complex. We suggest naming this source J1323+2941A to avoid misinterpretation arising from the fact that the coordinates of the currently listed radio counterpart 4C+29.48 is closer to a most probably unrelated radio source. (abridged)

output.explanation:
The universe's gamma-ray sky is characterized by the presence of blazars, which are active galactic nuclei with jets pointing towards Earth at very small angles to our line of sight.

Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) refer to galaxies harboring supermassive black holes at their centers. Blazars are a type of AGN whose jets emit gamma-rays due to the relativistic motion of charged particles. Brightness Temperature is a measure of radio wave intensity, while Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) combines signals from multiple telescopes to achieve high-resolution imaging.

The interaction between these processes involves the emission and propagation of radiation across different wavelengths. The blazar's compact core and steep-spectrum jet feature are indicative of its relativistic nature, which leads to gamma-ray production. Meanwhile, the two other radio complexes exhibit steep spectra but lack optical or infrared counterparts, suggesting they may be unrelated to the blazar.

The northernmost complex contains a blazar with an associated optical source at redshift 1.142 and mid-infrared colors consistent with gamma-ray emission. The possibility of these features being lobes of a radio galaxy or gravitationally lensed images is discussed, but their association with the blazar residing in this complex is proposed for subsequent versions of the Fermi catalog.

title: Dust arcs in the region of Jupiter's Trojan asteroids
input: Aims. The surfaces of the Trojan asteroids are steadily bombarded by interplanetary micrometeoroids, which releases ejecta of small dust particles. These particles form the faint dust arcs that are associated with asteroid clouds. Here we analyze the particle dynamics and structure of the arc in the region of the Trojan asteroids. Methods. We calculate the total cross section of the Trojan asteroids and the production rate of dust particles. The motion of the particles is perturbed by a variety of forces. We simulate the dynamical evolution of the dust particles, and explore the overall features of the Trojan dust arc. Results. The simulations show that the arc is mainly composed of grains in the size range 4-10 microns. Compared to the Trojan asteroids, the dust arc is distributed more widely in the azimuthal direction, extending to a range of [30,120] degrees relative to Jupiter. The peak number density does not develop at . There exist two peaks that are azimuthally displaced from .

output.explanation:
The solar system's Trojan asteroids reside in a stable Lagrange point, influenced by Jupiter's gravitational pull and the orbital dynamics of nearby celestial bodies. Key terms include micrometeoroids: small particles from space that collide with asteroid surfaces; cross section: an object's interaction area; and azimuthal direction: the angle around a central point.

The motion of these ejected dust particles is affected by various forces, including gravity and radiation pressure. Simulations reveal how this system behaves over time, particularly in terms of particle size distribution. The arc formed by these particles consists mainly of grains with diameters between 4-10 microns.

The mechanism behind the formation and structure of the dust arc involves complex interactions between ejected particles and their environment. As perturbed by various forces, these particles spread out over a range in azimuthal direction relative to Jupiter. Notably, two peaks emerge in the number density distribution, displaced from each other by an angle not specified.

The simulations show that the dust arc extends more widely in azimuthal direction than the Trojan asteroids themselves, spanning a range of [30,120] degrees relative to Jupiter.

title: Dynamics and distribution of Jovian dust ejected from the Galilean satellites
input: In this paper, the dynamical analysis of the Jovian dust originating from the four Galilean moons is presented. High accuracy orbital integrations of dust particles are used to determine their dynamical evolution. A variety of forces are taken into account, including the Lorentz force, solar radiation pressure, Poynting-Robertson drag, solar gravity, the satellites' gravity, plasma drag, and gravitational effects due to non-sphericity of Jupiter. More than 20,000 dust particles from each source moon in the size range from 0.05 micron to 1 cm are simulated over 8,000 (Earth) years until each dust grain hits a sink (moons, Jupiter, or escape from the system). Configurations of dust number density in the Jovicentric equatorial inertial frame are calculated and shown. In a Jovicentric frame rotating with the Sun the dust distributions are found to be asymmetric. For certain small particle sizes, the dust population is displaced towards the Sun, while for certain larger sizes, the dust population is displaced away from the Sun. The average lifetime as a function of particle size for ejecta from each source moon is derived, and two sharp jumps in the average lifetime are analyzed. Transport of dust between the Galilean moons and to Jupiter is investigated. Most of the orbits for dust particles from Galilean moons are prograde, while, surprisingly, a small fraction of orbits are found to become retrograde mainly due to solar radiation pressure and Lorentz force. The distribution of orbital elements is also analyzed.

output.explanation:
The Jovian system is a complex environment where various forces interact to shape the behavior of dust particles originating from its Galilean moons. Key terms such as Poynting-Robertson drag refer to specific mechanisms through which charged particles lose energy while traversing the solar wind, whereas plasma drag involves interactions between charged particles and the surrounding plasma.

The Lorentz force arises due to electromagnetic interactions between moving charges and magnetic fields, introducing a significant influence on dust particle trajectories. Non-sphericity of Jupiter introduces gravitational effects that further complicate these dynamics.

In this context, the dynamical evolution of dust particles is governed by a delicate balance of forces including solar gravity, satellites' gravity, radiation pressure from the Sun, and plasma drag. As a result, configurations of dust number density exhibit asymmetry in a Jovicentric frame rotating with the Sun.

For smaller particles, displacement towards the Sun occurs due to increased radiation pressure relative to gravitational forces. Conversely, larger particles are displaced away from the Sun as their inertia dominates over radiation pressure effects.

title: Numerical simulations of ICME-ICME interactions
input: We present hydrodynamical simulations of interacting Coronal Mass Ejections in the Interplanetary medium (ICMEs). In these events, two consecutive CMEs are launched from the Sun in similar directions within an interval of time of a few hours. In our numerical model, we assume that the ambient solar wind is characterized by its velocity and mass-loss rate. Then, the CMEs are generated when the flow velocity and mass-loss rate suddenly change, with respect to the ambient solar wind conditions during two intervals of time, which correspond to the durations of the CMEs. After their interaction, a merged region is formed and evolve as a single structure into the interplanetary medium. In this work, we are interested in the general morphology of this merged region, which depends on the initial parameters of the ambient solar wind and each of the CMEs involved. In order to understand this morphology, we have performed a parametric study in which we characterize the effects of the initial parameters variations on the density and velocity profiles at 1 AU, using as reference the well-documented event of July 25th, 2004. Based on this parametrization we were able to reproduce with a high accuracy the observed profiles. Then, we apply the parametrization results to the interaction events of May 23, 2010; August 1, 2010; and November 9, 2012. With this approach and using values for the input parameters within the CME observational errors, our simulated profiles reproduce the main features observed at 1 AU. Even though we do not take into account the magnetic field, our models give a physical insight into the propagation and interaction of ICMEs.

output.explanation:
The Sun's corona is a region where Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) originate and interact with the surrounding Interplanetary medium (IPM). CMEs are massive plasma bursts that erupt from the Sun, carrying magnetic fields and energy into space.

Key terms to understand here include Coronal Mass Ejection (CME), referring to these massive plasma bursts, and Interplanetary medium (IPM), where they interact. The ambient solar wind is characterized by its velocity and mass-loss rate, which are crucial factors in determining the morphology of merged regions formed after CME interactions.

The interaction between two consecutive CMEs leads to a complex process where the plasmas from each event merge, resulting in changes to their density and velocity profiles. This merging occurs due to sudden changes in flow velocity and mass-loss rate with respect to ambient solar wind conditions during specific time intervals corresponding to CME durations.

The morphology of merged regions depends on initial parameters such as velocity and mass-loss rate, which influence the properties of these regions at 1 AU, a critical distance from the Sun. Our models give physical insight into ICME propagation and interaction without considering magnetic fields.

title: Detailed abundance analysis of globular clusters in the Local Group: NGC 147, NGC 6822, and Messier 33
input: We present new abundance measurements for eleven GCs in the Local Group galaxies NGC 147, NGC 6822, and Messier 33. These are combined with previously published observations of four GCs in the Fornax and WLM galaxies. The abundances were determined from analysis of integrated-light spectra, obtained with HIRES on the Keck I telescope and with UVES on the VLT. We find that the clusters with [Fe/H]<-1.5 are all alpha-enhanced at about the same level as Milky Way GCs. Their Na abundances are also generally enhanced relative to Milky Way halo stars, suggesting that these extragalactic GCs resemble their Milky Way counterparts in containing significant fractions of Na-rich stars. For [Fe/H]>-1.5, the GCs in M33 are also alpha-enhanced, while the GCs that belong to dwarfs (NGC 6822 SC7 and Fornax 4) have closer to Solar-scaled alpha-element abundances, thus mimicking the abundance trends observed in field stars in nearby dwarf galaxies. The abundance patterns in SC7 are remarkably similar to those in the Galactic GC Ruprecht 106, including significantly sub-solar [Na/Fe] and [Ni/Fe] ratios. In NGC 147, the GCs with [Fe/H]<-2.0 account for about 6% of the total luminosity of stars in the same metallicity range, a lower fraction than those previously found in the Fornax and WLM galaxies, but substantially higher than in the Milky Way halo.

output.explanation:
The Local Group of galaxies is a collection of gravitationally bound systems that contain various types of celestial objects, including globular clusters and dwarf galaxies.

In astronomy, alpha-enhancement refers to an overabundance of certain chemical elements relative to iron in globular clusters. Na-rich stars denote a high concentration of sodium in these stars. Metallicity is the measure of how much heavy elements are present in a star or galaxy.

The abundance patterns in globular clusters are shaped by their complex histories, including star formation and dynamical interactions within the cluster. The process of alpha-enhancement can lead to variations in the abundances of elements such as iron, sodium, and nickel across different globular clusters.

Globular clusters with low metal content exhibit similar levels of alpha-enhancement as those found in the Milky Way galaxy. However, for more metal-rich clusters in M33, their abundance patterns differ from those observed in our galaxy. In contrast, some dwarf galaxies' globular clusters display solar-scaled alpha-element abundances.

title: Morphology and Kinematics of Filaments in the Serpens and Perseus Molecular Clouds
input: We present H13CO+ (J=1-0) and HNC (J=1-0) maps of regions in Serpens South, Serpens Main and NGC 1333 containing filaments. We also observe the Serpens regions using H13CN (J=1-0). These dense gas tracer molecular line observations carried out with CARMA have an angular resolution of ~7", a spectral resolution of ~0.16 km/s and a sensitivity of 50-100 mJy/beam. Although the large scale structure compares well with the Herschel dust continuum maps, we resolve finer structure within the filaments identified by Herschel. The H13CO+ emission distribution agrees with the existing CARMA N2H+ (J=1-0) maps; so they trace the same morphology and kinematics of the filaments. The H13CO+ maps additionally reveal that many regions have multiple structures partially overlapping in the line-of-sight. In two regions, the velocity differences are as high as 1.4 m/s. We identify 8 filamentary structures having typical widths of 0.03-0.08 pc in these tracers. At least 50% of the filamentary structures have distinct velocity gradients perpendicular to their major axis with average values in the range 4-10 km/s/pc. These findings are in support of the theoretical models of filament formation by 2-D inflow in the shock layer created by colliding turbulent cells. We also find evidence of velocity gradients along the length of two filamentary structures; the gradients suggest that these filaments are inflowing towards the cloud core.

output.explanation:
Molecular clouds in the Serpens South, Serpens Main and NGC 1333 regions are characterized by complex networks of filaments 

 Filaments can be thought of as long, thin threads of gas that crisscross these cloud structures. Key terms include filamentary structure, which refers to a thread-like formation within molecular clouds, and velocity gradient, which is the rate at which velocity changes perpendicular to the major axis of an object. The CARMA observations have revealed finer details about filaments than Herschel dust continuum maps 

 Filamentary structures are formed through 2-D inflow in shock layers created by colliding turbulent cells. This process can be understood as a result of gas flowing into the cloud core, causing velocity gradients along the length of some filamentary structures. The H13CO+ emission distribution agrees with existing CARMA N2H+ maps 

 In regions where multiple filaments overlap in the line-of-sight, distinct velocity differences are observed, reaching up to 1.4 m/s in two areas. This suggests that these overlapping filaments have different velocities and may be inflowing towards the cloud core.

title: The massive Dirac equation in the Kerr-Newman-de Sitter and Kerr-Newman black hole spacetimes
input: Exact solutions of the Dirac general relativistic equation (DE) that describe the dynamics of a massive, electrically charged particle with half-integer spin in the curved spacetime geometry of an electrically charged, rotating Kerr-Newman-(anti) de Sitter black hole (BH) are investigated. We first, derive the DE in the Kerr-Newman-de Sitter (KNdS) BH background using a generalised Kinnersley null tetrad in the Newman-Penrose formalism. In this frame, we prove the separation of the DE into ordinary differential equations for the radial and angular parts. Under specific transformations of the independent and dependent variables we prove that the transformed radial equation for a massive charged spin fermion in the background KNdS BH constitutes a highly non-trivial generalisation of Heun's equation. Using a Regge-Wheeler-like independent variable we transform the radial equation in the KNdS background into a Schrödinger-like differential equation and investigate its asymptotic behaviour near the event and cosmological horizons. For a massive fermion (MF) in the background of a Kerr-Newman (KN) BH we first prove that the radial and angular equations that result from the separation of DE reduce to the generalised Heun differential equation (GHE). The local solutions of such GHE are derived and can be described by holomorphic functions whose power series coefficients are determined by a four-term recurrence relation. Using asymptotic analysis we derive the solutions for the MF far away from the KN BH and the solutions near the event horizon . The determination of the separation constant as an eigenvalue problem in the KN background is investigated. Using the aforementioned four-term recursion formula we prove that in the non-extreme KN geometry there are no bound states with , where and are the energy and mass of the fermion respectively.

output.explanation:
The study of black holes involves understanding the behavior of massive, electrically charged particles with half-integer spin in their curved spacetime geometry.

A key concept is Heun's equation, which describes certain physical systems as second-order linear differential equations. Another important term is Schrödinger-like differential equations, which resemble the time-independent Schrödinger equation from quantum mechanics but apply to different types of particles in curved spacetime. Additionally, a generalized Kinnersley null tetrad within the Newman-Penrose formalism facilitates the separation of the Dirac equation into ordinary differential equations governing radial and angular parts.

The interaction between these processes involves transforming the radial equation using specific variable transformations, resulting in a highly non-trivial generalization of Heun's equation. This transformation also enables researchers to investigate the asymptotic behavior near event and cosmological horizons.

In the Kerr-Newman black hole background, local solutions are derived for massive fermions described by holomorphic functions with power series coefficients determined by a four-term recurrence relation. The determination of the separation constant as an eigenvalue problem is also investigated, revealing that in non-extreme geometry there are no bound states with specific energy and mass values.

title: Compton thick AGN in the NuSTAR era
input: We present the 2-100 keV spectral analysis of 30 candidate Compton thick (CT-) active galactic nuclei (AGN) selected in the Swift-BAT 100-month survey. The average redshift of these objects is 0.03 and they all lie within 500 Mpc. We used the MyTorus (Murphy et al. 2009) model to perform X-ray spectral fitting both without and with the contribution of the NuSTAR data in the 3-50 keV energy range. When the NuSTAR data are added to the fit, 14 out of 30 of these objects (47% of the whole sample) have intrinsic absorption N cm at the 3 confidence level, i.e., they are re-classified from Compton thick to Compton thin. Consequently, we infer an overall observed fraction of CT-AGN with respect to the whole AGN population lower than the one reported in previous works, and as low as 4%. We find evidence that this over-estimation of N is likely due to the low quality of a subsample of spectra, either in the 2-10 keV band or in the Swift-BAT one.

output.explanation:
Active galactic nuclei reside in a vast, star-filled expanse of space within 500 Mpc, with an average redshift of 0.03.

Compton thick AGN are characterized by their high absorption rates due to dense gas and dust surrounding the supermassive black hole at their center. Compton thin refers to lower levels of absorption; Compton thick denotes higher absorption rates; redshift is a measure of how much light from distant objects has shifted towards the red end of the spectrum due to expansion of space.

The interaction between X-rays emitted by AGN and surrounding gas and dust determines absorption rates. The MyTorus model allows for X-ray spectral fitting, analyzing properties of Compton thick objects.

When considering both Swift-BAT and NuSTAR data in the 3-50 keV energy range, nearly half of the sample is reclassified from Compton thick to Compton thin due to lower intrinsic absorption levels. This indicates an overall observed fraction of CT-AGN as low as 4%. The discrepancy may be attributed to poor spectral quality in certain subsamples.

title: SN 2016X: A Type II-P Supernova with A Signature of Shock Breakout from Explosion of A Massive Red Supergiant
input: We present extensive ultraviolet (UV) and optical photometry, as well as dense optical spectroscopy for type II Plateau (IIP) supernova SN 2016X that exploded in the nearby ( 15 Mpc) spiral galaxy UGC 08041. The observations span the period from 2 to 180 days after the explosion; in particular, the Swift UV data probably captured the signature of shock breakout associated with the explosion of SN 2016X. It shows very strong UV emission during the first week after explosion, with contribution of 20 -- 30% to the bolometric luminosity (versus 15% for normal SNe IIP). Moreover, we found that this supernova has an unusually long rise time of about 12.6 0.5 days in the band (versus 7.0 days for typical SNe IIP). The optical light curves and spectral evolution are quite similar to the fast-declining type IIP object SN 2013ej, except that SN 2016X has a relatively brighter tail. Based on the evolution of photospheric temperature as inferred from the data in the early phase, we derive that the progenitor of SN 2016X has a radius of about 930 70 R . This large-size star is expected to be a red supergiant star with an initial mass of 19 -- 20 M based on the mass radius relation of the Galactic red supergiants, and it represents one of the most largest and massive progenitors found for SNe IIP.

output.explanation:
The universe is home to vast spiral galaxies, where stars and celestial events unfold. Supernovae are a key phenomenon within these galaxies, specifically type II Plateau (IIP) supernovae like SN 2016X. These explosions occur when massive stars collapse in on themselves.

A red supergiant star is a large, luminous star with an extended outer atmosphere. The term 'photospheric temperature' refers to the surface temperature of a star, which can be inferred from its spectral evolution. In the context of SN 2016X, ultraviolet and optical photometry were conducted over an extended period following its explosion.

The process of shock breakout occurs when a supernova's shock wave breaks through the outer layers of the star, releasing energy into space. This event is thought to have been captured by Swift UV data during the first week after SN 2016X's explosion. The observations revealed that SN 2016X exhibited very strong UV emission contributing approximately 20-30% to its bolometric luminosity.

SN 2016X had an unusually long rise time of about 12.6 days in a specific band, significantly longer than typical SNe IIP with a rise time of around 7.0 days. The optical light curves and spectral evolution of SN 2016X are quite similar to those of the fast-declining type IIP object SN 2013ej, except that it has a relatively brighter tail.

title: Transient rotation of photospheric vector magnetic fields associated with a solar flare
input: As one of the most violent eruptions on the Sun, flares are believed to be powered by magnetic reconnection. The fundamental physics involving the release, transfer and deposition of energy have been studied extensively. Taking advantage of the unprecedented resolution provided by the 1.6-m Goode Solar Telescope, here we show a sudden rotation of vector magnetic fields, about 12 -20 counterclockwise, associated with a flare. Unlike the permanent changes reported previously, the azimuth-angle change is transient and co-spatial/temporal with H emission. The measured azimuth angle becomes closer to that in potential fields suggesting untwist of flare loops. The magnetograms were obtained in the near infrared at 1.56~ m, which is minimally affected by flare emission and no intensity profile change was detected. We believe that these transient changes are real and discuss the possible explanations in which the high energy electron beams or waves play a crucial role.

output.explanation:
The Sun's surface is a dynamic environment where magnetic fields are in constant motion, driving powerful eruptions known as flares.

Magnetic reconnection refers to the process by which these fields interact and release energy. A key concept here is vector magnetic field, which describes the orientation of magnetic forces within this system. The azimuth angle defines the direction of these forces relative to a reference point.

During a flare event, changes in the vector magnetic field can occur due to the untwisting of twisted loops. This process involves the rotation of magnetic fields by a certain degree counterclockwise. In this case, a sudden rotation was observed, with an angle change that is both transient and co-spatial/temporal with H emission.

The measured azimuth angle approaches that found in potential fields, suggesting that flare loops are indeed untwisting. This phenomenon can be linked to the high-energy electron beams or waves that play a crucial role in driving these changes.

title: The Dark Energy Survey Image Processing Pipeline
input: The Dark Energy Survey (DES) is a five-year optical imaging campaign with the goal of understanding the origin of cosmic acceleration. DES performs a 5000 square degree survey of the southern sky in five optical bands (g,r,i,z,Y) to a depth of ~24th magnitude. Contemporaneously, DES performs a deep, time-domain survey in four optical bands (g,r,i,z) over 27 square degrees. DES exposures are processed nightly with an evolving data reduction pipeline and evaluated for image quality to determine if they need to be retaken. Difference imaging and transient source detection are also performed in the time domain component nightly. On a bi-annual basis, DES exposures are reprocessed with a refined pipeline and coadded to maximize imaging depth. Here we describe the DES image processing pipeline in support of DES science, as a reference for users of archival DES data, and as a guide for future astronomical surveys.

output.explanation:
The universe's expansion is a complex phenomenon that can be studied through optical imaging campaigns like the Dark Energy Survey (DES). The DES observes a vast region of the southern sky in five different bands: g, r, i, z, and Y. These observations are made with an unprecedented depth of ~24th magnitude, which allows for detailed studies of distant galaxies and stars.

The key terms used in this context include 'optical band', referring to a specific range of wavelengths within the electromagnetic spectrum; 'magnitude', measuring the brightness of celestial objects; and 'time-domain survey', focusing on transient events such as supernovae explosions. These concepts are crucial for understanding how DES operates.

DES's image processing pipeline involves nightly data reduction, where images are evaluated for quality and areas requiring re-observation are identified. Difference imaging techniques are also applied to detect subtle variations in light intensity, enabling the identification of transient sources. This process is repeated every six months with an improved pipeline, resulting in coadded images with enhanced depth.

The DES image processing pipeline ensures high accuracy for science applications by combining multiple observations and reprocessing data regularly. The survey's time-domain component focuses on detecting transient events like supernovae explosions, which can be identified through changes in brightness over short periods.

title: Finite conformal quantum gravity and spacetime singularities
input: We show that a class of finite quantum non-local gravitational theories is conformally invariant at classical as well as at quantum level. This is actually a range of conformal anomaly-free theories in the spontaneously broken phase of the Weyl symmetry. At classical level we show how the Weyl conformal invariance is able to tame all the spacetime singularities that plague not only Einstein gravity, but also local and weakly non-local higher derivative theories. The latter statement is proved by a singularity theorem that applies to a large class of weakly non-local theories. Therefore, we are entitled to look for a solution of the spacetime singularity puzzle in a missed symmetry of nature, namely the Weyl conformal symmetry. Following the seminal paper by Narlikar and Kembhavi, we provide an explicit construction of singularity-free black hole exact solutions in a class of conformally invariant theories.

output.explanation:
The universe's spacetime is a complex, dynamic entity governed by the laws of gravity and relativity. Conformal invariance refers to the property of remaining unchanged under specific transformations that alter the metric tensor.

Weyl conformal symmetry is a fundamental concept in this context, describing the behavior of theories under these transformations. A key aspect of Weyl's theory is its ability to tame spacetime singularities by transforming them into smooth regions.

The resolution of spacetime singularities relies on understanding how matter behaves at high densities and the role of conformal symmetry in resolving these issues. Conformally invariant theories exhibit a unique property that allows for singularity-free solutions, particularly in black hole physics.

A class of finite quantum non-local gravitational theories demonstrates this property by exhibiting conformal invariance at both classical and quantum levels. This behavior enables the elimination of singularities present in local higher derivative theories, as demonstrated through explicit construction of singularity-free black hole exact solutions.

title: The double helium-white dwarf channel for the formation of AM CVn binaries
input: Most close double helium white dwarfs will merge within a Hubble time due to orbital decay by gravitational-wave radiation. However, a significant fraction with low mass ratios will survive for a long time as a consequence of stable mass transfer. Such stable mass transfer between two helium white dwarfs (HeWD) provides one channel for the production of AM\,CVn binary stars. In previous calculations of double HeWD progenitors, the accreting HeWD was treated as a point mass. We have computed the evolution of 16 double HeWD models in order to investigate the consequences of treating the detailed evolution of both components. We find that the boundary between binaries having stable and unstable mass transfer is slightly modified by this approach. By comparing with observed periods and mass ratios, we redetermine masses of eight known AM\,CVn stars by our double HeWDs channel, i.e. HM\,Cnc, AM CVn, V406\,Hya, J0926, J1240, GP\,Com, Gaia14aae and V396\,Hya. We propose that central spikes in the triple-peaked emission spectra of J1240, GP\,Com and V396\,Hya and the surface abundance ratios of N/C/O in GP\,Com can be explained by the stable double HeWD channel. The mass estimates derived from our calculations are used to discuss the predicted gravitational wave signal in the context of the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA).

output.explanation:
Close double helium white dwarfs are systems consisting of two extremely dense stars primarily composed of helium, with masses roughly the same size as our sun but compressed into a volume no larger than that of Earth.

HeWD refers to a type of star known as a helium white dwarf. A HeWD is formed when a low-mass star undergoes a series of nuclear reactions in its core until it eventually sheds its outer layers, leaving behind the hot and dense core.

The evolution of these binary star systems is governed by gravitational forces and mass transfer between the two stars. In some cases where the mass ratio between the two stars is low, stable mass transfer occurs instead of merger. This process involves one star transferring material onto its companion, potentially leading to the formation of an AM CVn binary star.

The boundary between binaries having stable and unstable mass transfer is slightly modified by treating both components with detailed evolution rather than as point masses. By applying these findings to eight known AM CVn stars, certain characteristics can be explained: central spikes in their emission spectra and surface abundance ratios.

title: Extreme Gravity Tests with Gravitational Waves from Compact Binary Coalescences: (I) Inspiral-Merger
input: The observation of the inspiral and merger of compact binaries by the LIGO/Virgo collaboration ushered in a new era in the study of strong-field gravity. We review current and future tests of strong gravity and of the Kerr paradigm with gravitational-wave interferometers, both within a theory-agnostic framework (the parametrized post-Einsteinian formalism) and in the context of specific modified theories of gravity (scalar-tensor, Einstein-dilaton-Gauss-Bonnet, dynamical Chern-Simons, Lorentz-violating, and extra dimensional theories). In this contribution we focus on (i) the information carried by the inspiral radiation, and (ii) recent progress in numerical simulations of compact binary mergers in modified gravity.

output.explanation:
Strong-field gravity phenomena occur in regions of intense gravitational forces, warping spacetime around black holes and neutron stars. Key terms include the Kerr paradigm, which describes rotating black holes as solutions to Einstein's general relativity theory, and modified theories such as scalar-tensor, Einstein-dilaton-Gauss-Bonnet, dynamical Chern-Simons, Lorentz-violating, and extra dimensional theories. These alternative frameworks propose modifications to the gravitational field or spacetime geometry. 

The Kerr paradigm is a solution to general relativity theory that describes rotating black holes. Scalar-tensor theories introduce additional fields beyond gravity, while Einstein-dilaton-Gauss-Bonnet theories modify gravity in high-energy environments with a dilaton field. Dynamical Chern-Simons theories involve topological terms affecting spacetime geometry, and Lorentz-violating theories break fundamental symmetries of physics. Extra dimensional theories propose additional spatial dimensions. 

The parametrized post-Einsteinian formalism is used to analyze gravitational signals from inspiraling binaries, encoding information about their masses, spins, and orbital parameters in these signals. This framework allows for testing the Kerr paradigm without assuming a specific theory of gravity. Inspiral radiation carries crucial information for understanding strong-field gravity systems. 

The behavior of compact binary mergers within modified theories of gravity is being studied through numerical simulations, which provide precise calculations of merger outcomes and valuable insights into the behavior of these systems.

title: Generalized Lomb-Scargle analysis of decay rate measurements from the Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt
input: We apply the generalized Lomb-Scargle (LS) periodogram to independently confirm the claim by Sturrock et al (arXiv:1605.03088) of oscillation at a frequency of 11/year in the decay rates of from measurements at the Physikalisch Technische Bundesanstalt (PTB), which however has been disputed by Kossert and Nahle (arXiv:1407.2493). For this analysis, we made two different { ansatze} for the errors. For each peak in the LS periodogram, we evaluate the statistical significance using non-parametric bootstrap resampling. We find using both of these error models evidence for ~11/year periodicity in the data for two of the three samples, but at a lower significance than that claimed by Sturrock et al.

output.explanation:
The analysis of decay rates in measurements from the Physikalisch Technische Bundesanstalt (PTB) involves identifying periodic patterns at specific frequencies.

Key terms include 'periodogram', a graphical representation of power spectral density, and 'bootstrap resampling', a statistical technique for evaluating the significance of potential peaks. The periodogram is used to analyze data sets with irregular sampling intervals by quantifying the distribution of power across different frequencies.

The interaction between these processes can be understood as follows: the periodogram identifies periodic components within noisy datasets through non-parametric bootstrap resampling, which helps researchers evaluate the statistical significance of potential peaks. This analysis aims to confirm or refute claims of oscillation at a frequency of 11/year in the decay rates.

Two out of three samples exhibit evidence for ~11/year periodicity using both error models, but with lower significance than previously reported.

title: Anelastic spherical dynamos with radially variable electrical conductivity
input: A series of numerical simulations of the dynamo process operating inside gas giant planets has been performed. We use an anelastic, fully nonlinear, three-dimensional, benchmarked MHD code to evolve the flow, entropy and magnetic field. Our models take into account the varying electrical conductivity, high in the ionised metallic hydrogen region, low in the molecular outer region. Our suite of electrical conductivity profiles ranges from Jupiter-like, where the outer hydrodynamic region is quite thin, to Saturn-like, where there is a thick non-conducting shell. The rapid rotation leads to the formation of two distinct dynamical regimes which are separated by a magnetic tangent cylinder - mTC. Outside the mTC there are strong zonal flows, where Reynolds stress balances turbulent viscosity, but inside the mTC Lorentz force reduces the zonal flow. The dynamic interaction between both regions induces meridional circulation. We find a rich diversity of magnetic field morphologies. There are Jupiter-like steady dipolar fields, and a belt of quadrupolar dominated dynamos spanning the range of models between Jupiter-like and Saturn-like conductivity profiles. This diversity may be linked to the appearance of reversed sign helicity in the metallic regions of our dynamos. With Saturn-like conductivity profiles we find models with dipolar magnetic fields, whose axisymmetric components resemble those of Saturn, and which oscillate on a very long time-scale. However, the non-axisymmetric field components of our models are at least ten times larger than those of Saturn, possibly due to the absence of any stably stratified layer.

output.explanation:
Gas giant planets are characterized by a metallic hydrogen region with high electrical conductivity and an outer molecular layer with low conductivity.

The varying conductivity profiles can be described in terms of key technical terms: Anelastic refers to the ability of fluids to store energy without changing volume, while MHD stands for magnetohydrodynamics - the study of magnetic fields interacting with fluids. The dynamo process relies on these principles.

Rapid rotation leads to two distinct dynamical regimes separated by a magnetic tangent cylinder - mTC. Outside this boundary, strong zonal flows form due to Reynolds stress balancing turbulent viscosity, while inside it, Lorentz force reduces these flows. This dynamic interaction induces meridional circulation and generates diverse magnetic field morphologies.

The simulations reveal a rich diversity of magnetic fields, including steady dipolar fields and quadrupolar dominated dynamos spanning Jupiter-like to Saturn-like conductivity profiles. In some models, reversed sign helicity appears in metallic regions, possibly linked to this diversity.

title: Quintessential inflation: A unified scenario of inflation and dark energy
input: Quintessential inflation unifies inflation and late time acceleration by a single scalar field. Such a scenario, with canonical and non-canonical scalar fields, has been discussed . The scalar field behaves as an inflaton field during inflation and as a quintessence field during late time. Also the predictions of the models has been compared with the recent Planck data.

output.explanation:
The universe's expansion is driven by a single scalar field, which behaves as an inflaton during the inflationary era and as quintessence in the late-time acceleration phase. This unified scenario combines two fundamental phenomena: the rapid expansion of space in the early universe and the current accelerating expansion. The scalar field's dynamics are governed by its canonical or non-canonical properties.

The term 'inflaton' refers to a scalar field that drives inflation, while 'quintessence' describes a field responsible for late-time acceleration. In this context, the inflaton is the same entity as quintessence, unified under a single description. The predictions of these models have been compared with recent data from Planck observations.

The universe's expansion can be understood through the lens of scalar fields, which are hypothetical particles that permeate space and drive its evolution. Inflation occurs when the inflaton field dominates the energy density of the universe, causing a rapid expansion of space. Late-time acceleration is driven by quintessence, which gradually takes over as the dominant component.

The unified scenario predicts specific features that can be tested against observational data. The comparison with Planck data aims to validate or refute these predictions, providing insights into the nature of the universe's evolution.

title: Accurate effective temperatures of the metal-poor benchmark stars HD 140283, HD 122563 and HD 103095 from CHARA interferometry
input: Large stellar surveys of the Milky Way require validation with reference to a set of "benchmark" stars whose fundamental properties are well-determined. For metal-poor benchmark stars, disagreement between spectroscopic and interferometric effective temperatures has called the reliability of the temperature scale into question. We present new interferometric measurements of three metal-poor benchmark stars, HD 140283, HD 122563, and HD 103095, from which we determine their effective temperatures. The angular sizes of all the stars were determined from observations with the PAVO beam combiner at visible wavelengths at the CHARA array, with additional observations of HD 103095 made with the VEGA instrument, also at the CHARA array. Together with photometrically derived bolometric fluxes, the angular diameters give a direct measurement of the effective temperature. For HD 140283 we find θ_LD = 0.324+/-0.005 mas, Teff = 5787+/-48 K; for HD 122563, θ_LD = 0.926+/-0.011 mas, Teff = 4636+/-37 K; and for HD 103095 θ_LD = 0.595+/-0.007 mas, Teff = 5140+/-49 K. Our temperatures for HD 140283 and HD 103095 are hotter than the previous interferometric measurements by 253 K and 322 K, respectively. We find good agreement between our temperatures and recent spectroscopic and photometric estimates. We conclude some previous interferometric measurements have been affected by systematic uncertainties larger than their quoted errors.

output.explanation:
The Milky Way's stellar surveys rely on benchmark stars with well-determined properties for validation.

Benchmark stars are a set of reference points used to validate large-scale stellar surveys, such as the one conducted in our galaxy. The term 'benchmark' refers to these specific stars that serve as standards for comparison. A star's angular size (θ_LD) is its apparent diameter, typically measured in milliarcseconds.

Effective temperature (Teff), on the other hand, measures a star's surface temperature in Kelvin. These two quantities are closely related and can be used to determine each other's values. The process involves measuring the angular sizes of metal-poor benchmark stars using instruments like the PAVO beam combiner at visible wavelengths.

By combining this information with photometrically derived bolometric fluxes, researchers can calculate a direct measurement of effective temperature for these stars. This method was applied to three specific metal-poor benchmark stars: HD 140283 and two others. The calculated temperatures show that the values obtained are higher than previous interferometric measurements by up to 322 K.

title: Imaging black holes: past, present and future
input: This paper briefly reviews past, current, and future efforts to image black holes in the radio regime. Black holes seem like mystical objects, but they are an integral part of current astrophysics and are at the center of attempts to unify quantum physics and general relativity. Yet, nobody has ever seen a black hole. What do they look like? Initially, this question seemed more of an academic nature. However, this has changed over the past two decades. Observations and theoretical considerations suggest that the supermassive black hole, Sgr A*, in the center of our Milky Way is surrounded by a compact, foggy emission region radiating at and above 230 GHz. It has been predicted that the event horizon of Sgr A* should cast its shadow onto that emission region, which could be detectable with a global VLBI array of radio telescopes. In contrast to earlier pictures of black holes, that dark feature is not supposed to be due to a hole in the accretion flow, but would represent a true negative image of the event horizon. Currently, the global Event Horizon Telescope consortium is attempting to make such an image. In the future those images could be improved by adding more telescopes to the array, in particular at high sites in Africa. Ultimately, a space array at THz frequencies, the Event Horizon Imager, could produce much more detailed images of black holes. In combination with numerical simulations and precise measurements of the orbits of stars - ideally also of pulsars - these images will allow us to study black holes with unprecedented precision.

output.explanation:
Black holes reside at the heart of galaxies, playing a pivotal role in modern astrophysics as it seeks to merge quantum physics and general relativity.

Key terms include: event horizon - the boundary beyond which nothing escapes; supermassive black hole - an extremely massive black hole found at galaxy centers; VLBI array - a network of radio telescopes working together to form a virtual Earth-sized telescope. 

The compact emission region surrounding Sgr A* in our Milky Way's core interacts with its event horizon, producing a detectable shadow that could be observed through a global VLBI array.

This phenomenon is predicted to produce a true negative image of the event horizon, distinct from earlier depictions where it was seen as an absence in the accretion flow. The Event Horizon Telescope consortium's efforts aim to capture such images using radio telescopes, with future advancements potentially involving expanded arrays and space-based THz frequency imagers like the Event Horizon Imager.

title: Bounds on graviton mass using weak lensing and SZ effect in galaxy clusters
input: In General Relativity (GR), the graviton is massless. However, a common feature in several theoretical alternatives of GR is a non-zero mass for the graviton. These theories can be described as massive gravity theories. Despite many theoretical complexities in these theories, on phenomenological grounds, the implications of massive gravity have been widely used to put bounds on graviton mass. One of the generic implications of giving a mass to the graviton is that the gravitational potential will follow a Yukawa-like fall off. We use this feature of massive gravity theories to probe the mass of graviton by using the largest gravitationally bound objects, namely galaxy clusters. In this work, we use the mass estimates of galaxy clusters measured at various cosmologically defined radial distances measured via weak lensing (WL) and Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (SZ) effect. We also use the model independent values of Hubble parameter smoothed by a non-parametric method, Gaussian process. Within confidence region, we obtain the mass of graviton eV with the corresponding Compton length scale Mpc from weak lensing and eV with Mpc from SZ effect. This analysis improves the upper bound on graviton mass obtained earlier from galaxy clusters.

output.explanation:
The universe is described by General Relativity, a fundamental theory of gravity that predicts the behavior of massive objects on large scales. In this framework, the graviton is considered massless, but some alternative theories propose giving it a non-zero mass, leading to massive gravity theories.

In these models, the gravitational potential follows a Yukawa-like fall off, which can be used to constrain the graviton's mass using galaxy clusters as probes. Galaxy clusters are the largest gravitationally bound objects in the universe and their masses have been estimated at various cosmological distances through weak lensing and Sunyaev-Zel'dovich effect measurements.

A key concept in this analysis is the Yukawa potential, which describes how the gravitational force between two objects decreases with distance. This type of potential is characterized by a Compton length scale, which represents the distance over which the gravitational force becomes significantly weaker than Newton's law would predict.

The graviton mass is bounded within confidence regions to eV with corresponding Compton length scales Mpc from weak lensing and eV with Mpc from SZ effect measurements. This analysis improves upon previous bounds obtained using galaxy clusters.

title: Primordial Black Holes from Inflaton Fragmentation into Oscillons
input: We show that fragmentation of the inflaton into long-lived spatially localized oscillon configurations can lead to copious production of black holes. In a single-field inflation model primordial black holes of sublunar mass can form, and they can account for all of the dark matter. We also explore the possibility that solar-mass primordial black holes, particularly relevant for gravitational wave astronomy, are produced from the same mechanism.

output.explanation:
The universe's early stages involve rapid expansion, known as inflation, which can be driven by a single field called the inflaton. During this period, the inflaton undergoes oscillations that can lead to its fragmentation into localized configurations called oscillons. 

The key concept here is the inflaton itself, often referred to as a scalar field in cosmology. A scalar field is an abstract mathematical object used to describe physical quantities with magnitude but no direction. In this context, it's essential to understand that the inflaton's behavior can be influenced by its interactions and properties, such as its mass or potential energy density. 

The fragmentation of the inflaton into oscillons results in localized regions where the field is highly concentrated. These oscillons can then undergo further evolution, potentially leading to the formation of black holes. The process involves a complex interplay between the inflaton's dynamics and the gravitational collapse that occurs when matter becomes sufficiently dense. 

The production of primordial black holes from this mechanism has significant implications for our understanding of dark matter. In particular, it suggests that sublunar mass black holes could be responsible for all of the observed dark matter, while solar-mass black holes might also be produced through the same process, making them relevant for gravitational wave astronomy.

title: Gravitational corrections to light propagation in a perturbed FLRW-universe and corresponding weak lensing spectra
input: When the gravitational lensing of the large-scale structure is calculated from a cosmological model a few assumptions enter: one assumes that the photons follow unperturbed background geodesics, which is usually referred to as the Born-approximation, the lenses move slowly, the source-redshift distribution is evaluated relative to the background quantities and the lensing effect is linear in the gravitational potential. Even though these approximations are small individually they could sum up, especially since they include local effects such as the Sachs-Wolfe and peculiar motion, but also non-local ones like the Born-approximation and the integrated Sachs-Wolfe effect. In this work we will address all points mentioned and perturbatively calculate the effect on a tomographic cosmic shear power spectrum of each effect individually as well as all cross-correlations. Our findings show that each effect is at least 4 to 5 orders of magnitude below the leading order lensing signal. Finally we sum up all effects to estimate the overall impact on parameter estimation by a future cosmological weak lensing survey such as Euclid in a CDM cosmology with parametrisation , , , , and , using 5 tomographic bins. We consistently find a parameter bias of , which is therefore completely negligible for all practical purposes, confirming that other effects such as intrinsic alignments and magnification bias will be the dominant systematic source in future surveys.

output.explanation:
The universe's large-scale structure is shaped by the gravitational lensing of light, a phenomenon where massive objects bend and distort it.

Key terms in this context include geodesics, which are curved paths in spacetime that light follows; background quantities, representing average properties of the universe; and gravitational potential, measuring an object's mass-energy influence on its surroundings. The integrated Sachs-Wolfe effect refers to changes in photon energy as it passes through regions with varying potentials.

The lensing process involves various assumptions, including photons following unperturbed geodesics (Born-approximation), lenses moving slowly, and source-redshift distributions evaluated relative to background quantities. These approximations can accumulate, incorporating local factors like Sachs-Wolfe and peculiar motion, as well as non-local influences such as the integrated Sachs-Wolfe effect.

Perturbative calculations of individual effects on a tomographic cosmic shear power spectrum reveal that each is significantly weaker than the primary lensing signal. The combined impact of these effects on future surveys like Euclid, studying a CDM universe with specific parameters, is found to be negligible, resulting in an insignificant parameter bias.

title: Applications of deep learning to relativistic hydrodynamics
input: Relativistic hydrodynamics is a powerful tool to simulate the evolution of the quark gluon plasma (QGP) in relativistic heavy ion collisions. Using 10000 initial and final profiles generated from 2+1-d relativistic hydrodynamics VISH2+1 with MC-Glauber initial conditions, we train a deep neural network based on stacked U-net, and use it to predict the final profiles associated with various initial conditions, including MC-Glauber, MC-KLN and AMPT and TRENTo. A comparison with the VISH2+1 results shows that the network predictions can nicely capture the magnitude and inhomogeneous structures of the final profiles, and nicely describe the related eccentricity distributions (n=2, 3, 4). These results indicate that deep learning technique can capture the main features of the non-linear evolution of hydrodynamics, showing its potential to largely accelerate the event-by-event simulations of relativistic hydrodynamics.

output.explanation:
The universe's most extreme environments are created in relativistic heavy ion collisions, where the quark gluon plasma is formed. This state of matter is characterized by its fluid-like behavior and complex interactions between particles.

Key terms like 'hydrodynamics' describe how fluids behave under conditions where the speed of light plays a significant role, while 'non-linear evolution' refers to the intricate balances between energy density effects and relativistic behavior in these systems. The quark gluon plasma's properties are encoded in its final profiles, which exhibit magnitude and inhomogeneous structures.

A deep neural network is trained on initial conditions generated from 2+1-d relativistic hydrodynamics to predict these final profiles for various scenarios. This process involves intricate balances between energy density effects and relativistic behavior, allowing the network to capture the main features of the quark gluon plasma's non-linear evolution.

The results demonstrate that this technique can accelerate event-by-event simulations by capturing the magnitude and inhomogeneous structures of the final profiles, as well as related eccentricity distributions (n=2, 3, 4). This indicates a potential to largely accelerate these simulations.

title: The Blazar PG 1553+113 as a Binary System of Supermassive Black Holes
input: The BL Lac PG 1553+113 has been continuously monitored in gamma rays with Fermi-LAT for over 9 years. Its updated light curve now includes 5 iterations of a main pattern comprising a high peak and a longer trough, with a period P 2.2 yr. Our analysis of 2015-2017 data confirms the occurrence in January 2017 of a new peak fitting in the previous trend. In addition, we identify secondary peaks ("twin peaks") that occur in closely symmetric pairs on both sides of most main peaks, including the last one; their occurrence is supported by correlated X-ray outbursts. We stress that the above features strongly point to binary dynamics in a system of two black holes (BHs) of some 10^8 and 10^7 M_sun. At periastron the smaller BH periodically stresses the jet j_1 launched by the heavier companion, and triggers MHD-kinetic tearing instabilities. These lead to magnetic reconnections and to acceleration of electrons that produce synchrotron emission from the optical to X-ray bands, and inverse Compton scattering into the GeV range. For the origin of the twin peaks we discuss two possibilities: a single-jet model, based on added instabilities induced in j_1 by the smaller companion BH on its inner orbital arc; and a two-jet model with the smaller BH supporting its own, precessing jet j_2 that contributes lower, specific GeV emissions. Such behaviors combining time stability with amplitude variations betray plasma instabilities driven in either jet by binary dynamics, and can provide a double signature of the long-sought supermassive BH binaries.

output.explanation:
The universe contains supermassive black holes at the centers of galaxies, which can be in binary systems with other black holes.

A BL Lac object is an active galactic nucleus characterized by strong optical and radio emission; a black hole is a region of spacetime where gravity is so intense that not even light can escape; periastron refers to the point in an elliptical orbit when an object is closest to its companion.

The mechanism at play involves binary dynamics, where two celestial objects interact through gravitational forces. At periastron, the smaller black hole periodically stresses a jet launched by the heavier companion, triggering magnetic reconnections and electron acceleration. This process produces synchrotron emission across various bands and inverse Compton scattering into the GeV range.

The occurrence of twin peaks on both sides of most main peaks is attributed to either a single-jet model or a two-jet model, with the former involving added instabilities in j_1 by the smaller companion BH and the latter proposing that the smaller BH supports its own precessing jet contributing lower GeV emissions.
