title: Galactic Reddening in 3D from Stellar Photometry - An Improved Map
input: We present a new 3D map of interstellar dust reddening, covering three quarters of the sky (declinations greater than -30 degrees) out to a distance of several kiloparsecs. The map is based on high-quality stellar photometry of 800 million stars from Pan-STARRS 1 and 2MASS. We divide the sky into sightlines containing a few hundred stars each, and then infer stellar distances and types, along with the line-of-sight dust distribution. Our new map incorporates a more accurate average extinction law and an additional 1.5 years of Pan-STARRS 1 data, tracing dust to greater extinctions and at higher angular resolutions than our previous map. Out of the plane of the Galaxy, our map agrees well with 2D reddening maps derived from far-infrared dust emission. After accounting for a 15% difference in scale, we find a mean scatter of 10% between our map and the Planck far-infrared emission-based dust map, out to a depth of 0.8 mag in E(r-z), with the level of agreement varying over the sky. Our map can be downloaded at http://argonaut.skymaps.info, or by its DOI: 10.7910/DVN/LCYHJG.

output.explanation:
The interstellar medium is a vast, diffuse gas and dust component of the Galaxy that scatters and absorbs light from stars.

The 3D map of interstellar dust reddening provides a detailed picture of this phenomenon across three quarters of the sky. Key terms include extinction law, which describes how much light is absorbed or scattered by dust as it travels through space, and angular resolution, which refers to the level of detail in the map's depiction of the dust distribution.

The map's accuracy relies on high-quality stellar photometry from Pan-STARRS 1 and 2MASS surveys, allowing for precise inference of stellar distances, types, and line-of-sight dust distributions. The new map incorporates an improved average extinction law and additional data from Pan-STARRS 1, enabling the tracing of dust to greater extinctions at higher angular resolutions than its predecessor.

The agreement between this map and far-infrared emission-based maps is notable, particularly out of the plane of the Galaxy. After accounting for a scale difference, the mean scatter between the two types of maps is approximately 10% in terms of E(r-z) magnitude.

title: Another unWISE Update: The Deepest Ever Full-sky Maps at 3-5 microns
input: We have uniformly reprocessed ~140 terabytes of WISE and NEOWISE exposures to create the deepest ever full-sky maps at 3.4 microns (W1) and 4.6 microns (W2). Our coadds include ~4 years of observations and therefore feature ~4 times greater integer frame coverage than the AllWISE Atlas stacks. Our new, publicly available maps should find a wide range of applications, and in particular will enable the selection of luminous red galaxy and quasar targets for the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI).

output.explanation:
The universe is a vast expanse of interstellar gas and dust, emitting light at specific wavelengths due to thermal radiation.

A coadd refers to the process of merging multiple exposures into a single map. This technique allows for the creation of detailed maps by combining observations taken over time. In this context, coadds are used to generate full-sky maps at 3.4 microns (W1) and 4.6 microns (W2).

The term WISE refers to the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer satellite, which captures images of the sky in near-infrared wavelengths. NEOWISE is a follow-up mission that continues this work. The resulting maps are publicly available and feature greater depth and coverage than previous full-sky maps.

These new maps will enable researchers to select luminous red galaxy and quasar targets for further study using the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI). This selection of targets is crucial in understanding the properties of these celestial bodies, particularly those related to dark energy.

title: Experimental Confirmation of the Standard Magnetorotational Instability Mechanism with a Spring-Mass Analogue
input: The Magnetorotational Instability (MRI) has long been considered a plausibly ubiquitous mechanism to destabilize otherwise stable Keplerian flows to support radially outward transport of angular momentum. Such an efficient transport process would allow fast accretion in astrophysical objects such as stars and black holes to release copious kinetic energy that powers many of the most luminous sources in the universe. But the standard MRI under a purely vertical magnetic field has heretofore never been directly measured despite numerous efforts over more than a decade. Here we report an unambiguous laboratory demonstration of the spring-mass analogue to the standard MRI by comparing motion of a spring-tethered ball within different rotating flows. The experiment corroborates the theory: efficient outward angular momentum transport manifests only for cases with a weak spring in quasi-Keperian flow. Our experimental method accomplishes this in a new way, thereby connecting solid and fluid mechanics to plasma astrophysics.

output.explanation:
The universe is home to various astrophysical objects, including stars and black holes, which are sustained by the rapid accretion of material.

In this context, angular momentum plays a crucial role in these systems' dynamics. A key term here is Keplerian flow, referring to fluid rotation at different rates depending on its distance from the axis of rotation. Quasi-Keplerian flow is another concept, describing rotating fluids that exhibit behavior similar to Kepler's laws but with some deviations.

The Magnetorotational Instability (MRI) relies on magnetic fields destabilizing these otherwise stable flows. The efficiency of angular momentum transport depends on spring-like forces within the systems and their rotation rates. A weak spring in a quasi-Keplerian flow enables efficient outward transport, which is essential for rapid accretion.

The MRI's behavior can be understood through its interaction with magnetic fields and rotating fluids. In cases where a weak spring is present in quasi-Keplerian flow, the system exhibits efficient angular momentum transport, allowing for fast accretion.

title: On the observability of individual Population III stars and their stellar-mass black hole accretion disks through cluster caustic transits
input: We summarize panchromatic Extragalactic Background Light data to place upper limits on the integrated near-infrared surface brightness (SB) that may come from Population III stars and possible accretion disks around their stellar-mass black holes (BHs) in the epoch of First Light, broadly taken from z 7-17. Theoretical predictions and recent near-infrared power-spectra provide tighter constraints on their sky-signal. We outline the physical properties of zero metallicity Population III stars from MESA stellar evolution models through helium-depletion and of BH accretion disks at z 7. We assume that second-generation non-zero metallicity stars can form at higher multiplicity, so that BH accretion disks may be fed by Roche-lobe overflow from lower-mass companions. We use these near-infrared SB constraints to calculate the number of caustic transits behind lensing clusters that the James Webb Space Telescope and the next generation ground-based telescopes may observe for both Population III stars and their BH accretion disks. Typical caustic magnifications can be 10 -10 , with rise times of hours and decline times of 1 year for cluster transverse velocities of 1000 km s . Microlensing by intracluster medium objects can modify transit magnifications, but lengthen visibility times. Depending on BH masses, accretion-disk radii and feeding efficiencies, stellar-mass BH accretion-disk caustic transits could outnumber those from Population III stars. To observe Population III caustic transits directly may require to monitor 3-30 lensing clusters to AB 29 mag over a decade.

output.explanation:
The universe in its early stages is characterized by the formation of Population III stars, which are massive and short-lived objects that burn through their fuel quickly. These stars can collapse into stellar-mass black holes (BHs), leaving behind disks that continue to accrete material.

Population III stars have zero metallicity, meaning they do not contain elements forged in previous generations of star formation. This characteristic is reflected in the physical properties of these objects, including helium-depletion through MESA stellar evolution models. BH accretion disks at high redshifts also exhibit distinct features due to their environment.

The near-infrared surface brightness (SB) of Population III stars and BH accretion disks plays a crucial role in determining their observable effects on the sky-signal. Theoretical predictions suggest tighter constraints on this signal, which can be used to calculate the number of caustic transits behind lensing clusters.

Caustic magnifications can reach 10^-10 with rise times of hours and decline times of one year for cluster transverse velocities of 1000 km/s. Microlensing by intracluster medium objects modifies transit magnifications while lengthening visibility times, potentially leading to an increase in the number of stellar-mass BH accretion-disk caustic transits observed compared to Population III stars.

title: Indications of an unexpected signal associated with the GW170817 binary neutron star inspiral
input: We report experimental evidence at the 2.5 level for an unexpected signal associated with the GW170817 binary neutron star inspiral. This evidence derives from a laboratory experiment simultaneously measuring the -decay rates of Si-32 and Cl-36 in a common detector. Whereas the Si-32 and Cl-36 decay rates show no statistical correlation before or after the inspiral, they are highly correlated ( ) in the 5 hour time interval immediately following the inspiral. If we interpret this correlation as arising from the influence of particles emitted during the inspiral, then we can estimate the mass of these particles from the time delay between the gravity-wave signal and a peak in the -decay data. We find for particles of energy 10 MeV, 16 eV which includes the neutrino mass region 2 eV. The latter is based on existing limits for the masses of the three known neutrino flavors. Additionally, we find that the correlation is even stronger if we include data in the 80 minute period before the arrival of the gravity wave signal. Given the large number of radionuclides whose decays are being monitored at any given time, we conjecture that other groups may also be in a position to search for statistically suggestive fluctuations of radionuclide decay rates associated with the GW170817 inspiral, and possibly with other future inspirals.

output.explanation:
Gravitational waves from binary neutron star inspirals like GW170817 can interact with matter in extreme environments. 

The experiment measured the decay rates of two radioactive isotopes, Si-32 and Cl-36, which undergo beta-decay - a process where a neutron is converted into a proton, an electron, and an antineutrino. Beta-decay refers to this specific type of radioactive decay. The key concept here is that external influences can affect the decay rates. 

The experiment found an unexpected correlation between Si-32 and Cl-36's decay rates within 5 hours after the inspiral, suggesting particles from the event interacted with the detector. This interaction could be due to particles emitted during the inspiral affecting the beta-decay process. 

The mass of these particles can be estimated based on the time delay between the gravity-wave signal and a peak in the beta-decay data. The researchers found this value for 10 MeV energy particles, which includes the neutrino mass region constrained by existing limits.

title: Extreme Gravity Tests with Gravitational Waves from Compact Binary Coalescences: (II) Ringdown
input: The LIGO/Virgo detections of binary black hole mergers marked a watershed moment in astronomy, ushering in the era of precision tests of Kerr dynamics. We review theoretical and experimental challenges that must be overcome to carry out black hole spectroscopy with present and future gravitational wave detectors. Among other topics, we discuss quasinormal mode excitation in binary mergers, astrophysical event rates, tests of black hole dynamics in modified theories of gravity, parameterized "post-Kerr" ringdown tests, exotic compact objects, and proposed data analysis methods to improve spectroscopic tests of Kerr dynamics by stacking multiple events.

output.explanation:
The study of binary black hole mergers has led to a new era in astronomy, enabling precision tests of Kerr dynamics. Black holes are regions where gravity is so strong that not even light can escape. Quasinormal modes refer to the oscillations of gravitational waves as they decay after a merger. Astrophysical event rates determine how often such mergers occur. Modified theories of gravity propose alternative explanations for black hole behavior, which can be tested using observations of gravitational wave signals. 

 Key terms like quasinormal modes and modified theories require understanding the behavior of gravitational waves in different scenarios. Quasi-normal mode excitation is a process where these oscillations are excited due to interactions between merging objects. Modified gravity theories propose alternative explanations for black hole dynamics, which can be tested using observations of gravitational wave signals. 

 In binary mergers, quasinormal modes interact with factors like astrophysical event rates and modified gravity theories. The ringdown phase is particularly important for testing Kerr dynamics as any deviations would manifest during this stage. This process relies on the interaction between merging objects and their environment. 

 By stacking multiple events, researchers can improve spectroscopic tests of Kerr dynamics by combining data from different mergers to increase sensitivity and accuracy.

title: The origin of diverse -element abundances in galaxy discs
input: Spectroscopic surveys of the Galaxy reveal that its disc stars exhibit a spread in at fixed , manifest at some locations as a bimodality. The origin of these diverse, and possibly distinct, stellar populations in the Galactic disc is not well understood. We examine the Fe and -element evolution of 133 Milky Way-like galaxies from the EAGLE simulation, to investigate the origin and diversity of their - distributions. We find that bimodal distributions arise in galaxies whose gas accretion histories exhibit episodes of significant infall at both early and late times, with the former fostering more intense star formation than the latter. The shorter characteristic consumption timescale of gas accreted in the earlier episode suppresses its enrichment with iron synthesised by Type Ia SNe, resulting in the formation of a high- sequence. We find that bimodality in similar to that seen in the Galaxy is rare, appearing in approximately 5 percent of galaxies in our sample. We posit that this is a consequence of an early gas accretion episode requiring the mass accretion history of a galaxy's dark matter halo to exhibit a phase of atypically-rapid growth at early epochs. The scarcity of EAGLE galaxies exhibiting distinct sequences in the - plane may therefore indicate that the Milky Way's elemental abundance patterns, and its accretion history, are not representative of the broader population of disc galaxies.

output.explanation:
The Galaxy's disc stars reside within a vast, rotating disk of stars and gas that makes up the Milky Way galaxy. The process of star formation is influenced by various factors, including the availability of gas and the rate at which it is consumed.

Gas accretion history refers to how gas is drawn into a galaxy, while Type Ia SNe are supernovae that synthesize iron through explosive nucleosynthesis. Characteristic consumption timescale is the time it takes for gas to be consumed by star formation, and elemental abundance patterns describe the distribution of chemical elements within stars.

In galaxies with bimodal distributions, significant infall of gas occurs at both early and late times. The earlier episode fosters more intense star formation than the latter due to differences in characteristic consumption timescales. This leads to a suppression of iron enrichment in the shorter timescale, resulting in the formation of high- sequences.

Bimodality similar to that seen in the Galaxy is rare, appearing in only a small fraction of galaxies with distinct sequences in the - plane.

title: Abell 1367: a high fraction of late-type galaxies displaying HI morphological and kinematic perturbations
input: To investigate the effects the cluster environment has on Late-Type Galaxies (LTGs) we studied HI perturbation signatures for all Abell 1367 LTGs with HI detections. We used new VLA HI observations combined with AGES single dish blind survey data. Our study indicates that the asymmetry between the high-and low-velocity wings of the characteristic double-horn integrated HI spectrum as measured by the asymmetry parameter, Aflux, can be a useful diagnostic for ongoing and/or recent HI stripping. 26% of A1367 LTGs have an Aflux ratio, more asymmetrical than 3 times the 1σ spread in the Aflux ratio distribution of an undisturbed sample of isolated galaxies (2%) and samples from other denser environments (10% to 20%). Over half of the A 1367 LTGs, which are members of groups or pairs, have an Aflux ratio larger than twice the 1 σ spread found in the isolated sample. This suggests inter-group/pair interactions could be making a significant contribution to the LTGs displaying such Aflux ratios. The study also demonstrates that the definition of the HI offset from the optical centre of LTGs is resolution dependent, suggesting that unresolved AGES HI offsets that are significantly larger than the pointing uncertainties (> 2 σ) reflect interactions which have asymmetrically displaced significant masses of lower density HI, while having minimal impact on the location of the highest density HI in resolved maps. The distribution of Aflux from a comparable sample of Virgo galaxies provides a clear indication that the frequency of HI profile perturbations is lower than in A 1367.

output.explanation:
Galaxies in dense clusters like Abell 1367 reside within a complex gravitational environment, where numerous interactions shape their structure and evolution. The HI perturbation signatures studied here refer to the characteristic double-horn integrated HI spectrum, which is crucial for understanding gas dynamics.

The asymmetry parameter Aflux quantifies this phenomenon by measuring the difference between high- and low-velocity wings of the spectrum. In Abell 1367, approximately one-quarter of Late-Type Galaxies (LTGs) exhibit an Aflux ratio more extreme than in isolated galaxies or those from other denser environments.

The mechanism behind these asymmetries involves gravitational interactions within groups or pairs, which can displace lower-density gas while leaving higher-density regions intact. This displacement is resolution-dependent and affects the definition of HI offset from optical centers.

In Abell 1367, over half of LTGs display Aflux ratios larger than twice the spread found in isolated samples, suggesting inter-group interactions significantly contribute to these asymmetries. In contrast, a comparable sample of Virgo galaxies shows a lower frequency of HI profile perturbations.

title: Disc-Halo Interactions in ΛCDM
input: We present a new method for embedding a stellar disc in a cosmological dark matter halo and provide a worked example from a ΛCDM zoom-in simulation. The disc is inserted into the halo at a redshift z = 3 as a zero-mass rigid body. Its mass and size are then increased adiabatically while its position, velocity, and orientation are determined from rigid-body dynamics. At z = 1, the rigid disc is replaced by an N-body disc whose particles sample a three-integral distribution function (DF). The simulation then proceeds to z = 0 with live disc and halo particles. By comparison, other methods assume one or more of the following: the centre of the rigid disc during the growth phase is pinned to the minimum of the halo potential, the orientation of the rigid disc is fixed, or the live N-body disc is constructed from a two rather than three-integral DF. In general, the presence of a disc makes the halo rounder, more centrally concentrated, and smoother, especially in the innermost regions. We find that methods in which the disc is pinned to the minimum of the halo potential tend to overestimate the amount of adiabatic contraction. Additionally, the effect of the disc on the subhalo distribution appears to be rather insensitive to the disc insertion method. The live disc in our simulation develops a bar that is consistent with the bars seen in late-type spiral galaxies. In addition, particles from the disc are launched or "kicked up" to high galactic latitudes.

output.explanation:
Galaxies reside within vast dark matter halos, influencing their growth and evolution.

A key concept in this context is the three-integral distribution function (DF), which describes the distribution of stars within a disc by considering not only energy but also two additional integrals.

The process of embedding a stellar disc into its surrounding halo involves complex interactions between rigid-body dynamics, adiabatic growth, and N-body simulations. The rigid disc is initially inserted as a zero-mass body at redshift z = 3, with its mass and size increased while maintaining position, velocity, and orientation.

The presence of the stellar disc can significantly impact the halo's shape and density profile, making it rounder and more centrally concentrated in its innermost regions. However, methods that pin the rigid disc to the minimum of the halo potential tend to overestimate adiabatic contraction.

title: An Investigation of the Ranges of Validity of Asteroid Thermal Models for Near-Earth Asteroid Observations
input: The majority of known asteroid diameters are derived from thermal-infrared observations. Diameters are derived using asteroid thermal models that approximate their surface temperature distributions and compare the measured thermal-infrared flux with model-dependent predictions. The most commonly used thermal model is the Near-Earth Asteroid Thermal Model (NEATM), which is usually perceived as superior to other models like the Fast-Rotating Model (FRM). We investigate the applicability of the NEATM and the FRM to thermal-infrared observations of Near-Earth Objects using synthetic asteroids with properties based on the real Near-Earth Asteroid (NEA) population. We find the NEATM to provide more accurate diameters and albedos than the FRM in most cases, with a few exceptions. The modeling results are barely affected by the physical properties of the objects, but we find a large impact of the solar phase angle on the modeling results. We conclude that the NEATM provides statistically more robust diameter estimates for NEAs observed at solar phase angles less than ~65°, while the FRM provides more robust diameter estimates for solar phase angles greater than ~65°. We estimate that <5% of all NEA diameters and albedos derived up to date are affected by systematic effects that are of the same order of magnitude as the typical thermal model uncertainties. We provide statistical correction functions for diameters and albedos derived using the NEATM and FRM as a function of solar phase angle.

output.explanation:
The solar system's asteroid belt is a region where numerous Near-Earth Objects (NEOs) reside, periodically approaching our planet. Thermal-infrared observations are used to estimate their diameters by measuring the heat emitted from their surfaces and comparing these measurements with model predictions.

The thermal models employed in this process rely on approximations about an asteroid's surface temperature distribution. Key terms like albedo refer to the measure of how much sunlight is reflected off an object's surface, while thermal-infrared flux pertains to the amount of heat emitted by a surface within a specific wavelength range.

The accuracy of these models depends on their ability to account for factors influencing asteroid temperatures, such as solar phase angle - the angle between the Sun, the observer, and the asteroid. This angle plays a crucial role in determining the effectiveness of thermal-infrared observations.

The Near-Earth Asteroid Thermal Model (NEATM) is found to provide more accurate diameter estimates than the Fast-Rotating Model (FRM), particularly when observing NEOs at solar phase angles less than 65°, while the FRM provides more robust results for angles greater than 65°.

title: Phase-transition sound of inflation at gravitational waves detectors
input: It is well-known that the first-order phase transition (PT) will yield a stochastic gravitational waves (GWs) background with a logo-like spectrum. However, we show that when such a PT happened during the primordial inflation, the GWs spectrum brought by the PT will be reddened, which thus records the unique voiceprint of inflation. We assess the abilities of the GW detectors to detect the corresponding signal.

output.explanation:
The universe's early stages are characterized by rapid expansion and the emergence of distinct signatures in its gravitational waves background. A first-order phase transition is a critical phenomenon where matter undergoes a sudden change, producing stochastic GWs with specific properties.

In this context, key terms such as 'primordial inflation' refer to an era of accelerated growth, while 'first-order phase transition' describes the abrupt transformation of matter. Additionally, 'stochastic gravitational waves' are ripples in space-time that carry information about the universe's evolution.

When a first-order PT occurs within an inflating universe, it interacts with the expanding space-time, leading to redshift and alteration of the GWs spectral shape. This unique signature records the voiceprint of inflation, making it a valuable tool for understanding this early era.

The resulting GWs spectrum brought by the PT will be reddened due to the expansion, which can potentially be detected by future GW detectors.

title: The nuclear activity and central structure of the elliptical galaxy NGC 5322
input: We have analysed a new high-resolution e-MERLIN 1.5 GHz radio continuum map together with and SDSS imaging of NGC 5322, an elliptical galaxy hosting radio jets, aiming to understand the galaxy's central structure and its connection to the nuclear activity. We decomposed the composite + SDSS surface brightness profile of the galaxy into an inner stellar disc, a spheroid, and an outer stellar halo. Past works showed that this embedded disc counter-rotates rapidly with respect to the spheroid. The images reveal an edge-on nuclear dust disc across the centre, aligned along the major-axis of the galaxy and nearly perpendicular to the radio jets. After careful masking of this dust disc, we find a central stellar mass deficit in the spheroid, scoured by SMBH binaries with final mass such that . We propose a three-phase formation scenario for NGC 5322 where a few ( ) "dry" major mergers involving SMBHs built the spheroid with a depleted core. The cannibalism of a gas-rich satellite subsequently creates the faint counter-rotating disc and funnels gaseous material directly onto the AGN, powering the radio core with a brightness temperature of K and the low-power radio jets ( W Hz ) which extend kpc. The outer halo can later grow via minor mergers and the accretion of tidal debris. The low-luminosity AGN/jet-driven feedback may have quenched the late-time nuclear star formation promptly, which could otherwise have replenished the depleted core.

output.explanation:
Galaxies like NGC 5322 reside in vast, star-filled expanses of space.

Key terms include **spheroid**, the central region composed primarily of older stars, and **supermassive black hole (SMBH)**, an extremely massive black hole at a galaxy's centre. The presence of SMBH binaries with masses such that  indicates a central stellar mass deficit within the spheroid.

The processes described interact through mergers between galaxies, supermassive black holes, and star formation. In this scenario, dry major mergers involving SMBHs build the spheroid with a depleted core. The cannibalism of a gas-rich satellite then creates the counter-rotating disc and funnels gaseous material onto the AGN (active galactic nucleus), powering the radio core.

The system exhibits a central stellar mass deficit, scoured by SMBH binaries. Low-luminosity feedback from the AGN may have quenched late-time nuclear star formation.

title: A Conception of Engineering Design for Remote Unattended Operation Public Observatory
input: Public observatory project is playing more and more important role in science popularization education and scientific research, and many amateur astronomers also have began to build their own observatories in remote areas. As a result of the limitation of technical condition and construction funds for amateur astronomers, their system often breaks down, and then a stable remote unattended operation system becomes very critical. Hardware connection and control is the basic and core part in observatory design. Here we propose a conception of engineering hardware design for public observatory operation as a bridge between observatory equipment and observation software. It can not only satisfy multiple observation mode requirement, but also save cost.

output.explanation:
Astronomical observatories are increasingly being used for science education and research, with amateur astronomers building their own remote facilities. However, these systems often malfunction due to limited technical expertise and funding. A stable unattended operation system is therefore crucial for maintaining functionality.

The term 'observatory equipment' refers to the hardware components necessary for astronomical observations, such as telescopes and cameras. In contrast, 'observation software' encompasses the programming tools used to control and analyze data from these instruments.

In designing a public observatory's engineering hardware, it is essential to bridge the gap between this equipment and software. This involves creating an interface that allows users to seamlessly interact with their systems, enabling multiple observation modes while minimizing costs.

A stable remote unattended operation system can be achieved by implementing robust hardware connection and control mechanisms. These ensure that observatory equipment functions correctly even in areas with limited technical expertise and funding.

title: High-resolution imaging and near-infrared spectroscopy of penumbral decay
input: Combining high-resolution spectropolarimetric and imaging data is key to understanding the decay process of sunspots as it allows us scrutinizing the velocity and magnetic fields of sunspots and their surroundings. Active region NOAA 12597 was observed on 24/09/2016 with the 1.5-m GREGOR solar telescope using high-spatial resolution imaging as well as imaging spectroscopy and near-infrared (NIR) spectropolarimetry. Horizontal proper motions were estimated with LCT, whereas LOS velocities were computed with spectral line fitting methods. The magnetic field properties were inferred with the SIR code for the Si I and Ca I NIR lines. At the time of the GREGOR observations, the leading sunspot had two light-bridges indicating the onset of its decay. One of the light-bridges disappeared, and an elongated, dark umbral core at its edge appeared in a decaying penumbral sector facing the newly emerging flux. The flow and magnetic field properties of this penumbral sector exhibited weak Evershed flow, moat flow, and horizontal magnetic field. The penumbral gap adjacent to the elongated umbral core and the penumbra in that penumbral sector displayed LOS velocities similar to granulation. The separating polarities of a new flux system interacted with the leading and central part of the already established active region. As a consequence, the leading spot rotated 55-degree in clockwise direction over 12 hours. In the high-resolution observations of a decaying sunspot, the penumbral filaments facing flux emergence site contained a darkened area resembling an umbral core filled with umbral dots. This umbral core had velocity and magnetic field properties similar to the sunspot umbra. This implies that the horizontal magnetic fields in the decaying penumbra became vertical as observed in flare-induced rapid penumbral decay, but on a very different time-scale.

output.explanation:
The sun's surface is a dynamic system where intense magnetic activity and convective motions interact.

Key terms in this context include umbral cores, penumbrae, Evershed flow, moat flow, and LOS velocities. An umbral core is a dark region with strong magnetic fields, while a penumbra is the lighter outer layer with weaker magnetic fields. Evershed flow refers to outward plasma motion in the penumbra.

The interaction between emerging flux and established active regions can lead to changes in sunspot morphology. In this system, the decay process involves the weakening of horizontal magnetic fields, which become vertical as observed in flare-induced rapid penumbral decay but on a different time-scale. This is evident from the appearance of an elongated dark umbral core at the edge of the leading sunspot.

The flow and magnetic field properties of the decaying penumbral sector exhibited weak Evershed flow, moat flow, and horizontal magnetic fields. The separating polarities of a new flux system interacted with the established active region, causing the leading spot to rotate 55 degrees in clockwise direction over 12 hours.

title: Galaxy Formation in Sterile Neutrino Dark Matter Models
input: We investigate galaxy formation in models with dark matter (DM) constituted by sterile neutrinos. Given their large parameter space, defined by the combinations of sterile neutrino mass and mixing parameter with active neutrinos, we focus on models with keV, consistent with the tentative 3.5 keV line detected in several X-ray spectra of clusters and galaxies. We consider i) two resonant production models with and , to cover the range of mixing parameter consistent with the 3.5 keV line; ii) two scalar-decay models, representative of the two possible cases characterizing such a scenario: a freeze-in and a freeze-out case. We also consider thermal Warm Dark Matter with particle mass keV. Using a semi-analytic model, we compare the predictions for the different DM scenarios with a wide set of observables. We find that comparing the predicted evolution of the stellar mass function, the abundance of satellites of Milky Way-like galaxies, and the global star formation history of galaxies with observations does not allow to disentangle the effects of the baryonic physics from those related to the different DM models. On the other hand, the distribution of the stellar-to-halo mass ratios, the abundance of faint galaxies in the UV luminosity function at , and the specific star formation and age distribution of local, low-mass galaxies constitute potential probes for the considered DM scenarios. We discuss how next observations with upcoming facilities will enable to rule out or to strongly support DM models based on sterile neutrinos.

output.explanation:
Galaxies reside within vast cosmic structures, governed by gravity and the evolution of matter and energy. Dark matter (DM) is a crucial component in shaping galaxy morphology.

Dark matter can be constituted by sterile neutrinos, hypothetical particles with mass and mixing parameter with active neutrinos. The keV mass range is particularly intriguing due to its potential connection to the 3.5 keV line detected in X-ray spectra of clusters and galaxies. Key terms include 'sterile neutrinos,' which are DM candidates; 'resonant production models,' where sterile neutrino masses arise from resonant interactions with active neutrinos; and 'scalar-decay models,' describing scenarios in which scalar fields decay into sterile neutrinos.

In these models, the processes of galaxy formation interact through complex mechanisms. The semi-analytic model employed compares predictions against diverse observables to investigate DM scenarios based on sterile neutrinos.

The distribution of stellar-to-halo mass ratios and specific star formation distributions of local low-mass galaxies are identified as potential probes for distinguishing between different DM models, including those with keV particle masses. The abundance of faint galaxies at UV luminosity function  constitutes another probe for these scenarios.

title: Extensive broadband X-ray monitoring during the formation of a giant radio jet base in Cyg X-3 with AstroSat
input: We present X-ray spectral and timing behavior of Cyg X-3 as observed by AstroSat during the onset of a giant radio flare on 01-02 April 2017. Within a time-scale of few hours, the source shows a transition from the hypersoft state (HPS) to a more luminous state (we termed as the very high state) which coincides with the time of the steep rise in radio flux density by an order of magnitude. Modeling the SXT and LAXPC spectra jointly in 0.5-70.0 keV, we found that the first few hours of the observation is dominated by the HPS with no significant counts above 17 keV. Later, an additional flat powerlaw component suddenly appeared in the spectra which extends to very high energies with the powerlaw photon index of 1.49 +/- 0.04. Such a flat powerlaw component has never been reported from Cyg X-3. Interestingly the fitted powerlaw model in 25-70 keV, when extrapolated to the radio frequency, predicts the radio flux density consistent with the trend measured from RATAN-600 telescope at 11.2 GHz. This provides a direct evidence of the synchrotron origin of flat X-ray powerlaw component and the most extensive monitoring of the broadband X-ray behavior at the moment of decoupling the giant radio jet base from the compact object in Cyg X-3. Using SXT and LAXPC observations, we determine the giant flare ejection time as MJD 57845.34 +/- 0.08 when 11.2 GHz radio flux density increases from ~100 to ~478 mJy.

output.explanation:
The intense activity of Cyg X-3 is set against the backdrop of a binary system, where a compact object orbits a massive star. The source's behavior during this period is characterized by a transition from the hypersoft state (HPS) to a more luminous very high state, coinciding with a steep rise in radio flux density.

The HPS is marked by a lack of significant counts above 17 keV, while the very high state introduces an additional flat powerlaw component extending to high energies with a photon index of 1.49 +/- 0.04. This component has never been observed from Cyg X-3 before and suggests the presence of synchrotron radiation.

The fitted powerlaw model in 25-70 keV, when extrapolated to radio frequencies, predicts a consistent trend with measurements at 11.2 GHz by RATAN-600 telescope. This provides direct evidence for the synchrotron origin of the flat X-ray powerlaw component and allows for monitoring of broadband X-ray behavior during the decoupling of the giant radio jet base from the compact object in Cyg X-3.

The ejection time of the giant flare is determined to be MJD 57845.34 +/- 0.08, corresponding to a significant increase in 11.2 GHz radio flux density from ~100 to ~478 mJy.

title: Galaxy And Mass Assembly (GAMA): The effect of galaxy group environment on active galactic nuclei
input: In galaxy clusters, efficiently accreting active galactic nuclei (AGN) are preferentially located in the infall regions of the cluster projected phase-space, and are rarely found in the cluster core. This has been attributed to both an increase in triggering opportunities for infalling galaxies, and a reduction of those mechanisms in the hot, virialised, cluster core. Exploiting the depth and completeness ( per cent at mag) of the Galaxy And Mass Assembly survey (GAMA), we probe down the group halo mass function to assess whether AGN are found in the same regions in groups as they are in clusters. We select 451 optical AGN from 7498 galaxies with in 695 groups with at . By analysing the projected phase-space positions of these galaxies we demonstrate that when split both radially, and into physically derived infalling and core populations, AGN position within group projected phase-space is dependent on halo mass. For groups with , AGN are preferentially found in the infalling galaxy population with confidence. At lower halo masses we observe no difference in AGN fraction between core and infalling galaxies. These observations support a model where a reduced number of low-speed interactions, ram pressure stripping and intra-group/cluster medium temperature, the dominance of which increase with halo mass, work to inhibit AGN in the cores of groups and clusters with , but do not significantly affect nuclear activity in cores of less massive structures.

output.explanation:
Galaxy clusters are vast, gravitationally bound systems comprising numerous galaxies and hot gas.

The term 'virialised' refers to the state of thermal equilibrium in clusters, where the virial temperature is reached. Ram pressure stripping is a mechanism where galaxies are stripped of gas as they move through hot cluster medium.

Infall regions offer increased triggering opportunities for active galactic nuclei (AGN) due to higher collision rates. Conversely, reduced low-speed interactions and ram pressure stripping at higher halo masses inhibit AGN activity in cluster cores. This suppression is thought to be caused by the dominance of intra-group/cluster medium temperature increasing with halo mass.

In galaxy groups with high halo masses, AGN are preferentially found in infalling galaxies, whereas no difference in AGN fraction between core and infalling galaxies is observed at lower halo masses.

title: QUBIC - The Q&U Bolometric Interferometer for Cosmology - A novel way to look at the polarized Cosmic Microwave Background
input: In this paper we describe QUBIC, an experiment that takes up the challenge posed by the detection of primordial gravitational waves with a novel approach, that combines the sensitivity of state-of-the art bolometric detectors with the systematic effects control typical of interferometers. The so-called "self-calibration" is a technique deeply rooted in the interferometric nature of the instrument and allows us to clean the measured data from instrumental effects. The first module of QUBIC is a dual band instrument (150 GHz and 220 GHz) that will be deployed in Argentina during the Fall 2018.

output.explanation:
The universe's early moments are characterized by the presence of gravitational waves, ripples in spacetime that carry information about cosmic events. QUBIC is an experiment designed to detect these primordial signals using a unique approach.

Bolometers and interferometers are two types of instruments used for precise measurements: bolometers measure temperature changes with high sensitivity, while interferometers use interference patterns created by light waves to make accurate readings. Self-calibration is a technique that leverages the instrument's own properties to correct data from instrumental effects in real-time.

The self-calibration process relies on the principles of interferometry and the inherent characteristics of QUBIC's design. By using its own properties, the instrument can remove systematic errors from measurements, allowing for cleaner data collection. This technique is deeply rooted in the nature of interferometric instruments.

QUBIC will operate at two frequency bands: 150 GHz and 220 GHz. The experiment aims to detect primordial gravitational waves by combining the sensitivity of bolometric detectors with the systematic effects control typical of interferometers.

title: Constraining gravity at large scales with the 2MASS Photometric Redshift catalogue and Planck lensing
input: We present a new measurement of structure growth at obtained by correlating the cosmic microwave background (CMB) lensing potential map from the satellite with the angular distribution of the 2MASS Photometric Redshift galaxies. After testing for, and finding no evidence for systematic effects, we calculate the angular auto- and cross-power spectra. We combine these spectra to estimate the amplitude of structure growth using the bias-independent estimator introduced by Giannantonio et al. 2016. We find that the relative amplitude of with respect to the predictions based on cosmology is , fully consistent with the expectations for the standard cosmological model. Considering statistical errors only, we forecast that a joint analysis between an LSST-like photometric galaxy sample and lensing maps from upcoming ground-based CMB surveys like the Simons Observatory and CMB-S4 can yield sub-percent constraints on the growth history and differentiate between different models of cosmic acceleration.

output.explanation:
The universe's large-scale structure is shaped by the gravitational attraction between matter clumps, a phenomenon known as structure growth. The cosmic microwave background (CMB) lensing potential map encodes information about mass distribution in the universe, allowing researchers to study this process without relying on galaxy bias.

Key terms include 'cosmic microwave background' (CMB), referring to residual heat from the Big Bang, and 'structure growth', describing how matter clumps together under gravity. The CMB is a remnant of the early universe's thermal history, while structure growth is driven by gravitational forces between massive objects.

The process involves correlating the CMB lensing potential map with the angular distribution of galaxies from 2MASS Photometric Redshift catalog to estimate the amplitude of structure growth. This requires calculating angular auto- and cross-power spectra, which are then combined using a bias-independent estimator introduced by Giannantonio et al.

The relative amplitude of this effect is found to be consistent with predictions based on standard cosmology, indicating that the universe's expansion history aligns with expectations. Considering statistical errors only, future surveys like LSST and ground-based CMB experiments can yield sub-percent constraints on the growth history and differentiate between different models of cosmic acceleration.

title: The Use of Color Sensors for Spectrographic Calibration
input: The wavelength calibration of spectrographs is an essential but challenging task in many disciplines. Calibration is traditionally accomplished by imaging the spectrum of a light source containing features that are known to appear at certain wavelengths and mapping them to their location on the sensor. This is typically required in conjunction with each scientific observation to account for mechanical and optical variations of the instrument over time, which may span years for certain projects. The method presented here investigates the usage of color itself instead of spectral features to calibrate a spectrograph. The primary advantage of such a calibration is that any broad-spectrum light source such as the sky or an incandescent bulb is suitable. This method allows for calibration using the full optical pathway of the instrument instead of incorporating separate calibration equipment that may introduce errors. This paper focuses on the potential for color calibration in the field of radial velocity astronomy, in which instruments must be finely calibrated for long periods of time to detect tiny Doppler wavelength shifts. This method is not restricted to radial velocity, however, and may find application in any field requiring calibrated spectrometers such as sea water analysis, cellular biology, chemistry, atmospheric studies, and so on. This paper demonstrates that color sensors have the potential to provide calibration with greatly reduced complexity.

output.explanation:
The physical setting for wavelength calibration involves the interaction between light sources and spectrographic instruments, which are used to analyze the spectrum of celestial objects in various fields such as astronomy and atmospheric studies.

Spectral features refer to specific wavelengths that appear in a light source's spectrum, while color sensors measure the overall color or hue of the light. Color is defined by its wavelength composition, with different colors corresponding to distinct ranges of wavelengths.

Color calibration relies on the principle that any broad-spectrum light source can be used as a reference for calibrating spectrographic instruments. This method leverages the full optical pathway of the instrument, eliminating the need for separate calibration equipment that may introduce errors. The interaction between color sensors and spectrographs enables accurate wavelength measurement.

Color calibration has the potential to provide simplified calibration in various fields such as radial velocity astronomy, sea water analysis, cellular biology, chemistry, and atmospheric studies. This method can be used with broad-spectrum light sources like the sky or an incandescent bulb, offering a convenient alternative to traditional spectral feature-based calibration.

title: Decaying Massive Particle in Matter and Radiation Dominated Eras
input: According to the standard model of cosmology, the early universe has been dominated by radiation or non-relativistic matter in several eras of its history. However, many cosmological calculations involving particle processes are commonly done using Minkowskian results for them, although, for more precise treatment, quantum field theory in curved spacetime is needed. This paper aims to fill this gap by presenting decay rates for matter and radiation dominated universes in this more precise treatment. We provide a study of the average decay rates for a process where a conformally coupled massive scalar field decays into massless scalar particles. It is found that the presence of a curved spacetime modifies the Minkowskian result considerably for early times but asymptotically only by an additive term proportional to the inverse of mass and interaction time. Thus, the correction is small for large time scales, but on the time scales of the order of , the relative correction term may be of importance.

output.explanation:
The universe's evolution is shaped by periods of radiation and non-relativistic matter dominance, as dictated by the standard model of cosmology.

In this context, it's crucial to understand key terms like conformal coupling: a property where a field's behavior remains unchanged under certain transformations. Additionally, Minkowskian results refer to calculations performed in flat spacetime, while quantum field theory in curved spacetime accounts for the universe's dynamic geometry.

The interaction between these concepts is rooted in the decay of a massive scalar field into massless particles. In this process, the presence of curvature significantly alters the expected outcome at early times but introduces only a minor correction proportional to the inverse of mass and interaction time over large scales. This subtle modification becomes more pronounced on shorter timescales.

The study reveals that for matter- or radiation-dominated universes, the decay rates are affected by the curved spacetime's influence, leading to distinct outcomes compared to Minkowskian results.

title: ALMA Dust Polarization Observations of Two Young Edge-on Protostellar Disks
input: Polarized emission is detected in two young nearly edge-on protostellar disks in 343 GHz continuum at ~ 50 au (~ 0.12") resolution with Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array. One disk is in HH 212 (Class 0) and the other in HH 111 (early Class I) protostellar system. Polarization fraction is ~ 1%. The disk in HH 212 has a radius of ~ 60 au. The emission is mainly detected from the nearside of the disk. The polarization orientations are almost perpendicular to the disk major axis, consistent with either self-scattering or emission by grains aligned with a poloidal field around the outer edge of the disk because of optical depth effect and temperature gradient; the presence of a poloidal field would facilitate the launching of a disk wind, for which there is already tentative evidence in the same source. The disk of HH 111 VLA 1 has a larger radius of ~ 220 au and is thus more resolved. The polarization orientations are almost perpendicular to the disk major axis in the nearside, but more along the major axis in the farside, forming roughly half of an elliptical pattern there. It appears that toroidal and poloidal magnetic field may explain the polarization on the near and far side of the disk, respectively. However, it is also possible that the polarization is due to self-scattering. In addition, alignment of dust grains by radiation flux may play a role in the farside. Our observations reveal a diversity of disk polarization patterns that should be taken into account in future modeling efforts.

output.explanation:
Protostellar disks are regions in space where star formation occurs, and they can be nearly edge-on, allowing for observations of polarized emission at high resolution.

Polarization fraction refers to the degree to which light vibrates in a particular plane as it travels through space. In this context, polarization is often caused by scattering or alignment of dust grains with magnetic fields. The term 'optical depth effect' describes how the amount of material along a line of sight affects the observed radiation.

The interaction between polarized emission and disk structure can be understood in terms of self-scattering, where light scatters off particles within the disk, or by alignment of dust grains with magnetic fields. The presence of poloidal and toroidal magnetic fields may explain different polarization patterns on opposite sides of a disk.

Polarization orientations are almost perpendicular to the major axis of each disk on one side but follow an elliptical pattern on the other. This suggests that both self-scattering and alignment of dust grains by radiation flux could contribute to these patterns, particularly in regions with varying magnetic field strengths.

title: A method for determining the radius of an open cluster from stellar proper motions
input: We propose a method for calculating the radius of an open cluster in an objective way from an astrometric catalogue containing, at least, positions and proper motions. It uses the minimum spanning tree (hereinafter MST) in the proper motion space to discriminate cluster stars from field stars and it quantifies the strength of the cluster-field separation by means of a statistical parameter defined for the first time in this paper. This is done for a range of different sampling radii from where the cluster radius is obtained as the size at which the best cluster-field separation is achieved. The novelty of this strategy is that the cluster radius is obtained independently of how its stars are spatially distributed. We test the reliability and robustness of the method with both simulated and real data from a well-studied open cluster (NGC 188), and apply it to UCAC4 data for five other open clusters with different catalogued radius values. NGC 188, NGC 1647, NGC 6603 and Ruprecht 155 yielded unambiguous radius values of 15.2+/-1.8, 29.4+/-3.4, 4.2+/-1.7 and 7.0+/-0.3 arcmin, respectively. ASCC 19 and Collinder 471 showed more than one possible solution but it is not possible to know whether this is due to the involved uncertainties or to the presence of complex patterns in their proper motion distributions, something that could be inherent to the physical object or due to the way in which the catalogue was sampled.

output.explanation:
The galaxy contains open clusters, which are gravitationally bound groups of stars with distinct spatial distributions and proper motion patterns.

A key concept in understanding these systems is the minimum spanning tree, a network that connects points in space through the shortest possible path. Proper motion space refers to the analysis of an object's movement over time.

The method uses the MST as a tool for distinguishing between cluster stars and field stars by identifying clusters with strong proper motion correlations. A statistical parameter quantifies this separation, allowing researchers to determine the optimal sampling radius at which the best distinction between cluster and field stars occurs.

This approach provides an objective way of calculating the radius of an open cluster independently of its spatial distribution. The method is tested using simulated data and real observations from various clusters with different catalogued radii, yielding unambiguous radius values for some while others show multiple possible solutions due to uncertainties or complex patterns in their proper motion distributions.

title: Venus upper clouds and the UV-absorber from MESSENGER/MASCS observations
input: One of the most intriguing, long-standing questions regarding Venus' atmosphere is the origin and distribution of the unknown UV-absorber, responsible for the absorption band detected at the near-UV and blue range of Venus' spectrum. In this work, we use data collected by MASCS spectrograph on board the MESSENGER mission during its second Venus flyby in June 2007 to address this issue. Spectra range from 0.3 μm to 1.5 μm including some gaseous H2O and CO2 bands, as well as part of the SO2 absorption band and the core of the UV absorption. We used the NEMESIS radiative transfer code and retrieval suite to investigate the vertical distribution of particles in the Equatorial atmosphere and to retrieve the imaginary refractive indices of the UV-absorber, assumed to be well mixed with Venus' small mode-1 particles. The results show an homogeneous Equatorial atmosphere, with cloud tops (height for unity optical depth) at 75+/-2 km above surface. The UV absorption is found to be centered at 0.34+/-0.03 μm with a full width half maximum of 0.14+/-0.01 μm. Our values are compared with previous candidates for the UV aerosol absorber, among which disulfur oxide (S2O) and dioxide disulfur (S2O2) provide the best agreement with our results.

output.explanation:
The Venusian atmosphere is a vast, gaseous envelope surrounding the planet, primarily composed of carbon dioxide and sulfuric acid droplets. Key terms in this context include 'mode-1 particles', which refer to small aerosol particles well-mixed throughout the Equatorial region, and 'imaginary refractive indices', which describe the optical properties of these particles.

The interaction between UV radiation and atmospheric particles is a critical aspect of Venus' atmosphere. The presence of mode-1 particles influences the absorption or transmission of light at different wavelengths, affecting the overall behavior of the system.

In this scenario, the vertical distribution of particles in the Equatorial atmosphere plays a crucial role. The cloud tops, defined as the height for unity optical depth, are found to be approximately 75 km above the surface. This homogeneous atmosphere is characterized by an unknown UV-absorber responsible for the absorption band detected at near-UV and blue wavelengths.

The results indicate that this UV absorption is centered at a wavelength of 0.34 μm with a full width half maximum of 0.14 μm, showing agreement with previous candidates such as disulfur oxide (S2O) and dioxide disulfur (S2O2).

title: Reverberation Mapping of High-z, High-luminosity Quasars
input: We present Reverberation Mapping results after monitoring a sample of 17 high-z, high-luminosity quasars for more than 10 years using photometric and spectroscopic capabilities. Continuum and line emission flux variability is observed in all quasars. Using cross-correlation analysis we successfully determine lags between the variations in the continuum and broad emission lines for several sources. Here we present a highlight of our results and the determined radius--luminosity relations for Ly_alpha and CIV.

output.explanation:
High-redshift quasars are incredibly luminous objects in the universe, emitting vast amounts of energy.

Quasar variability refers to changes in light emitted over time, characterized by fluctuations in continuum and line emission flux. Continuum emission arises from hot cores within quasars, while line emission originates from surrounding gas clouds. Luminosity is defined as total energy output per unit time, whereas radius denotes the size of its emitting region.

The process of Reverberation Mapping involves analyzing fluctuations to determine lags between variations in different parts of a quasar. By applying cross-correlation analysis, researchers can infer distances between hot cores and surrounding gas clouds. This technique relies on measuring delays between changes in brightness and emission from these components.

Reverberation Mapping results show that continuum and line emission flux variability is observed in all high-z, high-luminosity quasars monitored for over 10 years. The determined radius--luminosity relations for Ly_alpha and CIV highlight the importance of understanding quasar behavior.

title: A rapid decrease in the rotation rate of comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresák
input: Cometary outgassing can produce torques that change the spin state of the nucleus, influencing the evolution and lifetimes of comets (1,2). If these torques spin up the rotation to the point that centripetal forces exceed the material strength of the nucleus, the comet may fragment (3). Torques that slow down the rotation can cause the spin state to become unstable, but if the torques persist, the nucleus may eventually reorient itself and start to spin up again (4). Simulations predict that most comets will go through a short phase of changing spin states, after which changes occur gradually over long times (5). We report on observations of comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresák during its highly favourable close approach to Earth (0.142 au on April 1, 2017) that reveal a dramatic spin-down. Between March and May 2017, the nucleus' apparent rotation period increased from 20 hours to over 46 hours, reflecting a rate of change more than an order of magnitude larger than has ever been measured before. This phenomenon must be caused by a fortuitous alignment of the comet's gas emission in such a way as to produce an anomalously strong torque that is slowing the nucleus' spin rate. The behaviour of 41P suggests that it is in a distinct evolutionary state and that its rotation may be approaching the point of instability.

output.explanation:
Comets are icy bodies that orbit the Sun, and their outgassing can produce torques.

Torque is a force caused by uneven gas emission around a comet's nucleus, which changes its spin state. The material strength of a comet determines how much centripetal force it can withstand before fragmenting.

When comets are spun up or slowed down by torques, their rotation rates change. If the forces become too strong, the nucleus may break apart. Conversely, when torques slow down a comet's spin, its state becomes unstable, but in some cases, the nucleus reorients itself and starts spinning faster again.

The rapid change observed in 41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresák's rotation period from 20 hours to over 46 hours between March and May is attributed to a fortuitous alignment of gas emission that produced an anomalously strong torque slowing down the nucleus' spin rate. This phenomenon suggests the comet may be entering a distinct evolutionary state, where its rotation approaches instability.

title: Occurrence and persistence of magnetic elements in the quiet Sun
input: Turbulent convection efficiently transports energy up to the solar photosphere, but its multi-scale nature and dynamic properties are still not fully understood. Several works in the literature have investigated the emergence of patterns of convective and magnetic nature in the quiet Sun at spatial and temporal scales from granular to global. Aims. To shed light on the scales of organisation at which turbulent convection operates, and its relationship with the magnetic flux therein, we studied characteristic spatial and temporal scales of magnetic features in the quiet Sun. Methods. Thanks to an unprecedented data set entirely enclosing a supergranule, occurrence and persistence analysis of magnetogram time series were used to detect spatial and long-lived temporal correlations in the quiet Sun and to investigate their nature. Results. A relation between occurrence and persistence representative for the quiet Sun was found. In particular, highly recurrent and persistent patterns were detected especially in the boundary of the supergranular cell. These are due to moving magnetic elements undergoing motion that behaves like a random walk together with longer decorrelations ( h) with respect to regions inside the supergranule. In the vertices of the supegranular cell the maximum observed occurrence is not associated with the maximum persistence, suggesting that there are different dynamic regimes affecting the magnetic elements.

output.explanation:
The solar photosphere is a complex environment where turbulent convection plays a crucial role in energy transport, involving the chaotic motion of fluids influenced by magnetic fields. Turbulent convection can be characterized as fluid dynamics with irregular motions and supergranules are large-scale cell-like structures in this region.

Supergranules have distinct properties such as spatial scales from granular to global. Magnetogram time series analysis is a method used for detecting correlations within these regions. The study found that magnetic features exhibit different dynamic regimes, particularly at the boundary of supergranular cells and vertices.

The motion of moving magnetic elements behaves like a random walk with decorrelations occurring over longer distances compared to regions inside the cell. This suggests distinct properties in the quiet Sun's magnetic flux. A relationship between occurrence and persistence was found representative for this region.

Highly recurrent and persistent patterns were detected, especially at the boundary of supergranular cells due to moving magnetic elements undergoing random walk-like motion with decorrelations occurring over longer distances compared to regions inside the cell.

title: The K2-138 System: A Near-Resonant Chain of Five Sub-Neptune Planets Discovered by Citizen Scientists
input: K2-138 is a moderately bright (V = 12.2, K = 10.3) main sequence K-star observed in Campaign 12 of the NASA K2 mission. It hosts five small (1.6-3.3R_Earth) transiting planets in a compact architecture. The periods of the five planets are 2.35 d, 3.56 d, 5.40 d, 8.26 d, and 12.76 d, forming an unbroken chain of near 3:2 resonances. Although we do not detect the predicted 2-5 minute transit timing variations with the K2 timing precision, they may be observable by higher cadence observations with, for example, Spitzer or CHEOPS. The planets are amenable to mass measurement by precision radial velocity measurements, and therefore K2-138 could represent a new benchmark systems for comparing radial velocity and TTV masses. K2-138 is the first exoplanet discovery by citizen scientists participating in the Exoplanet Explorers project on the Zooniverse platform.

output.explanation:
The universe is home to a diverse array of stars, including main sequence K-stars like K2-138, which are characterized by their stable and long-lived nature due to hydrogen fusion in their cores.

A main sequence star is defined as one that fuses hydrogen into helium in its core. The term 'transiting planet' refers to a planet whose orbit brings it between the parent star and Earth, causing a measurable decrease in brightness. A compact architecture describes a system where planets are closely packed around their host star.

The five small transiting planets around K2-138 have radii similar to those of our planet, forming an unbroken chain of near 3:2 resonances due to gravitational interactions between the planets and their parent star. This unique configuration is thought to be a result of the system's compact architecture.

Although predicted transit timing variations were not detected with the K2 mission's precision, they may still be observable by higher cadence observations using more precise instruments like Spitzer or CHEOPS.

title: Ages of the Bulge globular clusters NGC 6522 and NGC 6626 (M28) from HST Proper-motion-cleaned Color-Magnitude Diagrams
input: Bulge globular clusters (GCs) with metallicities [Fe/H] <~ -1.0 and blue horizontal branches are candidates to harbor the oldest populations in the Galaxy. Based on the analysis of HST proper-motion-cleaned color-magnitude diagrams in filters F435W and F625W, we determine physical parameters for the old bulge globular clusters NGC 6522 and NGC 6626 (M28), both with well-defined blue horizontal branches. We compare these results with similar data for the inner halo cluster NGC 6362. These clusters have similar metallicities (-1.3 <= [Fe/H] <= -1.0) obtained from high resolution spectroscopy. We derive ages, distance moduli, and reddening values by means of statistical comparisons between observed and synthetic fiducial lines employing likelihood statistics and the Markov chain Monte Carlo method. The synthetic fiducial lines were generated using alpha-enhanced BaSTI and Dartmouth stellar evolutionary models, adopting both canonical (Y ~ 0.25) and enhanced (Y~ 0.30-0.33) helium abundances. RR Lyrae stars were employed to determine the HB magnitude level, providing an independent indicator to constrain the apparent distance modulus and the helium enhancement. The shape of the observed fiducial line could be compatible with some helium enhancement for NGC 6522 and NGC 6626, but the average magnitudes of RR Lyrae stars tend to rule out this hypothesis. Assuming canonical helium abundances, BaSTI and Dartmouth models indicate that all three clusters are coeval, with ages between ~ 12.5 and 13.0 Gyr. The present study also reveals that NGC 6522 has at least two stellar populations, since its CMD shows a significantly wide subgiant branch compatible with 14% +/- 2% and 86% +/- 5% for first and second generations, respectively.

output.explanation:
The Galaxy's oldest populations are thought to reside in bulge globular clusters with low metallicities and blue horizontal branches. These metal-poor clusters, such as NGC 6522 and NGC 6626, have well-defined blue horizontal branches and similar metallicities (-1.3 <= [Fe/H] <= -1.0) obtained from high resolution spectroscopy. The term 'metallicity' refers to the abundance of elements heavier than hydrogen in a star or cluster. 

The analysis of color-magnitude diagrams for these clusters, generated using Hubble Space Telescope data and filters F435W and F625W, reveals their physical parameters. These diagrams are plots of an object's brightness against its color. The synthetic fiducial lines used to compare observed and predicted values were created with stellar evolutionary models that account for helium enhancement. 

The shape of the observed fiducial line could be compatible with some helium enrichment in NGC 6522 and NGC 6626, but RR Lyrae stars indicate a more likely scenario under canonical helium abundances. The ages of these clusters are estimated to be between ~12.5 and 13.0 Gyr using BaSTI and Dartmouth models. 

The study also reveals that NGC 6522 has at least two stellar populations, with the first generation accounting for approximately 14% +/- 2% of its subgiant branch.

title: Semi-Analytic Galaxies - I. Synthesis of environmental and star-forming regulation mechanisms
input: We present results from the semi-analytic model of galaxy formation SAG applied on the MultiDark simulation MDPL2. SAG features an updated supernova (SN) feedback scheme and a robust modelling of the environmental effects on satellite galaxies. This incorporates a gradual starvation of the hot gas halo driven by the action of ram pressure stripping (RPS), that can affect the cold gas disc, and tidal stripping (TS), which can act on all baryonic components. Galaxy orbits of orphan satellites are integrated providing adequate positions and velocities for the estimation of RPS and TS. The star formation history and stellar mass assembly of galaxies are sensitive to the redshift dependence implemented in the SN feedback model. We discuss a variant of our model that allows to reconcile the predicted star formation rate density at with the observed one, at the expense of an excess in the faint end of the stellar mass function at . The fractions of passive galaxies as a function of stellar mass, halo mass and the halo-centric distances are consistent with observational measurements. The model also reproduces the evolution of the main sequence of star forming central and satellite galaxies. The similarity between them is a result of the gradual starvation of the hot gas halo suffered by satellites, in which RPS plays a dominant role. RPS of the cold gas does not affect the fraction of quenched satellites but it contributes to reach the right atomic hydrogen gas content for more massive satellites ( ).

output.explanation:
Galaxies reside within vast networks of galaxy clusters, their evolution influenced by the surrounding environment and internal processes.

Key terms to understand this context include supernova (SN) feedback, which regulates star formation through energy releases from exploding stars; ram pressure stripping (RPS), a process where hot gas halos are stripped due to interactions with the intergalactic medium; tidal stripping (TS), a phenomenon affecting all baryonic components as galaxies orbit within clusters.

The semi-analytic model of galaxy formation, SAG, incorporates these mechanisms to simulate galaxy evolution. In this framework, RPS can impact cold gas discs, while TS affects various baryonic components. Orphan satellite galaxies have their orbits integrated to estimate the effects of RPS and TS on their star formation history and stellar mass assembly.

The model's redshift dependence in SN feedback influences these processes. A variant of SAG reconciles predicted with observed star formation rate densities at a given redshift, but introduces an excess in the faint end of the stellar mass function at another redshift. The fractions of passive galaxies match observational measurements based on stellar mass, halo mass, and distances from cluster centers.

title: The Orbit of the Companion to HD 100453A: Binary-Driven Spiral Arms in a Protoplanetary Disk
input: HD 100453AB is a 10+/-2 Myr old binary whose protoplanetary disk was recently revealed to host a global two-armed spiral structure. Given the relatively small projected separation of the binary (1.05", or ~108 au), gravitational perturbations by the binary seemed to be a likely driving force behind the formation of the spiral arms. However, the orbit of these stars remained poorly understood, which prevented a proper treatment of the dynamical influence of the companion on the disk. We observed HD 100453AB between 2015-2017 utilizing extreme adaptive optics systems on the Very Large Telescope and Magellan Clay Telescope. We combined the astrometry from these observations with published data to constrain the parameters of the binary's orbit to a=1.06"+/-0.09", e=0.17+/-0.07, and i=32.5+/- 6.5 degrees. We utilized publicly available ALMA CO data to constrain the inclination of the disk to i~28 degrees, which is relatively co-planar with the orbit of the companion and consistent with previous estimates from scattered light images. Finally, we input these constraints into hydrodynamical and radiative transfer simulations to model the structural evolution of the disk. We find that the spiral structure and truncation of the circumprimary disk in HD 100453 are consistent with a companion-dirven origin. Furthermore, we find that the primary star's rotation, its outer disk, and the companion exhibit roughly the same direction of angular momentum, and thus the system likely formed from the same parent body of material.

output.explanation:
The HD 100453AB system is a young binary consisting of two stars separated by approximately 108 astronomical units, embedded within a protoplanetary disk featuring a global spiral structure.

The key terms in this context are the orbital parameters and inclination angles. The orbit's semi-major axis (a) can be understood as the average distance between the two stars, while eccentricity (e) describes how elliptical their orbits are. Inclination angle (i), on the other hand, refers to the tilt of both the binary's orbit and the disk relative to our line of sight.

The spiral structure in protoplanetary disks is often driven by gravitational interactions between stars or planets within them. However, for HD 100453AB, it was unclear whether such forces were at play due to limited understanding of the binary's dynamics. By combining astrometric observations from multiple telescopes with existing data, researchers constrained the orbital parameters and inclination angle of the disk.

The findings suggest that both the spiral structure and truncation of the primary star's disk are consistent with a companion-driven origin. This implies that the system likely formed from material sharing the same direction of angular momentum, indicating a common parent body.

title: Axionic Landscape for Higgs Near-Criticality
input: The measured value of the Higgs quartic coupling is peculiarly close to the critical value above which the Higgs potential becomes unstable, when extrapolated to high scales by renormalization group running. It is tempting to speculate that there is an anthropic reason behind this near-criticality. We show how an axionic field can provide a landscape of vacuum states in which scans. These states are populated during inflation to create a multiverse with different quartic couplings, with a probability distribution that can be computed. If is peaked in the anthropically forbidden region of Higgs instability, then the most probable universe compatible with observers would be close to the boundary, as observed. We discuss three scenarios depending on the Higgs vacuum selection mechanism: decay by quantum tunneling; by thermal fluctuations or by inflationary fluctuations.

output.explanation:
The universe's fundamental forces are governed by a delicate balance of energy densities, with the Higgs field playing a crucial role in giving mass to elementary particles.

A key parameter in this potential is the quartic coupling, which determines the rate at which the Higgs field decays into other particles. The term 'quartic' refers to a mathematical operation involving four variables or quantities. In physics, it often describes interactions between multiple fields or particles.

The introduction of an axionic field creates a multiverse with diverse quartic couplings by populating different vacuum states during inflation, which is a period of rapid expansion in the early universe's history.
