Our final result for this system D/H =2.48^{+0.41}_{-0.35}*10^{-5} has the same relative uncertainty of 17% as the previous estimate by Burles & Tytler despite the far higher signal-to-noise of our dataset. A weighted mean of 13 D/H measurements available in the literature (including our result) gives the primordial deuterium abundance of (D/H)_p = (2.545 +/- 0.025)*10^{-5} and the corresponding baryon density of the Universe of Omega_b h^2 = 0.02174 +/- 0.00025 marginally inconsistent with the 2015 Planck CMB data.

output.explanation:
The universe is observed at a specific point in space, where light from a distant quasar passes through an absorption system with a redshift of z_abs = 2.504.

In this context, the Lyman Limit refers to the boundary beyond which hydrogen gas absorbs all wavelengths shorter than the Ly-alpha line, and the D/H ratio is a measure of deuterium abundance relative to hydrogen.

The presence of low-column-density H I clouds in the absorption system contaminates the deuterium feature, limiting precision in estimating its abundance. This contamination arises due to non-relativistic behavior of particles within these clouds.

As a result, despite having a higher signal-to-noise dataset than previous observations, the estimated D/H ratio has the same relative uncertainty as before. The primordial deuterium abundance and corresponding baryon density of the universe are marginally inconsistent with 2015 Planck CMB data.

title: A radiative neutrino mass model in light of DAMPE excess with hidden gauged symmetry
input: We propose a one-loop induced neutrino mass model with hidden gauge symmetry, in which we successfully involve a bosonic dark matter (DM) candidate propagating inside a loop diagram in neutrino mass generation to explain the excess recently reported by the DArk Matter Particle Explorer (DAMPE) experiment. In our scenario dark matter annihilates into four leptons through boson as DM DM and decays into leptons via one-loop effect. We then investigate branching ratios of taking into account lepton flavor violations and neutrino oscillation data.

output.explanation:
The universe is comprised of vast regions where particles interact through hidden gauge symmetries, enabling unique physical processes to unfold.

A bosonic dark matter candidate refers to a type of particle that can participate in loop diagrams influencing neutrino mass generation. Hidden gauge symmetry is a concept describing the interaction between particles in these regions. Dark matter annihilates into four leptons via an intermediate particle, while also decaying into individual leptons through one-loop effects.

In this context, dark matter interacts with other particles to produce specific outcomes. The bosonic nature of the dark matter candidate allows it to participate in loop diagrams, influencing neutrino mass generation. This process involves a complex interplay between different physical mechanisms.

The model predicts that dark matter annihilates into four leptons through an intermediate particle and decays into individual leptons via one-loop effects. The branching ratios of these processes are influenced by lepton flavor violations and neutrino oscillation data.

title: The first continuous optical monitoring of the transitional millisecond pulsar PSR J1023+0038 with Kepler
input: We report on the first continuous, 80 day optical monitoring of the transitional millisecond pulsar PSR J1023+0038 carried out in mid-2017 with Kepler in the K2 configuration, when an X-ray subluminous accretion disk was present in the binary. Flares lasting from minutes to 14 hr were observed for 15.6% of the time, which is a larger fraction than previously reported on the basis of X-ray and past optical observations, and more frequently when the companion was at the superior conjunction of the orbit. A sinusoidal modulation at the binary orbital period was also present with an amplitude of ~16%, which varied by a few percent over timescales of days, and with a maximum that took place 890 +/- 85 s earlier than the superior conjunction of the donor. We interpret these phenomena in terms of reprocessing of the X-ray emission by an asymmetrically heated companion star surface and/or a non-axisymmetric outflow possibly launched close to the inner Lagrangian point. Furthermore, the non-flaring average emission varied by up to ~ 40% over a time scale of days in the absence of correspondingly large variations of the irradiating X-ray flux. The latter suggests that the observed changes in the average optical luminosity might be due to variations of the geometry, size, and/or mass accretion rate in the outer regions of the accretion disk.

output.explanation:
The binary system PSR J1023+0038 is a complex astrophysical setting where a pulsar and its companion star are gravitationally bound together in an orbit.

A key term to understand this phenomenon is 'accretion disk', which refers to the disk of matter that forms around a neutron star when it accretes material from a companion. The presence of such a disk indicates that matter is being transferred through Roche lobe overflow or stellar wind, leading to reprocessing of X-ray emission by an asymmetrically heated companion surface.

The uneven heating caused by the pulsar's radiation leads to flares lasting from minutes to 14 hours, observed for a significant fraction of time during the monitoring period. Additionally, a sinusoidal modulation at the binary orbital period was detected with varying amplitude over timescales of days.

These phenomena suggest that changes in optical luminosity are due to variations in accretion disk geometry and/or mass accretion rate.

title: Spatially inhomogeneous acceleration of electrons in solar flares
input: The imaging spectroscopy capabilities of the Reuven Ramaty high energy solar spectroscopic imager (RHESSI) enable the examination of the accelerated electron distribution throughout a solar flare region. In particular, it has been revealed that the energisation of these particles takes place over a region of finite size, sometimes resolved by RHESSI observations. In this paper, we present, for the first time, a spatially distributed acceleration model and investigate the role of inhomogeneous acceleration on the observed X-ray emission properties. We have modelled transport explicitly examining scatter-free and diffusive transport within the acceleration region and compare with the analytic leaky-box solution. The results show the importance of including this spatial variation when modelling electron acceleration in solar flares. The presence of an inhomogeneous, extended acceleration region produces a spectral index that is, in most cases, different from the simple leaky-box prediction. In particular, it results in a generally softer spectral index than predicted by the leaky-box solution, for both scatter-free and diffusive transport, and thus should be taken into account when modelling stochastic acceleration in solar flares.

output.explanation:
Solar flares are intense releases of energy that occur on the surface of the sun, involving charged particles such as electrons and protons in a region of finite size.

The 'leaky-box' model is a concept used to describe X-ray emission properties, assuming a uniform acceleration region with specific spectral index predictions. However, recent observations have revealed that energisation takes place over a finite-sized area, suggesting the need for spatial variation consideration in acceleration models.

Inhomogeneous acceleration refers to varying electron-acceleration rates across different parts of this region, leading to complex energy distributions among accelerated particles. This phenomenon can be attributed to the interaction between charged particles and magnetic fields within the solar flare region.

The presence of an extended acceleration region produces a generally softer spectral index than predicted by the leaky-box model for both scatter-free and diffusive transport, indicating that spatial variation is crucial for accurately modelling stochastic acceleration in solar flares.

title: Ten years of speckle interferometry at SOAR
input: Since 2007, close binary and multiple stars are observed by speckle interferometry at the 4.1 m Southern Astrophysical Research (SOAR) telescope. The HRCam instrument, observing strategy and planning, data processing and calibration methods, developed and improved during ten years, are presented here in a concise way. Thousands of binary stars were measured with diffraction-limited resolution (29mas at 540nm wavelength) and a high accuracy reaching 1mas; two hundred new pairs or subsystems were discovered. To date, HRCam has performed over 11000 observations with a high efficiency (up to 300 stars per night). An overview of the main results delivered by this instrument is given.

output.explanation:
Astronomers have been studying close binary and multiple stars for over a decade using speckle interferometry, which allows them to achieve high-resolution imaging by combining multiple short exposures.

Speckle interferometry relies on the principle that light from a star becomes distorted as it passes through Earth's atmosphere due to turbulence. The diffraction limit is a key concept in understanding the accuracy of these measurements, determining the minimum angle between two objects that can be resolved as separate entities. In this context, 29mas refers to the specified value at a wavelength of 540nm.

The HRCam instrument has been optimized for high-precision measurements using speckle interferometry. Its development over ten years has led to advancements in binary star detection and characterization. The telescope's efficiency is also noteworthy, allowing for multiple observations per night.

Thousands of new pairs or subsystems have been discovered through the use of HRCam, with a diffraction-limited resolution of 29mas at 540nm wavelength and high accuracy reaching 1mas.

title: Ultraluminous X-ray sources as neutrino pulsars
input: The classical limit on the accretion luminosity of a neutron star is given by the Eddington luminosity. The advanced models of accretion onto magnetized neutron stars account for the appearance of magnetically confined accretion columns and allow the accretion luminosity to be higher than the Eddington value by a factor of tens. However, the recent discovery of pulsations from ultraluminous X-ray source (ULX) in NGC 5907 demonstrates that the accretion luminosity can exceed the Eddington value up to by a factor of 500. We propose a model explaining observational properties of ULX-1 in NGC 5907 without any ad hoc assumptions. We show that the accretion column at extreme luminosity becomes advective. Enormous energy release within a small geometrical volume and advection result in very high temperatures at the bottom of accretion column, which demand to account for the energy losses due to neutrino emission which can be even more effective than the radiation energy losses. We show that the total luminosity at the mass accretion rates above is dominated by the neutrino emission similarly to the case of core-collapse supernovae. We argue that the accretion rate measurements based on detected photon luminosity in case of bright ULXs powered by neutron stars can be largely underestimated due to intense neutrino emission. The recently discovered pulsating ULX-1 in galaxy NGC 5907 with photon luminosity of is expected to be even brighter in neutrinos and is thus the first known Neutrino Pulsar.

output.explanation:
Neutron stars are incredibly dense objects formed from the remnants of massive stellar collapses, with intense gravitational fields that govern their behavior.

Accretion luminosity refers to the energy released as matter accumulates onto a neutron star's surface, while magnetized accretion columns describe narrow channels where this matter is confined. The Eddington limit marks the maximum rate at which this energy can be released before being overwhelmed by outward pressure forces.

In extreme cases of ultraluminous X-ray sources (ULXs), these columns become advective, leading to intense energy releases within small volumes due to the rapid transfer of matter and heat. This phenomenon demands consideration of neutrino emission as a significant cooling mechanism, potentially surpassing radiation losses in efficiency.

As accretion rates increase beyond the Eddington limit, total luminosity becomes dominated by neutrinos, similar to core-collapse supernovae. The detection of photon luminosity in ULXs may underestimate their true brightness due to intense neutrino emission, as seen in the recently discovered pulsating ULX-1 in NGC 5907 with a photon luminosity of , which is expected to be even brighter in neutrinos and thus classified as a Neutrino Pulsar.

title: Cobalt: A GPU-based correlator and beamformer for LOFAR
input: For low-frequency radio astronomy, software correlation and beamforming on general purpose hardware is a viable alternative to custom designed hardware. LOFAR, a new-generation radio telescope centered in the Netherlands with international stations in Germany, France, Ireland, Latvia, Poland, Sweden and the UK, has successfully used software real-time processors based on IBM Blue Gene technology since 2004. Since then, developments in technology have allowed us to build a system based on commercial off-the-shelf components that combines the same capabilities with lower operational cost. In this paper we describe the design and implementation of a GPU-based correlator and beamformer with the same capabilities as the Blue Gene based systems. We focus on the design approach taken, and show the challenges faced in selecting an appropriate system. The design, implementation and verification of the software system shows the value of a modern test-driven development approach. Operational experience, based on three years of operations, demonstrates that a general purpose system is a good alternative to the previous supercomputer-based system or custom-designed hardware.

output.explanation:
Radio astronomy relies on precise signal processing to detect faint signals from distant celestial objects, which can be achieved through software correlation and beamforming on general purpose hardware. This approach is particularly useful for low-frequency radio astronomy.

In this context, LOFAR stands for a Low-Frequency Array, referring to an array of antennas that work together as a single telescope. Beamforming refers to the process of combining signals from multiple antennas to form a directional beam. Correlation involves comparing these combined signals with each other and with reference signals to extract useful information.

LOFAR's design is based on commercial off-the-shelf components, which are more cost-effective than custom-designed hardware or supercomputer-based systems. The system uses GPU-based correlators and beamformers that match the capabilities of IBM Blue Gene technology used in previous implementations.

The successful operation of LOFAR over three years demonstrates that general-purpose systems can be a good alternative to traditional approaches, offering lower operational costs without compromising performance.

title: Automated Spectral Classification of Galaxies using Machine Learning Approach on Alibaba Cloud AI platform (PAI)
input: Automated spectral classification is an active research area in astronomy at the age of data explosion. While new generation of sky survey telescopes (e.g. LAMOST and SDSS) produce huge amount of spectra, automated spectral classification is highly required to replace the current model fitting approach with human intervention. Galaxies, and especially active galactic nucleus (AGNs), are important targets of sky survey programs. Efficient and automated methods for galaxy spectra classification is the basis of systematic study on physical properties and evolution of galaxies. To address the problem, in this paper we carry out an experiment on Alibaba Cloud AI plaform (PAI) to explore automated galaxy spectral classification using machine learning approach. Supervised machine learning algorithms (Logistic Regression, Random Forest and Linear SVM) were performed on a dataset consist of ~ 10000 galaxy spectra of SDSS DR14, and the classification results of which are compared and discussed. These galaxy spectra each has a subclass tag (i.e. AGNs, Starburst, Starforming, and etc.) that we use as training labels.

output.explanation:
Galaxies and their active galactic nuclei (AGNs) are the focus of modern astronomy, with a vast amount of spectra being produced by new generation sky survey telescopes like LAMOST and SDSS.

A key term to understand is an AGN, which refers to a supermassive black hole at the center of a galaxy that actively accretes material from its surroundings. Another important concept is starburst galaxies, where intense star formation occurs due to the collapse of gas and dust in the interstellar medium.

The classification of galaxy spectra relies on analyzing their spectral properties, which contain information about physical conditions and evolutionary stages. Machine learning algorithms such as Logistic Regression, Random Forest, and Linear SVM are employed for efficient classification using large datasets like SDSS DR14.

These supervised machine learning methods enable the accurate identification of galaxy subclasses based on training labels assigned to each spectrum, allowing scientists to explore properties and evolution of galaxies in a systematic manner. By leveraging these algorithms, researchers can replace current model fitting approaches with human intervention.

title: Improving Orbit Prediction Accuracy through Supervised Machine Learning
input: Due to the lack of information such as the space environment condition and resident space objects' (RSOs') body characteristics, current orbit predictions that are solely grounded on physics-based models may fail to achieve required accuracy for collision avoidance and have led to satellite collisions already. This paper presents a methodology to predict RSOs' trajectories with higher accuracy than that of the current methods. Inspired by the machine learning (ML) theory through which the models are learned based on large amounts of observed data and the prediction is conducted without explicitly modeling space objects and space environment, the proposed ML approach integrates physics-based orbit prediction algorithms with a learning-based process that focuses on reducing the prediction errors. Using a simulation-based space catalog environment as the test bed, the paper demonstrates three types of generalization capability for the proposed ML approach: 1) the ML model can be used to improve the same RSO's orbit information that is not available during the learning process but shares the same time interval as the training data; 2) the ML model can be used to improve predictions of the same RSO at future epochs; and 3) the ML model based on a RSO can be applied to other RSOs that share some common features.

output.explanation:
The space environment is characterized by a vast array of objects, including satellites and debris. Predicting the trajectories of these resident space objects (RSOs) with high accuracy is crucial for collision avoidance. However, current physics-based models often fail to achieve this goal due to limited information about the space environment conditions and RSO body characteristics. 

A key concept in understanding this problem is that of machine learning (ML), which involves training models on large datasets and making predictions without explicitly modeling every aspect of a system. In the context of RSO trajectory prediction, ML can be used to integrate physics-based algorithms with a learning process focused on reducing errors. 

The proposed approach relies on a simulation-based space catalog environment as its test bed. This setup allows for evaluating three types of generalization capability: improving predictions for the same RSO over time intervals not covered during training, predicting future epochs, and applying knowledge gained from one RSO to others with shared features. 

The accuracy of orbit predictions is a critical concern in space operations. By leveraging ML techniques, it may be possible to improve current methods and reduce the risk of satellite collisions.

title: Spatially resolved star formation and dust attenuation in Mrk848: Comparison of the integral field spectra and the UV-to-IR SED
input: We investigate the star formation history and the dust attenuation in the galaxy merger Mrk848. Thanks to the multiwavelength photometry from the ultraviolet (UV) to the infrared (IR), and MaNGA's integral field spectroscopy, we are able to study this merger in a detailed way. We divide the whole merger into the core and tail regions, and fit both the optical spectrum and the multi-band spectral energy distribution (SED) to models to obtain the star formation properties for each region respectively. We find that the color excess of stars in the galaxy measured with the multi-band SED fitting is consistent with that estimated both from the infrared excess (the ratio of IR to UV flux) and from the slope of the UV continuum. Furthermore, the reliability of the is examined with a set of mock SEDs, showing that the dust attenuation of the stars can be well constrained by the UV-to-IR broadband SED fitting. The dust attenuation obtained from optical continuum is only about half of . The ratio of the to the obtained from the Balmer decrement is consistent with the local value (around 0.5). The difference between the results from the UV-to-IR data and the optical data is consistent with the picture that younger stellar populations are attenuated by an extra dust component from the birth clouds compared to older stellar populations which are only attenuated by the diffuse dust. Both with the UV-to-IR SED fitting and the spectral fitting, we find that there is a starburst younger than 100~Myr in one of the two core regions, consistent with the scenario that the interaction-induced gas inflow can enhance the star formation in the center of galaxies.

output.explanation:
Galaxies in the process of merging are complex systems where stars, gas, and dust interact.

Dust attenuation is a critical concept that can be measured through various methods, including infrared excess ratio (IR/UV flux), UV continuum slope, and Balmer decrement - which refers to the ratio between hydrogen emission lines in the optical spectrum. The color excess of stars can also be estimated using these different measurements.

The processes described involve interactions between dust attenuation, star formation properties, and stellar populations within a galaxy merger. Dust attenuation affects how we observe star formation activity by altering our view of the galaxy's light. Younger stellar populations are subject to additional dust attenuation due to birth clouds, whereas older populations experience only diffuse dust effects.

The study reveals that there is a consistent color excess across different measurements in Mrk848 and confirms the presence of a starburst younger than 100 Myr in one core region through both UV-to-IR SED fitting and spectral analysis. This supports the idea that gas inflow triggered by galaxy interactions can enhance central star formation.

title: Radio Galaxy Zoo: Compact and extended radio source classification with deep learning
input: Machine learning techniques have been increasingly useful in astronomical applications over the last few years, for example in the morphological classification of galaxies. Convolutional neural networks have proven to be highly effective in classifying objects in image data. The current work aims to establish when multiple components are present, in the astronomical context of synthesis imaging observations of radio sources. To this effect, we design a convolutional neural network to differentiate between different morphology classes using sources from the Radio Galaxy Zoo (RGZ) citizen science project. In this first step, we focus on exploring the factors that affect the performance of such neural networks, such as the amount of training data, number and nature of layers and the hyperparameters. We begin with a simple experiment in which we only differentiate between two extreme morphologies, using compact and multiple component extended sources. We found that a three convolutional layer architecture yielded very good results, achieving a classification accuracy of 97.4% on a test data set. The same architecture was then tested on a four-class problem where we let the network classify sources into compact and three classes of extended sources, achieving a test achieving a test accuracy of 93.5%. The best-performing convolutional neural network setup has been verified against RGZ Data Release 1 where a final test accuracy of 94.8% was obtained, using both original and augmented images. The use of sigma clipping does not offer a significant benefit overall, except in cases with a small number of training images.

output.explanation:
Radio sources in the universe are complex objects that can be studied through synthesis imaging observations, which combine data from multiple telescopes to produce a single image of an object.

Key terms such as convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and machine learning techniques rely on understanding concepts like layers, filtering, and pooling. In this context, compact sources refer to objects with minimal structure, while extended sources have more complex morphologies.

The process involves designing a CNN architecture that can differentiate between various morphology classes using sources from citizen science projects. A three-layer CNN setup was found to yield excellent results in distinguishing between these types of sources by applying filtering and pooling operations on the input data.

This setup achieved high classification accuracy rates when tested against datasets like the Radio Galaxy Zoo (RGZ) Data Release 1, but the use of sigma clipping did not provide significant benefits overall, except in cases where training images were limited.

title: Tidal disruption of fuzzy dark matter subhalo cores
input: We study tidal stripping of fuzzy dark matter (FDM) subhalo cores using simulations of the Schrödinger-Poisson equations and analyze the dynamics of tidal disruption, highlighting the differences with standard cold dark matter. Mass loss outside of the tidal radius forces the core to relax into a less compact configuration, lowering the tidal radius. As the characteristic radius of a solitonic core scales inversely with its mass, tidal stripping results in a runaway effect and rapid tidal disruption of the core once its central density drops below times the average density of the host within the orbital radius. Additionally, we find that the core is deformed into a tidally locked ellipsoid with increasing eccentricities until it is completely disrupted. Using the core mass loss rate, we compute the minimum mass of cores that can survive several orbits for different FDM particle masses and compare it with observed masses of satellite galaxies in the Milky Way.

output.explanation:
Galaxies and their dark matter subhalos interact through gravitational forces, shaping the universe's large-scale structure. Tidal stripping is a process where mass loss occurs outside the tidal radius, causing cores to relax into less compact configurations.

Fuzzy dark matter (FDM) refers to a type of dark matter characterized by its solitonic core structure, while 'tidal stripping' describes the removal of mass from subhalo cores due to tidal forces. Solitons are stable particle-like structures that arise in certain physical systems.

When FDM subhalos orbit within a larger host galaxy, tidal forces cause mass loss outside the tidal radius, leading to core relaxation and deformation into tidally locked ellipsoids with increasing eccentricities until complete disruption occurs. This process is driven by the inverse scaling of solitonic cores' characteristic radii with their masses.

Tidal stripping results in a runaway effect where rapid disruption occurs once central density drops below times the average host density within the orbital radius, ultimately leading to core destruction and potentially influencing observed satellite galaxy masses.

title: SETI is Part of Astrobiology
input: "Traditional SETI is not part of astrobiology" declares the NASA Astrobiology Strategy 2015 document. This is incorrect. In this white paper, I argue that SETI seen as the search for technosignatures characteristic of the future of life in the universe is a neglected complement to the search for biosignatures in NASA's astrobiology portfolio, and may offer the more fruitful avenue to the discovery of life elsewhere in the universe, as recognized by the Astro2010 decadal survey. I rebut six erroneous perceptions that may contribute to the field's absence from NASA's astrobiology strategy, and argue that since SETI is, quite obviously, part of astrobiology, SETI practitioners should at the very least be expressly encouraged to compete on a level playing field with practitioners of other subfields for NASA astrobiology resources.

output.explanation:
The universe's vast expanse is home to diverse forms of life, from simple organisms to complex civilizations.

Astrobiology encompasses the study of extraterrestrial life and its potential biosignatures, while SETI focuses on technosignatures characteristic of intelligent life. Biosignatures refer to signs of biological activity, whereas technosignatures are indicative of technological advancements.

The search for technosignatures can be seen as a complement to the search for biosignatures in astrobiology, with both approaches offering insights into the presence and nature of life elsewhere in the universe. The distinction between astrophysical and primordial phenomena is crucial in this context, as it helps researchers understand the origin and evolution of life.

SETI practitioners should be encouraged to compete on a level playing field with other subfields for NASA astrobiology resources, given that SETI is an integral part of astrobiology. This recognition may lead to more fruitful avenues in the discovery of extraterrestrial life.

title: Cosmic web dependence of galaxy clustering and quenching in SDSS
input: Galaxies exhibit different clustering and quenching properties in clusters, filaments, and the field, but it is still uncertain whether such differences are imprints of the tidal environment on galaxy formation, or if they reflect the variation of the underlying halo mass function across the cosmic web. We measure the dependence of galaxy clustering and quenching on the cosmic web in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey, characterized by the combination of spherical overdensity and tidal anisotropy centred on each galaxy. We find that galaxy clustering is a strong function of either or , and the large-scale galaxy bias shows complex and rich behaviour on the vs. plane. Using the mean galaxy colour as a proxy for the average quenched level of galaxies, we find that galaxy quenching is primarily a function of , with some subtle yet non-trivial dependence on at fixed . The quenched galaxies generally show stronger small-scale clustering than the star-forming ones at fixed or , while the characteristic scale at which the amplitude of clustering becomes comparable for both galaxy populations varies with and . We compare these observed cosmic web dependences of galaxy clustering and quenching with a mock galaxy catalogue constructed from the iHOD model, which places quenched and star-forming galaxies inside dark matter haloes based on the stellar-to-halo mass relation and the halo quenching model --- the and dependences of iHOD galaxies are thus solely derived from the cosmic web modulation of the halo mass function. The main observed trends are accounted for extremely well by the iHOD model. Thus any additional direct effect of the large-scale~( ) tidal field on galaxy formation must be extremely weak. [Abridged]

output.explanation:
Galaxies inhabit the cosmic web, a vast network of galaxy clusters and filaments that crisscross the universe.

Spherical overdensity refers to an area where dark matter density exceeds its surroundings by a certain factor, while tidal anisotropy describes the directionality and strength of gravitational forces on galaxies. Halo mass function is the distribution of these dark matter haloes within the cosmic web.

Galaxy clustering is influenced by both spherical overdensity and tidal anisotropy, with complex behavior emerging when considering their interplay. Quenching of star formation in galaxies also depends on these cosmic web properties.

Quenched galaxies exhibit stronger small-scale clustering than star-forming ones at fixed or , while the characteristic scale where clustering amplitudes become comparable varies with and . The iHOD model replicates these trends, suggesting a negligible direct effect of large-scale tidal fields on galaxy formation.

title: Low-Frequency Radio Absorption in Cassiopeia A
input: Cassiopeia A is one of the best-studied supernova remnants. Its shocked ejecta emits brightly in radio and X-rays. Its unshocked ejecta can be studied through infrared emission, the radio-active decay of Ti, and low frequency free-free absorption due to cold gas internal to the shell. Free-free absorption is affected by the mass, geometry, temperature, and ionisation conditions in the absorbing gas. Observations at the lowest radio frequencies constrain a combination of these properties. We use LOFAR LBA observations at 30-77 MHz and L-band VLA observations to compare -matched images with a common resolution of 17". We simultaneously fit, per pixel, for the emission measure and the ratio of the emission from the unabsorbed front of the shell versus the absorbed back of the shell. We explore the effects that low temperatures and a high degree of clumping can have on the derived physical properties, such as mass and density. We also compile published radio flux measurements, fit for the absorption processes that occur in the radio band, and consider how they affect the secular decline of the source. We find a mass in the unshocked ejecta of for an assumed gas temperature of K. This estimate is reduced for colder gas temperatures and if the ejecta are clumped. We measure the reverse shock to have a radius of " 6". We also find that a decrease in the amount of mass in the unshocked ejecta (as more and more material meets the reverse shock and heats up) cannot account for the observed low frequency behaviour of the secular decline rate. To reconcile our low frequency absorption measurements with models that predict little mass in the unshocked ejecta we need the ejecta to be very clumped, or the temperature in the cold gas to be low ( K). Both conditions can jointly contribute to the high absorption.

output.explanation:
The Cassiopeia A supernova remnant is a complex astrophysical system where shocked and unshocked ejecta interact.

Free-free absorption, a process that occurs in cold gas within the shell, depends on properties like mass, geometry, temperature, and ionisation conditions. Emission measure quantifies the amount of emitting material, while clumping refers to unevenly distributed gas.

The interaction between shocked and unshocked ejecta leads to complex phenomena such as low-frequency free-free absorption. This process is affected by various factors including mass, geometry, temperature, and ionisation conditions in the absorbing gas. The study uses LOFAR LBA observations at 30-77 MHz and VLA L-band observations to compare matched images with a common resolution of 17 arcseconds.

The derived physical properties such as mass and density are significantly affected by low temperatures and clumping. A mass estimate of solar masses in the unshocked ejecta is found for an assumed gas temperature of Kelvin. However, this value decreases with colder temperatures and clumping. The reverse shock has a radius of approximately arcseconds.

title: Strange mode instabilities and mass-loss in evolved massive primordial stars
input: A linear stability analysis of models for evolved primordial stars with masses between 150 and 250 M is presented. Strange mode instabilities with growth rates in the dynamical range are identified for stellar models with effective temperatures below log T = 4.5. For selected models the final fate of the instabilities is determined by numerical simulation of their evolution into the non-linear regime. As a result, the instabilities lead to finite amplitude pulsations. Associated with them are acoustic energy fluxes capable of driving stellar winds with mass-loss rates in the range between 7.7 10 and 3.5 10 M yr .

output.explanation:
Primordial stars with masses between 150 and 250 solar masses exist in a complex astrophysical setting where nuclear reactions drive their evolution.

The term 'effective temperature' refers to the surface temperature of these stars, while 'log T = 4.5' is a specific threshold below which certain instabilities emerge. The strange mode instability is one such phenomenon that can cause the star's core to pulsate with growing amplitude.

In this context, nuclear reactions in the star's core drive its evolution and stability. When the effective temperature drops below log T = 4.5, the star becomes susceptible to certain instabilities. These instabilities lead to finite amplitude pulsations that generate acoustic energy fluxes capable of driving stellar winds with mass-loss rates between specified values.

The growth rate of these oscillations falls within a particular range, indicating significant impact on the star's behavior. The final fate of these instabilities is determined by numerical simulation of their evolution into the non-linear regime.

title: The extreme blazar AO 0235+164 as seen by extensive ground and space radio observations
input: Clues to the physical conditions in radio cores of blazars come from measurements of brightness temperatures as well as effects produced by intrinsic opacity. We study the properties of the ultra compact blazar AO 0235+164 with RadioAstron ground-space radio interferometer, multi-frequency VLBA, EVN and single-dish radio observations. We employ visibility modeling and image stacking for deriving structure and kinematics of the source, and use Gaussian process regression to find the relative multi-band time delays of the flares. The multi-frequency core size and time lags support prevailing synchrotron self absorption. The intrinsic brightness temperature of the core derived from ground-based VLBI is close to the equipartition regime value. In the same time, there is evidence for ultra-compact features of the size of less than 10 as in the source, which might be responsible for the extreme apparent brightness temperatures of up to K as measured by RadioAstron. In 2007--2016 the VLBI components in the source at 43 GHz are found predominantly in two directions, suggesting a bend of the outflow from southern to northern direction. The apparent opening angle of the jet seen in the stacked image at 43 GHz is two times wider than that at 15 GHz, indicating a collimation of the flow within the central 1.5 mas. We estimate the Lorentz factor , the Doppler factor , and the viewing angle of the apparent jet base, derive the gradients of magnetic field strength and electron density in the outflow, and the distance between jet apex and the core at each frequency.

output.explanation:
Radio blazars are incredibly luminous objects, emitting massive amounts of energy across the electromagnetic spectrum.

The brightness temperature is a measure of how hot these regions appear to us from Earth, while intrinsic opacity can affect this value by scattering or absorbing emitted light. Intrinsic opacity refers to the absorption and emission of radiation within an object itself, rather than external factors.

Synchrotron self-absorption occurs when high-energy particles emit radiation that is then absorbed by lower-energy particles in the same region. This process helps explain how radio cores maintain their brightness temperatures.

The study found evidence for ultra-compact features within AO 0235+164, which could contribute to its extreme apparent brightness temperatures. The motion of VLBI components at 43 GHz suggests a bend in the outflow from south to north, and the opening angle of the jet indicates collimation of the flow within the central region.

title: A convergent kinetic theory of collisional star clusters (i) a self-consistent 'truncated' mean-field acceleration of stars
input: Fundamental relaxation processes in the secular evolution of a collisional star cluster of -'point' stars have been conventionally discussed based on either of collision kinetic theory (for strong two-body encounters) and wave one (for statistical acceleration and gravitational polarization). If combining the both theories together, one must introduce a self-consistent 'truncated' Newtonian mean-field (m.f.) acceleration of star at position and time due to a phase-space distribution function for stars where is the gravitational constant and the mass of stars. The lower limit of the distance between two stars is order of the Landau distance. The truncated m.f. acceleration is a necessary consequence due to the strong encounters and m.f. acceleration being not able to 'coexist' at specific distance between stars. The present paper aims at initiating a star-cluster convergent kinetic theory to self-consistently derive kinetic equations of star clusters, mathematically non-divergent in distance- and wavenumber- spaces based on the truncated m.f. acceleration, correct at time scales of the secular evolution. This will be achieved by focusing on mathematical formulations of the Kandrup's generalised-Landau equation including the effect of the strong encounters and by extending the Grad's truncated distribution function and Klimontovich's theory of non-ideal systems.

output.explanation:
The universe contains vast star clusters, where stars interact through gravity, forming complex systems with strong encounters at close distances.

A key concept in understanding these interactions is the Landau distance, which marks the lower limit for gravitational influences between two stars. The term 'mean-field acceleration' refers to a collective force exerted by all stars on an individual star due to its phase-space distribution function.

In this context, strong encounters and mean-field effects cannot coexist at specific distances without introducing contradictions. To resolve this issue, researchers have developed the concept of truncated Newtonian mean-field acceleration, which accounts for both strong interactions and collective forces.

The goal is to create a convergent kinetic theory that accurately describes star clusters over long time scales. This involves deriving non-divergent kinetic equations based on the truncated mean-field acceleration, using mathematical formulations like Kandrup's generalised-Landau equation and extending Grad's distribution function and Klimontovich's theory for non-ideal systems.

title: Flare Energy Release in the Lower Solar Atmosphere Near the Magnetic Field Polarity Inversion Line
input: We study flare processes in the solar atmosphere using observational data for a M1-class flare of June 12, 2014, obtained by New Solar Telescope (NST/BBSO) and Helioseismic Magnetic Imager (HMI/SDO). The main goal is to understand triggers and manifestations of the flare energy release in the photosphere and chromosphere using high-resolution optical observations and magnetic field measurements. We analyze optical images, HMI Dopplergrams and vector magnetograms, and use Non-Linear Force-Free Field (NLFFF) extrapolations for reconstruction of the magnetic topology and electric currents. The NLFFF modelling reveals interaction of two magnetic flux ropes with oppositely directed magnetic field in the PIL. These flux ropes are observed as a compact sheared arcade along the PIL in the high-resolution broad-band continuum images from NST. In the vicinity of PIL, the NST H alpha observations reveal formation of a thin three-ribbon structure corresponding to a small-scale photospheric magnetic arcade. The observational results evidence in favor of location of the primary energy release site in the chromospheric plasma with strong electric currents concentrated near the polarity inversion line. In this case, magnetic reconnection is triggered by the interacting magnetic flux ropes forming a current sheet elongated along the PIL.

output.explanation:
The solar atmosphere is a complex system where intense energy release processes occur through flare events, which involve the interaction of magnetic fields and plasma. The photosphere is the visible surface layer of the sun, while the chromosphere lies above it. A key concept in understanding this phenomenon is Non-Linear Force-Free Field (NLFFF), a method used for reconstructing the magnetic topology and electric currents.

The NLFFF modelling reveals interaction between two bundles of magnetized plasma called magnetic flux ropes with oppositely directed magnetic fields at their cores, known as polarity inversion lines. These flux ropes are observed as compact sheared arcades in high-resolution images from telescopes like NST. In the vicinity of these polarity inversion lines, thin three-ribbon structures form due to small-scale photospheric magnetic arcades.

The interaction between these magnetic flux ropes triggers a process called magnetic reconnection, which forms an elongated current sheet along the polarity inversion line. This process is thought to be responsible for releasing energy in the chromospheric plasma with strong electric currents concentrated near the polarity inversion line.

Magnetic reconnection occurs when oppositely directed magnetic fields interact and release their stored energy, forming a current sheet that can lead to intense energy releases in the solar atmosphere.

title: Consistent modelling of the meta-galactic UV background and the thermal/ionization history of the intergalactic medium
input: Recent observations suggest that hydrogen reionization ends late ( ) and proceeds quickly. We present here a new model of the meta-galactic UV/X-ray background (UVB) that is consistent with this. It adopts the most recent determinations of the ionizing emissivity due to stars and AGN, as well as of the HI absorber column density distribution. Another major improvement is a new treatment of the intergalactic medium (IGM) opacity for ionizing photons that is able to consistently capture the transition from a neutral to an ionized IGM. Previous synthesis models of the UVB, when used in simulations, yield reionization and thermal histories that are inconsistent with the assumed ionizing emissivities. With our new treatment, this discrepancy is fully resolved. In our fiducial model, galaxies leaking of their Lyman continuum emission drive HI reionization, while AGN drive HeII reionization (completing at and respectively). Due to the limited time available for cooling between HI and HeII reionization, higher IGM temperatures are predicted for late reionization scenarios. In our fiducial model, the predicted temperatures agree well with observational constraints at , while being slightly high compared to (somewhat uncertain) data above that. Models with a larger contribution of AGN are instead disfavoured by the temperature data, as well as by measurements of the HI and HeII Lyman- forest opacities. We also present "equivalent-equilibrium" ionization/heating rates that mimic our fiducial UVB model for use in simulation codes that assume ionization equilibrium.

output.explanation:
The universe's hydrogen reionization process occurs in a vast, diffuse environment known as the intergalactic medium (IGM).

The IGM is characterized by its ability to absorb or transmit ionizing photons from stars and active galactic nuclei (AGN), which are sources of ultraviolet and X-ray radiation. The opacity of the IGM for these photons determines how efficiently they can travel through space, influencing the reionization process.

The key terms in this context include 'reionization', referring to the transition from a neutral to an ionized state; 'UVB' or ultraviolet background, which is the cumulative radiation emitted by stars and AGN; and 'IGM opacity', describing how effectively these photons can traverse the IGM.

The reionization process involves two stages: hydrogen (HI) and helium (HeII). In our model, galaxies primarily drive HI reionization through their Lyman continuum emission, while AGN are responsible for HeII reionization. This late reionization scenario results in higher temperatures within the IGM due to limited cooling time between these two stages.

title: The dependence of galaxy clustering on stellar mass, star-formation rate and redshift at z = 0.8-2.2, with HiZELS
input: The deep, near-infrared narrow-band survey HiZELS has yielded robust samples of H-alpha emitting star-forming galaxies within narrow redshift slices at z = 0.8, 1.47 and 2.23. In this paper, we distinguish the stellar mass and star-formation rate (SFR) dependence of the clustering of these galaxies. At high stellar masses (M/M_sol>2x10^10), where HiZELS selects galaxies close to the so-called star-forming main sequence, the clustering strength is observed to increase strongly with stellar mass (in line with the results of previous studies of mass-selected galaxy samples) and also with SFR. These two dependencies are shown to hold independently. At lower stellar masses, however, where HiZELS probes high specific SFR galaxies, there is little or no dependence of the clustering strength on stellar mass, but the dependence on SFR remains: high-SFR low-mass galaxies are found in more massive dark matter haloes than their lower SFR counterparts. We argue that this is due to environmentally driven star formation in these systems. We apply the same selection criteria to the EAGLE cosmological hydrodynamical simulations. We find that, in EAGLE, the high-SFR low-mass galaxies are central galaxies in more massive dark matter haloes, in which the high SFRs are driven by a (halo-driven) increased gas content.

output.explanation:
Galaxies in the distant universe are embedded within vast networks of dark matter, which plays a crucial role in their evolution. The term stellar mass refers to the total amount of material in a galaxy's stars, while star-formation rate (SFR) measures how quickly new stars are being created.

Dark matter haloes are massive structures that surround galaxies and influence their growth through gravitational interactions. Stellar mass is often used as a proxy for a galaxy's overall size and importance within the universe.

The clustering of galaxies in high-redshift regions, such as those observed by HiZELS, can be influenced by both stellar mass and SFR. In particular, at high stellar masses, galaxies tend to cluster together more strongly due to their massive dark matter haloes and rapid star formation. However, this relationship becomes less clear-cut at lower stellar masses.

In regions where low-mass galaxies exhibit high SFRs, they are often found within more massive dark matter haloes, suggesting that environmental factors drive increased star formation in these systems.

title: The Effects of Environment on the Evolution of the Galaxy Stellar Mass Function
input: We study the effects of galaxy environment on the evolution of the stellar-mass function (SMF) over 0.2 < z < 2.0 using the FourStar Galaxy Evolution (ZFOURGE) survey and NEWFIRM Medium-Band Survey (NMBS) down to the stellar-mass completeness limit, log M / Msun > 9.0 (9.5) at z = 1.0 (2.0). We compare the SMFs for quiescent and star-forming galaxies in the highest and lowest environments using a density estimator based on the distance to the galaxies' third-nearest neighbors. For star-forming galaxies, at all redshifts there are only minor differences with environment in the shape of the SMF. For quiescent galaxies, the SMF in the lowest densities shows no evolution with redshift, other than an overall increase in number density (phi*) with time. This suggests that the stellar-mass dependence of quenching in relatively isolated galaxies is both universal and does not evolve strongly. While at z >~ 1.5 the SMF of quiescent galaxies is indistinguishable in the highest and lowest densities, at lower redshifts it shows a rapidly increasing number density of lower-mass galaxies, log M / Msun ~= 9-10. We argue this evolution can account for all the redshift evolution in the shape of the total quiescent-galaxy SMF. This evolution in the quiescent-galaxy SMF at higher redshift (z > 1) requires an environmental-quenching efficiency that decreases with decreasing stellar mass at 0.5 < z < 1.5 or it would overproduce the number of lower-mass quiescent galaxies in denser environments. This requires a dominant environment process such as starvation combined with rapid gas depletion and ejection at z > 0.5 - 1.0 for galaxies in our mass range. The efficiency of this process decreases with redshift allowing other processes (such as galaxy interactions and ram-pressure stripping) to become more important at later times, z < 0.5.

output.explanation:
Galaxies reside within vast networks of cosmic structures, influencing their evolution through interactions with neighboring galaxies and the surrounding environment.

The stellar-mass function (SMF) is a distribution of galaxy masses within a given population, while quiescent galaxies are those that have ceased producing new stars. Star-forming galaxies continue to forge new stellar populations.

Galaxy density can be quantified using metrics such as distance to the third-nearest neighbors. The SMFs for quiescent and star-forming galaxies in high- and low-density regions show distinct behavior, with minor differences between these populations at all redshifts.

Quiescent galaxy SMF shows little evolution with time except for an overall increase in number density, suggesting a universal dependence on stellar mass for quenching processes. However, the SMF of quiescent galaxies reveals a rapidly increasing number density of lower-mass galaxies at lower redshifts, which can account for all observed redshift evolution.

title: Accretion of clumpy cold gas onto massive black hole binaries: a possible fast route to binary coalescence
input: In currently favoured hierarchical cosmologies, the formation of massive black hole binaries (MBHBs) following galaxy mergers is unavoidable. Still, due the complex physics governing the (hydro)dynamics of the post-merger dense environment of stars and gas in galactic nuclei, the final fate of those MBHBs is still unclear. In gas-rich environments, it is plausible that turbulence and gravitational instabilities feed gas to the nucleus in the form of a series of cold incoherent clumps, thus providing a way to exchange energy and angular momentum between the MBHB and its surroundings. Within this context, we present a suite of smoothed-particle-hydrodynamical models to study the evolution of a sequence of near-radial turbulent gas clouds as they infall towards equal-mass, circular MBHBs. We focus on the dynamical response of the binary orbit to different levels of anisotropy of the incoherent accretion events. Compared to a model extrapolated from a set of individual cloud-MBHB interactions, we find that accretion increases considerably and the binary evolution is faster. This occurs because the continuous infall of clouds drags inwards circumbinary gas left behind by previous accretion events, thus promoting a more effective exchange of angular momentum between the MBHB and the gas. These results suggest that sub-parsec MBHBs efficiently evolve towards coalescence during the interaction with a sequence of individual gas pockets.

output.explanation:
Galactic nuclei are complex environments where massive black hole binaries form after galaxy mergers, governed by hydrodynamics and star-gas interactions in gas-rich areas.

Key terms include 'anisotropy,' referring to the uneven distribution of particles or properties, and 'incoherent clumps,' describing disordered collections of gas. Anisotropy is a measure of how evenly distributed something is, while an incoherent clump is a collection of gas that doesn't have a uniform structure.

The mechanism involves near-radial turbulent gas clouds infalling towards equal-mass circular binaries, with the level of anisotropy affecting the dynamical response of the binary orbit. The continuous infall of these clouds drags in circumbinary gas left behind by previous accretion events, promoting angular momentum exchange between the binary and gas.

This leads to increased accretion rates and faster binary evolution compared to individual cloud-MBHB interactions, suggesting that sub-parsec MBHBs efficiently evolve towards coalescence during interaction with a sequence of gas pockets.

title: New Spectral Model for Constraining Torus Covering Factors from Broadband X-ray Spectra of Active Galactic Nuclei
input: The basic unified model of active galactic nuclei (AGN) invokes an anisotropic obscuring structure, usually referred to as a torus, to explain AGN obscuration as an angle-dependent effect. We present a new grid of X-ray spectral templates based on radiative transfer calculations in neutral gas in an approximately toroidal geometry, appropriate for CCD-resolution X-ray spectra (FWHM > 130 eV). Fitting the templates to broadband X-ray spectra of AGN provides constraints on two important geometrical parameters of the gas distribution around the supermassive black hole: the average column density and the covering factor. Compared to the currently available spectral templates, our model is more flexible, and capable of providing constraints on the main torus parameters in a wider range of AGN. We demonstrate the application of this model using hard X-ray spectra from NuSTAR (3-79 keV) for four AGN covering a variety of classifications: 3C 390.3, NGC 2110, IC 5063, and NGC 7582. This small set of examples was chosen to illustrate the range of possible torus configurations, from disk-like to sphere-like geometries with column densities below, as well as above, the Compton-thick threshold. This diversity of torus properties challenges the simple assumption of a standard geometrically and optically thick toroidal structure commonly invoked in the basic form of the unified model of AGN. Finding broad consistency between the our constraints and those from infrared modeling, we discuss how the approach from the X-ray band complements similar measurements of AGN structures at other wavelengths.

output.explanation:
Galaxies harbor supermassive black holes at their centers, which are surrounded by a complex environment of gas and dust.

A torus is an obscuring structure that can affect our view depending on its orientation. The column density refers to the average number of particles per unit area perpendicular to the direction of propagation in this context. It describes how much gas is distributed around the supermassive black hole. The covering factor represents the fraction of solid angle subtended by the obscuring material at the central source.

Radiative transfer calculations are used to model neutral gas in approximately toroidal geometry, creating X-ray spectral templates suitable for CCD-resolution spectra with a full width at half maximum greater than 130 eV. These templates allow us to constrain two important parameters: the average column density and covering factor. By fitting these templates to broadband X-ray spectra of AGN, we can determine the main torus parameters.

Our model demonstrates that it is more flexible than current spectral templates and capable of providing constraints on a wider range of AGN with diverse torus properties. The diversity of torus configurations challenges the simple assumption of a standard geometrically and optically thick toroidal structure commonly invoked in the unified model of AGN, with column densities below as well as above the Compton-thick threshold.

title: Marginally fast cooling synchrotron models for prompt GRBs
input: Previous studies have considered synchrotron as the emission mechanism for prompt Gamma-Ray Bursts (GRBs). These works have shown that the electrons must cool on a timescale comparable to the dynamic time at the source in order to satisfy spectral constraints while maintaining high radiative efficiency. We focus on conditions where synchrotron cooling is balanced by a continuous source of heating, and in which these constraints are naturally satisfied. Assuming that a majority of the electrons in the emitting region are contributing to the observed peak, we find that the energy per electron has to be GeV and that the Lorentz factor of the emitting material has to be very large , well in excess of the bulk Lorentz factor of the jet inferred from GRB afterglows. A number of independent constraints then indicate that the emitters must be moving relativistically, with , relative to the bulk frame of the jet and that the jet must be highly magnetized upstream of the emission region, . The emission radius is also strongly constrained in this model to cm. These values are consistent with magnetic jet models where the dissipation is driven by magnetic reconnection that takes place far away from the base of the jet.

output.explanation:
Gamma-Ray Bursts (GRBs) are extreme astrophysical events characterized by intense radiation across the electromagnetic spectrum, often involving relativistic jets of energetic particles. The key concept here is synchrotron emission, which occurs when charged particles accelerate in magnetic fields, emitting specific types of radiation. 

The Lorentz factor and relativistic motion play crucial roles: the Lorentz factor measures an object's velocity relative to its rest frame, while relativistic motion refers to objects moving at significant fractions of the speed of light. Synchrotron cooling is a process where energetic particles lose energy through electromagnetic interactions with their environment. 

The balance between synchrotron cooling and continuous heating within the emitting region is critical; it naturally satisfies spectral constraints and radiative efficiency requirements. In this scenario, electrons must possess energies around GeV and be part of a highly magnetized jet with Lorentz factors exceeding those inferred from GRB afterglows. This implies relativistic motion relative to the bulk frame of the jet and a highly magnetized upstream region, consistent with magnetic jet models where dissipation occurs through reconnection far from the base of the jet. 

The emission radius in this model is constrained to approximately cm.

title: Planck 2018 results. XI. Polarized dust foregrounds
input: The study of polarized dust emission has become entwined with the analysis of the cosmic microwave background (CMB) polarization. We use new Planck maps to characterize Galactic dust emission as a foreground to the CMB polarization. We present Planck EE, BB, and TE power spectra of dust polarization at 353 GHz for six nested sky regions covering from 24 to 71 % of the sky. We present power-law fits to the angular power spectra, yielding evidence for statistically significant variations of the exponents over sky regions and a difference between the values for the EE and BB spectra. The TE correlation and E/B power asymmetry extend to low multipoles that were not included in earlier Planck polarization papers. We also report evidence for a positive TB dust signal. Combining data from Planck and WMAP, we determine the amplitudes and spectral energy distributions (SEDs) of polarized foregrounds, including the correlation between dust and synchrotron polarized emission, for the six sky regions as a function of multipole. This quantifies the challenge of the component separation procedure required for detecting the reionization and recombination peaks of primordial CMB B modes. The SED of polarized dust emission is fit well by a single-temperature modified blackbody emission law from 353 GHz to below 70 GHz. For a dust temperature of 19.6 K, the mean spectral index for dust polarization is . By fitting multi-frequency cross-spectra, we examine the correlation of the dust polarization maps across frequency. We find no evidence for decorrelation. If the Planck limit for the largest sky region applies to the smaller sky regions observed by sub-orbital experiments, then decorrelation might not be a problem for CMB experiments aiming at a primordial B-mode detection limit on the tensor-to-scalar ratio at the recombination peak.

output.explanation:
The cosmic microwave background (CMB) and polarized dust emission are intricately linked phenomena. Polarized dust emission arises from the thermal radiation of interstellar dust grains, which is a foreground to CMB observations. The physical setting for this study involves the interaction between Galactic dust and the CMB.

Key terms in this context include 'modified blackbody emission law,' referring to the spectral energy distribution (SED) of polarized dust emission, and 'dust temperature,' denoting the thermal state of interstellar dust grains. Additionally, 'tensor-to-scalar ratio' is a measure of primordial fluctuations in the CMB.

The mechanism underlying this study involves characterizing Galactic dust emission as a foreground to CMB polarization using new Planck maps. The researchers analyze power spectra of dust polarization at 353 GHz for six nested sky regions and find evidence for statistically significant variations in the exponents over these regions. They also report a positive TB dust signal, indicating a correlation between polarized dust and synchrotron emission.

The study reveals that the SED of polarized dust emission is well-fit by a single-temperature modified blackbody emission law from 353 GHz to below 70 GHz. The researchers find no evidence for decorrelation in the polarization maps across frequency, suggesting that CMB experiments aiming at primordial B-mode detection may not face significant challenges due to foreground contamination.

title: Neutrino masses and their ordering: Global Data, Priors and Models
input: We present a Bayesian analysis of the combination of current neutrino oscillation, neutrinoless double beta decay and CMB observations. Our major goal is to carefully investigate the possibility to single out one neutrino mass ordering, Normal Ordering or Inverted Ordering, with current data. Two possible parametrizations (three neutrino masses versus the lightest neutrino mass plus the two oscillation mass splittings) and priors (linear versus logarithmic) are examined. We find that the preference for NO is only driven by neutrino oscillation data. Moreover, the values of the Bayes factor indicate that the evidence for NO is strong only when the scan is performed over the three neutrino masses with logarithmic priors; for every other combination of parameterization and prior, the preference for NO is only weak. As a by-product of our Bayesian analyses, we are able to a) compare the Bayesian bounds on the neutrino mixing parameters to those obtained by means of frequentist approaches, finding a very good agreement; b) determine that the lightest neutrino mass plus the two mass splittings parametrization, motivated by the physical observables, is strongly preferred over the three neutrino mass eigenstates scan and c) find that there is a weak-to-moderate preference for logarithmic priors. These results establish the optimal strategy to successfully explore the neutrino parameter space, based on the use of the oscillation mass splittings and a logarithmic prior on the lightest neutrino mass. We also show that the limits on the total neutrino mass can change dramatically when moving from one prior to the other. These results have profound implications for future studies on the neutrino mass ordering, as they crucially state the need for self-consistent analyses which explore the best parametrization and priors, without combining results that involve different assumptions.

output.explanation:
The universe's neutrino population is governed by the weak force, which mediates interactions between particles and antiparticles. Neutrinos are among these fundamental particles, participating in processes like beta decay and oscillations. The two primary types of neutrino mass ordering – Normal Ordering (NO) and Inverted Ordering (IO) – determine how neutrinos arrange themselves within this framework. NO implies a hierarchical structure with the lightest neutrino having the smallest mass, while IO suggests an inverted hierarchy where the heaviest neutrino has the lowest mass.

The combination of current data from neutrino oscillations, double beta decay, and cosmic microwave background (CMB) observations is analyzed using Bayesian statistics to determine which ordering is more likely. Two approaches are considered: one focusing on three distinct neutrino masses and another centered around the lightest neutrino's mass plus two key mass splittings.

The analysis explores different prior assumptions – linear versus logarithmic distributions for these parameters, where a logarithmic distribution represents a range of possible values with equal probability. The term 'Bayes factor' refers to a statistical measure used in Bayesian inference to compare the relative evidence of competing hypotheses.

The results indicate that Normal Ordering is only preferred when using three neutrino masses and logarithmic priors; otherwise, the preference for NO remains weak. This suggests that the choice of prior significantly influences the outcome of the analysis.

title: Initial conditions for Inflation in an FRW Universe
input: We examine the class of initial conditions which give rise to inflation. Our analysis is carried out for several popular models including: Higgs inflation, Starobinsky inflation, chaotic inflation, axion monodromy inflation and non-canonical inflation. In each case we determine the set of initial conditions which give rise to sufficient inflation, with at least e-foldings. A phase-space analysis has been performed for each of these models and the effect of the initial inflationary energy scale on inflation has been studied numerically. This paper discusses two scenarios of Higgs inflation: (i) the Higgs is coupled to the scalar curvature, (ii) the Higgs Lagrangian contains a non-canonical kinetic term. In both cases we find Higgs inflation to be very robust since it can arise for a large class of initial conditions. One of the central results of our analysis is that, for plateau-like potentials associated with the Higgs and Starobinsky models, inflation can be realised even for initial scalar field values which lie close to the minimum of the potential. This dispels a misconception relating to plateau potentials prevailing in the literature. We also find that inflation in all models is more robust for larger values of the initial energy scale.

output.explanation:
The universe's early stages are characterised by rapid expansion, a phenomenon known as inflation. This period is driven by an inflaton field with negative pressure.

Inflation can arise from various initial conditions, which are examined in the context of several popular models. These include Higgs inflation and Starobinsky inflation, both of which involve specific forms of curvature-driven expansion. The analysis also considers chaotic inflation, axion monodromy inflation, and non-canonical inflation.

Key terms appearing in this discussion include: plateau-like potentials, associated with the Higgs and Starobinsky models; scalar field values, representing the inflaton's magnitude; and initial energy scales, influencing the stability of inflation. Plateau-like potentials are characterised by a flat shape, allowing for inflation even at low inflaton field values close to their minimum potential energy.

The mechanism underlying these models involves an interplay between the inflaton field and its interactions with other fields in the universe. The robustness of Higgs inflation is attributed to its ability to arise from a broad range of initial conditions, particularly when the Higgs boson couples to the scalar curvature or has a non-canonical kinetic term. This allows for inflation even at low values of the inflaton field close to its minimum potential energy.

title: Predicted Number, Multiplicity, and Orbital Dynamics of TESS M Dwarf Exoplanets
input: We present a study of the M dwarf exoplanetary systems forthcoming from NASA's TESS mission. While the mission's footprint is too complex to be characterized by a single detection completeness, we extract an ensemble completeness function that recovers the M dwarf planet detections from previous work. We employ this completeness function, together with a dual-population planet occurrence model that includes compact multiple planetary systems, to infer anew the planet yield. We predict both the number of M dwarf planets likely from TESS and their system architectures. We report four main findings: first, that TESS will likely detect more planets orbiting M dwarfs that previously predicted. Around stars with spectral types between M1V--M4V, we predict TESS will find 990 350 planets orbiting 715 255 stars, a 1.5-fold increase over previous predictions. Secondly, TESS will find two or more transiting planets around 20% of these host stars, a number similar to the multiplicity yield of NASA's Kepler mission. Thirdly, TESS light curves in which one or more planets are detected will often contain transits of additional planets below the detection threshold of TESS. Among a typical set of 200 TESS hosts to one or more detected planets, 116 28 transiting planets will be missed. Transit follow-up efforts with the photometric sensitivity to detect an Earth or larger around a mid-M dwarf, even with very modest period completeness, will readily result in additional planet discoveries. And fourth, the strong preference of TESS for systems of compact multiples indicates that TESS planets will be dynamically cooler on average than Kepler planets, with 90% of TESS-detected planets residing in orbits with .

output.explanation:
M dwarf stars are a type of small, cool star that is abundant in the universe.

The detection footprint of TESS can be understood by considering its ability to detect planets in different regimes. A key concept here is ensemble completeness function, which allows for recovering M dwarf planet detections from previous work. This function serves as a tool for inferring the number of planets likely to be detected by TESS and their system architectures.

The term 'compact multiple planetary systems' refers to configurations where several planets orbit close together around an M dwarf star. The detection threshold represents the minimum signal strength required for a planet's transit to be identified as such.

The mechanism behind TESS's detection of M dwarf exoplanets involves its ability to capture transits of multiple planets in compact systems, often resulting in undetected planets below the detection threshold. This is particularly significant because it implies that many planets will remain unnoticed despite their presence being inferred from light curves of detected planets.

title: Hybrid modeling of redshift space distortions
input: The observed power spectrum in redshift space appears distorted due to the peculiar motion of galaxies, known as redshift-space distortions (RSD). While all the effects in RSD are accounted for by the simple mapping formula from real to redshift spaces, accurately modeling redshift-space power spectrum is rather difficult due to the non-perturbative properties of the mapping. Still, however, a perturbative treatment may be applied to the power spectrum at large-scales, and on top of a careful modeling of the Finger-of-God effect caused by the small-scale random motion, the redshift-space power spectrum can be expressed as a series of expansion which contains the higher-order correlations of density and velocity fields. In our previous work [JCAP 8 (Aug., 2016) 050], we provide a perturbation-theory inspired model for power spectrum in which the higher-order correlations are evaluated directly from the cosmological -body simulations. Adopting a simple Gaussian ansatz for Finger-of-God effect, the model is shown to quantitatively describe the simulation results. Here, we further push this approach, and present an accurate power spectrum template which can be used to estimate the growth of structure as a key to probe gravity on cosmological scales. Based on the simulations, we first calibrate the uncertainties and systematics in the pertrubation theory calculation in a fiducial cosmological model. Then, using the scaling relations, the calibrated power spectrum template is applied to a different cosmological model. We demonstrate that with our new template, the best-fitted growth functions are shown to reproduce the fiducial values in a good accuracy of 1 \% at for cosmologies with different Hubble parameters.

output.explanation:
The universe's large-scale structure is shaped by the gravitational pull of galaxies, which are in constant motion due to their peculiar velocities. This motion causes distortions in the observed power spectrum when viewed from redshift space.

Redshift-space distortions (RSD) refer to the distortion caused by the peculiar velocities of galaxies, while Finger-of-God effect describes the small-scale random motion that affects galaxy distributions. The mapping formula for real and redshift spaces accounts for all RSD effects but accurately modeling this distortion remains challenging due to its non-perturbative nature.

The interaction between RSD and Finger-of-God effect can be understood through their combined influence on the power spectrum. By applying a perturbative treatment to the power spectrum at large scales, we can express it as an expansion series containing higher-order correlations of density and velocity fields. This approach allows us to evaluate these correlations directly from cosmological N-body simulations.

Our new template demonstrates excellent accuracy in reproducing fiducial values for various Hubble parameters by calibrating the uncertainties and systematics in perturbation theory calculations within a fiducial cosmological model, then applying the calibrated template to different cosmologies using scaling relations. The best-fitted growth functions show a good agreement with the calibrated power spectrum.

title: BlueTides simulation: establishing black hole-galaxy relations at high-redshift
input: The scaling relations between the mass of supermassive black holes ( ) and host galaxy properties (stellar mass, , and velocity dispersion, ), provide a link between the growth of black holes (BHs) and that of their hosts. Here we investigate if and how the BH-galaxy relations are established in the high- universe using , a high-resolution large volume cosmological hydrodynamic simulation. We find the and relations at : and at , both fully consistent with the local measurements.
