The slope of the relation is slightly steeper for high star formation rate and galaxies while it remains unchanged as a function of Eddington accretion rate onto the BH. The intrinsic scatter in relation in all cases ( ) is larger at these redshifts than inferred from observations and larger than in relation ( ). We find the gas-to-stellar ratio in the host (which can be very high at these redshifts) to have the most significant impact setting the intrinsic scatter of . The scatter is significantly reduced when galaxies with high gas fractions ( as ) are excluded (making the sample more comparable to low- galaxies); these systems have the largest star formation rates and black hole accretion rates, indicating that these fast-growing systems are still moving toward the relation at these high redshifts. Examining the evolution (from to 8) of high mass black holes in plane confirms this trend.

output.explanation:
The universe at high redshifts is characterized by intense star formation and the growth of supermassive black holes (BHs) within their host galaxies.

A key concept in this context is stellar mass, which refers to the total amount of stars present in a galaxy. Velocity dispersion, on the other hand, describes how fast stars are moving within a galaxy's central region. The Eddington accretion rate represents the maximum rate at which matter can flow onto a black hole before it becomes unstable.

The growth of BHs and their host galaxies is intricately linked through complex interactions between star formation, gas accretion, and black hole growth. As gas-rich systems with high star formation rates and black hole accretion rates are excluded from the analysis, the intrinsic scatter in the relationship between BH mass and galaxy properties is significantly reduced.

The relations established at these redshifts show that fast-growing systems are still moving toward the established relationships between BH mass and galaxy properties. This trend suggests that high-redshift universes exhibit a distinct pattern of black hole growth and galaxy evolution, which continues to evolve as the universe ages.

title: Impact of Lyman alpha pressure on metal-poor dwarf galaxies
input: Understanding the origin of strong galactic outflows and the suppression of star formation in dwarf galaxies is a key problem in galaxy formation. Using a set of radiation-hydrodynamic simulations of an isolated dwarf galaxy embedded in a halo, we show that the momentum transferred from resonantly scattered Lyman- (Lya) photons is an important source of stellar feedback which can shape the evolution of galaxies. We find that Lya feedback suppresses star formation by a factor of two in metal-poor galaxies by regulating the dynamics of star-forming clouds before the onset of supernova explosions (SNe). This is possible because each Lya photon resonantly scatters and imparts 10-300 times greater momentum than in the single scattering limit. Consequently, the number of star clusters predicted in the simulations is reduced by a factor of , compared to the model without the early feedback. More importantly, we find that galactic outflows become weaker in the presence of strong Lya radiation feedback, as star formation and associated SNe become less bursty. We also examine a model in which radiation field is arbitrarily enhanced by a factor of up to 10, and reach the same conclusion. The typical mass loading factors in our metal-poor dwarf system are estimated to be near the mid plane, while it is reduced to at larger radii. Finally, we find that the escape of ionizing radiation and hence the reionization history of the Universe is unlikely to be strongly affected by Lya feedback.

output.explanation:
Galaxies reside within dark matter halos, where gas is embedded and can form stars through the collapse of molecular clouds into dense regions called star clusters.

The process of resonant scattering occurs when photons interact with neutral atoms or molecules in a way that imparts significant momentum to the surrounding gas. In this context, Lyman-alpha (Lya) photons are particularly effective at transferring 10-300 times more momentum than in single scattering limit due to their resonance frequency.

The interaction between Lya feedback and star-forming clouds is critical in regulating the dynamics of these systems before supernova explosions occur. This regulation can suppress star formation by a factor of two in metal-poor galaxies, effectively reducing the number of predicted star clusters and associated outflows.

As a result of this suppression, galactic outflows become weaker due to less bursty star formation and associated supernovae. The mass loading factors within these systems are also affected, with higher values near the mid-plane and lower values at larger radii.

title: Beyond Falsifiability: Normal Science in a Multiverse
input: Cosmological models that invoke a multiverse - a collection of unobservable regions of space where conditions are very different from the region around us - are controversial, on the grounds that unobservable phenomena shouldn't play a crucial role in legitimate scientific theories. I argue that the way we evaluate multiverse models is precisely the same as the way we evaluate any other models, on the basis of abduction, Bayesian inference, and empirical success. There is no scientifically respectable way to do cosmology without taking into account different possibilities for what the universe might be like outside our horizon. Multiverse theories are utterly conventionally scientific, even if evaluating them can be difficult in practice.

output.explanation:
The universe is vast and contains regions beyond our observable horizon, where conditions may differ significantly from those in our vicinity. The concept of a multiverse refers to these unobservable areas of space. In cosmology, evaluating models that involve the multiverse relies on established methods such as abduction and Bayesian inference.

Abduction involves making educated guesses based on available data, while Bayesian inference is a statistical approach used to update probabilities in light of new information. Empirical success, or the ability of a model to accurately predict observations, is also crucial for evaluating these models.

The process of considering different possibilities for the universe beyond our observable horizon can be complex and challenging. However, this complexity does not necessarily render multiverse theories unscientific. In fact, they adhere to standard scientific principles by relying on empirical evidence and established methods of evaluation.

Multiverse theories are often criticized due to concerns over the role of unobservable phenomena in legitimate scientific theories. Nevertheless, these models can be evaluated using conventional scientific approaches, making them a valid area of study within cosmology.

title: Absolute stability window and upper bound on the magnetic field strength in a strongly magnetized strange quark star
input: Magnetized strange quark stars, composed of strange quark matter (SQM) and self-bound by strong interactions, can be formed if the energy per baryon of magnetized SQM is less than that of the most stable Fe nucleus under the zero external pressure and temperature. Utilizing the MIT bag model description of magnetized SQM under charge neutrality and beta equilibrium conditions, the corresponding absolute stability window in the parameter space of the theory is determined. It is shown that there exists the maximum magnetic field strength allowed by the condition of absolute stability of magnetized SQM. The value of this field, G, represents the upper bound on the magnetic field strength which can be reached in a strongly magnetized strange quark star.

output.explanation:
Strange quark stars are hypothetical celestial objects composed of strange quark matter, a state of matter that is self-bound by strong interactions. The stability of these stars depends on the energy per baryon of magnetized SQM being less than that of iron under zero external pressure and temperature.

The MIT bag model provides a description of magnetized SQM, which involves charge neutrality - the balance between positive and negative charges within the star. Beta equilibrium is also crucial in this context, referring to a state where certain types of particles are converted into others at an equal rate.

In this scenario, strong interactions play a key role in binding strange quark matter together. The magnetization of SQM affects its stability, with the MIT bag model describing how it behaves under different conditions. Charge neutrality and beta equilibrium help determine the absolute stability window for magnetized SQM.

Within this window, there exists a maximum magnetic field strength allowed by the condition of absolute stability, denoted as G. This value represents the upper bound on the magnetic field strength that can be reached in a strongly magnetized strange quark star.

title: Descendants of the first stars: the distinct chemical signature of second generation stars
input: Extremely metal-poor (EMP) stars in the Milky Way (MW) allow us to infer the properties of their progenitors by comparing their chemical composition to the metal yields of the first supernovae. This method is most powerful when applied to mono-enriched stars, i.e. stars that formed from gas that was enriched by only one previous supernova. We present a novel diagnostic to identify this subclass of EMP stars. We model the first generations of star formation semi-analytically, based on dark matter halo merger trees that yield MW-like halos at the present day. Radiative and chemical feedback are included self-consistently and we trace all elements up to zinc. Mono-enriched stars account for only of second generation stars in our fiducial model and we provide an analytical formula for this probability. We also present a novel analytical diagnostic to identify mono-enriched stars, based on the metal yields of the first supernovae. This new diagnostic allows us to derive our main results independently from the specific assumptions made regarding Pop III star formation, and we apply it to a set of observed EMP stars to demonstrate its strengths and limitations. Our results may provide selection criteria for current and future surveys and therefore contribute to a deeper understanding of EMP stars and their progenitors.

output.explanation:
The universe's early stages are characterized by the formation of extremely metal-poor (EMP) stars within the Milky Way, which can be used to infer properties about their progenitors through comparisons with chemical composition and first supernovae yields.

In this context, 'metal-poor' refers to a low abundance of elements heavier than hydrogen and helium. Additionally, EMP stars that formed from gas enriched solely by one previous supernova are known as mono-enriched stars.

The formation process of EMP stars involves interactions between dark matter halos and gas within these systems, with radiative and chemical feedback mechanisms playing crucial roles in shaping their elemental composition. These processes determine the likelihood of mono-enriched star formation through semi-analytical modeling based on dark matter halo merger trees that yield MW-like halos at the present day.

Our model suggests that only a small fraction of second-generation stars are mono-enriched, with an analytical formula describing this probability derived from our semi-analytical model. We also introduce a novel diagnostic tool to identify these stars based on the metal yields of first supernovae, allowing us to derive results independently from specific assumptions regarding Pop III star formation and apply it to observed EMP stars.

title: How Special Is the Solar System?
input: Given the fact that Earth is so far the only place in the Milky Way galaxy known to harbor life, the question arises of whether the solar system is in any way special. To address this question, I compare the solar system to the many recently discovered exoplanetary systems. I identify two main features that appear to distinguish the solar system from the majority of other systems: (i) the lack of super-Earths, (ii) the absence of close-in planets. I examine models for the formation of super-Earths, as well as models for the evolution of asteroid belts, the rate of asteroid impacts on Earth, and of snow lines, all of which may have some implications for the emergence and evolution of life on a terrestrial planet. Finally, I revisit an argument by Brandon Carter on the rarity of intelligent civilizations, and I review a few of the criticisms of this argument.

output.explanation:
The Milky Way galaxy is a vast, star-filled expanse where planets are born and evolve.

Key terms like super-Earth refer to planets with masses significantly larger than Earth's, while close-in planets orbit their stars at extremely small distances. An asteroid belt is a region of space containing numerous rocky objects that can impact terrestrial planets.

The formation of super-Earths may be influenced by the presence and evolution of an asteroid belt, which in turn affects planetary migration and composition. The rate of asteroid impacts on Earth also plays a crucial role in shaping its environment.

The solar system appears to lack both super-Earths and close-in planets compared to other exoplanetary systems, suggesting that it may have undergone unique formation processes. This uniqueness could be linked to the absence of these features, which are common in many other planetary systems.

title: Singularities in Spherically Symmetric Solutions with Limited Curvature Invariants
input: We investigate static, spherically symmetric solutions in gravitational theories which have limited curvature invariants, aiming to remove the singularity in the Schwarzschild space-time. We find that if we only limit the Gauss-Bonnet term and the Ricci scalar, then the singularity at the origin persists. Moreover we find that the event horizon can develop a curvature singularity. We also investigate a new class of theories in which all components of the Riemann tensor are bounded. We find that the divergence of the quadratic curvature invariants at the event horizon is avoidable in this theory. However, other kinds of singularities due to the dynamics of additional degrees of freedom cannot be removed, and the space-time remains singular.

output.explanation:
The universe's gravitational forces are so strong in certain regions that they warp spacetime around massive objects like black holes, creating a phenomenon known as the Schwarzschild space-time.

In this context, curvature invariants measure how much spacetime is distorted by mass and energy. A key term to understand here is the Gauss-Bonnet term, which refers to a specific mathematical expression used to describe gravitational theories.

Theories with limited curvature invariants attempt to remove singularities from the Schwarzschild space-time. However, if only the Gauss-Bonnet term and Ricci scalar are constrained, these singularities persist at the origin of the space-time. Furthermore, high curvature on the event horizon can lead to a new type of singularity.

In another class of theories where all components of the Riemann tensor are bounded, quadratic curvature invariants do not diverge at the event horizon. Nevertheless, other types of singularities caused by additional degrees of freedom remain present, indicating that these space-times still have singularities.

title: Analysis of June 2, 2016 bolide event
input: On June 2, 2016 at 10h56m UTC, a magnitude superbolide was observed over Arizona. Fragments were located a few days later and the meteorites were given the name Dishchii'bikoh. We present analysis of this event based on 3 cameras and a multi-spectral sensor observations by the SkySentinel continuous fireball-monitoring camera network, supplemented by a dash cam footage and a fragmentation model. The bolide began its luminous flight at an altitude of km at coordinates N planetographic latitude and W longitude, and it had a pre-atmospheric velocity of km/s. The calculated orbital parameters indicate that the meteoroid did not belong to any presently known asteroid family. From our calculations, the impacting object had an initial mass of metric tonnes with an estimated initial diameter of m.

output.explanation:
The Earth's atmosphere is the setting for a rare and spectacular event, where a massive object from space enters at high speed, producing intense light and potentially causing damage upon impact. 

A key term in this context is 'superbolide,' which refers to an extremely bright meteor that outshines all other objects in the sky. Another important concept is 'pre-atmospheric velocity,' or the speed of a meteoroid before it enters Earth's atmosphere, typically measured in kilometers per second. 

The event described occurred on June 2, 2016, over Arizona, where fragments were later found and named Dishchii'bikoh. The analysis is based on observations from multiple sources: three cameras, a multi-spectral sensor, dash cam footage, and a fragmentation model. These tools allowed researchers to track the bolide's trajectory and estimate its initial mass and diameter. 

The calculated orbital parameters indicate that this meteoroid did not belong to any known asteroid family, suggesting it may be an isolated object from space. The impacting object had an estimated initial mass of metric tonnes with a corresponding diameter of meters.

title: Cosmological inference from standard sirens without redshift measurements
input: The purpose of this work is to investigate the prospects of using the future standard siren data without redshift measurements to constrain cosmological parameters. With successful detections of gravitational wave (GW) signals an era of GW astronomy has begun. Unlike the electromagnetic domain, GW signals allow direct measurements of luminosity distances to the sources, while their redshifts remain to be measured by identifying electromagnetic counterparts. This leads to significant technical problems for almost all possible BH-BH systems. It is the major obstacle to cosmological applications of GW standard sirens. In this paper, we introduce the general framework of using luminosity distances alone for cosmological inference. The idea is to use the prior knowledge of the redshift probability distribution for coalescing sources from the intrinsic merger rates assessed with population synthesis codes. Then the posterior probability distributions for cosmological parameters can be calculated. We demonstrate the performance of our method on the simulated mock data and show that the luminosity distance measurement would enable an accurate determination of cosmological parameters up to uncertainty level. We also find that in order to infer to 1% level with flat CDM model, we need about events.

output.explanation:
The universe's expansion is governed by cosmological parameters, which describe the evolution of its structure and composition.

A redshift refers to a stretching effect on light waves as they travel through expanding space, while luminosity distance measures how far away objects appear due to their intrinsic brightness. In gravitational wave astronomy, luminosity distances serve as proxies for redshifts.

The merger rates of coalescing sources are simulated using population synthesis codes, providing prior knowledge of the redshift probability distribution. This information is then combined with direct measurements from luminosity distance to calculate posterior probability distributions for cosmological parameters.

By leveraging both direct and indirect measures of cosmic distances, it becomes possible to constrain cosmological parameters up to a certain uncertainty level. The method relies on accurately modeling the redshift probability distribution from simulated merger rates.

title: OGLE-2014-BLG-0289: Precise Characterization of a Quintuple-Peak Gravitational Microlensing Event
input: We present the analysis of the binary-microlensing event OGLE-2014-BLG-0289. The event light curve exhibits very unusual five peaks where four peaks were produced by caustic crossings and the other peak was produced by a cusp approach. It is found that the quintuple-peak features of the light curve provide tight constraints on the source trajectory, enabling us to precisely and accurately measure the microlensing parallax . Furthermore, the three resolved caustics allow us to measure the angular Einstein radius . From the combination of and , the physical lens parameters are uniquely determined. It is found that the lens is a binary composed of two M dwarfs with masses and separated in projection by au. The lens is located in the disk with a distance of ~kpc. It turns out that the reason for the absence of a lensing signal in the { Spitzer} data is that the time of observation corresponds to the flat region of the light curve.

output.explanation:
The universe's disk is home to a vast array of celestial objects, including binary systems composed of two stars.

The term caustic refers to an area on the sky where the gravitational pull is so strong that it severely bends light from background sources. A cusp approach occurs when an object approaches but does not cross one of these boundaries.

The event's light curve displays five peaks, with four resulting from crossings through regions of intense gravitational influence and the remaining peak caused by a close encounter without crossing. This unusual pattern imposes strict constraints on the source's path, allowing for precise measurement of microlensing parallax. Furthermore, three distinct areas of high gravitational pull enable determination of the angular Einstein radius.

The combination of these parameters uniquely determines the physical properties of the lens: it is a binary system consisting of two M dwarfs with masses and separated by approximately au in projection. The lens is located at a distance of about kpc from Earth, situated within the disk.

title: IAU WG, Data-driven Astronomy Education and Public Outreach,current status and working plans
input: IAU Inter-Commission B2-C1-C2 WG Data-driven Astronomy Education and Public Outreach (DAEPO) was launched officially in April 2017. With the development of many mega-science astronomical projects, for example CTA, DESI, EUCLID, FAST, GAIA, JWST, LAMOST, LSST, SDSS, SKA, and large scale simulations, astronomy has become a Big Data science. Astronomical data is not only necessary resource for scientific research, but also very valuable resource for education and public outreach (EPO), especially in the era of Internet and Cloud Computing. IAU WG Data-driven Astronomy Education and Public Outreach is hosted at the IAU Division B (Facilities, Technologies and Data Science) Commission B2 (Data and Documentation), and organized jointly with Commission C1 (Astronomy Education and Development), Commission C2 (Communicating Astronomy with the Public), Office of Astronomy for Development (OAD), Office for Astronomy Outreach (OAO) and several other non IAU communities, including IVOA Education Interest Group, American Astronomical Society Worldwide Telescope Advisory Board, Zooniverse project and International Planetarium Society. The working group has the major objectives to: Act as a forum to discuss the value of astronomy data in EPO, the advantages and benefits of data driven EPO, and the challenges facing to data driven EPO; Provide guidelines, curriculum, data resources, tools, and e-infrastructure for data driven EPO; Provide best practices of data driven EPO. In the paper, backgrounds, current status and working plans in the future are introduced. More information about the WG is available at: http://daepo.china-vo.org/

output.explanation:
Astronomy has become a complex field with the development of large-scale simulations and surveys that generate vast amounts of data. This phenomenon is often referred to as Big Data, characterized by its immense volume and complexity.

The term 'data driven' refers to using large datasets for educational purposes, while EPO stands for Education and Public Outreach, a critical aspect of modern astronomy aiming to engage the general public with astronomical concepts and discoveries. In this context, data is treated as a key component in EPO efforts.

Data-driven astronomy education relies on leveraging the potential of big data, which involves examining its value, benefits, challenges, and best practices associated with using large datasets for educational purposes. The working group provides guidelines, curriculum materials, and resources to facilitate this process, including tools and e-infrastructure that enable educators to effectively utilize astronomical data.

The primary objective is to enhance the impact of EPO efforts in modern astronomy by addressing challenges and promoting best practices. This involves providing a forum for discussing the value of data in EPO efforts and offering guidelines for implementing data-driven initiatives.

title: The Sloan Digital Sky Survey Reverberation Mapping Project: the CIV Blueshift, Its Variability, and Its Dependence Upon Quasar Properties
input: We use the multi-epoch spectra of 362 quasars from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Reverberation Mapping project to investigate the dependence of the blueshift of CIV relative to MgII on quasar properties. We confirm that high-blueshift sources tend to have low CIV equivalent widths (EWs), and that the low-EW sources span a range of blueshift. Other high-ionization lines, such as HeII, also show similar blueshift properties. The ratio of the line width (measured as both the full-width at half maximum and the velocity dispersion) of CIV to that of MgII increases with blueshift. Quasar variability might enhance the connection between the CIV blueshift and quasar properties (e.g., EW). The variability of the MgII line center (i.e., the wavelength that bisects the cumulative line flux) increases with blueshift. In contrast, the CIV line center shows weaker variability at the extreme blueshifts. Quasars with the high-blueshift CIV lines tend to have less variable continuum emission, when controlling for EW, luminosity, and redshift. Our results support the scenario that high-blueshift sources tend to have large Eddington ratios.

output.explanation:
Quasars are luminous objects in the universe, emitting intense radiation and strong gravitational fields that influence gas and ion motion within their vicinity.

In this context, Eddington ratio represents the proportion of energy released through accretion to that available from a central black hole's mass-energy budget. Equivalent width (EW) is a measure of line strength relative to continuum emission. The blueshift phenomenon refers to observed displacement of certain spectral lines towards shorter wavelengths compared to their expected positions.

The interaction between quasar properties and the motion of gas and ions leads to distinct behaviors in high-ionization lines like CIV, MgII, and HeII. These lines exhibit varying degrees of blueshift depending on quasar characteristics such as EW and luminosity.

High-blueshift sources tend to have low EWs for CIV and a range of blueshift values among these sources. The ratio of line widths between CIV and MgII increases with increasing blueshift, while the variability of the MgII line center grows with blueshift. In contrast, the CIV line center shows reduced variability at extreme blueshifts. Quasars displaying high-blueshift CIV lines tend to have less variable continuum emission when accounting for factors like EW, luminosity, and redshift.

title: FSD: Frequency Space Differential measurement of CMB spectral distortions
input: Although the Cosmic Microwave Background agrees with a perfect blackbody spectrum within the current experimental limits, it is expected to exhibit certain spectral distortions with known spectral properties. We propose a new method, Frequency Space Differential (FSD) to measure the spectral distortions in the CMB spectrum by using the inter-frequency differences of the brightness temperature. The difference between the observed CMB temperature at different frequencies must agree with the frequency derivative of the blackbody spectrum, in the absence of any distortion. However, in the presence of spectral distortions, the measured inter-frequency differences would also exhibit deviations from blackbody which can be modeled for known sources of spectral distortions like . Our technique uses FSD information for the CMB blackbody, , or any other sources of spectral distortions to model the observed signal. Successful application of this method in future CMB missions can provide an alternative method to extract spectral distortion signals and can potentially make it feasible to measure spectral distortions without an internal blackbody calibrator.

output.explanation:
The universe's early stages are characterized by the Cosmic Microwave Background, a remnant of the Big Bang.

A blackbody spectrum refers to thermal radiation emitted by an idealized object in thermodynamic equilibrium, relying on Planck's law describing energy density variations across frequencies. Frequency denotes oscillations or cycles per second within electromagnetic waves.

The CMB's spectral properties are crucial for understanding its behavior and composition. The brightness temperature is a measure of the CMB's thermal radiation intensity at different frequencies. In the absence of distortions, inter-frequency differences in brightness temperature should match the frequency derivative of the blackbody spectrum.

However, when spectral distortions occur, these comparisons deviate from predicted values for a perfect blackbody. The Frequency Space Differential (FSD) method leverages this deviation to model and extract information about known sources of spectral distortions like . By applying FSD in future CMB missions, it becomes feasible to measure spectral distortions without an internal calibrator.

title: Ultraviolet Detection of the Binary Companion to the Type IIb SN 2001ig
input: We present HST/WFC3 ultraviolet imaging in the F275W and F336W bands of the Type IIb SN 2001ig at an age of more than 14 years. A clear point source is detected at the site of the explosion having and mag. Despite weak constraints on both the distance to the host galaxy NGC 7424 and the line-of-sight reddening to the supernova, this source matches the characteristics of an early B-type main sequence star having K and . A BPASS v2.1 binary evolution model, with primary and secondary masses of 13 M and 9 M respectively, is found to resemble simultaneously in the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram both the observed location of this surviving companion, and the primary star evolutionary endpoints for other Type IIb supernovae. This same model exhibits highly variable late-stage mass loss, as expected from the behavior of the radio light curves. A Gemini/GMOS optical spectrum at an age of 6 years reveals a narrow He II emission line, indicative of continuing interaction with a dense circumstellar medium at large radii from the progenitor. We review our findings on SN 2001ig in the context of binary evolution channels for stripped-envelope supernovae. Owing to the uncrowded nature of its environment in the ultraviolet, this study of SN 2001ig represents one of the cleanest detections to date of a surviving binary companion to a Type IIb supernova.

output.explanation:
The universe's most massive stars reside in regions where they can form binary systems through gravitational interactions between nearby stars, a process that affects their properties and final stages of evolution.

Key terms such as 'Hertzsprung-Russell diagram' refer to a graphical representation of stellar evolution, illustrating how stars change in brightness and color over time. In this context, it's essential to understand that main sequence stars like those found on the B-type branch are characterized by their surface temperatures and luminosities.

The process described here involves binary star systems where one component is a massive star undergoing nuclear fusion in its core. As this primary star evolves, it can transfer material onto its companion through mass loss or other mechanisms. This interaction affects both stars' properties, influencing the system's overall behavior and final stages of evolution.

A surviving companion at SN 2001ig matches characteristics expected for an early B-type main sequence star with specific mass values. A binary evolution model incorporating these parameters successfully reproduces both the location of this companion and the primary star's evolutionary endpoints in other Type IIb supernovae, exhibiting highly variable late-stage mass loss consistent with radio light curve behavior.

title: Reconstructing warm inflation
input: The reconstruction of a warm inflationary universe model from the scalar spectral index and the tensor to scalar ratio as a function of the number of e-folds is studied. Under a general formalism we find the effective potential and the dissipative coefficient in terms of the cosmological parameters and considering the weak and strong dissipative stages under the slow roll approximation. As a specific example, we study the attractors for the index given by and for the ratio , in order to reconstruct the model of warm inflation. Here, expressions for the effective potential and the dissipation coefficient are obtained.

output.explanation:
The universe is described as undergoing a period of warm inflation, characterized by the gradual expansion of space driven by potential energy. This type of cosmological evolution involves complex interactions between various fields and particles.

In this context, key observables such as the scalar spectral index and tensor to scalar ratio are crucial for understanding the model's parameters. The slow roll approximation provides an effective description of these systems in terms of their fundamental properties.

The dissipative coefficient plays a central role in characterizing the interaction between the inflaton field and other degrees of freedom, influencing the system's behavior. In particular, two regimes emerge: weak dissipation where energy density effects are minimal, and strong dissipation where the system becomes more complex.

In this framework, specific attractors can be identified for certain values of the scalar spectral index and tensor to scalar ratio, allowing for the reconstruction of warm inflation models.

title: Searching for Exoplanets Using a Microresonator Astrocomb
input: Detection of weak radial velocity shifts of host stars induced by orbiting planets is an important technique for discovering and characterizing planets beyond our solar system. Optical frequency combs enable calibration of stellar radial velocity shifts at levels required for detection of Earth analogs. A new chip-based device, the Kerr soliton microcomb, has properties ideal for ubiquitous application outside the lab and even in future space-borne instruments. Moreover, microcomb spectra are ideally suited for astronomical spectrograph calibration and eliminate filtering steps required by conventional mode-locked-laser frequency combs. Here, for the calibration of astronomical spectrographs, we demonstrate an atomic/molecular line-referenced, near-infrared soliton microcomb. Efforts to search for the known exoplanet HD 187123b were conducted at the Keck-II telescope as a first in-the-field demonstration of microcombs.

output.explanation:
The detection of planets beyond our solar system relies on measuring the subtle shifts in a star's radial velocity caused by an orbiting planet, which is typically measured using spectrographs that analyze light from stars.

To understand this process, we need to define some key terms: a Kerr soliton microcomb is a device that produces optical frequency combs through mode-locking; near-infrared radiation has wavelengths slightly longer than visible light. Mode-locking refers to the process where light pulses are created at regular intervals using a laser.

The core concept here involves understanding how these devices generate spectra with equally spaced lines, which can be used as a reference for calibration in astronomical spectrography. This is particularly useful because microcomb spectra eliminate the need for filtering steps required by conventional frequency combs.

In this context, an atomic/molecular line-referenced near-infrared soliton microcomb was demonstrated and tested at the Keck-II telescope to search for the exoplanet HD 187123b. The device's properties make it suitable for use outside the lab due to its compact size and low power consumption.

title: Formation of trans-Neptunian satellite systems at the stage of condensations
input: The formation of trans-Neptunian satellite systems at the stage of rarefied preplanetesimals (i.e., condensations of dust and/or objects less than 1 m in diameter) is discussed. It is assumed that trans-Neptunian objects (including those with satellites) could form as a result of compression of parental rarefied preplanetesimals. The formulas for calculating the angular momentum of two colliding condensations with respect to their center of mass, which were applied earlier in (Ipatov, 2010) in the comparison of such momenta with the angular momenta of observed satellite systems, are used to estimate the angular momenta of condensations needed to form satellite systems. It is demonstrated that the angular velocities of condensations used in (Nesvorny et al., 2010) as the initial data in the computer simulation of compression of rarefied preplanetesimals and subsequent formation of trans-Neptunian satellite systems may be obtained in collisions of preplanetesimals with their radii comparable to the corresponding Hill radii. For example, these angular velocities are in the range of possible values of angular velocities of a parental rarefied preplanetesimal formed as a result of a merger of two colliding rarefied preplanetesimals that moved in circular heliocentric orbits before a collision. Some rarefied preplanetesimals formed as a result of collision of preplanetesimals in the region of formation of solid small bodies acquire such angular momenta that are sufficient to form satellite systems of small bodies. It is likely that the ratio of the number of rarefied preplanetesimals with such angular momenta to the total number of rarefied preplanetesimals producing classical trans-Neptunian objects with diameters larger than 100 km was 0.45 (the initial fraction of satellite systems among all classical trans-Neptunian objects).

output.explanation:
The solar system's outer reaches, beyond Neptune, are home to a vast array of small bodies and celestial objects.

A rarefied preplanetesimal is defined as a condensation of dust or smaller objects less than 1 m in diameter. The term 'rarefied' refers to the low density of these preplanetesimals. In contrast, classical trans-Neptunian objects are larger bodies with diameters greater than 100 km.

The process by which rarefied preplanetesimals compress and form larger bodies is crucial for understanding satellite system formation. When two condensations collide, they transfer angular momentum, a key factor in determining whether satellites will form. The Hill radius plays a significant role in this context, marking the distance from a celestial body where its gravitational influence becomes substantial.

The mechanism of satellite system formation involves collisions between preplanetesimals with radii comparable to their respective Hill radii. This transfer of angular momentum can lead to the acquisition of sufficient angular momenta by some rarefied preplanetesimals, enabling them to form small body satellite systems. The ratio of these preplanetesimals to those producing classical trans-Neptunian objects larger than 100 km may have been around a certain value, indicating that a significant portion of such objects could potentially host satellite systems.

title: VLBA Determination of the Distance to Nearby Star-forming Regions. VIII. The LkH 101 cluster
input: The LkH 101 cluster takes its name from its more massive member, the LkH 101star, which is an M star whose true nature is still unknown. The distance to the LkH 101 cluster has been controversial for the last few decades, with estimated values ranging from 160 to 800 pc. We have observed members and candidate members of the LkH 101 cluster with signs of magnetic activity, using the Very Long Baseline Array, in order to measure their trigonometric parallax and, thus, obtain a direct measurement of their distances. A young star member, LkH 101 VLA J043001.15+351724.6, was detected at four epochs as a single radio source. The best fit to its displacement on the plane of the sky yields a distance of 535 29 pc. We argue that this is the distance to the LkH 101 cluster.

output.explanation:
The LkH 101 cluster resides in a region of the galaxy where young stars and their associated magnetic fields are prevalent.

The term 'magnetic activity' refers to the manifestation of strong magnetic fields on or near the surface of these stars, often resulting in intense radiation and charged particle emissions.

A key concept relevant to this study is trigonometric parallax, a method used to determine an object's distance by measuring its apparent shift against a background of more distant objects when viewed from different angles.

The LkH 101 cluster contains various young star members, including the radio-emitting source LkH 101 VLA J043001.15+351724.6, which was observed at multiple epochs to track its movement across the sky. By analyzing this displacement, researchers have derived a distance estimate of approximately 535 parsecs for this particular member and, by extension, the entire cluster.

title: Primordial Black Holes - Perspectives in Gravitational Wave Astronomy -
input: This is a review article on the primordial black holes (PBHs), with particular focus on the massive ones ( ) which have not evaporated by the present epoch by the Hawking radiation. By the detections of gravitational waves by LIGO, we have gained a completely novel tool to observationally search for PBHs complementary to the electromagnetic waves. Based on the perspective that gravitational-wave astronomy will make a significant progress in the next decades, a purpose of this article is to give a comprehensive review covering a wide range of topics on PBHs. After discussing PBH formation as well as several inflation models leading to PBH production, we summarize various existing and future observational constraints. We then present topics on formation of PBH binaries, gravitational waves from PBH binaries, various observational tests of PBHs by using gravitational waves.

output.explanation:
Primordial black holes are formed in the early universe, particularly massive ones that have not yet evaporated through Hawking radiation by the present epoch. These objects exist within a big-picture setting of cosmic structure formation and evolution. 

The concept of primordial black hole is closely tied to inflation models leading to their production. Inflation refers to an extremely rapid expansion phase in the early universe, smoothing out any irregularities. Key terms include inflationary era, during which space expands exponentially, and density perturbations, small fluctuations that can eventually form structures like galaxies or PBHs. 

The interaction between primordial black holes and gravitational waves is a crucial aspect of their study. Gravitational waves are ripples in spacetime produced by violent cosmic events such as the merger of two compact objects. The detection of these waves by LIGO has opened up new avenues for observing PBHs, complementing traditional electromagnetic observations. 

The formation and evolution of massive primordial black hole binaries is a significant area of study. These binary systems can produce characteristic gravitational wave signatures that are distinct from other astrophysical sources.

title: The Radial Velocity Variability of the K-giant Gamma Draconis: Stellar Variability Masquerading as a Planet
input: We present precise stellar radial velocity measurements of Gamma Dra taken from 2003 to 2017. The data from 2003 to 2011 show coherent, long-lived variations with a period of 702 d. These variations are consistent with the presence of a planetary companion having m sin i = 10.7 M_Jup whose orbital properties are typical for giant planets found around evolved stars. An analysis of the Hipparcos photometry, Ca II S-index measurements, and measurements of the spectral line shapes during this time show no variations with the radial velocity of the planet which seems to "confirm"' the presence of the planet. However, radial velocity measurements taken 2011 -- 2017 seem to refute this. From 2011 to 2013 the radial velocity variations virtually disappear only to return in 2014, but with a noticeable phase shift. The total radial velocity variations are consistent either with amplitude variations on timescales of ~ 10.6 yr, or the beating effect between two periods of 666 d and 801 d. It seems unlikely that both these signals stem from a two-planet system. A simple dynamical analysis indicates that there is only a 1-2 % chance that the two-planet is stable. Rather, we suggest that this multi-periodic behavior may represent a new form of stellar variability, possibly related to oscillatory convective modes. If such intrinsic stellar variability is common around K giant stars and is attributed to planetary companions, then the planet occurrence rate among these stars may be significantly lower than thought.

output.explanation:
Stellar radial velocity measurements are used to study the motion of stars, particularly those that may be hosting planets. Radial velocity is a measure of how much a star's position appears to shift along our line of sight due to gravitational forces exerted by orbiting bodies.

In this context, key terms like 'm sin i' refer to the minimum mass of a planet calculated using its orbital period and the inclination angle between our line of sight and the plane of its orbit. The term 'K giant stars' describes a class of evolved stars that have exhausted their hydrogen fuel and expanded in size.

The presence of a planetary companion can cause radial velocity variations, which are periodic changes in the star's motion towards or away from us. These variations can be caused by either amplitude changes on timescales of about 10.6 years or the beating effect between two periods of approximately 666 days and 801 days.

The observed behavior suggests that Gamma Dra exhibits multi-periodic radial velocity variations, which may represent a new form of stellar variability related to oscillatory convective modes. This could imply that intrinsic stellar activity is common among K giant stars and mistakenly attributed to planetary companions, leading to an underestimation of the planet occurrence rate in these stars.

title: Power-Law Statistics Of Driven Reconnection In The Magnetically Closed Corona
input: Numerous observations have revealed that power-law distributions are ubiquitous in energetic solar processes. Hard X-rays, soft X-rays, extreme ultraviolet radiation, and radio waves all display power-law frequency distributions. Since magnetic reconnection is the driving mechanism for many energetic solar phenomena, it is likely that reconnection events themselves display such power-law distributions. In this work, we perform numerical simulations of the solar corona driven by simple convective motions at the photospheric level. Using temperature changes, current distributions, and Poynting fluxes as proxies for heating, we demonstrate that energetic events occurring in our simulation display power-law frequency distributions, with slopes in good agreement with observations. We suggest that the braiding-associated reconnection in the corona can be understood in terms of a self-organized criticality model driven by convective rotational motions similar to those observed at the photosphere.

output.explanation:
The sun's outer atmosphere, the corona, is a complex region where magnetic fields play a crucial role in driving energetic processes.

The term 'power-law distribution' refers to a statistical pattern where events occur with frequencies that decrease as their intensity increases, often described by an inverse power of the event size. In contrast, 'self-organized criticality' (SOC) is a concept describing systems that exist in a state of perpetual instability, where small changes can lead to large-scale effects.

The corona's magnetic field lines become tangled and eventually break due to convective motions at the sun's surface, releasing energy in the form of X-rays and other forms of radiation. This process is thought to be responsible for braiding-associated reconnection, a phenomenon that can be understood through an SOC model driven by rotational flows similar to those observed at the photosphere.

The simulations demonstrate that energetic events occurring within this system display power-law frequency distributions with slopes in agreement with observations, suggesting that magnetic reconnection may indeed exhibit such characteristics.

title: Origin of orbits of secondaries in the discovered trans-Neptunian binaries
input: The dependences of inclinations of orbits of secondaries in the discovered trans-Neptunian binaries on the distance between the primary and the secondary, on the eccentricity of orbits of the secondary around the primary, on the ratio of diameters of the secondary and the primary, and on the elements of heliocentric orbits of these binaries are studied. These dependences are interpreted using the model of formation of a satellite system in a collision of two rarefied condensations composed of dust and/or objects less than 1 m in diameter. It is assumed in this model that a satellite system forms in the process of compression of a condensation produced in such a collision. The model of formation of a satellite system in a collision of two condensations agrees with the results of observations: according to observational data, approximately 40% of trans-Neptunian binaries have a negative angular momentum relative to their centers of mass.

output.explanation:
The vast expanse of our solar system, beyond Neptune's orbit, is home to numerous binary systems consisting of two celestial bodies gravitationally bound together.

In the context of these trans-Neptunian binaries, key terms like 'rarefied condensations' refer to loosely bound collections of particles. These can be composed of dust or small objects less than 1 m in diameter. The term 'negative angular momentum' signifies a specific orientation in the orbital plane.

The process by which these satellite systems form is thought to involve collisions between such rarefied condensations. Compression plays a crucial role in shaping the resulting system's angular momentum, leading to the observed inclinations of orbits around their centers of mass. The model suggests that this compression occurs as a result of the collision.

According to observational data, approximately 40% of trans-Neptunian binaries exhibit negative angular momentum relative to their centers of mass. This finding supports the proposed model's agreement with observations.

title: Neutron Anomalous Magnetic Moment in Dense Magnetized Systems
input: In this work, we calculate the neutron anomalous magnetic moment supposing that this value can depend on the density and magnetic field of system. We employ the lowest order constraint variation (LOCV) method and nuclear potential to calculate the medium dependency of the neutron anomalous magnetic moment. It is confirmed that the neutron anomalous magnetic moment increases by increasing the density, while it decreases as the magnetic field grows. The energy and equation of state for the system have also been investigated.

output.explanation:
The physical setting for this study involves the behavior of neutrons in a system where density and magnetic field play crucial roles.

The key terms here are 'neutron anomalous magnetic moment', which refers to an intrinsic property of neutrons, and 'lowest order constraint variation' (LOCV) method, a mathematical approach used to calculate this property's dependence on the system's conditions. The neutron anomalous magnetic moment is essentially a measure of how much a neutron's spin deviates from its expected behavior in the presence of a magnetic field.

The mechanism at play involves the interaction between neutrons and their environment, specifically the density and magnetic field of the system. As the density increases, the neutron anomalous magnetic moment grows, while it decreases as the magnetic field strengthens. This suggests that the neutron's spin behavior is influenced by both its surroundings and the external magnetic field.

The study also explores the energy and equation of state for this system, providing further insight into how neutrons behave in different conditions.

title: Mapping low frequency carbon radio recombination lines towards Cassiopeia A at 340, 148, 54 and 43 MHz
input: Quantitative understanding of the interstellar medium requires knowledge of its physical conditions. Low frequency carbon radio recombination lines (CRRLs) trace cold interstellar gas, and can be used to determine its physical conditions (e.g., electron temperature and density). In this work we present spatially resolved observations of the low frequency ( MHz) CRRLs centered around C , C , C and C towards Cassiopeia A on scales of pc. We compare the spatial distribution of CRRLs with other ISM tracers. This comparison reveals a spatial offset between the peak of the CRRLs and other tracers, which is very characteristic for photodissociation regions and that we take as evidence for CRRLs being preferentially detected from the surfaces of molecular clouds. Using the CRRLs we constrain the gas electron temperature and density. These constraints on the gas conditions suggest variations of less than a factor of two in pressure over pc scales, and an average hydrogen density of - cm . From the electron temperature and density maps we also constrain the ionized carbon emission measure, column density and path length. Based on these, the hydrogen column density is larger than cm , with a peak of cm towards the South of Cassiopeia A. Towards the southern peak the line of sight length is pc over a pc wide structure, which implies that the gas is a thin surface layer on a large (molecular) cloud that is only partially intersected by Cassiopeia A. These observations highlight the utility of CRRLs as tracers of low density extended HI and CO-dark gas halo's around molecular clouds.

output.explanation:
The interstellar medium is a vast, diffuse gas that permeates the universe and contains various forms of matter such as molecular clouds and atomic species like carbon. 

The term photodissociation regions refers to areas where intense radiation from nearby stars breaks down molecular clouds, leading to ionization and characteristic spatial offsets between different types of interstellar medium tracers. In this context, low frequency carbon radio recombination lines (CRRLs) serve as valuable indicators of cold interstellar gas conditions such as electron temperature and density. 

The CRRL process involves the collision of electrons with neutral atoms, releasing energy in the form of radiation at specific frequencies typically measured in MHz. The spatial distribution of CRRLs can be used to infer physical parameters like pressure variations over pc scales and average hydrogen densities (approximately - cm). 

Based on these findings, the hydrogen column density is found to be larger than cm towards the southern peak of Cassiopeia A, indicating that the gas forms a thin surface layer on a large molecular cloud only partially intersected by Cassiopeia A.

title: A magnetar model for the hydrogen-rich super-luminous supernova iPTF14hls
input: Transient surveys have recently revealed the existence of H-rich super-luminous supernovae (SLSN; e.g., iPTF14hls, OGLE-SN14-073) characterized by an exceptionally large time-integrated bolometric luminosity, a sustained blue optical color, and Doppler-broadened HI lines at all times. Here, I investigate the effect that a magnetar (initial rotational energy of 4x10^50erg and field strength of 7x10^13G) would have on the properties of a typical Type II SN ejecta (mass of 13.35Msun, kinetic energy of 1.32x10^51erg, 0.077Msun of 56Ni) produced by the terminal explosion of an H-rich blue-supergiant star. I present a non-LTE time-dependent radiative transfer simulation of the resulting photometric and spectroscopic evolution from 1d until 600d after explosion. With magnetar power, the model luminosity and brightness are enhanced, the ejecta is everywhere hotter and more ionised, and the spectrum formation region is much more extended. This magnetar-powered SN ejecta reproduces most of the observed properties of SLSN iPTF14hls, including the sustained brightness of -18mag in the R band, the blue optical color, and the broad HI lines for 600d. The non-extreme magnetar properties, combined with the standard Type II SN ejecta properties offer an interesting alternative to the pair-unstable super-massive star model recently proposed, which involves a highly-energetic and super-massive ejecta. Hence, such Type II SLSNe may differ from standard Type II SNe exclusively through the influence of a magnetar.

output.explanation:
Supernovae are massive stellar explosions that release enormous energy into space, influencing the surrounding environment. A magnetar is a type of neutron star with an incredibly strong magnetic field and rotational energy.

Key terms to understand in this context include non-LTE radiative transfer, which refers to situations where radiation and matter are not in thermal equilibrium, and super-luminous supernovae (SLSNe), characterized by exceptionally large time-integrated bolometric luminosity. Additionally, a Type II SN ejecta is produced by the terminal explosion of an H-rich blue-supergiant star.

When a magnetar interacts with the ejecta from a typical Type II supernova, it can significantly alter its properties through non-LTE radiative transfer simulations that account for complex interactions between light and matter. The magnetar's influence causes the model luminosity and brightness to increase, resulting in hotter and more ionized ejecta.

The combination of non-extreme magnetar properties with standard Type II supernova ejecta characteristics offers an interesting alternative explanation for SLSNe like iPTF14hls, which may differ from typical Type II supernovae solely due to the presence of a magnetar.

title: Atmospheric Beacons of Life from Exoplanets Around G and K Stars
input: The current explosion in detection and characterization of thousands of extrasolar planets from the Kepler mission, the Hubble Space Telescope, and large ground-based telescopes opens a new era in searches for Earth-analog exoplanets with conditions suitable for sustaining life. As more Earth-sized exoplanets are detected in the near future, we will soon have an opportunity to identify habitable worlds. Which atmospheric biosignature gases from habitable planets can be detected with our current capabilities? The detection of the common biosignatures from nitrogen-oxygen rich terrestrial-type exoplanets including molecular oxygen (O2), ozone (O3), water vapor (H2O), carbon dioxide (CO2), nitrous oxide (N2O), and methane (CH4) requires days of integration time with largest space telescopes, and thus are very challenging for current instruments. In this paper we propose to use the powerful emission from rotational-vibrational bands of nitric oxide, hydroxyl and molecular oxygen as signatures of nitrogen, oxygen, and water rich atmospheres of terrestrial type exoplanets highlighted by the magnetic activity from young G and K main-sequence stars. The signals from these fundamental chemical prerequisites of life we call atmospheric beacons of life create a unique opportunity to perform direct imaging observations of Earth-sized exoplanets with high signal-to-noise and low spectral resolution with the upcoming NASA missions.

output.explanation:
The search for life beyond Earth is centered in the habitable zones of extrasolar planets where conditions allow liquid water to exist, a phenomenon linked to planetary formation and atmospheric properties.

Key terms such as rotational-vibrational bands refer to specific patterns of light emitted by molecules when they rotate or vibrate. This process is related to molecular structure and energy states, which are influenced by the presence of nitrogen, oxygen, and other elements in an atmosphere. Nitrogen-oxygen rich atmospheres emit powerful signals from nitric oxide, hydroxyl, and molecular oxygen due to magnetic activity in young G and K main-sequence stars.

The interaction between these atmospheric components creates a unique opportunity for direct imaging observations of Earth-sized exoplanets with high signal-to-noise and low spectral resolution. The detection of atmospheric beacons of life relies on the emission patterns from rotational-vibrational bands, which are fundamental components necessary for life in terrestrial-type exoplanets.

The signals from nitric oxide, hydroxyl, and molecular oxygen can be detected directly using upcoming NASA missions, offering a new era in searches for Earth-analog exoplanets with conditions suitable for sustaining life. This detection method is particularly useful for identifying habitable worlds due to its ability to bypass the challenges associated with detecting common biosignatures such as O2, O3, H2O, CO2, N2O, and CH4.

title: Magnetic Flux Cancelation as the Trigger of Solar Coronal-Hole Coronal Jets
input: We investigate in detail the magnetic cause of minifilament eruptions that drive coronal-hole jets. We study 13 random on-disk coronal hole jet eruptions, using high resolution X-ray images from Hinode/XRT, EUV images from SDO/AIA, and magnetograms from SDO/HMI. For all 13 events, we track the evolution of the jet-base region and find that a minifilament of cool (transition-region-temperature) plasma is present prior to each jet eruption. HMI magnetograms show that the minifilaments reside along a magnetic neutral line between majority-polarity and minority-polarity magnetic flux patches. These patches converge and cancel with each other, with an average cancelation rate of ~0.6 X 10$^18 Mx hr^{-1} for all 13 jets. Persistent flux cancelation at the neutral line eventually destabilizes the minifilament field, which erupts outward and produces the jet spire. Thus, we find that all 13 coronal-hole-jet-driving minifilament eruptions are triggered by flux cancelation at the neutral line. These results are in agreement with our recent findings Panesar et al 2016b for quiet-region jets, where flux cancelation at the underlying neutral line triggers the minifilament eruption that drives each jet. Thus from that study of quiet-Sun jets and this study of coronal hole jets, we conclude that flux cancelation is the main candidate for triggering quiet region and coronal hole jets

output.explanation:
The sun's corona is a region where intense magnetic activity occurs, involving hot plasma and strong magnetic fields.

A minifilament is a small region of cool plasma that resides along the boundary between areas with opposite magnetic polarities. Magnetic neutral lines are regions where these oppositely charged magnetic fields meet. Flux patches refer to areas of concentrated magnetic field strength.

When flux patches converge, they cancel each other out, releasing energy in the process. This energy release can destabilize a minifilament, causing it to erupt outward as a coronal-hole jet. The rate at which this cancellation occurs is measured by tracking changes in magnetic field strength over time.

Flux cancellation at the neutral line triggers all 13 observed coronal-hole-jet-driving minifilament eruptions, with an average cancelation rate of ~0.6 X 10$^18 Mx hr^{-1}$ for these events.

title: A Radio Continuum Study of Dwarf Galaxies: 6 cm imaging of Little Things
input: In this paper we examine to what extent the radio continuum can be used as an extinction free probe of star formation in dwarf galaxies. To that aim we observe nearby dwarf galaxies with the Very Large Array at 6 cm ( - GHz) in C-configuration. We obtained images with - resolution and noise levels of - . We detected emission associated with of the dwarf galaxies, of which are new detections. The general picture is that of an interstellar medium largely devoid of radio continuum emission, interspersed by isolated pockets of emission associated with star formation. We find an average thermal fraction of - % and an average magnetic field strength of - , only slightly lower than that found in larger, spiral galaxies. At 100 pc scales, we find surprisingly high values for the average magnetic field strength of up to 50 . We find that dwarf galaxies follow the theoretical predictions of the radio continuum-star formation rate relation within regions of significant radio continuum emission but that the non-thermal radio continuum is suppressed relative to the star formation rate when considering the entire optical disk. We examine the far-infrared-star formation rate relation for our sample and find that the far-infrared is suppressed compared to the expected star formation rate. We discuss explanations for these observed relations and the impact of our findings on the radio continuum-far-infrared relation. We conclude that radio continuum emission at centimetre wavelengths has the promise of being a largely extinction-free star formation rate indicator. We find that star formation rates of gas rich, low mass galaxies can be estimated with an uncertainty of dex between the values of and .

output.explanation:
Dwarf galaxies reside in a vast, diffuse environment where star formation is a complex process.

The radio continuum emission observed at 6 cm wavelengths can be understood through the concept of thermal fraction and non-thermal fraction. Thermal fraction refers to the proportion of radio continuum emission originating from ionized gas, while non-thermal fraction accounts for synchrotron radiation. The latter is suppressed relative to star formation rate in dwarf galaxies when considering their entire optical disk.

The suppression of non-thermal radio continuum emission and far-infrared-star formation rate relation can be attributed to the interaction between magnetic fields and ionized gas within these galaxies. At smaller scales, surprisingly high values for average magnetic field strength up to 50 are observed. This suggests that dwarf galaxies follow theoretical predictions of the radio continuum-star formation rate relation within regions of significant radio continuum emission but deviate from it when considering their entire optical disk.

The findings indicate that star formation rates in gas-rich, low-mass galaxies can be estimated with an uncertainty of dex between and .

title: Optimal and fast E/B separation with a dual messenger field
input: We adapt our recently proposed dual messenger algorithm for spin field reconstruction and showcase its efficiency and effectiveness in Wiener filtering polarized cosmic microwave background (CMB) maps. Unlike conventional preconditioned conjugate gradient (PCG) solvers, our preconditioner-free technique can deal with high-resolution joint temperature and polarization maps with inhomogeneous noise distributions and arbitrary mask geometries with relative ease. Various convergence diagnostics illustrate the high quality of the dual messenger reconstruction. In contrast, the PCG implementation fails to converge to a reasonable solution for the specific problem considered. The implementation of the dual messenger method is straightforward and guarantees numerical stability and convergence. We show how the algorithm can be modified to generate fluctuation maps, which, combined with the Wiener filter solution, yield unbiased constrained signal realizations, consistent with observed data. This algorithm presents a pathway to exact global analyses of high-resolution and high-sensitivity CMB data for a statistically optimal separation of E and B modes. It is therefore relevant for current and next-generation CMB experiments, in the quest for the elusive primordial B-mode signal.

output.explanation:
The cosmic microwave background radiation is a faint glow that permeates the universe, originating from the Big Bang event.

Polarized CMB maps contain fluctuations in temperature and polarization patterns, which encode valuable information about the early cosmos.
The dual messenger algorithm for spin field reconstruction enables efficient processing of high-resolution joint temperature and polarization maps with varying noise distributions and complex mask geometries.

Key terms include: Wiener filtering, preconditioned conjugate gradient solvers, numerical stability, convergence diagnostics. Wiener filtering is a technique used to reduce noise in CMB maps, while preconditioned conjugate gradient solvers are conventional methods that require preprocessing for efficient computation.
The dual messenger algorithm achieves numerical stability and convergence without the need for preconditioning.

The mechanism involves reconstructing spin fields from polarized CMB maps using the dual messenger method. This process enables the generation of fluctuation maps, which can be combined with Wiener filter solutions to produce unbiased constrained signal realizations consistent with observed data.
The algorithm's efficiency and effectiveness in handling high-resolution joint temperature and polarization maps make it a valuable tool for current and next-generation CMB experiments seeking to separate E and B modes. It presents a pathway to exact global analyses of high-resolution and high-sensitivity CMB data, particularly relevant for the quest to detect primordial B-mode signals.

title: INTEGRAL results on the electromagnetic counterparts of gravitational waves
input: Thanks to its high orbit and a set of complementary detectors providing continuous coverage of the whole sky, the INTEGRAL satellite has unique capabilities for the identification and study of the electromagnetic radiation associated to gravitational waves signals and, more generally, for multi-messenger astrophysics. Here we briefly review the results obtained during the first two observing runs of the advanced LIGO/Virgo interferometers.

output.explanation:
The vastness of space allows for the existence of satellites in high orbits, enabling them to observe electromagnetic radiation from various directions.

The term 'multi-messenger astrophysics' refers to the study of cosmic events through multiple forms of observation, including gravitational waves and electromagnetic signals.

Gravitational waves are ripples in spacetime produced by massive cosmic events such as black hole mergers or supernovae explosions. These waves carry information about their sources and can be detected using laser interferometers like LIGO/Virgo. The detection of gravitational waves opens up new avenues for multi-messenger astrophysics, where electromagnetic observations complement the data from gravitational wave detectors.

The advanced LIGO/Virgo interferometers have been operating in a way that allows them to provide continuous coverage of the whole sky, enabling scientists to study electromagnetic radiation associated with gravitational waves and other cosmic events.

title: Advances in mean-field dynamo theory and applications to astrophysical turbulence
input: Recent advances in mean-field theory are reviewed and applications to the Sun, late-type stars, accretion disks, galaxies, and the early Universe are discussed. We focus particularly on aspects of spatio-temporal nonlocality, which is one of the main insights that emerged from applying the test-field method to magnetic fields of different length and timescales. We also review the status of nonlinear quenching and the relation to magnetic helicity, which is an important observational diagnostic of modern solar dynamo theory. Both solar and some stellar dynamos seem to operate in an intermediate regime that has not yet been possible to model successfully. This regime is bracketed by antisolar-like differential rotation on one end and stellar activity cycles belonging to the superactive stars on the other. The difficulty in modeling this regime may be related to shortcomings in modelling solar/stellar convection. On galactic and extragalactic length scales, the observational constraints are still less stringent and uncertain, but recent advances both in theory and in observations suggest that more conclusive comparisons may soon be possible. The possibility of inversely cascading magnetic helicity throughout all of the early Universe is particularly exciting in explaining the lower limits of magnetic fields on cosmological length scales and the possibility of parity breaking and finite helicity of such a field.

output.explanation:
The universe is home to a vast array of celestial objects, including stars, galaxies, and accretion disks, which are all governed by complex magnetic fields.

Magnetic helicity refers to the amount of twist in these magnetic field lines, while spatio-temporal nonlocality describes how different parts of the field interact with each other over time and space. The test-field method is a tool used to study this phenomenon.

The interaction between magnetic helicity and nonlinear quenching is crucial for understanding modern solar dynamo theory. Nonlinear quenching occurs when the strength of the magnetic field affects its own generation, leading to complex behavior in systems like the Sun's magnetic field. The difficulty in modeling certain regimes, such as those found in superactive stars, may be due to limitations in simulating convection processes.

The possibility of inversely cascading magnetic helicity throughout the early Universe has significant implications for our understanding of cosmic magnetic fields and their role in shaping the universe's evolution.

title: Detecting Electron Density Fluctuations from Cosmic Microwave Background Polarization using a Bispectrum Approach
input: Recent progress in high sensitivity Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) polarization experiments opens up a window on large scale structure (LSS), as CMB polarization fluctuations on small angular scales can arise from a combination of LSS and ionization fluctuations in the late universe. Gravitational lensing effects can be extracted from CMB datasets with quadratic estimators but reconstructions of electron density fluctuations (EDFs) with quadratic estimators are found to be significantly biased by the much larger lensing effects in the secondary CMB fluctuations. In this paper we establish a bispectrum formalism using tracers of LSS to extract the subdominant EDFs from CMB polarization data. We find that this bispectrum can effectively reconstruct angular band-powers of cross correlation between EDFs and LSS tracers. Next generation CMB polarization experiments in conjunction with galaxy surveys and cosmic infrared background experiments can detect signatures of EDFs with high significance.

output.explanation:
The universe's large-scale structure is a complex web of galaxy clusters and superclusters, with matter distributed throughout the cosmos. Large scale structure (LSS) refers to the distribution of galaxies on vast scales, while Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) polarization fluctuations are tiny variations in the CMB's temperature and polarization patterns.

The term LSS encompasses the collective properties of these galaxy distributions, which can be influenced by various astrophysical processes. In contrast, primordial fluctuations refer to the initial perturbations that seeded structure formation in the early universe. The distinction between these two types is crucial for understanding the origins of cosmic structures.

Gravitational lensing effects distort light from distant sources as it passes through the gravitational field of foreground matter. This distortion can be isolated using quadratic estimators, but its impact on electron density fluctuations (EDFs) is significant due to their subdominant nature compared to secondary CMB fluctuations caused by lensing.

The bispectrum formalism developed in this work uses tracers of LSS to extract EDFs from CMB polarization data. By analyzing the cross-correlation between these fluctuations and their corresponding tracers, researchers can effectively measure angular band-powers representing the subdominant EDFs. Next-generation experiments will be able to detect signatures of EDFs with high significance by combining CMB polarization measurements with galaxy surveys and cosmic infrared background observations.

title: The IRON Project: Photoionization of Fe ions
input: The IRON Project, initiated in 1991, aims at two main objectives, i) study the characteristics of and calculate large-scale high accuracy data for atomic radiative and collisional processes, and ii) application in solving astrophysical problems. It focuses on the complex iron and iron-peak elements commonly observed in the spectra of astrophysical plasmas. The present report will illustrate the characteristics of the dominant atomic process of photoionization that have been established under the project and the preceding the Opacity Project and their importance in applications.

output.explanation:
Astrophysical plasmas are complex, ionized gases found throughout the universe, often emitting spectra that reveal their composition and temperature.

Photoionization cross-sections describe how easily atoms absorb photons at different energies. These cross-sections are crucial for accurately modeling astrophysical plasmas. The Opacity Project has established a foundation for understanding these processes.

The photoionization process involves the absorption of photons by iron and its peak elements, leading to their ionization. This process is essential in determining the physical conditions within these plasmas. By accurately modeling this process, scientists can gain insights into the chemical composition of distant stars and galaxies.

Photoionization plays a crucial role in astrophysical problems involving iron and its peak elements. The IRON Project has established high-accuracy data for photoionization cross-sections, enabling researchers to better understand these processes and solve various astrophysical problems.

title: Frequency Reference Stability and Coherence Loss in Radio Astronomy Interferometers Application to the SKA
input: The requirements on the stability of the frequency reference in the Square Kilometre Array (SKA), as a radio astronomy interferometer, are given in terms of maximum accepted degree of coherence loss caused by the instability of the frequency reference.
