The resulting field structures are shaped by the interplay between the magnetic field's strength and the rotation period.

The study of white dwarfs with variable magnetic fields reveals a large diversity in their field structure, from simple dipole configurations to complex patterns featuring spots or multiple poles. This diversity may hold clues to understanding how these magnetic fields form in the first place.

title: A detached stellar-mass black hole candidate in the globular cluster NGC 3201
input: As part of our massive spectroscopic survey of 25 Galactic globular clusters with MUSE, we performed multiple epoch observations of NGC 3201 with the aim of constraining the binary fraction. In this cluster, we found one curious star at the main-sequence turn-off with radial velocity variations of the order of 100 km/s, indicating the membership to a binary system with an unseen component since no other variations appear in the spectra. Using an adapted variant of the generalized Lomb-Scargle periodogram, we could calculate the orbital parameters and found the companion to be a detached stellar-mass black hole with a minimum mass of 4.36 0.41 solar masses. The result is an important constraint for binary and black hole evolution models in globular clusters as well as in the context of gravitational wave sources.

output.explanation:
Galactic globular clusters are densely packed star systems found in the Milky Way's halo, containing a diverse range of stellar populations and binary systems.

A key term to understand is radial velocity: it measures an object's motion along our line of sight, typically expressed in units of speed or km/s. Another important concept is orbital parameters, which describe the characteristics of an orbit, such as its period and eccentricity.

The presence of a binary system with a detached stellar-mass black hole can be inferred from radial velocity variations. In this case, a star at the main-sequence turn-off exhibited a variation of 100 km/s, indicating membership to a binary system with an unseen component. The orbital parameters were calculated using an adapted variant of the generalized Lomb-Scargle periodogram.

The result revealed that the companion is a detached stellar-mass black hole with a minimum mass of approximately 4.36 solar masses.

title: Supernova Neutrino Detection in LZ
input: In the first 10 seconds of a core-collapse supernova, almost all of its progenitor's gravitational potential, O(10 ~ergs), is carried away in the form of neutrinos. These neutrinos, with O(10~MeV) kinetic energy, can interact via coherent elastic neutrino-nucleus scattering (CE NS) depositing O(1~keV) in detectors. In this work, we demonstrate that low-background dark matter detectors, such as LUX-ZEPLIN (LZ), optimized for detecting low-energy depositions, are capable of detecting these neutrino interactions. For instance, a 27~M supernova at 10~kpc is expected to produce 350 neutrino interactions in the 7-tonne liquid xenon active volume of LZ. Based on the LS220 EoS neutrino flux model for a SN, the Noble Element Simulation Technique (NEST), and predicted CE NS cross-sections for xenon, to study energy deposition and detection of SN neutrinos in LZ. We simulate the response of the LZ data acquisition system (DAQ) and demonstrate its capability and limitations in handling this interaction rate. We present an overview of the LZ detector, focusing on the benefits of liquid xenon for supernova neutrino detection. We discuss energy deposition and detector response simulations and their results. We present an analysis technique to reconstruct the total number of neutrinos and the time of the supernova core bounce.

output.explanation:
A core-collapse supernova's gravitational potential is released as neutrinos in the first 10 seconds, carrying O(10 ~ergs) of energy and possessing kinetic energies of O(10~MeV). These high-energy particles can interact with nuclei via coherent elastic neutrino-nucleus scattering (CE NS), depositing around O(1~keV) in detectors. 

The core concept here involves the interaction between neutrinos, nuclei, and detector materials like liquid xenon. CE NS is a process where neutrinos scatter off atomic nuclei without exchanging energy or momentum, resulting in minimal energy loss for the neutrino but depositing around O(1~keV) of energy in the nucleus. 

The key to understanding this phenomenon lies in coherent elastic scattering and its dependence on nuclear properties like spin and isospin. In detectors optimized for low-energy depositions, such as LUX-ZEPLIN (LZ), these interactions can be detected. For instance, a 27~M supernova at 10~kpc would produce approximately 350 neutrino interactions in the 7-tonne liquid xenon active volume of LZ. 

The detector's response to this interaction rate is simulated using techniques like NEST and predicted CE NS cross-sections for xenon. The Noble Element Simulation Technique (NEST) models energy deposition, while predicted cross-sections describe the likelihood of these interactions occurring in liquid xenon.

title: An explosion is triggered by the late collapse of the compact remnant from a neutron star merger
input: It is known that a binary neutron star merger produces a hypermassive neutron star. The lifetime of this compact remnant depends on the total mass and the equation of state. The collapse of this compact remnant to a black- hole-torus system is expected to give rise to a powerful jet and a short gamma-ray burst. Nevertheless, if the collapse is delayed half a second or so, the surrounding matter would be already accreted and/or expelled and hence no torus will be formed. However, the collapse itself will give rise to a quasi-isotropic magnetized fireball. This magnetic bomb will dissipate much of its energy due to magnetic re-connection and will produce the prompt emission, when the fireball will become transparent to gamma-rays. The energy range of such an explosion depends on the initial magnetic field strength of the two neutron stars and the amplification of the magnetic energy during merger. We discuss the production of a quasi-isotropic magnetized fireball and its subsequent interaction with the ejected matter during merger, as the outcome of the coalescence of a binary neutron star system. We further discuss a possible origin for the duration of the burst and the radial stratification of the flow following the quasi-normal modes of the black hole.

output.explanation:
Binary neutron star mergers create compact remnants known as hypermassive neutron stars, which have a limited lifetime influenced by their mass and the equation of state governing their behavior. 

The collapse of these remnants into black-hole-torus systems is expected to produce powerful jets and short gamma-ray bursts. However, if this process is delayed by half a second or more, surrounding matter may be accreted or expelled before torus formation can occur. Instead, the collapse generates a quasi-isotropic magnetized fireball, often referred to as a magnetic bomb. 

The energy released from this fireball is dissipated through magnetic reconnection, producing prompt emission when it becomes transparent to gamma-rays. The explosion's energy range depends on the initial magnetic field strengths of the neutron stars and the amplification of their magnetic energies during merger. 

A quasi-isotropic magnetized fireball forms as a result of binary neutron star coalescence, interacting with ejected matter in the process. This interaction is crucial to understanding burst duration and radial flow stratification following black hole quasi-normal modes.

title: Warm Quasi-Single Field Inflation
input: We study quasi-single field inflation with a warm inflation background. The thermal effects at small scales can sufficiently enhance the magnitude of the primordial standard clock signal. This scenario offers us the possibility of probing the UV physics of the very early universe without the exponentially small Boltzmann factor when the mass of the isocurvaton is much heavier than Hubble. The thermal effects at small scales can be studied using the flat space thermal field theory, connected to an effective description using non-Bunch-Davies vacuum at large scales, with large clock signal.

output.explanation:
The universe underwent a period of rapid expansion in the very early stages, known as inflation. This era is characterized by an exponential growth of space and time.

Inflation can be divided into two categories: astrophysical and primordial. The distinction between these two types lies in their respective origins and scales. Astrophysical phenomena occur on larger scales, while primordial events take place at the earliest moments after the Big Bang.

Key terms that appear in this context include inflationary background, which refers to a universe with a non-zero temperature and entropy density; quasi-single field, describing a scalar field driving expansion; thermal effects, arising from particle interactions in a hot environment; flat space thermal field theory, an effective description of large-scale phenomena; and non-Bunch-Davies vacuum, a theoretical framework for understanding the early universe.

The warm inflation background enables the study of thermal effects at small scales. These effects can enhance the magnitude of the primordial standard clock signal without being suppressed by the exponentially small Boltzmann factor when the mass of the isocurvaton exceeds Hubble's scale.

title: Electromagnetic emission from blitzars and its impact on non-repeating fast radio bursts
input: It has been suggested that a non-repeating fast radio burst (FRB) represents the final signal of a magnetized neutron star collapsing to a black hole. In this model, a supramassive neutron star supported by rapid rotation, will collapse to a black hole several thousand to million years after its birth as a result of spin down. The collapse violently snaps the magnetic-field lines anchored on the stellar surface, thus producing an electromagnetic pulse that will propagate outwards and accelerate electrons producing a massive radio burst, i.e. a "blitzar". We present a systematic study of the gravitational collapse of rotating and magnetised neutron stars with special attention to far-field evolution at late times after the collapse. By considering a series of neutron stars with rotation ranging from zero to millisecond periods and different magnetic-field strengths, we show that the blitzar emission is very robust and always characterised by a series sub-millisecond pulses decaying exponentially in amplitude. The luminosity and energy released when the magnetosphere is destroyed are well reproduced by a simple expression in terms of the stellar magnetic field and radius. Finally, we assess the occurrence of pair production during a blitzar scenario, concluding that for typical magnetic-field strengths of and spin frequencies of a few Hz, pair production is suppressed. Overall, the very good match between the results of the simulations and the luminosities normally observed for FRBs lends credibility to the blitzar model as a simple and yet plausible explanation for the phenomenology of non-repeating FRBs.

output.explanation:
The collapse of a magnetized neutron star into a black hole is thought to produce an intense electromagnetic pulse, known as a blitzar. This phenomenon occurs when the magnetic-field lines anchored on the stellar surface are violently snapped during the collapse. The resulting radio burst can be massive and is characterized by a series of sub-millisecond pulses decaying exponentially in amplitude.

The process begins with a supramassive neutron star supported by rapid rotation, which eventually collapses to a black hole after several thousand to million years due to spin down. This collapse triggers the emission of electromagnetic radiation that accelerates electrons and produces the radio burst. The luminosity and energy released during this event can be described using a simple expression in terms of the stellar magnetic field and radius.

The simulations considered neutron stars with varying rotation periods, ranging from zero to millisecond periods, and different magnetic-field strengths. The results show that the blitzar emission is robust and consistent across these scenarios. Additionally, pair production during a blitzar event was found to be suppressed for typical magnetic-field strengths of several Gauss and spin frequencies of a few Hz.

The model's predictions match well with observed luminosities for non-repeating fast radio bursts (FRBs), lending credibility to the blitzar scenario as an explanation for their phenomenology.

title: Towards a theoretical determination of the geographical probability distribution of meteoroid impacts on Earth
input: Tunguska and Chelyabinsk impact events occurred inside a geographical area of only 3.4\% of the Earth's surface. Although two events hardly constitute a statistically significant demonstration of a geographical pattern of impacts, their spatial coincidence is at least tantalizing. To understand if this concurrence reflects an underlying geographical and/or temporal pattern, we must aim at predicting the spatio-temporal distribution of meteoroid impacts on Earth. For this purpose we designed, implemented and tested a novel numerical technique, the "Gravitational Ray Tracing" (GRT) designed to compute the relative impact probability (RIP) on the surface of any planet. GRT is inspired by the so-called ray-casting techniques used to render realistic images of complex 3D scenes. In this paper we describe the method and the results of testing it at the time of large impact events. Our findings suggest a non-trivial pattern of impact probabilities at any given time on Earth. Locations at from the apex are more prone to impacts, especially at midnight. Counterintuitively, sites close to apex direction have the lowest RIP, while in the antapex RIP are slightly larger than average. We present here preliminary maps of RIP at the time of Tunguska and Chelyabinsk events and found no evidence of a spatial or temporal pattern, suggesting that their coincidence was fortuitous. We apply the GRT method to compute theoretical RIP at the location and time of 394 large fireballs. Although the predicted spatio-temporal impact distribution matches marginally the observed events, we successfully predict their impact speed distribution.

output.explanation:
The Earth's surface is a complex system with diverse geographical features, including mountains and oceans that can affect the trajectory of incoming meteoroids. The study focuses on understanding how these factors influence the likelihood of impacts at different locations and times.

Key terms in this context include 'apex', which refers to the direction from which most comets originate, and 'antapex', its opposite direction. Additionally, 'Gravitational Ray Tracing' (GRT) is a numerical technique used to compute relative impact probabilities (RIP).

The GRT method works by simulating the path of meteoroids as they approach the Earth's surface, taking into account gravitational forces and other factors that affect their trajectory. This allows researchers to predict where impacts are more likely to occur at any given time.

According to the study, locations near the apex direction have a lower relative impact probability (RIP), while areas opposite to this direction have slightly higher RIP values than average. The research also found that sites far from the apex direction are more prone to impacts, especially around midnight.

title: Probing the BSM physics with CMB precision cosmology: an application to supersymmetry
input: The cosmic history before the BBN is highly determined by the physics that operates beyond the Standard Model (BSM) of particle physics and it is poorly constrained observationally. Ongoing and future precision measurements of the CMB observables can provide us with significant information about the pre-BBN era and hence possibly test the cosmological predictions of different BSM scenarios. Supersymmetry is a particularly motivated BSM theory and it is often the case that different superymmetry breaking schemes require different cosmic histories with specific reheating temperatures or low entropy production in order to be cosmologically viable. In this paper we quantify the effects of the possible alternative cosmic histories on the and CMB observables assuming a generic non-thermal stage after cosmic inflation. We analyze TeV and especially multi-TeV supersymmetry breaking schemes assuming the neutralino and gravitino dark matter scenarios. We complement our analysis considering the Starobinsky inflation model to exemplify the improved CMB predictions that a unified description of the early universe cosmic evolution yields. Our analysis underlines the importance of the CMB precision measurements that can be viewed, to some extend, as complementary to the laboratory experimental searches for supersymmetry or other BSM theories.

output.explanation:
The universe's early history is shaped by the interplay between astrophysical and primordial processes, with a focus on the pre-Big Bang Nucleosynthesis era. 

The term 'Beyond-Standard Model' (BSM) refers to physics operating beyond the Standard Model of particle physics, while Supersymmetry (SUSY) is a motivated BSM theory that requires distinct cosmic histories for different SUSY breaking schemes. The non-relativistic nature of particles in certain regimes can lead to suppression effects on their behavior. 

The universe's evolution after inflation involves a generic non-thermal stage, where particles interact non-classically. This scenario enables the analysis of alternative cosmic histories' effects on CMB observables, particularly focusing on TeV and multi-TeV SUSY breaking schemes within neutralino and gravitino dark matter frameworks. 

The precision measurements of CMB observables can provide significant information about pre-BBN era secrets, potentially testing cosmological predictions from various BSM theories like Supersymmetry or other motivated scenarios. The analysis underlines the importance of these precision measurements as a complementary approach to laboratory searches for supersymmetry.

title: Forecasting Solar Flares Using Magnetogram-based Predictors and Machine Learning
input: We propose a forecasting approach for solar flares based on data from Solar Cycle 24, taken by the Helioseismic and Magnetic Imager (HMI) on board the Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO) mission. In particular, we use the Space-weather HMI Active Region Patches (SHARP) product that facilitates cut-out magnetograms of solar active regions (AR) in the Sun in near-real-time (NRT), taken over a five-year interval (2012 - 2016). Our approach utilizes a set of thirteen predictors, which are not included in the SHARP metadata, extracted from line-of-sight and vector photospheric magnetograms. We exploit several Machine Learning (ML) and Conventional Statistics techniques to predict flares of peak magnitude >M1 and >C1, within a 24 h forecast window. The ML methods used are multi-layer perceptrons (MLP), support vector machines (SVM) and random forests (RF). We conclude that random forests could be the prediction technique of choice for our sample, with the second best method being multi-layer perceptrons, subject to an entropy objective function. A Monte Carlo simulation showed that the best performing method gives accuracy ACC=0.93(0.00), true skill statistic TSS=0.74(0.02) and Heidke skill score HSS=0.49(0.01) for >M1 flare prediction with probability threshold 15% and ACC=0.84(0.00), TSS=0.60(0.01) and HSS=0.59(0.01) for >C1 flare prediction with probability threshold 35%.

output.explanation:
The Sun is a massive ball of hot, glowing gas that is the center of our solar system. Solar flares are intense bursts of radiation and high-energy particles that occur when magnetic energy builds up in the Sun's surface.

A magnetogram is a visual representation of the magnetic field at the Sun's surface, while photosphere refers to the visible layer of the Sun's atmosphere where light is produced. An active region (AR) on the Sun is an area with strong magnetic fields that can trigger solar flares.

The forecasting approach uses machine learning and conventional statistics techniques to analyze data from line-of-sight and vector photospheric magnetograms, which contain information about the strength and orientation of magnetic fields in the Sun's surface. These methods identify patterns in the magnetogram data associated with flares of peak magnitude >M1 and >C1.

The results show that random forests outperform other methods for predicting these events within a 24-hour forecast window, achieving high accuracy rates.

title: Fast Generation of Covariance Matrices for Weak Lensing
input: Upcoming weak lensing surveys will probe large fractions of the sky with unprecedented accuracy. To infer cosmological constraints, a large ensemble of survey simulations are required to accurately model cosmological observables and their covariances. We develop a parallelized multi-lens-plane pipeline called UFalcon, designed to generate full-sky weak lensing maps from lightcones within a minimal runtime. It makes use of L-PICOLA, an approximate numerical code, which provides a fast and accurate alternative to cosmological -Body simulations. The UFalcon maps are constructed by nesting 2 simulations covering a redshift-range from to without replicating the simulation volume. We compute the convergence and projected overdensity maps for L-PICOLA in the lightcone or snapshot mode. The generation of such a map, including the L-PICOLA simulation, takes about 3 hours walltime on 220 cores. We use the maps to calculate the spherical harmonic power spectra, which we compare to theoretical predictions and to UFalcon results generated using the full -Body code GADGET-2. We then compute the covariance matrix of the full-sky spherical harmonic power spectra using 150 UFalcon maps based on L-PICOLA in lightcone mode. We consider the PDF, the higher-order moments and the variance of the smoothed field variance to quantify the accuracy of the covariance matrix, which we find to be a few percent for scales to . We test the impact of this level of accuracy on cosmological constraints using an optimistic survey configuration, and find that the final results are robust to this level of uncertainty. The speed and accuracy of our developed pipeline provides a basis to also include further important features such as masking, varying noise and will allow us to compute covariance matrices for models beyond CDM. [abridged]

output.explanation:
The universe's large-scale structure is shaped by gravitational forces that act on vast scales, creating a complex web of matter and energy. Key terms in this context include cosmological observables, which describe the distribution of mass and light across the sky; covariances, which quantify the relationships between these observables; and redshift-range, which refers to the range of distances over which we observe objects.

The UFalcon pipeline operates by combining multiple simulations that cover a specific redshift-range without replicating simulation volumes. This process involves using L-PICOLA, an approximate numerical code that provides fast and accurate results for cosmological -Body simulations. By nesting these simulations together, UFalcon generates full-sky weak lensing maps from lightcones within a minimal runtime.

The mechanism behind UFalcon's efficiency lies in its ability to compute convergence and projected overdensity maps using L-PICOLA in the lightcone or snapshot mode. This allows for the creation of detailed maps that describe how matter is distributed across different scales, which are then used to calculate power spectra. The accuracy of these power spectra was compared to theoretical predictions and found to be within a few percent for certain ranges.

The speed and accuracy of UFalcon's pipeline provide a basis for computing covariance matrices for models beyond CDM, allowing researchers to explore new possibilities in cosmological constraints.

title: Experiments Indicate Regolith is Looser in the Lunar Polar Regions than at the Lunar Landing Sites
input: Since the Apollo program or earlier it has been widely believed that the lunar regolith was compacted through vibrations including nearby impact events, thermal stress release in the regolith, deep moon quakes, and shallow moon quakes. Experiments have shown that vibrations both compact and re-loosen regolith as a function of depth in the lunar soil column and amplitude of the vibrational acceleration. Experiments have also identified another process that is extremely effective at compacting regolith: the expansion and contraction of individual regolith grains due to thermal cycling in the upper part of the regolith where the diurnal thermal wave exists. Remote sensing data sets from the Moon suggest that the soil is less compacted in regions where there is less thermal cycling, including infrared emissions measured by the Diviner radiometer on the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter (LRO). Here, we performed additional experiments in thermal cycling simulated lunar regolith and confirm that it is an effective compaction mechanism and may explain the remote sensing data. This creates a consistent picture that the soil really is looser in the upper layers in polar regions, which may be a challenge for rovers that must drive in the looser soil.

output.explanation:
The lunar regolith is a complex system influenced by various physical processes, primarily occurring on the Moon's surface and subsurface. The upper part of the regolith experiences diurnal thermal waves, causing individual grains to expand and contract due to temperature fluctuations. This phenomenon is known as thermal cycling. 

The key concept here involves understanding the behavior of lunar soil under different conditions. Thermal cycling can be defined as the process by which individual regolith grains undergo expansion and contraction in response to changes in ambient temperature. The diurnal thermal wave refers to the daily variation in temperature that occurs on the Moon's surface, resulting from the balance between solar radiation and radiative cooling. 

The mechanism of compaction through thermal cycling involves the repeated expansion and contraction of individual regolith grains, leading to a gradual increase in density as the grains pack more tightly together. This process is particularly effective in the upper part of the regolith where the diurnal thermal wave exists. The effectiveness of this mechanism has been confirmed by experiments simulating lunar conditions, which have shown that it can lead to significant compaction of the soil. 

The remote sensing data from the Moon suggests that regions with less thermal cycling exhibit looser soil, consistent with the idea that thermal cycling is an effective compaction mechanism.

title: Cosmological constraints from low-redshift data
input: In this paper we summarise the constraints that low-redshift data --such as supernovae Ia (SN Ia), baryon acoustic oscillations (BAO) and cosmic chronometers (CC)-- are able to set on the concordance model and its extensions, as well as on inhomogeneous but isotropic models. We provide a broad overlook into these cosmological scenarios and several aspects of data analysis. In particular, we review a number of systematic issues of SN Ia analysis that include magnitude correction techniques, selection bias and their influence on the inferred cosmological constraints. Furthermore, we examine the isotropic and anisotropic components of the BAO data and their individual relevance for cosmological model-fitting. We extend the discussion presented in earlier works regarding the inferred dynamics of cosmic expansion and its present rate from the low-redshift data. Specifically, we discuss the cosmological constraints on the accelerated expansion and related model-selections. In addition, we extensively talk about the Hubble constant problem, then focus on the low-redshift data constraint on that is based on CC. Finally, we present the way in which this result compares the two of high-redshift estimate and local (redshift zero) measurements that are in tension.

output.explanation:
The universe's large-scale structure and evolution are shaped by its cosmological parameters, which can be constrained using low-redshift data such as supernovae Ia (SN Ia), baryon acoustic oscillations (BAO), and cosmic chronometers (CC). These datasets provide information about the concordance model and its extensions, as well as inhomogeneous but isotropic models. 

The key concept of redshift is crucial here: it measures how much light from distant objects has been stretched due to the expansion of space. Redshift zero corresponds to our local universe, while low-redshift data refers to observations at relatively small distances. Supernovae Ia are used as 'standard candles' to measure cosmic distances and infer cosmological parameters. 

The term isotropic refers to uniformity in all directions, whereas anisotropic describes variations or asymmetries. BAO data can be decomposed into these two components: the isotropic part provides information about the universe's expansion history, while the anisotropic component reveals potential deviations from this picture. 

The Hubble constant problem arises when different measurements of this fundamental parameter yield conflicting results. Low-redshift data, particularly CC, offer a unique perspective on this issue by constraining the present rate of cosmic expansion and its acceleration.

title: A radio frequency study of the accreting millisecond X-ray pulsar, IGR J16597 3704, in the globular cluster NGC 6256
input: We present Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array radio frequency observations of the new accreting millisecond X-ray pulsar (AMXP), IGR J16597 3704, located in the globular cluster NGC 6256. With these data, we detect a radio counterpart to IGR J16597 3704, and determine an improved source position. Pairing our radio observations with quasi-simultaneous Swift/XRT X-ray observations, we place IGR J16597 3704 on the radio -- X-ray luminosity plane, where we find that IGR J16597 3704 is one of the more radio-quiet neutron star low-mass X-ray binaries known to date. We discuss the mechanisms that may govern radio luminosity (and in turn jet production and evolution) in AMXPs. Further, we use our derived radio position to search for a counterpart in archival Hubble Space Telescope and Chandra X-ray Observatory data, and estimate an upper limit on the X-ray luminosity of IGR J16597 3704 during quiescence.

output.explanation:
A neutron star in the globular cluster is surrounded by a disk of accreting material, which can lead to intense X-ray emission and jet formation. Key terms include: AMXP (accreting millisecond X-ray pulsar), characterized by its short pulse period; radio-quiet neutron stars, with low levels of radio emission; and neutron star low-mass X-ray binaries, systems where a companion star transfers matter onto the neutron star.

The interaction between accretion disk and neutron star leads to jet production. The mechanisms governing radio luminosity in AMXPs are complex, involving factors such as jet evolution. By analyzing quasi-simultaneous observations from multiple telescopes, researchers can better comprehend these processes and their impact on neutron star behavior.

Radio waves emanating from IGR J16597-3704 indicate the presence of a jet. The detection of radio counterparts is crucial for understanding AMXP behavior. In turn, this information helps to place systems like IGR J16597-3704 on the radio-X-ray luminosity plane.

IGR J16597-3704 exhibits low levels of radio emission, making it one of the more radio-quiet neutron star low-mass X-ray binaries known to date. The system's behavior during quiescence can be inferred by searching for a counterpart in archival Hubble Space Telescope and Chandra X-ray Observatory data.

title: The Propitious Role of Solar Energetic Particles in the Origin of Life
input: We carry out 3-D numerical simulations to assess the penetration and bombardment effects of Solar Energetic Particles (SEPs), i.e. high-energy particle bursts during large flares and superflares, on ancient and current Mars. We demonstrate that the deposition of SEPs is non-uniform at the planetary surface, and that the corresponding energy flux is lower than other sources postulated to have influenced the origin of life. Nevertheless, SEPs may have been capable of facilitating the synthesis of a wide range of vital organic molecules (e.g. nucleobases and amino acids). Owing to the relatively high efficiency of these pathways, the overall yields might be comparable to (or even exceed) the values predicted for some conventional sources such as electrical discharges and exogenous delivery by meteorites. We also suggest that SEPs could have played a role in enabling the initiation of lightning. A notable corollary of our work is that SEPs may constitute an important mechanism for prebiotic synthesis on exoplanets around M-dwarfs, thereby mitigating the deficiency of biologically active ultraviolet radiation on these planets. Although there are several uncertainties associated with (exo)planetary environments and prebiotic chemical pathways, our study illustrates that SEPs represent a potentially important factor in understanding the origin of life.

output.explanation:
The Sun's high-energy particle bursts, known as Solar Energetic Particles (SEPs), interact with the Martian environment in complex ways. SEPs are comprised of charged particles accelerated to extremely high energies during large flares and superflares.

Key terms such as 'energy flux' refer to the rate at which energy from SEPs is transferred to the Martian environment, while 'Solar Energetic Particles' describe these bursts of energetic particles originating from the Sun. The term 'M-dwarfs' refers to a class of low-mass stars that are cooler and less luminous than the Sun.

The interaction between SEPs and organic molecules in the Martian soil may have facilitated the synthesis of vital compounds like nucleobases and amino acids, potentially rivaling conventional sources such as electrical discharges or meteorite impacts. This process relies on efficient energy conversion into chemical bonds. Furthermore, SEPs might have played a role in initiating lightning events by providing energetic input to overcome atmospheric resistance.

The deposition of SEPs at the Martian surface is non-uniform, resulting in varying energy flux levels across different regions due to complex interplay between SEP particle trajectories and planetary factors.

title: Resolving discrete pulsar spin-down states with current and future instrumentation
input: An understanding of pulsar timing noise offers the potential to improve the timing precision of a large number of pulsars as well as facilitating our understanding of pulsar magnetospheres. For some sources, timing noise is attributable to a pulsar switching between two different spin-down rates . Such transitions may be common but difficult to resolve using current techniques. In this work, we use simulations of -variable pulsars to investigate the likelihood of resolving individual transitions. We inject step-changes in the value of with a wide range of amplitudes and switching timescales. We then attempt to redetect these transitions using standard pulsar timing techniques. The pulse arrival-time precision and the observing cadence are varied. Limits on detectability based on the effects such transitions have on the timing residuals are derived. With the typical cadences and timing precision of current timing programs, we find we are insensitive to a large region of parameter space which encompasses small, short timescale switches. We find, where the rotation and emission states are correlated, that using changes to the pulse shape to estimate transition epochs, can improve detectability in certain scenarios. The effects of cadence on detectability are discussed and we make comparisons with a known population of intermittent and mode-switching pulsars. We conclude that for short timescale, small switches, cadence should not be compromised when new generations of ultra-sensitive radio telescopes are online.

output.explanation:
Pulsars are found in the magnetosphere, a region where electromagnetic forces dominate.

The spin-down rate is defined as the rate at which pulsars lose rotational energy due to magnetic braking and radiation losses.
The -variable pulsar refers to a type of neutron star with varying rotation periods. The pulse arrival-time precision measures how accurately we can determine when pulses arrive from these stars.

In some cases, timing noise arises from sudden changes in the spin-down rate, causing the pulsar to switch between two distinct modes. This phenomenon may occur frequently but remains challenging to detect using current methods. By analyzing the effects on pulse arrival-time precision and observing cadence, limits on detectability were derived.

Current timing programs are insensitive to a significant region of parameter space, encompassing small, short-timescale switches. However, by utilizing changes in pulse shape to estimate transition epochs, improved detectability can be achieved in certain scenarios.

title: Spitzer Microlensing Parallax for OGLE-2016-BLG-1067: a sub-Jupiter Orbiting an M-dwarf in the Disk
input: We report the discovery of a sub-Jupiter mass planet orbiting beyond the snow line of an M-dwarf most likely in the Galactic disk as part of the joint Spitzer and ground-based monitoring of microlensing planetary anomalies toward the Galactic bulge. The microlensing parameters are strongly constrained by the light curve modeling and in particular by the Spitzer-based measurement of the microlens parallax, . However, in contrast to many planetary microlensing events, there are no caustic crossings, so the angular Einstein radius, has only an upper limit based on the light curve modeling alone. Additionally, the analysis leads us to identify 8 degenerate configurations: the four-fold microlensing parallax degeneracy being doubled by a degeneracy in the caustic structure present at the level of the ground-based solutions. To pinpoint the physical parameters, and at the same time to break the parallax degeneracy, we make use of a series of arguments: the hierarchy, the Rich argument, and a prior Galactic model. The preferred configuration is for a host at with mass , orbited by a Saturn-like planet with at projected separation , about 2.1 times beyond the system snow line. Therefore, it adds to the growing population of sub-Jupiter planets orbiting near or beyond the snow line of M-dwarfs discovered by microlensing. Based on the rules of the real-time protocol for the selection of events to be followed up with Spitzer, this planet will not enter the sample for measuring the Galactic distribution of planets.

output.explanation:
The galaxy is composed of various stellar populations, including M-dwarfs - low-mass stars that are cooler and less massive than the Sun.

M-dwarf systems can host planets with masses ranging from those similar to Neptune's mass up to sub-Jupiter mass planets. The snow line marks a critical boundary in these systems where temperatures allow volatile compounds to condense into ice, enabling gas giant formation beyond this distance.

Microlensing events occur when the gravitational field of an object bends and focuses light from background sources, creating characteristic patterns that can be used to infer properties about the foreground object. In this case, the microlensing parameters are constrained by both light curve modeling and Spitzer-based measurements of the microlens parallax.

The analysis reveals eight degenerate configurations due to a combination of parallax and caustic structure degeneracies. To resolve these ambiguities, arguments such as the hierarchy, Rich's argument, and prior Galactic models are employed. The preferred configuration involves a host star at with mass , orbited by a Saturn-like planet with projected separation  about 2.1 times beyond its snow line.

title: Surface density: a new parameter in the fundamental metallicity relation of star-forming galaxies
input: Star-forming galaxies display a close relation among stellar mass, metallicity and star-formation rate (or molecular-gas mass). This is known as the fundamental metallicity relation (FMR) (or molecular-gas FMR), and it has a profound implication on models of galaxy evolution. However, there still remains a significant residual scatter around the FMR. We show here that a fourth parameter, the surface density of stellar mass, reduces the dispersion around the molecular-gas FMR. In a principal component analysis of 29 physical parameters of 41,338 star-forming galaxies, the surface density of stellar mass is found to be the fourth most important parameter. The new four-dimensional fundamental relation forms a tighter hypersurface that reduces the metallicity dispersion to 50\% of that of the molecular-gas FMR. We suggest that future analyses and models of galaxy evolution should consider the FMR in a four-dimensional space that includes surface density. The dilution time scale of gas inflow and the star-formation efficiency could explain the observational dependence on surface density of stellar mass.

output.explanation:
Galaxies undergoing star formation exist within a vast, dynamic universe governed by gravity and the laws of physics.

Metallicity refers to the abundance of elements heavier than hydrogen and helium in a galaxy's gas and stars. Star-forming galaxies exhibit a fundamental relationship among these quantities, known as the fundamental metallicity relation (FMR). This relationship has significant implications for models of galaxy evolution, but it still exhibits considerable scatter.

The surface density of stellar mass is a critical factor influencing this relationship. It represents the amount of stellar material condensed within a given area of a galaxy. The dilution time scale of gas inflow and star-formation efficiency could explain the observational dependence on surface density of stellar mass, which affects how galaxies form stars.

The inclusion of surface density in the fundamental metallicity relation reduces its dispersion by half, indicating that it plays a substantial role in shaping galaxy evolution.

title: Rates and delay times of Type Ia supernovae in the helium-enriched main-sequence donor scenario
input: The nature of the progenitors of Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) remains a mystery. Comparing theoretical rates and delay-time distributions of SNe Ia with those inferred observationally can constrain their progenitor models. In this work, taking thermohaline mixing into account in the helium-enriched main-sequence (HEMS) donor scenario, we address rates and delay times of SNe Ia in this channel by combining the results of self-consistent binary evolution calculations with population synthesis models. We find that the Galactic SN Ia rate from the HEMS donor scenario is around 0.6-1.2 per century, which is about 30% of the observed rate. Delay times of SNe Ia in this scenario cover a wide range of 0.1-1.0 Gyr. We also present the pre-explosion properties of companion stars in the HEMS donor scenario, which will be helpful for placing constraints on SN Ia progenitors through analyzing their pre-explosion images.

output.explanation:
The universe's core is home to massive stars and binary systems, where intense gravitational forces drive complex interactions between celestial bodies.

Thermohaline mixing refers to the process of combining two fluids with different densities, while helium-enriched main-sequence (HEMS) donors are stars that have been enriched with helium through mass transfer in binary systems. HEMS donors play a crucial role in the evolution of these binary systems by redistributing elements within their interiors.

In this scenario, HEMS donors interact with companion stars through mass exchange, leading to the formation of Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia). The rate at which SNe Ia occur from this channel is determined by the balance between the number of binary systems and the time it takes for them to produce a SN Ia. This process involves complex interactions between the donor stars and their companion stars.

The Galactic SN Ia rate from HEMS donors ranges from 0.6-1.2 per century, accounting for approximately 30% of observed SNe Ia rates. Delay times between binary system formation and SN Ia explosion span a wide range of 0.1-1.0 Gyr.

title: Rings and gaps in the disc around Elias 24 revealed by ALMA
input: We present Atacama Large Millimeter/sub-millimeter Array (ALMA) Cycle 2 observations of the 1.3 mm dust continuum emission of the protoplanetary disc surrounding the T Tauri star Elias 24 with an angular resolution of ( au). The dust continuum emission map reveals a dark ring at a radial distance of ( au) from the central star, surrounded by a bright ring at ( au). In the outer disc, the radial intensity profile shows two inflection points at and ( and au respectively). We perform global three-dimensional smoothed particle hydrodynamic gas/dust simulations of discs hosting a migrating and accreting planet. Combining the dust density maps of small and large grains with three dimensional radiative transfer calculations, we produce synthetic ALMA observations of a variety of disc models in order to reproduce the gap- and ring-like features observed in Elias 24. We find that the dust emission across the disc is consistent with the presence of an embedded planet with a mass of at an orbital radius of 60 au. Our model suggests that the two inflection points in the radial intensity profile are due to the inward radial motion of large dust grains from the outer disc. The surface brightness map of our disc model provides a reasonable match to the gap- and ring-like structures observed in Elias 24, with an average discrepancy of 5% of the observed fluxes around the gap region.

output.explanation:
The protoplanetary disc is a region where gas and dust interact, surrounding young stars like Elias 24.

A key term in this context is 'protoplanetary disc', referring to a rotating disk of gas and dust that surrounds young stars. The T Tauri star is characterized by strong stellar winds and intense magnetic activity. Large grains are crucial for understanding dust emission in these environments because they can absorb and re-emit radiation efficiently.

The interaction between large grains, other particles, and the embedded planet determines the overall appearance of the system, including its gap- and ring-like structures. The presence of an embedded planet with a mass at an orbital radius influences the motion of large grains through inward radial motion.

This gives rise to observed inflection points in the radial intensity profile, located at and (and au respectively). The system's behavior is consistent with the presence of this embedded planet, suggesting that the two inflection points are due to the inward radial motion of large dust grains from the outer disc.

title: Finding Mountains with Molehills: The Detectability of Exotopography
input: Mountain ranges, volcanoes, trenches, and craters are common on rocky bodies throughout the Solar System, and we might we expect the same for rocky exoplanets. With ever larger telescopes under design and a growing need to not just detect planets but also to characterize them, it is timely to consider whether there is any prospect of remotely detecting exoplanet topography in the coming decades. To test this, we devised a novel yet simple approach to detect and quantify topographical features on the surfaces of exoplanets using transit light curves. If a planet rotates as it transits its parent star, its changing silhouette yields a time-varying transit depth, which can be observed as an apparent and anomalous increase in the photometric scatter. Using elevation data for several rocky bodies in our solar system, we quantify each world's surface integrated relief with a "bumpiness" factor, and calculate the corresponding photometric scatter expected during a transit. Here we describe the kinds of observations that would be necessary to detect topography in the ideal case of Mars transiting a nearby white dwarf star. If such systems have a conservative occurrence rate of 10%, we estimate that the upcoming Colossus or OWL telescopes would be able to detect topography with <20 hours of observing time, which corresponds to ~400 transits with a duration of 2 minutes and orbital period of ~10 hours.

output.explanation:
The Solar System's rocky bodies are characterized by diverse topographical features such as mountain ranges and craters, which suggests that similar landscapes might exist on exoplanets.

Topography refers to the physical properties of a planet's surface, including its elevation data, relief, and 'bumpiness' factor. The bumpiness factor is used to quantify a world's surface integrated relief by analyzing elevation data for various planets in our solar system.

When a planet rotates as it transits its parent star, changes in its silhouette yield time-varying transit depths that can be detected through observations of apparent and anomalous increases in photometric scatter. This phenomenon is due to the varying brightness caused by the changing shape of the planet.

The detection of topography on exoplanets using transit light curves from telescopes like Colossus or OWL appears feasible, assuming a conservative occurrence rate of 10% for suitable systems. These instruments could potentially detect bumpiness with less than 20 hours of observing time.

title: Another look at AM Herculis radio-astrometric campaign with the e-EVN at 6 cm
input: We conducted radio-interferometric observations of the well known binary cataclysmic system AM Herculis. This particular system is formed by the magnetic white dwarf (primary) and the red dwarf (secondary), and is the prototype of so-called polars. Our observations were conducted with the European VLBI Network (EVN) in the e-EVN mode at 5 GHz. We obtained six astrometric measurements spanning one year, which make it possible to update the annual parallax for this system with the best precision to date ( mas), equivalent to the distance of pc. The system was observed mostly in the quiescent phase (visual magnitude ), when the radio emission was at the level of about Jy. Our analysis suggests that the radio flux of AM Herculis is modulated with the orbital motion. Such specific properties of the radiation can be explained using the emission mechanism similar to the scenario proposed for V471 Tauri and, in general, for RS CVn type stars. In this scenario the radio emission arises near the surface of the red dwarf, where the global magnetic field strength may reach a few kG. We argue that the quiescent radio emission distinguishes AM Herculis together with AR Ursae Majoris (the second known persistent radio polar) from other polars, as the systems with a magnetized secondary star.

output.explanation:
The binary system AM Herculis is a cataclysmic system consisting of a magnetic white dwarf and a red dwarf, with the latter's global magnetic field playing a crucial role in its behavior. A key term to understand here is 'cataclysmic system,' which refers to a binary system where mass transfer occurs from one star to another. In this context, another important concept is the 'quiescent phase,' during which the binary system's visual magnitude remains relatively constant. 

The global magnetic field strength of the red dwarf can reach several kilogauss (kG), influencing its surrounding environment and contributing to radio emission. The term 'polars' refers to cataclysmic systems where the primary is a magnetized white dwarf, such as AM Herculis. 

The mechanism behind AM Herculis' behavior involves the modulation of its radio flux with orbital motion due to strong magnetic fields near the surface of the red dwarf. This phenomenon can be explained by considering the interaction between the red dwarf's global magnetic field and nearby matter. The system was observed in the quiescent phase, where the radio emission level remained relatively constant at about Jansky (Jy). 

The claims made here are that AM Herculis' radio flux is modulated with orbital motion due to its magnetized secondary star, distinguishing it from other polars like AR Ursae Majoris.

title: Globular Cluster Formation and Evolution in the Context of Cosmological Galaxy Assembly: Open Questions
input: We discuss some of the key open questions regarding the formation and evolution of globular clusters (GCs) during galaxy formation and assembly within a cosmological framework. The current state-of-the-art for both observations and simulations is described, and we briefly mention directions for future research. The oldest GCs have ages 12.5 Gyr and formed around the time of reionisation. Resolved colour-magnitude diagrams of Milky Way GCs and direct imaging of lensed proto-GCs at z 6 with JWST promise further insight. Globular clusters are known to host multiple populations of stars with variations in their chemical abundances. Recently, such multiple populations have been detected in 2 Gyr old compact, massive star clusters. This suggests a common, single pathway for the formation of GCs at high and low redshift. The shape of the initial mass function for GCs remains unknown, however for massive galaxies a power-law mass function is favoured. Significant progress has been made recently modelling GC formation in the context of galaxy formation, with success in reproducing many of the observed GC-galaxy scaling relations.

output.explanation:
Galaxies are vast, gravitationally bound systems consisting of stars and dark matter. Globular clusters (GCs) reside within these galaxies, comprising ancient star populations that have been shaped by the galaxy's formation history.

Globular clusters can be understood in terms of their stellar composition: chemical abundances refer to variations in the elemental composition of stars within GCs. These variations are thought to arise from differences in the formation processes. The initial mass function (IMF) describes the distribution of masses among newly formed stars and remains unknown for GCs.

The formation of globular clusters involves complex astrophysical processes, including the collapse of gas clouds and the subsequent star formation. This process is influenced by the galaxy's overall structure and evolution. In particular, the presence of dark matter can affect the distribution of stars within the cluster.

Globular clusters at high redshifts have been found to share similarities with those at low redshifts, suggesting a common pathway for their formation. The oldest GCs have ages approximately 12.5 billion years and formed around the time of reionisation.

title: Where can a Trappist-1 planetary system be produced?
input: We study the evolution of protoplanetary discs that would have been precursors of a Trappist-1 like system under the action of accretion and external photoevaporation in different radiation environments. Dust grains swiftly grow above the critical size below which they are entrained in the photoevaporative wind, so although gas is continually depleted, dust is resilient to photoevaporation after only a short time. This means that the ratio of the mass in solids (dust plus planetary) to the mass in gas rises steadily over time. Dust is still stripped early on, and the initial disc mass required to produce the observed of Trappist-1 planets is high. For example, assuming a Fatuzzo & Adams (2008) distribution of UV fields, typical initial disc masses have to be per cent the stellar (which are still Toomre stable) for the majority of similar mass M dwarfs to be viable hosts of the Trappist-1 planets. Even in the case of the lowest UV environments observed, there is a strong loss of dust due to photoevaporation at early times from the weakly bound outer regions of the disc. This minimum level of dust loss is a factor two higher than that which would be lost by accretion onto the star during 10 Myr of evolution. Consequently even in these least irradiated environments, discs that are viable Trappist-1 precursors need to be initially massive ( per cent of the stellar mass).

output.explanation:
Protoplanetary discs form in the vicinity of low-mass stars, specifically M dwarfs.

Key terms include accretion, which is the process where material accumulates onto a central object, and photoevaporation, which refers to the removal of material due to radiation pressure. Additionally, Toomre stability describes a state where the disc remains stable against fragmentation.

As dust grains grow above a critical size in these discs, they become entrained in the photoevaporative wind, causing gas depletion but leaving behind resilient dust particles. This results in an increase of the mass ratio between solids and gas over time due to the resilience of dust to photoevaporation after only a short period.

The initial disc masses required for Trappist-1-like systems are substantial, with typical values being high percentages of the stellar mass to ensure Toomre stability. Even in low UV environments, a significant loss of dust occurs due to photoevaporation from weakly bound outer regions, exceeding accretion losses by a factor two over 10 Myr.

title: gravity after GW170817 and GRB170817A
input: The combined observation of GW170817 and its electromagnetic counterpart GRB170817A reveals that gravitational waves propagate at the speed of light in high precision. We apply the effective field theory approach to investigate the experimental consequences for the theory of gravity. We find that the speed of gravitational waves within gravity is exactly equal to the light speed, and hence the constraints from GW170817 and GRB170817A are trivially satisfied. The results are verified through the standard analysis of cosmological perturbations. Nevertheless, by examining the dispersion relation and the frequency of cosmological gravitational waves, we observe a deviation from the results of General Relativity, quantified by a new parameter. Although its value is relatively small in viable models, its possible future measurement in advancing gravitational-wave astronomy would be the smoking gun of testing this type of modified gravity.

output.explanation:
The universe's fabric is shaped by gravitational waves, ripples in spacetime caused by massive objects accelerating or decelerating. Gravitational wave propagation speed becomes a critical parameter for understanding the underlying physics.

The term 'effective field theory' refers to a framework used to describe complex physical systems and their interactions. Dispersion relations are key concepts that describe how different frequencies interact with spacetime. The frequency of cosmological gravitational waves can be thought of as a measure of their energy density within the universe, often described in terms of wavelength dependence.

The speed at which gravitational waves propagate is directly related to fundamental forces governing gravity, such as General Relativity. However, examining dispersion relations and frequencies reveals a deviation from General Relativity's predictions, quantified by a new parameter. This deviation has significant implications for our understanding of gravity and its role in shaping the universe.

The observation of GW170817 and GRB170817A confirms that gravitational waves propagate at light speed with high precision, verified through standard analysis of cosmological perturbations.

title: The Mass and Absorption Columns of Galactic Gaseous Halos
input: The galactic gaseous halo is a gas reservoir for the interstellar medium in the galaxy disk, supplying materials for star formation. We developed a gaseous halo model connecting the galaxy disk and the gaseous halo by assuming the star formation rate on the disk is balanced by the radiative cooling rate of the gaseous halo, including stellar feedback. In addition to a single-temperature gaseous halo in collisional ionization equilibrium, we also consider the photoionization effect and a steady-state cooling model. Photoionization is important for modifying the ion distribution in low-mass galaxies and outskirts of massive galaxies due to the low densities. The multi-phase cooling model dominates the region within the cooling radius, where t_cooling=t_Hubble. Our model reproduces most of the observed high ionization state ions for a wide range of galaxy masses (i.e., OVI, OVII, NeVIII, MgX, and OVIII). We find that the OVI column density has a narrow range around ~10^14 cm^-2 for halo masses from M_star ~ 3 * 10^10 Msun to 6*10^12 Msun, which is consistent with some but not all observational studies. For galaxies with halo masses <~ 3 * 10^11 Msun, photoionization produces most of the OVI, while for more massive galaxies, the OVI is from the medium that is cooling from higher temperatures. Fitting the Galactic (Milky-Way) OVII and OVIII suggests a gaseous halo model where the metallicity is ~0.55 Zsun and the gaseous halo has a maximum temperature of ~ 1.9 * 10^6 K. This gaseous halo model does not close the census of baryonic material within R200.

output.explanation:
The galaxy's gaseous halo is a vast reservoir of gas that supplies the interstellar medium in the disk, fueling star formation.

Collisional ionization equilibrium refers to the balance between collisions that excite or de-excite particles in the gaseous halo. Photoionization is the process by which high-energy radiation from stars strips away electrons from atoms, creating ions. Radiative cooling occurs when gas loses energy through electromagnetic radiation.

The model's core mechanism involves balancing star formation rates with radiative cooling and stellar feedback, while also accounting for photoionization effects in low-density regions of galaxies or their outskirts. This balance determines how gas cools within different regions of galaxies, influencing the abundance of certain ions such as OVI, OVII, NeVIII, MgX, and OVIII.

The model suggests that these ions have a narrow range of column densities around 10^14 cm^-2 for halo masses between 3 * 10^10 Msun and 6*10^12 Msun. For less massive galaxies, photoionization dominates the production of OVI, while in more massive ones, it is produced by gas cooling from higher temperatures.

title: The Dynamics of Truncated Black Hole Accretion Disks II: Magnetohydrodynamic Case
input: We study a truncated accretion disk using a well-resolved, semi-global magnetohydrodynamic simulation that is evolved for many dynamical times (6096 inner disk orbits). The spectral properties of hard state black hole binary systems and low-luminosity active galactic nuclei are regularly attributed to truncated accretion disks, but a detailed understanding of the flow dynamics is lacking. In these systems the truncation is expected to arise through thermal instability driven by sharp changes in the radiative efficiency. We emulate this behavior using a simple bistable cooling function with efficient and inefficient branches. The accretion flow takes on an arrangement where a "transition zone" exists in between hot gas in the inner most regions and a cold, Shakura Sunyaev thin disk at larger radii. The thin disk is embedded in an atmosphere of hot gas that is fed by a gentle outflow originating from the transition zone. Despite the presence of hot gas in the inner disk, accretion is efficient. Our analysis focuses on the details of the angular momentum transport, energetics, and magnetic field properties. We find that the magnetic dynamo is suppressed in the hot, truncated inner region of the disk which lowers the effective -parameter by .

output.explanation:
Accretion disks are complex systems where matter spirals toward a central object, such as a black hole or neutron star.

In astrophysics, an accretion disk is defined by the region of space around a compact object like a black hole or neutron star where gas and dust accumulate. A bistable cooling function refers to a simple model used in simulations that has two distinct states: efficient and inefficient branches. The Shakura Sunyaev thin disk is characterized as a cold, thin disk at larger radii.

The interaction between hot gas in the inner regions and the cold, Shakura Sunyaev thin disk creates an atmosphere of hot gas fed by a gentle outflow from the transition zone. This arrangement drives thermal instability that leads to sharp changes in radiative efficiency.

In these systems, the suppression of the magnetic dynamo in the hot, truncated inner region of the disk lowers the effective alpha-parameter.

title: The "FIP Effect" and the Origins of Solar Energetic Particles and of the Solar Wind
input: We find that the element abundances in solar energetic particles (SEPs) and in the slow solar wind (SSW), relative to those in the photosphere, show different patterns as a function of the first ionization potential (FIP) of the elements. Generally, the SEP and SSW abundances reflect abundance samples of the solar corona, where low-FIP elements, ionized in the chromosphere, are more efficiently conveyed upward to the corona than high-FIP elements that are initially neutral atoms. Abundances of the elements, especially C, P, and S show a crossover from low to high FIP at ~10 eV in the SEPs but ~14 eV for the solar wind. Naively this seems to suggest cooler plasma from sunspots beneath active regions. More likely, if the ponderomotive force of Alfvén waves preferentially conveys low-FIP ions into the corona, the source plasma that eventually will be shock-accelerated as SEPs originates in magnetic structures where Alfvén waves resonate with the loop length on closed magnetic field lines. This concentrates FIP fractionation near the top of the chromosphere. Meanwhile, the source of the SSW may lie near the base of diverging open-field lines surrounding, but outside of, active regions, where such resonance does not exist, allowing fractionation throughout the chromosphere. We also find that energetic particles accelerated from the solar wind itself by shock waves at corotating interaction regions (CIRs), generally beyond 1 AU, confirm the FIP pattern of the solar wind.

output.explanation:
The solar corona is a region of intense magnetic activity, where the Sun's atmosphere transitions into space.

First ionization potential (FIP) refers to an element's tendency to lose electrons in high-energy environments, while low-FIP elements tend to be more easily ionized than high-FIP elements. Alfvén waves are a type of wave that can convey ions through magnetic fields, and ponderomotive force is the effect by which these waves influence the motion of charged particles.

The distribution of elements within the solar corona is influenced by FIP fractionation, where low-FIP elements are more efficiently conveyed upward to the corona than high-FIP elements. This process is concentrated near the top of the chromosphere in areas where Alfvén waves resonate with closed magnetic field lines.

SEPs and SSW exhibit distinct patterns of element abundances relative to the photosphere, reflecting their origins within different magnetic environments. SEPs show a crossover from low to high FIP at ~10 eV, while the solar wind exhibits this transition at ~14 eV.

title: Formation of massive seed black holes via collisions and accretion
input: Models aiming to explain the formation of massive black hole seeds, and in particular the direct collapse scenario, face substantial difficulties. These are rooted in rather ad hoc and fine-tuned initial conditions, such as the simultaneous requirements of extremely low metallicities and strong radiation backgrounds. Here we explore a modification of such scenarios where a massive primordial star cluster is initially produced. Subsequent stellar collisions give rise to the formation of massive (10^4 - 10^5 solar mass) objects. Our calculations demonstrate that the interplay between stellar dynamics, gas accretion and protostellar evolution is particularly relevant. Gas accretion onto the protostars enhances their radii, resulting in an enhanced collisional cross section. We show that the fraction of collisions can increase from 0.1-1% of the initial population to about 10% when compared to gas-free models or models of protostellar clusters in the local Universe. We conclude that very massive objects can form in spite of initial fragmentation, making the first massive protostellar clusters viable candidate birth places for observed supermassive black holes.

output.explanation:
The universe's early stages are characterized by the formation of massive stars and their subsequent interactions with surrounding gas. A key concept in this process is a primordial star cluster, which can be thought of as a dense collection of newly formed stars that collide with one another due to gravitational forces. The term 'metallicities' refers to the abundance of elements heavier than hydrogen and helium, while 'radiation backgrounds' describe intense radiation fields that can influence star formation. Protostellar evolution is the process by which young stars grow in mass through accretion.

In this context, stellar collisions give rise to the formation of massive objects due to an enhanced collisional cross-section resulting from gas accretion onto protostars. This interplay between stellar dynamics and gas accretion plays a crucial role in shaping the outcome of these interactions.

The mechanism behind the increased fraction of collisions lies in the enhancement of radii for protostars that undergo gas accretion, thereby increasing their likelihood of interacting with other stars. This process can significantly increase compared to models without gas or those representative of local Universe conditions.

As a result, very massive objects can form despite initial fragmentation, making the first massive protostellar clusters viable candidate birth places for observed supermassive black holes.

title: OGLE-LMC-ECL-09937: The Most Massive Algol-Type Binary System With A Mass Measurement Accurate to 2%
input: This paper presents a detailed analysis of the light and radial velocity curves of the semi-detached eclipsing binary system OGLE-LMC-ECL-09937. The system is composed of a hot, massive and luminous primary star of a late-O spectral type, and a more evolved, but less massive and luminous secondary, implying an Algol-type system that underwent a mass transfer episode. We derive masses of 21.04 +/- 0.34 M_Sun and 7.61 +/- 0.09 M_Sun and radii of 9.93 +/- 0.06 R_Sun and 9.18 +/- 0.04 R_Sun, for the primary and the secondary component, respectively, which make it the most massive known Algol-type system with masses and radii of the components measured with <2% accuracy. Consequently, the parameters of OGLE-LMC-ECL-09937 provide an important contribution to the sparsely populated high-mass end of the stellar mass distribution, and an interesting object for stellar evolution studies, being a possible progenitor of a binary system composed of two neutron stars.

output.explanation:
The semi-detached eclipsing binary system OGLE-LMC-ECL-09937 is situated in a region where massive stars interact through gravitational forces and mass transfer episodes occur.

The primary star's late-O spectral type signifies high surface temperatures, while the secondary component has undergone significant evolution resulting in reduced luminosity compared to its massive counterpart. This configuration implies an Algol-type system that has experienced mass transfer.

Key terms such as 'spectral type' refer to a classification of stars based on their spectral characteristics, and 'mass transfer episode' describes gravitational interactions between the components.

The interaction between these two components drives complex behavior in OGLE-LMC-ECL-09937, where mass is transferred from the more evolved component to its massive counterpart. This process affects their orbital periods causing periodic eclipses that can be observed as changes in brightness and radial velocity curves.

title: Investigating the young Solar System analog HD95086
input: HD95086 (A8V, 17Myr) hosts a rare planetary system for which a multi-belt debris disk and a giant planet of 4-5MJup have been directly imaged. Our study aims to characterize the physical and orbital properties of HD95086b, search for additional planets at short and wide orbits and image the cold outer debris belt in scattered light. We used HARPS at the ESO 3.6m telescope to monitor the radial velocity of HD95086 over 2 years and investigate the existence of giant planets at less than 3au orbital distance. With the IRDIS dual-band imager and the IFS integral field spectrograph of SPHERE at VLT, we imaged the faint circumstellar environment beyond 10au at six epochs between 2015 and 2017. We do not detect additional giant planets around HD95086. We identified the nature (bound companion or background contaminant) of all point-like sources detected in the IRDIS field of view. None of them correspond to the ones recently discovered near the edge of the cold outer belt by ALMA. HD95086b is resolved for the first time in J-band with IFS. Its near-infrared spectral energy distribution is well fitted by a few dusty and/or young L7-L9 dwarf spectral templates. The extremely red 1-4um spectral distribution is typical of low-gravity objects at the L/T spectral type transition. The planet's orbital motion is resolved between January 2015 and May 2017. Together with past NaCo measurements properly re-calibrated, our orbital fitting solutions favor a retrograde low to moderate-eccentricity orbit e=0.2 (0.0 to 0.5), with a semi-major axis 52au corresponding to orbital periods of 288$ yrs and an inclination that peaks at i = 141deg, which is compatible with a planet-disk coplanar configuration. Finally, we report the detection in polarimetric differential imaging of the cold outer debris belt between 100 and 300au, consistent in radial extent with recent ALMA 1.3mm resolved observations.

output.explanation:
The star HD95086 is a young A-type main-sequence star, hosting an unusual planetary system with multiple debris disks and a giant planet called HD95086b.

A 'debris disk' refers to a ring of dust and small particles surrounding the star after planetary formation. An 'integral field spectrograph' (IFS) studies light coming from different parts of an object simultaneously. The term 'retrograde orbit' describes an orbital path that moves in the opposite direction compared to the rotation of its parent star.

The giant planet HD95086b interacts with its surrounding environment through gravitational forces, influencing the motion of nearby objects and potentially shaping the structure of the debris disk. Its near-infrared spectral energy distribution is well matched by dusty young L7-L9 dwarf templates, indicating a low-gravity object at the L/T spectral type transition.

The planet's orbital motion is resolved over two years, favoring an orbit with a semi-major axis of 52au and corresponding to an orbital period of approximately 288years. The inclination of this orbit peaks at i=141deg, consistent with a planet-disk coplanar configuration.

title: OGLE Collection of Star Clusters. New Objects in the Magellanic Bridge and the Outskirts of the Small Magellanic Cloud
input: The Magellanic System (MS) encompasses the nearest neighbors of the Milky Way, the Large (LMC) and Small (SMC) Magellanic Clouds, and the Magellanic Bridge (MBR). This system contains a diverse sample of star clusters. Their parameters, such as the spatial distribution, chemical composition and age distribution yield important information about the formation scenario of the whole Magellanic System. Using deep photometric maps compiled in the fourth phase of the Optical Gravitational Lensing Experiment (OGLE-IV) we present the most complete catalog of star clusters in the Magellanic System ever constructed from homogeneous, long time-scale photometric data. In this second paper of the series, we show the collection of star clusters found in the area of about 360 square degrees in the MBR and in the outer regions of the SMC. Our sample contains 198 visually identified star cluster candidates, 75 of which were not listed in any of the previously published catalogs. The new discoveries are mainly young small open clusters or clusters similar to associations.

output.explanation:
The Magellanic System is a vast, star-filled region of space comprising the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds and the Magellanic Bridge.

Star clusters are groups of stars that share similar characteristics such as spatial distribution, chemical composition, and age distribution. Spatial distribution refers to the positioning of these clusters within the system, while chemical composition pertains to their elemental makeup, and age distribution relates to the range of ages among them.

The gravitational forces acting on star clusters in this region cause them to interact with one another, influencing each other's motion and stability. This interaction is particularly evident in the Magellanic Bridge region where 198 visually identified cluster candidates reside, including 75 previously unknown entities.

These new discoveries are primarily young small open clusters or associations that resemble them, providing valuable information about the formation scenario of the whole Magellanic System.

title: Gauging the Helium Abundance of the Galactic Bulge RR Lyrae Stars
input: We report the first estimate of the He abundance of the population of RR Lyrae stars in the Galactic bulge. This is done by comparing the recent observational data with the latest models. We use the large samples of ab type RR Lyrae stars found by OGLE IV in the inner bulge and by the VVV survey in the outer bulge. We present the result from the new models computed by Marconi et al. (2017), showing that the minimum Period for fundamental RR Lyrae pulsators depends on the He content. By comparing these models with the observations in a Period versus effective temperature plane, we find that the bulk of the bulge ab type RR Lyrae are consistent with primordial He abundance Y=0.245, ruling out a significant He-enriched population. This work demonstrates that the He content of the bulge RR Lyrae is different from that of the bulk of the bulge population as traced by the red clump giants, that appear to be significantly more He-rich.

output.explanation:
The Galactic bulge is a densely packed region at the center of our galaxy, comprising older stars and various types of celestial objects. RR Lyrae stars are an essential component in understanding this environment, as they serve as cosmic clocks to measure distances within the Milky Way. The helium abundance refers to the proportion of helium present in these stars.

RR Lyrae stars can be classified into different types based on their pulsation periods and temperatures. Primordial helium abundance is a term used to describe the original amount of helium present in these stars when they formed, which is distinct from astrophysical processes that may alter this content over time.
