To make further progress, the next generation of CMB experiments (e.g. CMB-S4) will require a substantial increase in the number of detectors compared to the current stage 3 instruments. Arrays of kinetic inductance detectors (KIDs) provide a possible path to realising such large format arrays owing to their intrinsic multiplexing advantage and relative cryogenic simplicity. In this proceedings, we report on the design of a novel variant of the traditional KID design; the antenna-coupled lumped-element KID. A polarisation sensitive twin-slot antenna placed behind an optimised hemispherical lens couples power onto a thin-film superconducting microstrip line. The power is then guided into the inductive section of an aluminium KID where it is absorbed and modifies both the resonant frequency and quality factor of the KID. We present the various aspects of the design and preliminary results from the first set of seven-element prototype arrays and compare to the expected modelled performance.

output.explanation:
The cosmic microwave background (CMB) is a remnant of the universe's early stages, emitting faint radiation that can be detected by highly sensitive instruments.

A key concept in this context is kinetic inductance detectors (KIDs), which are superconducting devices capable of interacting with incoming radiation. KIDs consist of microstrip lines made from thin films of a superconductor, such as aluminium.

The mechanism behind KIDs involves the interaction between incoming radiation and the device's resonant frequency and quality factor. When power is coupled onto a thin-film superconducting microstrip line, it flows into the inductive section of an aluminium KID, where it is absorbed and modifies both frequency and quality factor.

The design presented here utilises an antenna-coupled lumped-element configuration to enhance coupling efficiency with the superconducting microstrip line. Preliminary results from seven-element prototype arrays show promising performance compared to modelled expectations.

title: Integral Field Spectroscopy of Supernova Remnant 1E0102-7219 Reveals Fast-moving Hydrogen and Sulfur-rich Ejecta
input: We study the optical emission from heavy element ejecta in the oxygen-rich young supernova remnant (SNR) 1E 0102.2-7219 (1E 0102) in the Small Magellanic Cloud. We have used the Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) optical integral field spectrograph at the Very Large Telescope (VLT) on Cerro Paranal and the wide field spectrograph (WiFeS) at the ANU 2.3 m telescope at Siding Spring Observatory to obtain deep observations of 1E 0102. Our observations cover the entire extent of the remnant from below 3500Å to 9350Å. Our observations unambiguously reveal the presence of fast-moving ejecta emitting in [S II], [S III], [Ar III], and [Cl II]. The sulfur-rich ejecta appear more asymmetrically distributed compared to oxygen or neon, a product of carbon-burning. In addition to the forbidden line emission from products of oxygen burning (S, Ar, Cl), we have also discovered Hα and Hβ emission from several knots of low surface brightness, fast-moving ejecta. The presence of fast-moving hydrogen points towards a progenitor that had not entirely shed its hydrogen envelope prior to the supernova. The explosion that gave rise to 1E 0102 is therefore commensurate with a Type IIb supernova.

output.explanation:
The Small Magellanic Cloud is a region of space where stars are born and die, hosting various types of celestial objects including supernova remnants.

The term oxygen-rich ejecta refers to regions with high concentrations of oxygen, while sulfur-rich ejecta are areas dominated by sulfur. Oxygen-rich ejecta are typically associated with the products of oxygen burning processes in massive stars. Sulfur-rich ejecta, on the other hand, result from carbon-burning processes that occur at higher temperatures and densities.

The optical emission from heavy element ejecta involves light emitted in specific wavelengths due to transitions between energy levels within atoms or ions. In this case, the presence of fast-moving hydrogen suggests that the progenitor star had not shed its entire hydrogen envelope before exploding. The asymmetric distribution of sulfur-rich ejecta compared to oxygen or neon is consistent with carbon-burning processes and indicates a complex explosion mechanism.

The system behavior involves the emission of light from heavy elements in specific wavelengths, including Hα and Hβ, indicating the presence of hydrogen. This phenomenon points towards a Type IIb supernova, which occurs when a massive star runs out of fuel and collapses, expelling its outer layers while retaining some hydrogen.

title: Axisymmetric force-free magnetosphere in the exterior of a neutron star II: Maximum storage and open field energies
input: A magnetar's magnetosphere gradually evolves by the injection of energy and helicity from the interior. Axisymmetric static solutions for a relativistic force-free magnetosphere with a power-law current model are numerically obtained. They provide information about the configurations in which the stored energy is large. The energy along a sequence of equilibria increases and becomes sufficient to open the magnetic field. A magnetic flux rope, in which a large amount of toroidal field is confined, is formed in the vicinity of the star, for states exceeding the open field energy. These states are energetically metastable, and the excess energy may be ejected as a magnetar outburst.

output.explanation:
Magnetars are known for their intense magnetic fields and rotational energy, which drive the evolution of their magnetospheres over time.

The term 'helicity' refers to the intrinsic spin or twist of a magnetic field line, while 'force-free' indicates that the electromagnetic forces balance each other out. In relativistic force-free magnetospheres, charged particles experience no net force from the magnetic field due to its configuration.

As energy and helicity are injected into the magnetosphere from within the star, the stored energy increases along a sequence of equilibria. Eventually, this energy becomes sufficient to break open the magnetic field lines, leading to the formation of a toroidal flux rope near the star's surface. This confined region contains a large amount of twisted magnetic field.

The states that form these flux ropes are energetically metastable and can release excess energy as powerful magnetar outbursts when they become unstable.

title: Analyzing interstellar infrared spectrum by circumcoronene (C54H18) related molecules
input: It is very important to identify carrier molecules of astronomical interstellar infrared spectrum (IR) to understand chemical evolution step of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) in the universe. In our previous study, it was suggested that coronene (C24H12) related PAH could reproduce such IR by the first principles quantum chemical calculation. In this paper, PAH candidates were enhanced to circumcoronene (C54H18) related molecules. Well known PAH oriented wavelength of 6.2, 7.7, 8.6, 11.3, and 12.7 micrometer were reproduced well by a void induced mono-cation (C53H18) having hydrocarbon two pentagons combined with 17 hexagons. Typical astronomical object are the red rectangle nebula and NGC6946, which is categorized as Type-B sectrum. Neutral circumcoronene show very strong IR peak at 11.1 micrometer, which is noted as Type-A spectrum observed in NGC1316 and NGC4589. Ubiquitously well observed spectrum was noted as Type-C, which could be explained by a suitable combination of Type-B and Type-A. Type-C objects are NGC7023, NGC2023 and so many. It should be noted that a dehydrogenated pure carbon mono-cation molecule (C53) show IR peaks at 6.3, 7.8, 8.5 micrometer, but no peak at 11.3 micrometer, which newly defined as Type-E. Such a strange characteristic can contribute to explain IR intensity ratio. Observed intensity ratio between peaks of 6.2, 7.7, 8.6, 11.3, and 12.7 micrometer each other were compared with above calculated IR intensities. Major intensity ratio was well reproduced by Type-B molecules. Variation of observed intensity ratio could be explained by a mixture degree between Type-B and Type-A, and also a mixture degree between Type-B and Type-E.

output.explanation:
The universe's interstellar medium is a vast, diffuse region where various physical processes shape the chemical evolution of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs).

A key concept in understanding PAH behavior is that they are carbon-based molecules emitting infrared radiation across specific wavelengths. To define this further, PAHs refer to polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon molecules.

The interaction between these processes involves the emission of IR radiation by PAHs, which can be attributed to their molecular structure and composition. Specifically, a void-induced mono-cation (C53H18) having two pentagons combined with 17 hexagons reproduces well-known wavelengths of 6.2, 7.7, 8.6, 11.3, and 12.7 micrometers.

The system's behavior is characterized by the presence of Type-B spectra in objects like NGC6946, which can be attributed to PAHs with a specific molecular structure. Additionally, neutral circumcoronene exhibits strong IR peaks at 11.1 micrometer, characteristic of Type-A spectra observed in certain galaxies.

title: Detection of variable VHE gamma-ray emission from the extra-galactic gamma-ray binary LMC P3
input: Context. Recently, the high-energy (HE, 0.1-100 GeV) -ray emission from the object LMC P3 in the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) has been discovered to be modulated with a 10.3-day period, making it the first extra-galactic -ray binary. Aims. This work aims at the detection of very-high-energy (VHE, >100 GeV) -ray emission and the search for modulation of the VHE signal with the orbital period of the binary system. Methods. LMC P3 has been observed with the High Energy Stereoscopic System (H.E.S.S.); the acceptance-corrected exposure time is 100 h. The data set has been folded with the known orbital period of the system in order to test for variability of the emission. Energy spectra are obtained for the orbit-averaged data set, and for the orbital phase bin around the VHE maximum. Results. VHE -ray emission is detected with a statistical significance of 6.4 . The data clearly show variability which is phase-locked to the orbital period of the system. Periodicity cannot be deduced from the H.E.S.S. data set alone. The orbit-averaged luminosity in the TeV energy range is erg/s. A luminosity of erg/s is reached during 20% of the orbit. HE and VHE -ray emissions are anti-correlated. LMC P3 is the most luminous -ray binary known so far.

output.explanation:
The Large Magellanic Cloud is a satellite galaxy of the Milky Way, hosting an object called LMC P3 that exhibits high-energy gamma-ray emission modulated by a 10.3-day period.

High-energy (HE) refers to gamma-ray energies between 0.1-100 GeV, while very-high-energy (VHE) corresponds to energies above 100 GeV. The detection of VHE gamma rays involves the High Energy Stereoscopic System (H.E.S.S.), which observed LMC P3 for a corrected exposure time.

The processes described in this context involve binary systems where one component emits gamma rays, interacting with each other through orbital periods. This interaction leads to modulated emission patterns that can be detected and analyzed using instruments like H.E.S.S.

VHE -ray emission is detected with a statistical significance of 6.4 sigma, indicating variability phase-locked to the orbital period. The orbit-averaged luminosity in the TeV energy range reaches erg/s, while a maximum luminosity of erg/s occurs during 20% of the orbit. Notably, high-energy and very-high-energy gamma-ray emissions are anti-correlated.

title: Extremophile life-form survey on rocky exoplanets
input: Search for different life-forms elsewhere is the fascinating area of research in astrophysics and astrobiology. Nearly 3500 exoplanets are discovered according to NASA exoplanet archive database. Earth Similarity Index (ESI) is defined as the geometrical mean of radius, density, escape velocity and surface temperature, ranging from 0 (dissimilar to Earth) to 1(Earth). In this research, rocky exoplanets that are suitable for rock dependent extremophiles, such as: Chroococcidiopsis and Acarosporamto are chosen, which can potentially survive are considered. The Colonizing Similarity Index (CSI) is introduced and analysed for 1650 rocky exoplanets, CSI is basically representing Earth-like planets that are suitable for rocky extremophiles which can survive in extreme temperatures (i.e. as hot as desert and cold as frozen lands). In this work the in-habitable exoplanets are recognised even for these rocky extremophiles to not potentially survive by using the CSI metric tool.

output.explanation:
The search for life beyond Earth is a captivating area of research in astrophysics and astrobiology, driven by the discovery of nearly 3500 exoplanets according to NASA's database.

A key term here is the geometrical mean, which calculates the average of multiple values. The Earth Similarity Index (ESI) measures how similar an exoplanet is to our own planet based on its radius, density, escape velocity, and surface temperature. This index ranges from 0 for dissimilarity to 1 for perfect similarity.

The Colonizing Similarity Index (CSI) has been developed to identify Earth-like planets suitable for rock-dependent extremophiles like Chroococcidiopsis and Acarosporamto. These organisms can survive in extreme conditions such as scorching heat or freezing temperatures. The CSI metric tool is used to determine whether these exoplanets are habitable even for the most resilient rock-dependent extremophiles.

The analysis of 1650 rocky exoplanets using CSI has identified those that might be habitable, but it also recognizes in-habitable exoplanets where these extremophiles cannot potentially survive. This distinction is crucial for understanding the potential for life on other worlds.

title: Cosmological Parameter Estimation Using the Genus Amplitude - Application to Mock Galaxy Catalogs
input: We study the topology of the matter density field in two dimensional slices, and consider how we can use the amplitude of the genus for cosmological parameter estimation. Using the latest Horizon Run 4 simulation data, we calculate the genus of the smoothed density field constructed from lightcone mock galaxy catalogs. Information can be extracted from the amplitude of the genus by considering both its redshift evolution and magnitude. The constancy of the genus amplitude with redshift can be used as a standard population, from which we derive constraints on the equation of state of dark energy - by measuring at and , we can place an order constraint on . By comparing to its Gaussian expectation value we can potentially derive an additional stringent constraint on the matter density . We discuss the primary sources of contamination associated with the two measurements - redshift space distortion and shot noise. With accurate knowledge of galaxy bias, we can successfully remove the effect of redshift space distortion, and the combined effect of shot noise and non-linear gravitational evolution is suppressed by smoothing over suitably large scales . Without knowledge of the bias, we discuss how joint measurements of the two and three dimensional genus can be used to constrain the growth factor . The method can be applied optimally to redshift slices of a galaxy distribution generated using the drop-off technique.

output.explanation:
The universe's large-scale structure is shaped by the distribution of matter, which can be described in terms of its density field. The genus is a topological feature that characterizes this distribution in two-dimensional slices.

In cosmology, the amplitude of the genus provides valuable information about certain parameters. To understand these parameters, researchers need to define key technical terms: galaxy bias refers to how galaxies are distributed within the universe; redshift space distortion affects measurements due to the expansion of space; shot noise arises from the random distribution of galaxies.

The processes described interact through a complex interplay between the density field and its topological features. The genus amplitude is influenced by both the redshift evolution and magnitude, which are essential for extracting information about cosmological parameters. By analyzing these factors, researchers can derive constraints on models of dark energy.

This study uses simulation data from Horizon Run 4 to calculate the genus of smoothed density fields constructed from galaxy catalogs. The constancy of the genus amplitude with redshift serves as a standard population, allowing for further constraint derivation. With accurate knowledge of galaxy bias, researchers can remove the effect of redshift space distortion and suppress the combined effect of shot noise and non-linear gravitational evolution by smoothing over large scales.

title: Spectral analysis of the He-enriched sdO-star HD 127493
input: The bright sdO star HD 127493 is known to be of mixed H/He composition and excellent archival spectra covering both optical and ultraviolet ranges are available. UV spectra play a key role as they give access to many chemical species that do not show spectral lines in the optical, such as iron and nickel. This encouraged the quantitative spectral analysis of this prototypical mixed H/He composition sdO star. We determined atmospheric parameters for HD 127493 in addition to the abundance of C, N, O, Si, S, Fe, and Ni in the atmosphere using non-LTE model atmospheres calculated with TLUSTY/SYNSPEC. A comparison between the parallax distance measured by Hipparcos and the derived spectroscopic distance indicate that the derived atmospheric parameters are realistic. From our metal abundance analysis, we find a strong CNO signature and enrichment in iron and nickel.

output.explanation:
The hot, luminous star HD 127493 is situated in the interstellar medium, where it interacts with surrounding gas and dust.

The atmosphere of this sdO star consists mainly of hydrogen and helium, but also contains other elements such as carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, silicon, sulfur, iron, and nickel. The ultraviolet spectra of HD 127493 are crucial for studying these chemical species, which do not emit spectral lines in the optical range.

The term 'non-LTE' refers to a state where the radiation from an atom or ion is not in thermal equilibrium with its surroundings. In this context, non-LTE model atmospheres were used to calculate the atmospheric parameters of HD 127493 and determine the abundance of various elements in its atmosphere. These calculations were performed using the TLUSTY/SYNSPEC code.

The derived atmospheric parameters for HD 127493 are consistent with a parallax distance measured by Hipparcos, indicating that they are realistic. The analysis revealed a strong CNO signature and enrichment in iron and nickel in the star's atmosphere.

title: The Globular Cluster NGC 6402 (M14). II. Variable Stars
input: We present time-series photometry for the Galactic globular cluster NGC 6402 (M14). The data consists of 137 images per filter, obtained using the 0.9m and 1.0m SMARTS telescopes at the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory. The images were obtained during two observing runs in 2006-2007. The image-subtraction package ISIS, along with DAOPHOT II/ALLFRAME, were used to perform crowded-field photometry and search for variable stars. We identified 130 variables, 8 of which are new discoveries. The variable star population is comprised of 56 ab-type RR Lyrae stars, 54 c-type RR Lyrae, 6 type II Cepheids, 1 W UMa star, 1 detached eclipsing binary, and 12 long-period variables. We provide Fourier decomposition parameters for the RR Lyrae, and discuss the physical parameters and photometric metallicity derived therefrom. The M14 distance modulus is also discussed, based on different approaches for the calibration of the absolute magnitudes of RR Lyrae stars. The possible presence of second-overtone RR Lyrae in M14 is critically addressed, with our results arguing against this possibility. By considering all of the RR Lyrae stars as members of the cluster, we derive d. This, together with the position of the RR Lyrae stars of both Bailey types in the period-amplitude diagram, suggests an Oosterhoff-intermediate classification for the cluster. Such an intermediate Oosterhoff type is much more commonly found in nearby extragalactic systems, and we critically discuss several other possible indications that may point to an extragalactic origin for this cluster.

output.explanation:
The Milky Way galaxy contains numerous globular clusters, dense regions of stars that are gravitationally bound together. 

The term 'RR Lyrae' refers to a specific type of variable star that pulsates due to the contraction and expansion of its outer layers. This phenomenon is caused by thermal pulses in the star's core, leading to periodic changes in brightness. 

The study analyzed time-series photometry data collected for NGC 6402 (M14), identifying 130 variables, including new discoveries. These variables can be classified into different types based on their light curves, such as RR Lyrae and type II Cepheids. The Fourier decomposition parameters for these stars provide information about their physical properties, including metallicity and distance from Earth. 

The researchers used different methods to calculate the absolute magnitudes of RR Lyrae stars in M14, determining its distance modulus based on various approaches. This process involves comparing the observed brightness of these stars with their intrinsic luminosity, leading to a classification of Oosterhoff-intermediate for the cluster.

title: Reionization Models Classifier using 21cm Map Deep Learning
input: Next-generation 21cm observations will enable imaging of reionization on very large scales. These images will contain more astrophysical and cosmological information than the power spectrum, and hence providing an alternative way to constrain the contribution of different reionizing sources populations to cosmic reionization. Using Convolutional Neural Networks, we present a simple network architecture that is sufficient to discriminate between Galaxy-dominated versus AGN-dominated models, even in the presence of simulated noise from different experiments such as the HERA and SKA.

output.explanation:
The universe's large-scale structure can be probed through next-generation 21cm observations, which will provide a new perspective on cosmic reionization.

Reionization refers to the process of ionizing neutral gas in the universe, typically by radiation from stars and quasars. Key terms include Galaxy-dominated models, where galaxies are primarily responsible for reionization, and AGN-dominated models, where active galactic nuclei play a more significant role.

Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) can efficiently process large amounts of data to extract relevant features. In this context, CNNs are used to differentiate between Galaxy-dominated and AGN-dominated models in the presence of simulated noise from experiments like HERA and SKA.

The ability to discriminate between these models is crucial for understanding reionization. By analyzing 21cm images using CNNs, scientists can gain insights into the early universe's evolution.

title: Jeans Instability in a Universe with Dissipation
input: The problem of Jeans gravitational instability is investigated for static and expanding universes within the context of the five and thirteen field theories which account for viscous and thermal effects. For the five-field theory a general dispersion relation has been derived with the help of relevant linearized perturbation equations, showing that the shear viscosity parameter alters the propagating modes for large and small wavelengths. The behavior of density and temperature contrasts are analyzed for the hard-sphere model in detail. In the small wavelengths regime, increasing the amount of shear viscosity into the system forces the harmonic perturbations to damp faster, however, in the opposite limit larger values of shear viscosity lead to smaller values of density and temperature contrasts. For the hyperbolic case, the dispersion relation becomes a polynomial in the frequency with two orders higher in relation to the five-field theory, indicating that the effects associated with the shear viscosity and heat flux are non-trivial. The profile of Jeans mass in terms of the temperature and number density is explored by contrasting with several data of molecular clouds. Regarding the dynamical evolution of the density, temperature, stress and heat flux contrasts for a universe dominated by pressureless matter, we obtain also damped harmonic waves for small wavelengths. In the case of large wavelengths, the density and temperature contrasts grow with time (due to the Jeans mechanism) while the stress and heat flux contrasts heavily decay with time.

output.explanation:
The universe is a vast, dynamic system governed by gravity and thermodynamics. In this context, two theories are used to understand the behavior of gravitational instability: five-field theory and thirteen-field theory.

In these theories, key terms like shear viscosity and heat flux play crucial roles in describing how matter interacts with its surroundings. Shear viscosity refers to a fluid's resistance to flow when subjected to stress, while heat flux is the transfer of thermal energy from one location to another.

The interplay between viscous effects and thermal conductivity determines the behavior of gravitational instability in different regimes. For instance, increasing shear viscosity can cause harmonic perturbations to damp faster at small wavelengths but lead to smaller density and temperature contrasts at larger scales.

In expanding universes dominated by pressureless matter, we observe distinct behaviors depending on wavelength: damped harmonic waves for small wavelengths and growing density and temperature contrasts due to the Jeans mechanism at large wavelengths.

title: The Radial and Rotational Velocity of Ophiuchi
input: We present the results of our spectroscopic monitoring campaign of Oph, carried out at the University observatory Jena with the spectrograph FLECHAS between July 2015 and September 2016. The main aim of the project is to determine the radial velocity of the star precisely, as a wide range of radial velocity measurements of Oph are given in the literature. Beside the proper motion and parallax, the radial velocity is an important input parameter for the calculation of the space motion of the star. Oph is considered to be a runaway star and potential former companion of the progenitor star of the pulsar PSRJ1932+1059, which both may have been located in a binary system and were then released during a supernova explosion about 1 Myr ago in the Upper Scorpius OB association. For the calculation that the pulsar and Oph could have been at the same place, a radial velocity of 9.0 km/s for Oph was used in the literature. By analysing the hydrogen and helium lines in 48 FLECHAS spectra, we determined the radial velocity of Oph to be 12.2 3.3 km/s and the projected rotational velocity to 432 16 km/s with no indication for variability.

output.explanation:
The star Oph resides in the Upper Scorpius OB association, a region of young stars that formed about 1 Myr ago from a giant molecular cloud.

The radial velocity is an important parameter for understanding the motion of Oph through space. It can be used to calculate its proper motion and parallax, which are essential for determining its position in the sky. Radial velocity measurements have been reported in various studies, but these values differ significantly. To resolve this discrepancy, a spectroscopic monitoring campaign was conducted using the FLECHAS spectrograph at the University observatory Jena between July 2015 and September 2016.

The radial velocity is determined by analyzing the shifts of hydrogen and helium lines in stellar spectra. These elements are abundant in stars like Oph and can be used as tracers for its motion. The projected rotational velocity, which represents how fast a star rotates along our line of sight, was also measured to be 432 km/s with high precision.

The analysis revealed that the radial velocity of Oph is approximately 12.2 km/s with an uncertainty of about 3.3 km/s. This value differs from previous estimates and has significant implications for understanding its space motion.

title: Quasi-periodicities of BL Lac Objects
input: We review the reports of possible year-long quasi-periodicities of BL Lac objects in the -ray and optical bands, and present a homogeneous time analysis of the light curves of PKS2155 304, PG1553+113, and BL Lac. Based on results from a survey covering the entire Fermi -ray sky we have estimated the fraction of possible quasi-periodic BL Lac objects. We compared the cyclical behaviour in BL Lac objects with that derived from the search of possible optical periodicities in quasars, and find that at z 1 the cosmic density of quasi-periodic BL Lac objects is larger than that of quasi-periodic quasars. If the BL Lac quasi-periodicities were due to a supermassive binary black hole (SBBH) scenario, there could be a tension with the upper limits on the gravitational wave background measured by the pulsar timing array. The argument clearly indicates the difficulties of generally associating quasi-periodicities of BL Lac objects with SBBHs.

output.explanation:
Active galactic nuclei, such as BL Lac objects, are characterized by intense -ray emission and complex light curves that can exhibit periodic patterns.

A key term in this context is a supermassive binary black hole (SBBH), which refers to two massive black holes orbiting each other at the centers of galaxies. Another important concept is redshift (z), a measure of how much light from distant objects has been stretched due to the expansion of the universe.

The quasi-periodicities observed in BL Lac objects are thought to arise from complex interactions between their -ray emission and optical bands, which may be influenced by the presence of SBBHs. However, if these periodicities were indeed caused by SBBHs, it would create tension with upper limits on gravitational wave backgrounds measured by pulsar timing arrays.

The study finds that at redshift z = 1, the cosmic density of quasi-periodic BL Lac objects is larger than that of quasi-periodic quasars. This suggests that BL Lac objects may be more prone to exhibiting periodic patterns in their light curves.

title: Chemical Abundances in the Leading Arm of the Magellanic Stream
input: The Leading Arm (LA) of the Magellanic Stream is a vast debris field of H I clouds connecting the Milky Way and the Magellanic Clouds. It represents an example of active gas accretion onto the Galaxy. Previously only one chemical abundance measurement had been made in the LA. Here we present chemical abundance measurements using Hubble Space Telescope/Cosmic Origins Spectrograph Green Bank Telescope spectra of four sightlines passing through the LA, and three nearby sightlines that may trace outer fragments of the LA. We find low oxygen abundances, ranging from 4.0(+4.0,-2.0) percent solar to 12.6(+6.2,-4.1) percent solar, in the confirmed LA directions, with the lowest values found in the region known as LA III, farthest from the LMC. These abundances are substantially lower than the single previous measurement, S/H=35+/-7 percent solar (Lu et al. 1998), but are in agreement with those reported in the SMC filament of the trailing Stream, supporting a common origin in the SMC (not the LMC) for the majority of the LA and the trailing Stream. This provides important constraints for models of the formation of the Magellanic System. Finally, the HVCs in two of the three nearby sightlines show H I columns, kinematics, and oxygen abundances consistent with LA membership. This suggests that the LA is larger than traditionally thought, extending at least 20 degrees further to the Galactic northwest.

output.explanation:
The Magellanic Stream is a vast debris field of H I clouds connecting the Milky Way and its satellite galaxies, representing an ongoing process of gas accretion.

H I refers to neutral atomic hydrogen, which plays a crucial role in galaxy formation. The Leading Arm (LA) is composed primarily of H I clouds, with oxygen abundance measurements used to determine its chemical composition.

Gas accretion involves the interaction between galaxies, leading to the exchange of material such as hydrogen gas and influencing the LA's evolution. Oxygen abundances are found to be low in confirmed LA directions, particularly farthest from the Large Magellanic Cloud.

The discovery of HVCs (high-velocity clouds) with characteristics consistent with LA membership indicates that the LA may extend beyond its traditionally thought boundaries, supported by observations extending at least 20 degrees further to the Galactic northwest.

title: Particle acceleration in the superwinds of starburst galaxies
input: Starbursts are galaxies undergoing massive episodes of star formation. The combined effect of stellar winds from hot stars and supernova explosions creates a high-temperature cavity in the nuclear region of these objects. The very hot gas expands adiabatically and escapes from the galaxy creating a superwind which sweeps matter from the galactic disk. The superwind region in the halo is filled with a multi-phase gas with hot, warm, cool, and relativistic components. The shocks associated with the superwind of starbursts and the turbulent gas region of the bubble inflated by them might accelerate cosmic rays up to high energies. In this work we calculate the cosmic ray production associated with the superwind using parameters that correspond to the nearby southern starburst galaxy NGC 253, which has been suggested as a potential accelerator of ultra-high energy cosmic rays. We evaluate the efficiency of both diffusive shock acceleration (DSA) and stochastic diffusive acceleration (SDA) in the superwind of NGC 253. We estimate the distribution of both hadrons and leptons and calculate the corresponding spectral energy distributions of photons. We find that the strong mass load of the superwind, recently determined through ALMA observations, strongly attenuates the efficiency of DSA in NGC 253, whereas SDA is constrained by the age of the starburst. We conclude that NGC 253 and similar starbursts can only accelerate iron nuclei beyond eV under very special conditions. If the central region of the galaxy harbors a starved supermassive black hole of , as suggested by some recent observations, a contribution in the range eV can be present for accretion rates in Eddington units. Only if very strong magnetic field amplification occurs close to the superwind shock energies of the order of 100 EeV might be achieved.

output.explanation:
Galaxies with intense star formation create high-temperature cavities in their centers due to the combined effect of stellar winds and supernova explosions.

A superwind is a type of gas outflow that expands adiabatically, carrying matter away from the galactic disk and filling the halo with multi-phase gas. This phenomenon involves hot, warm, cool, and relativistic components. Shocks associated with this process can accelerate cosmic rays to high energies.

Diffusive shock acceleration (DSA) is a mechanism where particles gain energy through repeated collisions with shocks, while stochastic diffusive acceleration (SDA) relies on stochastically interacting particles to gain energy. The efficiency of these mechanisms in starbursts like NGC 253 is critical for understanding cosmic ray production.

The strong mass load of the superwind recently determined through ALMA observations strongly attenuates the efficiency of DSA, while SDA is constrained by the age of the starburst. Under very special conditions, iron nuclei can only be accelerated beyond eV. If a starved supermassive black hole resides at the galaxy's center, accretion rates in Eddington units could contribute to energies up to eV.

title: Gravitational wave optical counterpart searching based on GRAWITA and DLT40 project during LIGO O2 run
input: The identification of the electromagnetic(EM) counterpart of gravitational wave(GW) trigger in the sky localization is a very difficult task because of the large uncertainty. Two complementary approaches are used in order to search for EM counterpart of GW signal with a typical large sky localization uncertainty: wide-field tilling search on high probability GW region, e.g. Gravitational Wave Inaf Team(GRAWITA) project or pointed search of selected galaxies in high probability GW region, e.g. Distance Less Than 40 Mpc survey(DLT40) project.

output.explanation:
The universe is governed by the laws of physics, where massive cosmic events such as supernovae and binary black hole mergers occur frequently.

Gravitational waves are ripples in spacetime that propagate through it, carrying information about their sources. They can be detected using sensitive instruments like LIGO.

Key terms include gravitational wave localization uncertainty, which refers to the difficulty of pinpointing a source's location due to limited data; wide-field tilling search, a method used to scan large areas for potential electromagnetic counterparts; and pointed searches, targeted efforts focusing on specific galaxies within high-probability regions. Gravitational waves are ripples in spacetime that propagate through it.

The interaction between gravitational wave signals and their corresponding electromagnetic counterparts is complex due to the uncertainty of localization. Wide-field tilling search projects like GRAWITA aim to scan extensive areas for potential electromagnetic counterparts, while focused efforts such as DLT40 concentrate on nearby galaxies with a distance of less than 40 megaparsecs.

title: Haze Production in the Atmospheres of super-Earths and mini-Neptunes: Insights from the Lab
input: Numerous solar system atmospheres possess aerosols including the characteristic organic hazes of Titan and Pluto. Haze particles substantially impact atmospheric temperatures structures and may provide organic material to the surface of a world, thereby affecting its habitability. Observations of exoplanet atmospheres suggest the presence of aerosols, especially in cooler (<800 K), smaller (<0.3 times Jupiter's mass) exoplanets. It remains unclear if the aerosols muting the spectroscopic features of exoplanet atmospheres are condensate clouds or photochemical hazes, which is difficult to predict from theory alone. We present here the first laboratory haze simulation experiments for atmospheric compositions expected for super-Earths and mini-Neptunes. We explored temperatures from 300 to 600 K and a range of atmospheric metallicities (100x, 1000x, 10000x solar); all simulated atmospheres produced particles, and the cooler (300 and 400 K) 1000x solar metallicity ("H2O-dominated", CH4-rich) experiments exhibited haze production rates higher than our standard Titan simulation (~10 mg/hr versus 7.4 mg/hr for Titan). However the particle production rates varied greatly, with measured rates as low as 0.04 mg/hr (100x solar metallicity, 600 K). Here we show that we should expect some, but not all, super-Earth and mini-Neptune atmospheres to possess a thick photochemically generated haze.

output.explanation:
The solar system's outer planets and dwarf worlds are characterized by the presence of aerosols, which significantly impact atmospheric temperatures and may provide organic material to their surfaces.

Aerosol formation in planetary atmospheres involves various physical processes, including metallicities, which refer to the abundance of elements heavier than hydrogen and helium relative to their solar system values. In this context, a 100x or 1000x metallicity indicates that an atmosphere contains ten times more heavy elements than our sun's atmosphere.

At lower temperatures (300-400 K), photochemical hazes can form through chemical reactions involving ultraviolet radiation. These processes result in the production of particles that can significantly impact an atmosphere's properties, such as its temperature structure and habitability.

The experiments described here simulated atmospheric conditions expected for super-Earths and mini-Neptunes, focusing on temperatures between 300 K and 600 K and varying metallicities (100x, 1000x, 10,000x solar). The results showed that all simulated atmospheres produced particles, with the cooler

title: Shaping HR8799's outer dust belt with an unseen planet
input: HR8799 is a benchmark system for direct imaging studies. It hosts two debris belts, which lie internally and externally to four giant planets. This paper considers how the four known planets and a possible fifth planet, interact with the external population of debris through N-body simulations. We find that when only the known planets are included, the inner edge of the outer belt predicted by our simulations is much closer to the outermost planet than recent ALMA observations suggest. We subsequently include a fifth planet in our simulations with a range of masses and semi-major axes, which is external to the outermost known planet. We find that a fifth planet with a mass and semi-major axis of 0.1 and 138au predicts an outer belt that agrees well with ALMA observations, whilst remaining stable for the lifetime of HR8799 and lying below current direct imaging detection thresholds. We also consider whether inward scattering of material from the outer belt can input a significant amount of mass into the inner belt. We find that for the current age of HR8799, only 1\% of the mass loss rate of the inner disk can be replenished by inward scattering. However we find that the higher rate of inward scattering during the first 10Myr of HR8799 would be expected to cause warm dust emission at a level similar to that currently observed, which may provide an explanation for such bright emission in other systems at Myr ages.

output.explanation:
The HR8799 system is a complex planetary environment with four known giant planets and possibly a fifth, located in the outer reaches of its orbit.

A debris belt is an accumulation of small particles that orbits around a star due to gravitational forces. In this context, it refers to a region where material from the disk has been perturbed into stable orbits by the gravitational influence of nearby planets.

The interaction between these giant planets and their surrounding environment can be understood through N-body simulations, which model the complex dynamics of multiple objects under mutual gravitational attraction. These simulations revealed that when only the four known planets are considered, their gravitational influence creates an inner edge to the outer belt much closer than observed by recent ALMA observations.

The introduction of a fifth planet into these simulations led to a configuration where its mass and semi-major axis were 0.1 and 138au respectively. This setup produced an outer belt consistent with ALMA data while maintaining system stability over HR8799's lifetime and remaining undetectable by current direct imaging methods.

title: The outflow structure of GW170817 from late time broadband observations
input: We present our broadband study of GW170817 from radio to hard X-rays, including NuSTAR and Chandra observations up to 165 days after the merger, and a multi-messenger analysis including LIGO constraints. The data are compared with predictions from a wide range of models, providing the first detailed comparison between non-trivial cocoon and jet models. Homogeneous and power-law shaped jets, as well as simple cocoon models are ruled out by the data, while both a Gaussian shaped jet and a cocoon with energy injection can describe the current dataset for a reasonable range of physical parameters, consistent with the typical values derived from short GRB afterglows. We propose that these models can be unambiguously discriminated by future observations measuring the post-peak behaviour, with slope -1.0 for the cocoon and -2.5 for the jet model.

output.explanation:
The merger of compact objects creates a complex environment involving relativistic jets and cocoon structures that interact with the surrounding interstellar medium, producing radiation across various wavelengths from radio to hard X-rays.

A jet is defined as a collimated outflow of energy, while a cocoon refers to a more diffuse structure formed by interactions between the jet and its surroundings. Energy injection into the cocoon can significantly alter its behavior.

The interaction between these structures determines their observable properties, such as radiation patterns in various wavelengths from radio to hard X-rays. The data collected from GW170817 reveal that homogeneous and power-law shaped jets are inconsistent with observations, while a Gaussian jet model and an energy-injected cocoon can describe the dataset for certain parameter ranges.

The post-peak behavior of these structures will be crucial in distinguishing between them: a slope of -1.0 is expected for the cocoon, while the jet model should exhibit a steeper decline at -2.5.

title: Mean Occupation Function of High Redshift Quasars from the Planck Cluster Catalog
input: We characterise the distribution of quasars within dark matter halos using a direct measurement technique for the first time at redshifts as high as . Using the Planck Sunyaev-Zeldovich (SZ) catalogue for galaxy groups and the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) DR12 quasar dataset, we assign host clusters/groups to the quasars and make a measurement of the mean number of quasars within dark matter halos as a function of halo mass. We find that a simple power-law fit of can be used to model the quasar fraction in dark matter halos. This suggests that the quasar fraction increases monotonically as a function of halo mass even to redshifts as high as .

output.explanation:
The universe's large-scale structure is comprised of vast regions where gravity dominates, known as dark matter halos. These halos come in various masses and contain galaxies. Quasars are incredibly luminous objects powered by supermassive black holes at their centers. 

The key concept here is that of quasar fraction, which refers to the proportion of quasars found within dark matter halos of a given mass. Dark matter is an invisible form of matter that does not emit or reflect light and can be inferred through gravitational effects on visible matter. In this context, the Planck Sunyaev-Zeldovich catalogue for galaxy groups provides a tool for identifying dark matter halos by detecting their thermal signatures in the cosmic microwave background radiation. 

The Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) DR12 quasar dataset offers a comprehensive catalog of quasars across various redshifts, allowing researchers to associate host clusters or groups with these luminous objects. By combining this information, scientists can study the distribution of quasars within dark matter halos and understand how their abundance changes as a function of halo mass. 

The research reveals that the quasar fraction in dark matter halos follows a simple power-law relationship, indicating an increase in quasar activity with higher halo masses even at high redshifts.

title: New simulation of QSO X-ray heating during the Cosmic Dawn
input: The upcoming radio interferometer Square Kilometre Array is expected to directly detect the redshifted 21-cm signal from the Cosmic Dawn for the first time. In this era temperature fluctuations from X-ray heating of the neutral intergalactic medium can impact this signal dramatically. Previously, in (Ross et al, 2017), we presented the first large-volume, 244 Mpc = 349 Mpc a side, fully numerical radiative transfer simulations of X-ray heating. This work is a follow-up where we now also consider QSO-like sources in addition to high mass X-ray binaries. Images of the two cases are clearly distinguishable at SKA1-LOW resolution and have RMS fluctuations above the expected noise. The inclusion of QSOs leads to a dramatic increase in non-Gaussianity of the signal, as measured by the skewness and kurtosis of the 21-cm signal. We conclude that this increased non-Gaussianity is a promising signature of early QSOs.

output.explanation:
The universe transitions from a dark era to the Cosmic Dawn, marking the formation of the first stars and galaxies. This period is characterized by intense X-ray heating of the neutral intergalactic medium, which impacts the 21-cm signal dramatically.

X-ray binaries are sources that emit high-energy radiation, while quasars are extremely luminous objects thought to be powered by supermassive black holes at galactic centers. Radiative transfer simulations model these processes to understand their effect on the 21-cm signal.

The interaction between X-rays and neutral gas leads to temperature fluctuations in the intergalactic medium. These fluctuations, in turn, affect the redshifted 21-cm signal detected by radio interferometers like the Square Kilometre Array (SKA).

The inclusion of quasars in radiative transfer simulations results in a dramatic increase in non-Gaussianity of the 21-cm signal, as measured by skewness and kurtosis. This increased non-Gaussianity is considered a promising signature for early quasar activity.

title: Probing the Seesaw Mechanism and Leptogenesis with the International Linear Collider
input: We investigate the potential of the International Linear Collider (ILC) to probe the mechanisms of neutrino mass generation and leptogenesis within the minimal seesaw model. Our results can also be used as an estimate for the potential of a Compact Linear Collider (CLIC). We find that heavy sterile neutrinos that simultaneously explain both, the observed light neutrino oscillations and the baryon asymmetry of the universe, can be found in displaced vertex searches at ILC. We further study the precision at which the flavour-dependent active-sterile mixing angles can be measured. The measurement of the ratios of these mixing angles, and potentially also of the heavy neutrino mass splitting, can test whether minimal type I seesaw models are the origin of the light neutrino masses, and it can be a first step towards probing leptogenesis as the mechanism of baryogenesis. Our results show that the ILC can be used as a discovery machine for New Physics in feebly coupled sectors that can address fundamental questions in particle physics and cosmology.

output.explanation:
The universe's fundamental forces and particles are governed by the Standard Model of particle physics, but it fails to explain certain phenomena such as neutrino mass generation.

A heavy sterile neutrino is a hypothetical particle that has a larger mass than the three known types of neutrinos (electron, muon, and tau). It interacts with normal matter through weak forces. A seesaw model refers to a theoretical framework for generating neutrino masses.

The International Linear Collider can accelerate electrons and positrons to high energies, allowing researchers to recreate conditions necessary for sterile neutrinos to interact with normal matter. Displaced vertex searches at the ILC could potentially detect heavy sterile neutrinos that explain both light neutrino oscillations and baryon asymmetry of the universe.

The precision at which flavour-dependent active-sterile mixing angles can be measured is crucial in this context, as it determines how strongly normal matter interacts with sterile neutrinos. Measuring these ratios could test whether minimal type I seesaw models are responsible for light neutrino masses and provide insight into leptogenesis as a mechanism of baryogenesis.

title: Similar complex kinematics within two massive, filamentary infrared dark clouds
input: Infrared dark clouds (IRDCs) are thought to be potential hosts of the elusive early phases of high-mass star formation. Here we conduct an in-depth kinematic analysis of one such IRDC, G034.43+00.24 (Cloud F), using high sensitivity and high spectral resolution IRAM-30m N H ( ) and C O ( ) observations. To disentangle the complex velocity structure within this cloud we use Gaussian decomposition and hierarchical clustering algorithms. We find that four distinct coherent velocity components are present within Cloud F. The properties of these components are compared to those found in a similar IRDC, G035.39-00.33 (Cloud H). We find that the components in both clouds have: high densities (inferred by their identification in N H ), trans-to-supersonic non-thermal velocity dispersions with Mach numbers of , a separation in velocity of 3 km s , and a mean red-shift of 0.3 km s between the N H (dense gas) and C O emission (envelope gas). The latter of these could suggest that these clouds share a common formation scenario. We investigate the kinematics of the larger-scale Cloud F structures, using lower-density-tracing CO ( ) observations. A good correspondence is found between the components identified in the IRAM-30m observations and the most prominent component in the CO data. We find that the IRDC Cloud F is only a small part of a much larger structure, which appears to be an inter-arm filament of the Milky Way.

output.explanation:
The Milky Way's interstellar medium hosts vast networks of gas and dust, with infrared dark clouds (IRDCs) being potential sites for high-mass star formation.

In astrophysics, a Mach number is the ratio of gas motion to sound speed, while trans-to-supersonic non-thermal velocity dispersions describe motions that approach or surpass local sound speeds. High-density regions within IRDCs are often associated with dense gas, whereas lower-density areas may correspond to envelope gas.

The complex velocity structure within an IRDC is a critical aspect of understanding its formation history. In Cloud F, four distinct coherent velocity components interact through physical processes that can be disentangled using Gaussian decomposition and hierarchical clustering algorithms.

Cloud F exhibits high densities, trans-to-supersonic non-thermal velocity dispersions with Mach numbers of , and a mean red-shift of 0.3 km s between N H (dense gas) and C O emission (envelope gas). This kinematic analysis suggests that Cloud F is part of an inter-arm filament within the Milky Way.

title: Galactic disk winds driven by cosmic ray pressure
input: Cosmic ray pressure gradients transfer energy and momentum to extraplanar gas in disk galaxies, potentially driving significant mass loss as galactic winds. This may be particularly important for launching high-velocity outflows of "cool" (T < 10^4 K) gas. We study cosmic-ray driven disk winds using a simplified semi-analytic model assuming streamlines follow the large-scale gravitational potential gradient. We consider scaled Milky Way-like potentials including a disk, bulge, and halo with a range of halo velocities V_H = 50-300 km/s, and streamline footpoints with radii in the disk R_0=1-16 kpc at height 1 kpc. Our solutions cover a wide range of footpoint gas velocity u_0, magnetic-to-cosmic-ray pressure ratio, gas-to-cosmic-ray pressure ratio, and angular momentum. Cosmic ray streaming at the Alfvén speed enables the effective sound speed C_eff to increase from the footpoint to a critical point where C_eff,c = u_c ~ V_H; this differs from thermal winds in which C_eff decreases outward. The critical point is typically at a height of 1-6 kpc from the disk, increasing with V_H, and the asymptotic wind velocity exceeds the escape speed of the halo. Mass loss rates are insensitive to the footpoint values of the magnetic field and angular momentum. In addition to numerical parameter space exploration, we develop and compare to analytic scaling relations. We show that winds have mass loss rates per unit area up to ~ Pi_0 V_H^-5/3 u_0^2/3 where Pi_0 is the footpoint cosmic ray pressure and u_0 is set by the upwelling of galactic fountains. The predicted wind mass-loss rate exceeds the star formation rate for V_H < 200 km/s and u_0 = 50 km/s, a typical fountain velocity.

output.explanation:
Galaxies are vast, gravitationally bound systems consisting of stars and gas.

The Alfvén speed is the maximum velocity at which magnetic fields can propagate through a plasma, while the effective sound speed represents the collective motion of particles in response to pressure gradients. A critical point marks the location where the effective sound speed equals the wind velocity. The halo's gravitational potential gradient guides the streamlines.

Cosmic ray streaming enables efficient energy transfer between magnetic fields and particles at the Alfvén speed, causing the effective sound speed to increase from its footpoint value to the critical point. This process differs from thermal winds where it decreases outward. The resulting wind velocities exceed the escape velocity of the galaxy's halo.

The mass loss rates associated with these cosmic ray driven winds are insensitive to magnetic field strength and angular momentum at the footpoint but depend on factors like Alfvén speed, effective sound speed, and critical point location. Specifically, they are proportional to Pi_0 V_H^-5/3 u_0^2/3 where Pi_0 is the footpoint cosmic ray pressure.

title: Nonparametric Methods in Astronomy: Think, Regress, Observe -- Pick Any Three
input: Telescopes are much more expensive than astronomers, so it is essential to minimize required sample sizes by using the most data-efficient statistical methods possible. However, the most commonly used model-independent techniques for finding the relationship between two variables in astronomy are flawed. In the worst case they can lead without warning to subtly yet catastrophically wrong results, and even in the best case they require more data than necessary. Unfortunately, there is no single best technique for nonparametric regression. Instead, we provide a guide for how astronomers can choose the best method for their specific problem and provide a python library with both wrappers for the most useful existing algorithms and implementations of two new algorithms developed here.

output.explanation:
Astronomical research relies on statistical methods to uncover relationships between variables, but current techniques can lead to incorrect results or require excessive data.

Nonparametric regression refers to the process of modeling complex relationships without making assumptions about their underlying structure. Statistical significance is a measure used to determine whether observed effects are due to chance or real patterns in the data.

The most commonly used statistical methods for finding relationships between variables in astronomy are flawed because they can lead to subtly yet catastrophically wrong results, even when using more data than necessary. This occurs because these techniques do not account for the underlying complexity of astronomical phenomena.

To minimize required sample sizes and avoid incorrect results, astronomers must choose the best statistical method for their specific problem. The provided guide helps astronomers select the most suitable technique by considering factors such as data efficiency and accuracy.

title: Elemental gas-phase abundances of intermediate redshift type Ia supernova star-forming host galaxies
input: The maximum luminosity of type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) depends on the oxygen abundance of the regions of the host galaxies where they explode. This metallicity dependence reduces the dispersion in the Hubble diagram (HD) when included with the traditional two-parameter calibration of SN Ia light-curve (LC) parameters and absolute magnitude. In this work, we use empirical calibrations to carefully estimate the oxygen abundance of galaxies hosting SNe Ia from the SDSS-II/SNe Survey at intermediate redshift, by measuring their emission line intensities. We also derive electronic temperature with the direct method for a small fraction of objects for consistency. We find a trend of decreasing oxygen abundance with increasing redshift for the most massive galaxies. Moreover, we study the dependence of the HD residuals (HR) with galaxy oxygen abundance obtaining a correlation in line with those found in other works. In particular, the HR vs oxygen abundance shows a slope of -0.186 0.123 mag dex (1.52 ), in good agreement with theoretical expectations. This implies smaller distance modulii after corrections for SNe Ia in metal-rich galaxies. Based on our previous results on local SNe Ia, we propose this dependence to be due to the lower luminosity of the SNe Ia produced in more metal-rich environments.

output.explanation:
Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) are a type of cosmic explosion that can be observed from vast distances, providing valuable information about the universe's expansion history.

Metallicity is an essential concept in astrophysics, referring to the amount of elements heavier than hydrogen and helium present in stars or interstellar gas. In this context, metallicity affects various processes, including SNe Ia maximum luminosity.

The Hubble diagram (HD) is a tool used for measuring distances across cosmic scales. By incorporating oxygen abundance into traditional SN Ia light-curve parameters and absolute magnitude calibrations, researchers can reduce dispersion in the HD. This process involves estimating galaxy oxygen abundances using empirical methods based on emission line intensities from surveys like SDSS-II/SNe Survey at intermediate redshifts.

The study reveals a trend where more massive galaxies exhibit decreasing oxygen abundance with increasing redshift. The Hubble diagram residuals (HR) also correlate with galaxy oxygen abundance, indicating smaller distance moduli after corrections for SNe Ia in metal-rich galaxies.

title: Detection of a Westward Hotspot Offset in the Atmosphere of a Hot Gas Giant CoRoT-2b
input: Short-period planets exhibit day-night temperature contrasts of hundreds to thousands of degrees K. They also exhibit eastward hotspot offsets whereby the hottest region on the planet is east of the substellar point; this has been widely interpreted as advection of heat due to eastward winds. We present thermal phase observations of the hot Jupiter CoRoT-2b obtained with the IRAC instrument on the Spitzer Space Telescope. These measurements show the most robust detection to date of a westward hotspot offset of 23 4 degrees, in contrast with the nine other planets with equivalent measurements. The peculiar infrared flux map of CoRoT-2b may result from westward winds due to non-synchronous rotation magnetic effects, or partial cloud coverage, that obscures the emergent flux from the planet's eastern hemisphere. Non-synchronous rotation and magnetic effects may also explain the planet's anomalously large radius. On the other hand, partial cloud coverage could explain the featureless dayside emission spectrum of the planet. If CoRoT-2b is not tidally locked, then it means that our understanding of star-planet tidal interaction is incomplete. If the westward offset is due to magnetic effects, our result represents an opportunity to study an exoplanet's magnetic field. If it has Eastern clouds, then it means that our understanding of large-scale circulation on tidally locked planets is incomplete.

output.explanation:
Short-period planets inhabit regions where intense stellar radiation heats their surfaces, causing extreme temperature variations between day and night.

The term 'hotspot offset' refers to the phenomenon where the hottest region on a planet is located east or west of its substellar point. This occurs due to wind patterns that distribute heat across the surface.

In the case of CoRoT-2b, non-synchronous rotation may induce magnetic effects leading to westward winds, while partial cloud coverage could obscure emergent flux from the eastern hemisphere. These factors might also explain the planet's large radius and featureless dayside emission spectrum.

The detection of a westward hotspot offset in CoRoT-2b suggests that our understanding of star-planet tidal interaction may be incomplete if this planet is not tidally locked. Alternatively, studying its magnetic field could provide valuable insights.

title: Optimal identification of HII regions during reionization in 21-cm observations
input: The ability of the future low frequency component of the Square Kilometre Array radio telescope (SKA-Low) to produce tomographic images of the redshifted 21-cm signal will enable direct studies of the evolution of the sizes and shapes of ionized regions during the Epoch of Reionization. However, a reliable identification of ionized regions in noisy interferometric data is not trivial. Here, we introduce an image processing method known as superpixels for this purpose. We compare this method with two other previously proposed ones, one relying on a chosen threshold and the other employing automatic threshold determination using the K-Means algorithm. We use a correlation test and compare power spectra and bubble size distributions to show that the superpixels method provides a better identification of ionized regions, especially in the case of noisy data. We also describe some possible additional applications of the superpixel method, namely the derivation of the ionization history and constraints on the source properties in specific regions.

output.explanation:
The Epoch of Reionization is a period in the universe's history when neutral gas was converted into plasma by radiation from stars and other sources, creating large-scale ionized regions known as bubbles. These bubbles can be identified through the redshifted 21-cm signal, which SKA-Low will detect using tomographic imaging.

The term superpixel refers to a small, uniform area within an image that can be used to identify distinct features. In this context, it's an image processing method for isolating ionized regions from surrounding noise in noisy interferometric data.

Superpixels are compared with two other methods: one relying on a manually chosen threshold and another using automatic threshold determination via K-Means clustering. The analysis shows that superpixels outperform these methods in identifying ionized regions, particularly when dealing with noisy data.

The superpixel method provides better identification of ionized regions due to its ability to isolate distinct features from surrounding noise, especially in the case of noisy interferometric data.

title: Probing galaxy assembly bias with LRG weak lensing observations
input: In Montero-Dorta et al. 2017, we show that luminous red galaxies (LRGs) from the SDSS-III Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS) at can be divided into two groups based on their star formation histories. So-called fast-growing LRGs assemble of their stellar mass at , whereas slow-growing LRGs reach the same evolutionary state at . We further demonstrate that these two subpopulations present significantly different clustering properties on scales of . Here, we measure the mean halo mass of each subsample using the galaxy-galaxy lensing technique, in the overlap of the LRG catalogue and the CS82 and CFHTLenS shear catalogues. We show that fast- and slow-growing LRGs have similar lensing profiles, which implies that they live in haloes of similar mass: and . This result, combined with the clustering difference, suggests the existence of galaxy assembly bias, although the effect is too subtle to be definitively proven given the errors on our current weak-lensing measurement. We show that this can soon be achieved with upcoming surveys like DES.

output.explanation:
The universe is composed of vast galaxy clusters, with luminous red galaxies being a key component. Luminous red galaxies are characterized by their high mass and distinct star formation histories.

A crucial term in this context is 'lensing profile,' which refers to the distortion of light around massive objects due to gravitational effects. Another important concept is 'halo mass,' which describes the amount of dark matter surrounding a galaxy.

The process begins with galaxies forming within their respective haloes, with fast-growing luminous red galaxies accumulating mass at a faster rate than slow-growing ones. This difference in growth rates leads to distinct clustering properties among these subpopulations. The lensing profiles of both groups are found to be similar, indicating that they reside within haloes of comparable masses.

The similarity in halo masses combined with the differing clustering properties suggests the presence of galaxy assembly bias. However, this effect remains subtle and requires further investigation due to current measurement uncertainties. Future surveys may provide more precise insights into this phenomenon.

title: Self-interacting dark matter constraints in a thick dark disk scenario
input: A thick dark matter disk is predicted in cold dark matter simulations as the outcome of the interaction between accreted satellites and the stellar disk in Milky Way sized halos. We study the effects of a self-interacting thick dark disk on the energetic neutrino flux from the Sun. We find that for particle masses between 100 GeV and 1 TeV and dark matter annihilation to heavy leptons either the self-interaction may not be strong enough to solve the small scale structure motivation or a dark disk cannot be present in the Milky Way.

output.explanation:
The universe's large-scale structure is shaped by the presence of dark matter, a type of matter that does not emit light.

Dark matter self-interaction refers to the hypothetical process by which these particles interact with one another through forces beyond gravity. A key term in understanding this phenomenon is 'self-interacting', meaning that the dark matter particles affect each other's behavior directly rather than solely through their gravitational pull. Another important concept is 'dark disk', a thick layer of dark matter predicted to form within the galaxy's halo.

The interaction between accreted satellites and the stellar disk in Milky Way sized halos leads to the formation of this dark disk, which can then affect its surroundings by altering particle distributions. In particular, it may influence the energetic neutrino flux from the Sun.

For particles with masses between 100 GeV and 1 TeV annihilating into heavy leptons, either a self-interacting thick dark disk is not strong enough to address small-scale structure motivations or such a disk cannot exist in the Milky Way.

title: ALMA Reveals an Inhomogeneous Compact Rotating Dense Molecular Torus at the NGC 1068 Nucleus
input: We present the results of our ALMA Cycle 4 high-spatial-resolution (0.04-0.07") observations, at HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 lines, of the nucleus of NGC 1068, the nearby prototypical type 2 active galactic nucleus (AGN). Our previous ALMA observations identified the compact emission of these lines at the putative location of the torus around a mass-accreting supermassive black hole. We now report that we have detected the rotation of this compact emission, with the eastern and western sides being redshifted and blueshifted, respectively. Unlike the previously reported CO J=6-5 emission, both the morphological and dynamical alignments of the HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 emission are roughly aligned along the east-west direction (i.e., the expected torus direction), suggesting that these molecular lines are better probes of a rotating dense molecular gas component in the torus. The western part of the torus exhibits larger velocity dispersion and stronger emission in the HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 lines than the eastern part, revealing a highly inhomogeneous molecular torus. The dense molecular gas in the torus and that of the host galaxy at 0.5-2.0" from the AGN along the torus direction are found to be counter-rotating, suggesting an external process happened in the past at the NGC 1068 nucleus.

output.explanation:
Active galactic nuclei (AGN) are characterized by a supermassive black hole surrounded by an accretion disk and a torus of dense molecular gas. 

The term 'torus' refers to the doughnut-shaped structure surrounding the AGN, while 'kinematics' is the study of how objects move under external forces. In this context, it involves understanding rotation and velocity dispersion within the torus. The latter measures cloud movement relative to each other. 

The compact emission observed at HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 lines originates from the torus, where dense molecular gas interacts with strong gravity. High-spatial-resolution observations reveal that these lines are better probes of a rotating dense molecular component in the torus than previously reported CO J=6-5 emission. 

The western part of the torus exhibits larger velocity dispersion and stronger emission in HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 lines, indicating an inhomogeneous structure with varying mass accretion or external influences.

title: Cored density profiles in the DARKexp model
input: The DARKexp model represents a novel and promising attempt to solve a long standing problem of statistical mechanics, that of explaining from first principles the quasi--stationary states at the end of the collisionless gravitational collapse. The model, which yields good fits to observation and simulation data on several scales, was originally conceived to provide a theoretical basis for the cusp of the Navarro--Frenk--White profile. In this note we show that it also allows for cored density profiles that, when viewed in three dimensions, in the limit have the conical shape characteristic of the Burkert profile. It remains to be established whether both cusps and cores, or only one of the two types, are allowed beyond the asymptotic analysis of this work.

output.explanation:
The universe's gravitational collapse is a complex process where matter accumulates under gravity, forming intricate structures. Quasi-stationary states refer to stable configurations that emerge at the end of these collapses. Statistical mechanics aims to explain these phenomena from first principles. The DARKexp model represents an attempt to apply statistical mechanics to quasi-stationary states in gravitational collapse.

Key terms like Navarro-Frenk-White profile and Burkert profile are used to describe density profiles formed during gravitational collapse. A cusp is a sharp increase in density towards the center, while core-like profiles exhibit a more gradual decrease in density as one moves inward. The DARKexp model allows for both types of profiles.

The interaction between matter accumulation under gravity and statistical mechanics leads to quasi-stationary states with distinct properties. These properties are influenced by the balance between gravitational forces and statistical fluctuations. In three-dimensional space, cored density profiles predicted by the DARKexp model can exhibit a conical shape characteristic of the Burkert profile.

The DARKexp model's ability to explain both cuspy and core-like profiles remains uncertain beyond its theoretical analysis. It is unclear whether both types are allowed or if only one prevails due to limitations in understanding gravitational collapse at very small scales.

title: Precision Projector Laboratory: Detector Characterization with an Astronomical Emulation Testbed
input: As astronomical observations from space benefit from improved sensitivity, the effectiveness of scientific programs is becoming limited by systematics that often originate in poorly understood image sensor behavior. Traditional, bottom-up detector characterization methods provide one way to model underlying detector physics, and generate ever more faithful numerical simulations, but this approach is vulnerable to preconceptions and over-simplification. The alternative top-down approach is laboratory emulation, which enables observation, calibration, and analysis scenarios to be tested without relying on a complete understanding of the underlying physics. This complements detector characterization and simulation efforts by testing their validity. We describe a laboratory facility and experimental testbed that supports the emulation of a wide range of mission concepts such as gravitational weak lensing measurements by WFIRST and high precision spectrophotometry of transiting exoplanets by JWST. An Offner relay projects readily customizable "scenes" (e.g. stars, galaxies, spectra) with very low optical aberration over the full area of a typical optical or near infrared image sensor. f/8 and slower focal ratios may be selected, spanning those of most proposed space missions and approximating the point spread function (PSF) size of seeing limited ground based surveys. Diffraction limited PSFs are projected over a wide field of view and wavelength range to deliver highly predictable image patterns down to sub-pixel scales with stable intensity and fine motion control. The testbed enables realistic validation of detector performance on science-like images, which aids mission design and survey strategy, as well as targeted investigations of various detector effects.

output.explanation:
Astronomical observations from space benefit from improved sensitivity, but this increased precision is limited by systematics originating in image sensor behavior.

In the context of detector characterization, a key term to understand is 'detector physics,' which refers to the underlying physical processes governing image sensors. Another important concept is an 'Offner relay,' a device that projects customizable images with minimal optical distortion over the full area of an image sensor. This allows for the simulation of various mission concepts.

The laboratory facility described in this context utilizes an Offner relay to project scenes with very low optical aberration, enabling the emulation of different space missions and their detector performance on science-like images. The testbed achieves this by projecting diffraction-limited point spread functions over a wide field of view and wavelength range, delivering highly predictable image patterns.

The facility's capabilities include simulating various mission concepts such as gravitational weak lensing measurements and high-precision spectrophotometry of transiting exoplanets. It enables realistic validation of detector performance on science-like images, aiding in mission design and survey strategy.

title: Status and performance of the THD2 bench in multi-deformable mirror configuration
input: The architecture of exoplanetary systems is relatively well known inward to 1 AU thanks to indirect techniques, which have allowed characterization of thousands of exoplanet orbits, masses and sometimes radii. The next step is the characterization of exoplanet atmospheres at long period, which requires direct imaging capability. While the characterization of a handful of young giant planets is feasible with dedicated instruments like SPHERE/VLT, GPI/Gemini, SCExAO/Subaru and soon with the coronagraphic capabilities aboard JWST, the spectroscopic study of mature giant planets and lower mass planets (Neptune-like, Super Earths) requires the achievement of better coronagraphic performance.
