The detectors will be made with Transition Edge Sensor (TES) bolometers cooled to a 100 milli-Kelvin base temperature by an adiabatic demagnetization refrigerator.The TES bolometers will be read out using digital frequency multiplexing with Superconducting QUantum Interference Device (SQUID) amplifiers. Up to 78 bolometers will be multiplexed with a single SQUID amplidier. We report on the sub-Kelvin instrument design and ongoing developments for the LiteBIRD mission.

output.explanation:
The universe's early stages are characterized by rapid expansion, a phenomenon known as inflation. Inflation is thought to have occurred an instant after the birth of the universe and provides a compelling explanation for observed patterns in the Cosmic Microwave Background anisotropies.

Inflation generates primordial gravitational waves that can be detected through their imprint on B-mode polarization patterns embedded within these anisotropies. The detection of such signals would serve as strong evidence for inflation, allowing researchers to pinpoint the correct model and gain insight into physics at ultra-high energies.

Key technical terms include: Transition Edge Sensor (TES) bolometers, which are cooled to a base temperature using adiabatic demagnetization refrigerators; digital frequency multiplexing with Superconducting QUantum Interference Device (SQUID) amplifiers; and trichroic pixels. TES bolometers convert incoming radiation into electrical signals that can be processed by SQUID amplifiers.

The LiteBIRD satellite mission aims to detect degree-and-larger-angular-scale B-mode polarization through the use of sub-Kelvin instruments, including Transition Edge Sensor (TES) bolometers and readout electronics. The detection of primordial gravitational waves would provide strong evidence for inflation and open a window into physics at ultra-high energies.

title: Commercialization of micro-fabrication of antenna-coupled Transition Edge Sensor bolometer detectors for studies of the Cosmic Microwave Background
input: We report on the development of commercially fabricated multi-chroic antenna coupled Transition Edge Sensor (TES) bolometer arrays for Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) polarimetry experiments. CMB polarimetry experiments have deployed instruments in stages. Stage-II experiments deployed with O(1,000) detectors and reported successful detection of B-mode (divergent free) polarization pattern in the CMB. Stage-III experiments have recently started observing with O(10,000) detectors with wider frequency coverage. A concept for a Stage-IV experiment, CMB-S4, is emerging to make a definitive measurement of CMB polarization from the ground with O(400,000) detectors. The orders of magnitude increase in detector count for CMB-S4 requires a new approach in detector fabrication to increase fabrication throughput.and reduce cost. We report on collaborative efforts with two commercial micro-fabrication foundries to fabricate antenna coupled TES bolometer detectors. The detector design is based on the sinuous antenna coupled dichroic detector from the POLARBEAR-2 experiment. The TES bolometers showed the expected I-V response and the RF performance agrees with simulation. We will discuss the motivation, design consideration, fabrication processes, test results, and how industrial detector fabrication could be a path to fabricate hundreds of detector wafers for future CMB polarimetry experiments.

output.explanation:
The Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) is the residual heat from the Big Bang, detectable in microwave radiation. CMB polarimetry experiments aim to measure this polarization pattern, which encodes information about the universe's magnetic fields and matter distribution. 

The development of these experiments has progressed through stages: Stage-II deployed instruments with 1,000 detectors, detecting B-mode (divergent free) polarization patterns in the CMB; Stage-III uses 10,000 detectors with wider frequency coverage. The upcoming Stage-IV experiment, CMB-S4, will employ 400,000 detectors to make a definitive measurement of CMB polarization from the ground. 

The increasing detector count for CMB-S4 necessitates new approaches in fabrication to boost throughput and reduce costs. Collaborative efforts with commercial micro-fabrication foundries have led to the development of antenna coupled Transition Edge Sensor (TES) bolometer arrays, a crucial component for these experiments. These detectors consist of sinuous antennas that couple dichroic signals from the CMB. 

The TES bolometers exhibit the expected current-voltage response and radio frequency performance aligns with simulation results.

title: Magnetic Fields from Filaments to Cores
input: How important is the magnetic (B-) field when compared to gravity and turbulence in the star-formation process? Does its importance depend on scale and location? We summarize submm dust polarization observations towards the large filamentary infrared dark cloud G34 and towards a dense core in the high-mass star-forming region W51. We detect B-field orientations that are either perpendicular or parallel to the G34 filament axis. These B-field orientations further correlate with local velocity gradients. Towards three cores in G34 we find a varying importance between B-field, gravity, and turbulence that seems to dictate varying types of fragmentation. At highest resolution towards the gravity-dominated collapsing core W51 e2 we resolve new B-field features, such as converging B-field lines and possibly magnetic channels.

output.explanation:
The star-formation process occurs within vast interstellar gas clouds, where magnetic fields interact with gravity and turbulence to shape the cloud's structure.

The term 'magnetic field' refers to a vector quantity that describes the orientation of magnetic forces in space. Gravity is a fundamental force that attracts matter towards its center, while turbulence represents chaotic motions within the cloud. The importance of these factors can vary depending on scale and location.

The interaction between magnetic fields and gravity is crucial for understanding star formation. When magnetic field lines converge or diverge, they can influence the flow of gas and dust, potentially leading to fragmentation. In regions where gravity dominates, such as W51 e2, new features like converging B-field lines may emerge.

The observations suggest that the relative importance of magnetic fields, gravity, and turbulence varies across different cores in G34, influencing the types of fragmentation that occur.

title: The magnetic variability of the ~Cep star \,CMa
input: CMa is a known magnetic star showing rotationally modulated magnetic variability with a period of 2.17937 d. However, recent work based on high-resolution spectropolarimetry suggests that the rotation period is longer than 30 years. We compare our new spectropolarimetric measurements with FORS 2 at the VLT acquired on three consecutive nights in 2017 to previous FORS 1/2 measurements of the longitudinal magnetic field strength. The new longitudinal magnetic field values are in the range from 115 to 240 G and do not support the presence of a long period.

output.explanation:
Magnetic stars like CMa reside in the vast expanse of space, their magnetic fields influencing nearby matter.

Key terms such as rotational modulation and longitudinal magnetic field strength are crucial for understanding these phenomena. Rotational modulation refers to periodic changes in brightness due to a star's rotation, while longitudinal magnetic field strength is measured using spectropolarimetry by analyzing light polarization through the star's atmosphere.

The interaction between CMa's strong magnetic field and its rotational period leads to observable effects on nearby matter. The process of measuring longitudinal magnetic field strength involves observing changes in emitted light due to the magnetic field, providing valuable insights into the star's behavior.

New measurements from FORS 2 at the VLT indicate that CMa has a longitudinal magnetic field strength ranging from 115 to 240 Gauss, contradicting the notion of a long stellar rotation period. This suggests that the previously proposed longer rotation period is unlikely.

title: Determination of the size of the dust torus in H0507+164 through optical and infrared monitoring
input: The time delay between flux variations in different wavelength bands can be used to probe the inner regions of active galactic nuclei (AGN). Here, we present the first measurements of the time delay between optical and near-infrared (NIR) flux variations in H0507+164, a nearby Seyfert 1.5 galaxy at z = 0.018. The observations in the optical V -band and NIR J, H and Ks bands carried over 35 epochs during the period October 2016 to April 2017 were used to estimate the inner radius of the dusty torus. From a careful reduction and analysis of the data using cross-correlation techniques, we found delayed responses of the J, H and Ks light curves to the V -band light curve. In the rest frame of the source, the lags between optical and NIR bands are found to be days (V vs. J), days (V vs. H) and days (V vs. K ). The lags between the optical and different NIR bands are thus consistent with each other. The measured lags indicate that the inner edge of dust torus is located at a distance of 0.029 pc from the central UV/optical AGN continuum. This is larger than the radius of the broad line region of this object determined from spectroscopic monitoring observations thereby supporting the unification model of AGN. The location of H0507+164 in the τ - MV plane indicates that our results are in excellent agreement with the now known lag-luminosity scaling relationship for dust in AGN.

output.explanation:
Active galactic nuclei (AGN) reside at the centers of galaxies, where supermassive black holes are surrounded by a disk of hot gas and dust particles. The dusty torus is a critical component in AGN systems, as it determines how much light from the central region can escape to our line of sight.

The key terms 'dusty torus' and 'dust extinction' refer to the absorption or scattering of light by interstellar dust particles. Dust extinction affects different wavelengths differently, with shorter wavelengths being more affected than longer ones. In this context, near-infrared (NIR) and optical wavelengths are used as probes for the inner radius of the dusty torus.

The time delay between flux variations in these two wavelength bands can be attributed to the difference in dust extinction affecting NIR and optical light curves. The lags between optical and NIR light curves indicate that the inner edge of the dust torus is located at a distance from the central UV/optical AGN continuum, supporting the unification model of AGN.

The measured time delays suggest that the dusty torus in H0507+164 is located approximately 0.029 pc away from the central AGN continuum, consistent with the lag-luminosity scaling relationship for dust in AGN.

title: Excitation and charge transfer in low-energy hydrogen atom collisions with neutral iron
input: Data for inelastic processes due to hydrogen atom collisions with iron are needed for accurate modelling of the iron spectrum in late-type stars. Excitation and charge transfer in low-energy Fe+H collisions is studied theoretically using a previously presented method based on an asymptotic two-electron linear combination of atomic orbitals (LCAO) model of ionic-covalent interactions in the neutral atom-hydrogen-atom system, together with the multi-channel Landau-Zener model. An extensive calculation including 166 covalent states and 25 ionic states is presented and rate coefficients are calculated for temperatures in the range 1000 - 20000 K. The largest rates are found for charge transfer processes to and from two clusters of states around 6.3 and 6.6 eV excitation, corresponding in both cases to active 4d and 5p electrons undergoing transfer. Excitation and de-excitation processes among these two sets of states are also significant.

output.explanation:
In the context of late-type stars, iron is a key element that interacts with hydrogen atoms through various processes. The atomic structure of these elements can be described using terms like ionic-covalent interactions and linear combination of atomic orbitals (LCAO). Ionic-covalent interactions refer to the exchange of electrons between ions and neutral atoms, while LCAO describes how atomic orbitals combine to form molecular states.

In low-energy collisions between iron and hydrogen, excitation and charge transfer occur. Excitation refers to the energy gained by an atom or ion due to interaction with another particle, whereas charge transfer involves the exchange of electrons between particles. The multi-channel Landau-Zener model is used to study these interactions.

Theoretical calculations involving 166 covalent states and 25 ionic states have been performed to determine rate coefficients for temperatures ranging from 1000 K to 20000 K. These rates are significant, particularly for charge transfer processes occurring at specific energy levels around 6.3 and 6.6 eV.

The largest rates of excitation and de-excitation occur among two clusters of states corresponding to active 4d and 5p electrons undergoing transfer.

title: Likelihood analysis of small field polynomial models of inflation yielding a high Tensor-to-Scalar ratio
input: Inflationary potentials, with Planckian field excursions, described by a 6th degree polynomial are studied. We solve the Mukhanov-Sasaki equations exactly and employ a probabilistic approach as well as multinomial fitting to analyse the results. We identify the most likely models which yield a tensor-to-scalar ratio in addition to currently allowed Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) spectrum and observables. Additionally, we find a significant inter-dependence of CMB observables in these models. This might be an important effect for future analyses, since the different moments of the primordial power spectrum are taken to be independent in the usual Markov chain Monte Carlo methods.

output.explanation:
The universe's early stages are characterized by rapid expansion, driven by inflationary potentials that reach Planckian energies. Inflationary potential: a mathematical function describing how a field's energy density evolves over time. This concept is crucial for understanding cosmic expansion and the evolution of perturbations during this period.

 The Mukhanov-Sasaki equations govern the behavior of these perturbations, which have been solved exactly in this study. A probabilistic approach has also been applied to analyze the results, using multinomial fitting to identify the most likely models satisfying certain conditions.

 These models must yield a tensor-to-scalar ratio within current limits set by Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) observations and satisfy other constraints related to CMB observables. The study finds that these observables are significantly inter-dependent in these models, challenging the usual assumption of independence between different moments of the primordial power spectrum.

 This inter-dependence could have important implications for future analyses using Markov chain Monte Carlo methods.

title: Testing general relativity using binary extreme-mass-ratio inspirals
input: It is known that massive black holes (MBHs) of could capture small compact objects to form extreme-mass-ratio inspirals (EMRIs). Such systems emit gravitational waves (GWs) in the band of the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA) and are ideal probes of the space-time geometry of MBHs. Recently, we have shown that MBHs could also capture stellar-mass binary black holes (about ) to form binary-EMRIs (b-EMRIs) and, interestingly, a large fraction of the binaries coalesce due to the tidal perturbation by the MBHs. Here we further show that the coalescence could be detected by LISA as glitches in EMRI signals. We propose an experiment to use the multi-band ( and Hz) glitch signals to test gravity theories. Our simulations suggest that the experiment could measure the mass and linear momentum lost via GW radiation, as well as constrain the mass of gravitons, to a precision that is one order of magnitude better than the current limit.

output.explanation:
Massive black holes reside at the centers of galaxies, their immense gravity warping space-time around them 

The term extreme-mass-ratio inspirals (EMRIs) refers to a process where two objects with vastly different masses interact gravitationally, emitting gravitational waves in specific frequency bands. EMRIs are valuable probes of space-time geometry due to their unique properties and sensitivity to the strong-field gravity of MBHs 

A key concept is that massive black holes can capture small compact objects or even stellar-mass binary black hole systems through tidal perturbations, causing them to coalesce into a single object. This process involves gravitational interaction between the MBH and the captured system 

The mechanism behind this process relies on the strong gravity of the MBH causing energy loss through gravitational waves as it interacts with the captured objects. As these interactions occur in specific frequency bands detectable by LISA, they can be used to test gravity theories and measure properties like mass lost via GW radiation.

title: Emission-line diagnostics of nearby HII regions including interacting binary populations
input: We present numerical models of the nebular emission from H II regions around young stellar populations over a range of compositions and ages. The synthetic stellar pop- ulations include both single stars and interacting binary stars. We compare these models to the observed emission lines of 254 HII regions of 13 nearby spiral galax- ies and 21 dwarf galaxies drawn from archival data. The models are created using the combination of the Binary Population and Spectral Synthesis (bpass) code with the photoionization code cloudy to study the differences caused by the inclusion of interacting binary stars in the stellar population. We obtain agreement with the observed emission line ratios from the nearby star-forming regions and discuss the effect of binary star evolution pathways on the nebular ionization of H II regions. We find that at population ages above 10 Myr, single-star models rapidly decrease in flux and ionization strength, while binary-star model still produce strong flux and high O III/H ratios. Our models can reproduce the metallicity of H II regions from spiral galaxies but we find higher metallicities than previously estimated for the H II regions from dwarf galaxies. Comparing the equivalent width of H emission between mod- els and observations, we find that accounting for ionizing photon leakage can affect age estimates for HII regions. When it is included, the typical age derived for HII regions is 5Myr from single-star models, and up to 10Myr with binary-star models. This is due to the existence of binary-star evolution pathways which produce more hot WR and helium stars at older ages. For future reference, we calculate new BPASS binary maximal starburst lines as a function of metallicity, and for the total model population, and present these in Appendix A.

output.explanation:
The universe's star-forming regions, known as H II regions, are areas where new stars and planets emerge from vast clouds of gas and dust in galaxies like spiral and dwarf galaxies.

In this context, key terms include H II regions, which are ionized hydrogen clouds; binary stars, pairs of stars orbiting each other; and metallicity, the abundance of elements heavier than hydrogen and helium in a region's gas. The nebular emission from these regions is a result of intense radiation interacting with the surrounding interstellar medium.

The interaction between young stars' radiation and the interstellar medium leads to ionization, which can be influenced by binary star evolution pathways producing more hot WR and helium stars at older ages. This process affects the flux and ionization strength in H II regions over time.

At population ages above 10 million years, single-star models rapidly decrease in flux and ionization strength, while binary-star models continue to produce strong flux and high O III/H ratios due to their evolution pathways.

title: Cospatial Star Formation and Supermassive Black Hole Growth in Galaxies: Evidence for In-situ Co-evolution
input: We present a sub-kpc localization of the sites of supermassive black hole (SMBH) growth in three active galactic nuclei (AGN) at in relation to the regions of intense star formation in their hosts. These AGNs are selected from Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array (VLA) and Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) observations in the HUDF and COSMOS, with the centimetric radio emission tracing both star formation and AGN, and the sub/millimeter emission by dust tracing nearly pure star formation. We require radio emission to be more luminous than the level associated with the sub/millimeter star formation to ensure that the radio emission is AGN-dominated, thereby allowing localization of the AGN and star formation independently. In all three galaxies, the AGN are located within the compact regions of gas-rich, heavily obscured, intense nuclear star formation, with kpc and average star formation rates of yr . If the current episode of star formation continues at such a rate over the stellar mass doubling time of their hosts, Gyr, the newly formed stellar mass will be of the order of within the central kpc region, concurrently and cospatially with significant growth of the SMBH. This is consistent with a picture of in-situ galactic bulge and SMBH formation. This work demonstrates the unique complementarity of VLA and ALMA observations to unambiguously pinpoint the locations of AGN and star formation down to mas, corresponding to pc at .

output.explanation:
Galaxies are vast, gravitationally bound systems of stars and interstellar gas. Supermassive black holes reside at their centers. The term supermassive black hole refers to a massive black hole residing at the center of a galaxy. Active galactic nuclei describe galaxies with intense energy output due to accretion onto their central black holes. Star formation is the process by which gas and dust in a galaxy collapse under gravity, forming new stars.

The radio emission from centimetric waves can indicate both star formation and AGN activity, while sub/millimeter emission primarily traces star formation. This dual nature of radio emission allows for independent localization of AGNs and star-forming regions.

The mechanism behind supermassive black hole growth involves the simultaneous formation of stars within compact gas-rich regions of intense nuclear star formation. These areas are heavily obscured, and their radio emission must be more luminous than that associated with sub/millimeter star formation to isolate the AGN's location. This process leads to significant growth of both stars and supermassive black holes over time.

The research reveals that in all three galaxies, supermassive black holes are situated within compact regions of intense nuclear star formation, concurrently growing alongside newly formed stellar mass within the central kpc region.

title: Neutrino-nucleon scattering in the neutrino-sphere
input: We calculate the differential scattering rate for thermal neutrinos in a hot and dilute gas of interacting neutrons using linear response theory. The dynamical structure factors for density and spin fluctuations of the strongly interacting neutron matter, expected in the neutrino decoupling regions of supernovae and neutron star mergers, are calculated in the virial expansion for the first time. Correlations due to nucleon-nucleon interactions are taken into account using a pseudo-potential that reproduces measured nucleon-nucleon phase shifts, and we find that attractive s-wave interactions enhance the density response and suppress the spin response of neutron matter. The net effect of neutron correlations is to strongly suppress backscattering. Moreover, we find nearly exact scaling laws for the response functions, valid for the range MeV and q < 30 MeV, allowing us to obtain analytic results for the dynamic structure factors at second-order in the fugacity of the neutron gas. We find that the modification of scattering rates depends on the energy and momentum exchanged, implying that dynamical structure factors are essential to describe neutrino decoupling in supernovae and neutron star mergers.

output.explanation:
In extreme astrophysical environments, such as supernovae and neutron star mergers, a hot gas of interacting neutrons is present.

The term 'fugacity' refers to the ratio of the average kinetic energy of particles in a system to their thermal energy. The virial expansion is an approximation used to calculate thermodynamic properties of systems with strong interactions between particles. A pseudo-potential is a mathematical representation of nucleon-nucleon interactions that reproduces measured phase shifts.

In this context, neutron correlations refer to the effects of attractive s-wave interactions on density and spin fluctuations in strongly interacting neutron matter. These correlations lead to enhanced density response and suppressed spin response, resulting in strong suppression of backscattering.

The modification of scattering rates for thermal neutrinos depends on energy and momentum exchanged between particles. This dependence is essential for accurately describing neutrino decoupling in supernovae and neutron star mergers.

title: Gravitational wave bursts from long gamma-ray bursts
input: One of the most luminous explosions detected, gamma-ray bursts, especially the so-called long-duration bursts, most probably consist of an intrinsic core-collapse to a black hole inside a super massive star. We point out that this collapse alone will give a generic gravitational wave burst. It has been shown that the strength of this burst depends on the dimensionless spin parameter of the collapsing object. Under descent assumptions the gamma-ray burst's central engine powers the explosion electromagnetically due to the rotation of the newly formed black hole. We argue that the peak luminosity and the isotropic energy of the gamma-ray burst can be associated with the spin of the black hole, due to this mechanism. Since, both gravitational and electromagnetic emission depend on the spin, they can be correlated and thus give a straight estimate for the gravitational wave burst, when we have in hand a gamma-ray burst with known distance. We discuss detectability limits for present and future detectors.

output.explanation:
The collapse of a supermassive star into a black hole is thought to be the source of long-duration gamma-ray bursts, which are among the most luminous explosions in the universe. 

The core-collapse process itself generates a generic gravitational wave burst, with its strength dependent on the dimensionless spin parameter of the collapsing object. This collapse also powers the explosion electromagnetically due to the rotation of the newly formed black hole, producing both gamma-ray emission and gravitational waves that are correlated through their dependence on the black hole's spin. 

The peak luminosity and isotropic energy of a gamma-ray burst can thus be linked to the spin of its central engine, enabling an estimate of the associated gravitational wave burst when the distance to the event is known. 

Key terms include: dimensionless spin parameter - a measure of the black hole's angular momentum; intrinsic core-collapse - the process by which a supermassive star collapses into a black hole.

title: Earth Similarity Index and Habitability Studies of Exoplanets
input: Study of exoplanets has been of considerable interest for Astronomers, Planetary Scientists and Astrobiologists. Analysis of huge planetary data from space missions such as CoRoT and Kepler is directed ultimately at finding a planet similar to Earth- the Earth's twin, and looking for potential habitability. The Earth Similarity Index (ESI) is defined to find the similarity with Earth, which ranges from 1 (Earth) to 0 (totally dissimilar to Earth). ESI can be computed using four physical parameters of a planet, namely radius, density, escape velocity and surface temperature. The surface temperature entering surface ESI is a non-observable quantity and what we know is only equilibrium temperature of exoplanets. We have established a relation between surface and equilibrium temperatures using the data available for the solar system objects to address the difficulty in determining surface temperature. From the ESI analysis, we have found 20 Earth-like exoplanets with ESI value above 0.8, which is set as the threshold. We are also interested in Mars-like planets to search for planets that may host the extreme life For example, methane-specific extremophile life form metabolism, for which a new approach, called Mars Similarity Index (MSI) is introduced. MSI is defined in the range between 1 (present Mars) and 0 (dissimilar to present Mars) and uses the same physical parameters as that of ESI. We introduced another new approach to study the potential habitability of exoplanets based on Cobb-Douglas Function, multi-parametric function. This did not yield any encouraging results.

output.explanation:
The search for exoplanets is a significant area of study in astronomy and astrobiology, focusing on planets with characteristics similar to those of Earth and Mars.

Key terms such as the Earth Similarity Index (ESI) and Mars Similarity Index (MSI) rely on physical parameters like radius, density, escape velocity, and surface temperature. The surface temperature is a non-observable quantity, making it challenging to assess similarity.

A relationship between surface and equilibrium temperatures has been established using data from our solar system objects. This enables the calculation of ESI, which quantifies the similarity of a planet to Earth, ranging from 1 for identical planets to 0 for those that are completely dissimilar.

The analysis reveals 20 exoplanets with an ESI value above 0.8, indicating they share characteristics similar to those of Earth. The MSI measures resemblance to present-day Mars and utilizes the same physical parameters as ESI.

title: Orbital stability in static axisymmetric fields
input: We investigate the stability of test-particle equilibrium orbits in axisymmetric, but otherwise arbitrary, gravitational and electromagnetic fields. We extend previous studies of this problem to include a toroidal magnetic field. We find that, even though the toroidal magnetic field does not alter the location of the circular orbits, it enters the problem as a gyroscopic force with the potential to provide gyroscopic stability. This is in essence similar to the situation encountered in the reduced three-body problem where rotation enables stability around the local maxima of the effective potential. Nevertheless, we show that gyroscopic stabilization by a toroidal magnetic field is impossible for axisymmetric force fields in source-free regions because in this case the effective potential does not possess any local maxima. As an example of an axisymmetric force field with sources, we consider the classical problem of a rotating, aligned magnetosphere. By analyzing the dynamics of halo and equatorial particle orbits we conclude that axisymmetric toroidal fields that are antisymmetric about the equator are unable to provide gyroscopic stabilization. On the other hand, a toroidal magnetic field that does not vanish at the equator can provide gyroscopic stabilization for positively charged particles in prograde equatorial orbits.

output.explanation:
Gravitational and electromagnetic fields govern the motion of celestial bodies in axisymmetric systems, where symmetry about an axis is a defining characteristic.

Key terms to understand include gyroscopic forces, which arise from charged particles interacting with magnetic fields; toroidal magnetic fields, resembling doughnuts wrapped around central axes; and source-free regions devoid of mass or charge. The effective potential is a mathematical tool used to predict particle behavior in these complex environments.

In axisymmetric systems, the presence of a toroidal magnetic field can significantly impact particle motion by introducing gyroscopic forces that stabilize orbits around local maxima in the effective potential. However, this stabilization is impossible for source-free regions lacking such maxima.

The study reveals that antisymmetric toroidal fields about the equator cannot provide gyroscopic stability, whereas fields not vanishing at the equator can stabilize positively charged particles in prograde equatorial orbits.

title: PSR J1618-3921: a recycled pulsar in an eccentric orbit
input: PSR~J1618 3921 is an -ms pulsar in a -d orbit around a likely low-mass He white dwarf companion, discovered in a survey of the intermediate Galactic latitudes at 1400 MHz conducted with the Parkes radio telescope in the late 1990s. Although PSR~J1618 3921 was discovered more than 15 years ago, only limited information has been published about this pulsar which has a surprisingly large orbital eccentricity ( ), considering its high spin frequency and likely small companion mass. The focus of this work is a precise measurement of the spin, astrometric and orbital characteristics of PSR J1618 3921. This was done with timing observations made at the Nançay Radio Telescope, from 2009 to 2017. We analyzed the timing data recorded at the Nançay Radio Telescope over several years to characterize the properties of PSR~J1618 3921. A rotation ephemeris for this pulsar was obtained by analyzing the times of arrival of the radio pulses at the telescope. We confirm the unusual eccentricity of PSR~J1618 3921 and discuss several hypotheses regarding its formation, in the context of other discoveries of recycled pulsars in eccentric orbits.

output.explanation:
The universe contains numerous binary systems, where two compact objects orbit each other in an elliptical path. PSR J1618 3921 is a pulsar residing in such a system with its companion white dwarf star. The orbital eccentricity of this system refers to the degree of its elliptical shape.

The term 'pulsar' describes a rapidly rotating neutron star emitting electromagnetic radiation, while a 'white dwarf' is a small hot star formed from low-mass stellar remnants. A pulsar's spin frequency measures how many rotations it completes per second. The companion white dwarf in PSR J1618 3921 likely has a small mass.

The interaction between the pulsar and its companion can be viewed as an orbital dance, where their gravitational pull causes them to move around each other in a complex pattern. This phenomenon is thought to occur when a neutron star accretes material from a companion star, causing it to slow down and eventually become a recycled pulsar.

The precise measurement of PSR J1618 3921's spin, astrometric, and orbital characteristics was achieved through timing observations made at the Nançay Radio Telescope between 2009 and 2017. The analysis confirmed its unusual eccentricity and provided insights into possible formation scenarios.

title: Inner and outer star forming regions over the disks of spiral galaxies. I. Sample characterization
input: Context. The knowledge of abundance distributions is central to understanding the formation and evolution of galaxies. Most of the relations employed for the derivation of gas abundances have so far been derived from observations of outer disk HII regions, despite the known differences between inner and outer regions. Aims. Using integral field spectroscopy (IFS) observations we aim to perform a systematic study and comparison of two inner and outer HII regions samples. The spatial resolution of the IFS, the number of objects and the homogeneity and coherence of the observations allow a complete characterization of the main observational properties and differences of the regions. Methods. We analyzed a sample of 725 inner HII regions and a sample of 671 outer HII regions, all of them detected and extracted from the observations of a sample of 263 nearby, isolated, spiral galaxies observed by the CALIFA survey. Results. We find that inner HII regions show smaller equivalent widths, greater extinction and luminosities, along with greater values of [NII]λ6583/Hα and [OII]λ3727/[OIII]λ5007 emission-line ratios, indicating higher metallicites and lower ionization parameters. Inner regions have also redder colors and higher photometric and ionizing masses, although Mion/Mphot is slighty higher for the outer regions. Conclusions. This work shows important observational differences between inner and outer HII regions in star forming galaxies not previously studied in detail. These differences indicate that inner regions have more evolved stellar populations and are in a later evolution state with respect to outer regions, which goes in line with the inside-out galaxy formation paradigm.

output.explanation:
Galaxies are vast, gravitationally bound systems consisting of stars, stellar remnants, interstellar gas, dust, and dark matter.

HII regions refer to areas where star formation occurs due to the presence of ionized hydrogen, while integral field spectroscopy (IFS) is a technique used for studying these regions with high spatial resolution. IFS enables researchers to analyze multiple objects simultaneously, allowing for a comprehensive characterization of their main observational features.

The process involves analyzing HII regions within galaxies using IFS observations. The interaction between the ionized gas and stellar populations in inner HII regions leads to distinct characteristics compared to outer ones, including smaller equivalent widths, greater extinction and luminosities, and specific emission-line ratios indicative of higher metallicites and lower ionization parameters.

Inner HII regions exhibit redder colors and higher photometric and ionizing masses than their outer counterparts. These findings suggest that inner regions have more evolved stellar populations and are in a later evolutionary state than their outer counterparts, aligning with the inside-out galaxy formation paradigm.

title: H-band discovery of additional Second-Generation stars in the Galactic Bulge Globular Cluster NGC 6522 as observed by APOGEE and Gaia
input: We present elemental abundance analysis of high-resolution spectra for five giant stars, deriving Fe, Mg, Al, C, N, O, Si and Ce abundances, and spatially located within the innermost regions of the bulge globular cluster NGC 6522, based on H-band spectra taken with the multi-object APOGEE-north spectrograph from the SDSS-IV Apache Point Observatory Galactic Evolution Experiment (APOGEE) survey. Of the five cluster candidates, two previously unremarked stars are confirmed to have second-generation (SG) abundance patterns, with the basic pattern of depletion in C and Mg simultaneous with enrichment in N and Al as seen in other SG globular cluster populations at similar metallicity. } In agreement with the most recent optical studies, the NGC 6522 stars analyzed exhibit (when available) only mild overabundances of the s-process element Ce, contradicting the idea of the NGC 6522 stars being formed from gas enriched by spinstars and indicating that other stellar sources such as massive AGB stars could be the primary intra-cluster medium polluters. The peculiar abundance signature of SG stars have been observed in our data, confirming the presence of multiple generations of stars in NGC 6522.

output.explanation:
The densest regions of the galaxy are home to globular clusters like NGC 6522, where stars have formed over billions of years through various astrophysical processes.

Globular cluster populations can be broadly classified into first-generation and second-generation (SG) abundance patterns. SG abundance patterns involve depletion in certain elements such as carbon and magnesium accompanied by enrichment in others like nitrogen and aluminum. This phenomenon is observed in other globular clusters at similar metallicity levels, indicating a shared formation mechanism.

The presence of multiple generations within NGC 6522 can be attributed to the interaction between different stellar populations. The process begins with the initial formation of first-generation stars from primordial gas clouds. These early stars then enrich their surroundings through various astrophysical processes such as supernovae explosions and mass loss, creating a chemical environment conducive to the formation of subsequent generations.

The peculiar abundance signature observed in NGC 6522 is characterized by mild overabundances of s-process elements like cerium, suggesting that massive AGB stars could be primary polluters within these clusters. This finding contradicts the idea of spinstars enriching the intra-cluster medium and highlights the complex interplay between different stellar populations in shaping the chemical composition of globular clusters.

title: New PARSEC database of alpha-enhanced stellar evolutionary tracks and isochrones I. Calibration with 47 Tuc (NGC104) and the improvement on RGB bump
input: Precise studies on the Galactic bulge, globular cluster, Galactic halo and Galactic thick disk require stellar models with alpha enhancement and various values of helium content. These models are also important for extra-Galactic population synthesis studies. For this purpose, we complement the existing PARSEC models, which are based on the solar partition of heavy elements, with alpha-enhanced partitions. We collect detailed measurements on the metal mixture and helium abundance for the two populations of 47 Tuc (NGC 104) from the literature, and calculate stellar tracks and isochrones with these alpha-enhanced compositions. By fitting the precise color-magnitude diagram with HST ACS/WFC data, from low main sequence till horizontal branch, we calibrate some free parameters that are important for the evolution of low mass stars like the mixing at the bottom of the convective envelope. This new calibration significantly improves the prediction of the RGB bump brightness. Comparison with the observed RGB and HB luminosity functions also shows that the evolutionary lifetimes are correctly predicted. As a further result of this calibration process, we derive the age, distance modulus, reddening, and the red giant branch mass loss for 47 Tuc. We apply the new calibration and alpha-enhanced mixtures of the two 47 Tuc populations ( [alpha/Fe] ~0.4 and 0.2) to other metallicities. The new models reproduce the RGB bump observations much better than previous models. This new PARSEC database, with the newly updated alpha-enhanced stellar evolutionary tracks and isochrones, will also be part of the new stellar products for Gaia.

output.explanation:
The galactic environment is characterized by distinct stellar populations, including the bulge, globular clusters, halo, and thick disk. These regions are home to stars with varying levels of helium content and alpha enhancement. Alpha elements refer to heavier-than-helium nuclei that play a crucial role in determining star properties.

Alpha enhancement refers to an increase in the ratio of alpha elements to iron, while helium content describes the proportion of helium in a star. These parameters influence the star's evolution, particularly during the red giant branch phase. The RGB bump is a notable feature marking the transition from main sequence to RGB phase.

The interaction between stellar models and observational data reveals how stars evolve over time. By fitting color-magnitude diagrams with high-precision HST ACS/WFC data, researchers can calibrate free parameters governing low-mass star evolution. This process involves adjusting parameters such as mixing at the bottom of the convective envelope to improve predictions for RGB bump brightness.

The new calibration significantly enhances accuracy in evolutionary lifetimes and luminosity functions for red giants and horizontal branch stars. By applying this updated model to other metallicities, researchers can derive age, distance modulus, reddening, and mass loss rates for various stellar populations.

title: Acceleration of ultrahigh-energy cosmic rays in starburst superwinds
input: The sources of ultrahigh-energy cosmic rays (UHECRs) have been stubbornly elusive. However, the latest report of the Pierre Auger Observatory provides a compelling indication for a possible correlation between the arrival directions of UHECRs and nearby starburst galaxies. We argue that if starbursts are sources of UHECRs, then particle acceleration in the large-scale terminal shock of the superwind that flows from the starburst engine represents the best known concept model in the market. We investigate new constraints on the model and readjust free parameters accordingly. We show that UHECR acceleration above about 10^{11} GeV remains consistent with observation. We also show that the model could accommodate hard source spectra as required by Auger data. We demonstrate how neutrino emission can be used as a discriminator among acceleration models.

output.explanation:
The universe is home to vast regions of interstellar gas and dust, where intense star-forming activities can create powerful outflows known as superwinds.

A key term in this context is a superwind: a large-scale flow driven by the collective energy released from newly formed stars and supernovae explosions. Another important concept is particle acceleration, which involves the transfer of energy to high-energy particles through complex interactions between magnetic fields, turbulent flows, and relativistic particles.

The terminal shock at the edge of these outflows represents a region where particles can be accelerated to ultrahigh energies. This process often involves non-linear mechanisms such as diffusive shock acceleration and reacceleration. The large-scale terminal shock is considered the best known concept model for accelerating UHECRs if starbursts are indeed their sources.

Particle acceleration above about 10^{11} GeV remains consistent with current observations, according to studies that have refined the parameters of this model to better align with observational data from Auger. Additionally, neutrino emission has been proposed as a potential discriminator among different acceleration models.

title: Dependence of the onset of the runaway greenhouse effect on the latitudinal surface water distribution of Earth-like planets
input: Liquid water is one of the most important materials affecting the climate and habitability of a terrestrial planet. Liquid water vaporizes entirely when planets receive insolation above a certain value, which is called the runaway greenhouse threshold. This threshold forms the inner most limit of the habitable zone. Here, we investigate the effect of the distribution of surface water on the runaway greenhouse threshold for Earth-sized planets using a three-dimensional dynamic atmosphere model. We considered a 1-bar atmosphere whose composition is similar to the current Earth's atmosphere with a zonally uniform distribution of surface water. As previous studies have already shown, we also recognized two climate regimes: the land planet regime, which has dry low latitude and wet high latitude region, and the aqua planet regime, which is globally wet. We showed that each regime is controlled by the width of the Hadley circulation, the amount of surface water, and the planetary topography. We found that the runaway greenhouse threshold varies continuously with the surface water distribution from about 130% (an aqua planet) to 180% (the extreme case of a land planet) of the present insolation at Earth's orbit. Our results indicate that the inner edge of the habitable zone is not a single sharp boundary, but a border whose location varies depending on planetary surface condition, such as the amount of surface water. Since land planets have wider habitable zones and less cloud cover, land planets would be good targets for future observations investigating planetary habitability.

output.explanation:
The climate and habitability of terrestrial planets are influenced by the presence of liquid water, which plays a crucial role in determining their environments. The runaway greenhouse threshold marks the point at which insolation causes all surface water to vaporize, forming the inner boundary of the habitable zone.

Key terms such as 'Hadley circulation' refer to large-scale wind patterns that transport heat between equatorial regions and mid-latitudes. A zonally uniform distribution is a state where surface water covers all longitudes equally. The aqua planet regime describes a climate scenario in which the entire planet is wet.

The interaction of these factors determines two distinct climate regimes: land planets with dry low-latitude areas and high-latitude wet regions, and aqua planets that are globally wet. This distinction arises from the combined effects of atmospheric dynamics, planetary characteristics such as topography, and surface water distribution.

The runaway greenhouse threshold varies continuously depending on surface water distribution, indicating that the habitable zone's inner edge is not a fixed boundary but rather shifts based on planetary conditions such as surface water abundance. Land planets possess wider habitable zones and reduced cloud cover, making them suitable targets for future studies examining planetary habitability.

title: Identification and mitigation of narrow spectral artifacts that degrade searches for persistent gravitational waves in the first two observing runs of Advanced LIGO
input: Searches are under way in Advanced LIGO and Virgo data for persistent gravitational waves from continuous sources, e.g. rapidly rotating galactic neutron stars, and stochastic sources, e.g. relic gravitational waves from the Big Bang or superposition of distant astrophysical events such as mergers of black holes or neutron stars. These searches can be degraded by the presence of narrow spectral artifacts (lines) due to instrumental or environmental disturbances. We describe a variety of methods used for finding, identifying and mitigating these artifacts, illustrated with particular examples. Results are provided in the form of lists of line artifacts that can safely be treated as non-astrophysical. Such lists are used to improve the efficiencies and sensitivities of continuous and stochastic gravitational wave searches by allowing vetoes of false outliers and permitting data cleaning.

output.explanation:
The cosmos harbors persistent and stochastic gravitational wave sources, including rapidly rotating galactic neutron stars and relic waves from the Big Bang or distant astrophysical events like black hole mergers. Gravitational wave detectors are designed to capture these signals, but their sensitivity can be compromised by narrow spectral artifacts caused by instrumental disturbances or environmental factors.

Gravitational wave searches involve identifying key terms such as gravitational waves, which are ripples in spacetime, and line artifacts, which are unwanted features that can degrade detection capabilities. Line artifacts arise from instrumental or environmental disturbances.

The presence of these line-like features must be mitigated to ensure accurate detection of gravitational waves. This is achieved by employing various methods for finding and removing non-astrophysical line artifacts from the data.

By creating lists of unwanted signals, scientists can improve the efficiency and sensitivity of their searches by excluding false outliers and cleaning up contaminated data.

title: ChromaStarPy: A stellar atmosphere and spectrum modeling and visualization lab in python
input: We announce ChromaStarPy, an integrated general stellar atmospheric modeling and spectrum synthesis code written entirely in python V. 3. ChromaStarPy is a direct port of the ChromaStarServer (CSServ) Java modeling code described in earlier papers in this series, and many of the associated JavaScript (JS) post-processing procedures have been ported and incorporated into CSPy so that students have access to ready-made "data products". A python integrated development environment (IDE) allows a student in a more advanced course to experiment with the code and to graphically visualize intermediate and final results, ad hoc, as they are running it. CSPy allows students and researchers to compare modeled to observed spectra in the same IDE in which they are processing observational data, while having complete control over the stellar parameters affecting the synthetic spectra. We also take the opportunity to describe improvements that have been made to the related codes, ChromaStar (CS), CSServ and ChromaStarDB (CSDB) that, where relevant, have also been incorporated into CSPy. The application may be found at the home page of the OpenStars project: http://www.ap.smu.ca/~ishort/OpenStars/ .

output.explanation:
Stellar atmospheres are complex systems governed by the interplay of radiative transfer and thermodynamic processes.

The term 'stellar atmospheric modeling' refers to the process of simulating these interactions using computational methods, while a spectrum synthesis code generates synthetic spectra that can be compared with observed spectra from stars. In this context, Python is used as the programming language for developing such codes.

A key aspect of ChromaStarPy is its ability to integrate various post-processing procedures into a single environment, allowing users to experiment with different stellar parameters affecting the synthetic spectra while having complete control over these parameters.

ChromaStarPy enables students and researchers to compare modeled to observed spectra in real-time, providing valuable insights into the properties of stars. This code also allows for improvements made to related codes, such as ChromaStar (CS), CSServ, and ChromaStarDB (CSDB), to be incorporated where relevant.

title: Accurate millimetre and submillimetre rest frequencies for - and -dithioformic acid, HCSSH
input: A better understanding of sulphur chemistry is needed to solve the interstellar sulphur depletion problem. A way to achieve this goal is to study new S-bearing molecules in the laboratory, obtaining accurate rest frequencies for an astronomical search. We focus on dithioformic acid, HCSSH, which is the sulphur analogue of formic acid. The aim of this study is to provide an accurate line list of the two HCSSH and isomers in their electronic ground state and a comprehensive centrifugal distortion analysis with an extension of measurements in the millimetre and submillimetre range. We studied the two isomers in the laboratory using an absorption spectrometer employing the frequency-modulation technique. The molecules were produced directly within a free-space cell by glow discharge of a gas mixture. We measured lines belonging to the electronic ground state up to 478 GHz, with a total number of 204 and 139 new rotational transitions, respectively, for and isomers. The final dataset also includes lines in the centimetre range available from literature. The extension of the measurements in the mm and submm range lead to an accurate set of rotational and centrifugal distortion parameters. This allows us to predict frequencies with estimated uncertainties as low as 5 kHz at 1 mm wavelength. Hence, the new dataset provided by this study can be used for astronomical search.

output.explanation:
The interstellar medium is a vast, diffuse region of space where various chemical processes occur. Sulphur chemistry plays a significant role in this environment.

Key terms such as dithioformic acid (HCSSH) and its isomers refer to specific types of molecules with unique properties. Dithioformic acid is the sulphur analogue of formic acid, meaning it has similar molecular structure but replaces hydrogen atoms with sulphur.

The laboratory study involved using an absorption spectrometer to measure rotational transitions in dithioformic acid and its isomers. These measurements were taken up to 478 GHz frequency range, allowing for accurate determination of rotational and centrifugal distortion parameters. This process enabled predictions of frequencies within a certain uncertainty threshold.

As a result of this study, an accurate line list was obtained for the two HCSSH isomers in their electronic ground state. The dataset also includes lines from the centimetre range available from literature. With estimated uncertainties as low as 5 kHz at 1 mm wavelength, this new dataset can be used for astronomical searches.

title: Medium-sized satellites of large Kuiper belt objects
input: While satellites of mid- to small-Kuiper belt objects tend to be similar in size and brightness to their primaries, the largest Kuiper belt objects preferentially have satellites with small fractional brightness. In the two cases where the sizes and albedos of the small faint satellites have been measured, these satellites are seen to be small icy fragments consistent with collisional formation. Here we examine Dysnomia and Vanth, the satellites of Eris and Orcus, respectively. Using the Atacama Large Millimeter Array, we obtain the first spatially resolved observations of these systems at thermal wavelengths. We find a diameter for Dysnomia of 700+/-115 km and for Vanth of 475+/-75 km, with albedos of 0.04_+0.02_-0.01 and 0.08+/-0.02 respectively. Both Dysnomia and Vanth are indistinguishable from typical Kuiper belt objects of their size. Potential implications for the formation of these types of satellites are discussed.

output.explanation:
The outer Solar System's Kuiper belt is a region where icy bodies and their satellites reside, with the largest objects often accompanied by smaller companions that are typically faint compared to their primaries.

Key terms include 'albedo', which refers to an object's reflectivity, and 'Kuiper belt object' (KBO), a type of icy body found in this region. The albedo is crucial for determining an object's size and composition.

The mechanism behind the formation of these small satellites involves collisional processes that shape their sizes and compositions. This process likely results in smaller, fainter companions compared to their larger primaries.

Dysnomia and Vanth, satellites of Eris and Orcus respectively, are found to be small icy bodies with diameters of approximately 700 km and 475 km, respectively, and albedos around a certain value. Notably, these satellites resemble typical KBOs of their size.

title: Probing narrow-line Seyfert 1 galaxies in the southern hemisphere
input: We present a new accurate catalog of narrow-line Seyfert 1 galaxies (NLS1s) in the southern hemisphere from the Six-degree Field Galaxy Survey (6dFGS) final data release, which is currently the most extensive spectroscopic survey available in the southern sky whose database has not yet been systematically explored. We classified 167 sources as NLS1s based on their optical spectral properties. We derived flux-calibrated spectra for the first time that the 6dFGS indeed does not provide. By analyzing these spectra, we obtained strong correlations between the monochromatic luminosity at 5100 A and the luminosity of Hbeta and [O III]5007 lines. The estimated central black hole mass and Eddington ratio have an average value of 8.6 x 10^6 M_Sun and 0.96 L_Edd respectively, which is a typical value for NLS1s. In the sample, 23 (13.8%) NLS1s were detected at radio frequencies, and 12 (7.0%) of them are radio-loud. Our results confirmed that radio-loud sources tend to have a higher redshift, more massive black hole, and higher radio and optical luminosity than radio-quiet sources.

output.explanation:
Galaxies in the southern hemisphere are being studied to understand their properties and behavior.

A supermassive black hole resides at the center of many galaxies, with its mass influencing various astrophysical phenomena. The term 'Eddington ratio' refers to a measure of matter accretion onto the black hole relative to its maximum capacity. In this context, it's essential to understand how these processes interact.

The mechanism behind identifying narrow-line Seyfert 1 galaxies (NLS1s) involves analyzing their spectra for specific properties, such as narrow emission lines indicating high-energy activity near the central black hole. The presence of these lines suggests a close relationship between energy output and central black hole activity.

Radio-loud NLS1s tend to have higher redshifts, more massive black holes, and greater luminosity in both radio and optical frequencies compared to their quieter counterparts.

title: Looking for a new test of general relativity in the solar system
input: This paper discusses three matter-of-principle methods for measuring the general relativity correction to the Newtonian values of the position of collinear Lagrangian points L1 and L2 of the Sun-Earth-satellite system. All approaches are based on time measurements. The first approach exploits a pulsar emitting signals and two receiving antennas located at L1 and L2, respectively. The second method is based on a relativistic positioning system based on the Lagrangian points themselves. These first two methods depend crucially on the synchronization of clocks at L1 and L2. The third method combines a pulsar and an artificial emitter at the stable points L4 or L5 forming a basis for the positioning of the collinear points L1 and L2. Further possibilities are mentioned and the feasibility of the measurements is considered.

output.explanation:
The Sun-Earth system's gravitational dynamics govern the behavior of celestial bodies in its vicinity, including Lagrangian points L1 and L2. These equilibrium positions allow a satellite to maintain a constant distance from both the Earth and the Sun. The general relativity correction affects these locations, necessitating precise measurements.

Key terms like 'collinear' refer to points aligned with the line connecting two celestial bodies, while 'Lagrangian points' are specific locations where the gravitational forces balance out. In this context, L1 is located between the Earth and the Sun, whereas L2 is on the opposite side of the Sun.

The methods proposed for measuring these corrections rely on time measurements. The first approach involves a pulsar emitting signals received by antennas at L1 and L2. This method requires synchronized clocks to accurately determine the position of these points. In contrast, the second approach utilizes a relativistic positioning system based directly on the Lagrangian points themselves.

The third method combines a pulsar with an artificial emitter located at stable points L4 or L5, which serves as a basis for determining the positions of collinear points L1 and L2. This setup enables further possibilities to be explored in measuring these corrections.

title: A Three-dimensional Simulation of a Magnetized Accretion Disk: Fast Funnel Accretion onto a Weakly Magnetized Star
input: We present the results of a global, three-dimensional magnetohydrodynamics simulation of an accretion disk with a rotating, weakly magnetized central star. The disk is threaded by a weak, large-scale poloidal magnetic field, and the central star has no strong stellar magnetosphere initially. Our simulation investigates the structure of the accretion flows from a turbulent accretion disk onto the star. The simulation reveals that fast accretion onto the star at high latitudes occurs even without a stellar magnetosphere. We find that the failed disk wind becomes the fast, high-latitude accretion as a result of angular momentum exchange mediated by magnetic fields well above the disk, where the Lorentz force that decelerates the rotational motion of gas can be comparable to the centrifugal force. Unlike the classical magnetospheric accretion scenario, fast accretion streams are not guided by magnetic fields of the stellar magnetosphere. Nevertheless, the accretion velocity reaches the free-fall velocity at the stellar surface due to the efficient angular momentum loss at a distant place from the star. This study provides a possible explanation why Herbig Ae/Be stars whose magnetic fields are generally not strong enough to form magnetospheres also show indications of fast accretion. A magnetically driven jet is not formed from the disk in our model. The differential rotation cannot generate sufficiently strong magnetic fields for the jet acceleration because the Parker instability interrupts the field amplification.

output.explanation:
Accretion disks are complex systems where gas spirals towards a central star, often accompanied by magnetic fields. In this context, the term accretion refers to the process of material falling onto the stellar surface. A key concept in understanding these flows is angular momentum exchange, which occurs when magnetic fields interact with the rotating disk. The Lorentz force, generated by these interactions, can decelerate gas motion and influence its trajectory.

A large-scale poloidal magnetic field threads through an accretion disk surrounding a weakly magnetized central star. Poloidal refers to a type of magnetic field oriented along the axis of rotation in such disks. The Parker instability is another concept mentioned here; it describes how differential rotation within the disk can interrupt magnetic field amplification.

The interaction between turbulent flows from the disk and its large-scale poloidal magnetic field leads to angular momentum exchange mediated by these fields above the disk. This process enables fast accretion streams to form at high latitudes, even without a stellar magnetosphere present.

Fast accretion onto the star's surface occurs due to efficient angular momentum loss mediated by magnetic fields. The resulting accretion velocity reaches free-fall values near the star's surface.

title: Gravity drives the evolution of infrared dark hubs: JVLA observations of SDC13
input: Converging networks of interstellar filaments i.e. hubs, have been recently linked to the formation of stellar clusters and massive stars. The goal is to study the kinematic and density structure of the SDC13 hub at high angular resolution to determine what drives its evolution and fragmentation. We have mapped SDC13, a 1000Msun infrared dark hub, in NH3(1,1) and NH3(2,2) emission lines, with both the JVLA and GBT down to 0.07pc. The mass-per-unit-lengths of all four hub filaments are thermally super-critical, consistent with the presence of tens of gravitationally bound cores along them. These cores exhibit regular separation of 0.37 +/- 0.16 pc suggesting gravitational instabilities running along these super-critical filaments are responsible for their fragmentation. The observed local increase of the dense gas velocity dispersion towards starless cores is believed to be a consequence of such fragmentation process. We see velocity gradient peaks towards 63% of the cores as expected during the early stages of filament fragmentation. The most massive cores are located at the filament junctions, where the velocity dispersion is the largest. We interpret this as the result of the hub morphology generating the largest acceleration gradients near the hub centre. We propose a scenario for the evolution of the SDC13 hub in which filaments first form as post-shock structures in a supersonic turbulent flow. Then gravity takes over and starts shaping the evolution of the hub, both fragmenting filaments and pulling the gas towards the centre of the gravitational well. By doing so, gravitational energy is converted into kinetic energy in both local (cores) and global (hub centre) potential well minima. Furthermore, the generation of larger gravitational acceleration gradients at the filament junctions promotes the formation of more massive cores. [abridged]

output.explanation:
The interstellar medium is a vast, diffuse gas that pervades the universe. In this context, super-critical filaments are regions where thermal energy exceeds gravitational forces, allowing gravitationally bound cores to form along their length.

A key term in understanding these systems is 'thermally super-critical', which refers to the state of a filament when its thermal energy surpasses the gravitational force holding it together. Another important concept is 'gravitational instabilities', which drive the fragmentation of filaments into smaller cores.

The process begins with the formation of post-shock structures in supersonic turbulent flows, where filaments first emerge as hubs for stellar cluster and massive star formation. As gravity takes hold, these filaments are shaped by gravitational forces that fragment them further, converting gravitational energy into kinetic energy within both local core regions and the global hub centre.

The SDC13 hub exhibits a regular separation of cores along its length, indicating that gravitational instabilities drive their fragmentation. The most massive cores form at filament junctions where acceleration gradients are largest due to the hub's morphology.

title: The Second Nucleus of NGC 7727: Direct Evidence for the Formation and Evolution of an Ultracompact Dwarf Galaxy
input: We present new observations of the late-stage merger galaxy NGC 7727, including HST/WFPC2 images and long-slit spectra obtained with the Clay telescope. NGC 7727 is relatively luminous ( ) and features two unequal tidal tails, various bluish arcs and star clusters, and two bright nuclei 480 pc apart in projection. These two nuclei have nearly identical redshifts, yet are strikingly different. The primary nucleus, hereafter Nucleus_1, fits smoothly into the central luminosity profile of the galaxy and appears--at various wavelengths--"red and dead." In contrast, Nucleus_2 is very compact, has a tidal radius of 103 pc, and exhibits three signs of recent activity: a post-starburst spectrum, an [O III]_5007 emission line, and a central X-ray point source. Its emission-line ratios place it among Seyfert nuclei. A comparison of Nucleus_2 ( ) with ultracompact dwarf galaxies (UCDs) suggests that it may be the best case yet for a massive UCD having formed through tidal stripping of a gas-rich disk galaxy. Evidence for this comes from its extended star-formation history, long blue tidal stream, and elevated dynamical-to-stellar-mass ratio. While the majority of its stars formed Gyr ago, about 1/3 by mass formed during starbursts in the past 2 Gyr. Its weak AGN activity is likely driven by a black hole of mass . We estimate that the former companion's initial mass was less than half that of then-NGC 7727, implying a minor, but significant, merger. By now this former companion has been largely shredded, leaving behind Nucleus_2 as a freshly minted UCD that probably moves on a highly eccentric orbit.

output.explanation:
Galaxies like NGC 7727 are formed through mergers of smaller galaxies, resulting in a complex system with various features such as tidal tails and nuclei.

A nucleus is the central region of a galaxy that contains a high concentration of stars and other celestial objects. In this context, Nucleus_1 refers to the primary nucleus of NGC 7727, which appears red and dead at various wavelengths.

Tidal stripping occurs when gas-rich disk material is removed from a galaxy during a merger event, leaving behind a compact remnant like Nucleus_2. This process can result in the formation of an ultracompact dwarf galaxy (UCD).

The system behavior described in this context involves the interaction between two nuclei with different properties: Nucleus_1 is relatively inactive and appears red and dead, while Nucleus_2 exhibits signs of recent activity such as a post-starburst spectrum and a central X-ray point source. The former companion to NGC 7727 likely had an initial mass less than half that of then-NGC 7727, indicating a minor but significant merger event.

title: Chiral Gravitational Waves and Baryon Superfluid Dark Matter
input: We develop a unified model of darkgenesis and baryogenesis involving strongly interacting dark quarks, utilizing the gravitational anomaly of chiral gauge theories. In these models, both the visible and dark baryon asymmetries are generated by the gravitational anomaly induced by the presence of chiral primordial gravitational waves. We provide a concrete model of an SU(2) gauge theory with two massless quarks. In this model, the dark quarks condense and form a dark baryon charge superfluid (DBS), in which the Higgs-mode acts as cold dark matter. We elucidate the essential features of this dark matter scenario and discuss its phenomenological prospects.

output.explanation:
The universe's evolution is characterized by a complex interplay between visible and dark matter, with the latter playing a crucial role in shaping its large-scale structure. 

The gravitational anomaly in chiral gauge theories enables the generation of both visible and dark baryon asymmetries through the presence of primordial gravitational waves. This phenomenon arises from the interaction between gravity and the strong nuclear force governing quark behavior within hadrons. 

A key concept is a strongly interacting dark sector, comprising massless quarks that condense to form a dark baryon charge superfluid (DBS). Within this DBS, the Higgs mode acts as cold dark matter, providing its formation and persistence mechanism. A chiral gauge theory is an SU(2) gauge theory with two massless quarks. 

The presence of primordial gravitational waves induces a gravitational anomaly that gives rise to both visible and dark baryon asymmetries in the universe's early stages. This unified model of darkgenesis and baryogenesis provides a novel framework for understanding matter-antimatter asymmetry, with its essential feature being the emergence of a complex interplay between gravitational waves, chiral gauge theories, and strongly interacting quarks.

title: Illustrating chaos: A schematic discretization of the general three-body problem in Newtonian gravity
input: We present a formalism for constructing schematic diagrams to depict chaotic three-body interactions in Newtonian gravity. This is done by decomposing each interaction in to a series of discrete transformations in energy- and angular momentum-space. Each time a transformation is applied, the system changes state as the particles re-distribute their energy and angular momenta. These diagrams have the virtue of containing all of the quantitative information needed to fully characterize most bound or unbound interactions through time and space, including the total duration of the interaction, the initial and final stable states in addition to every intervening temporary meta-stable state. As shown via an illustrative example for the bound case, prolonged excursions of one of the particles, which by far dominates the computational cost of the simulations, are reduced to a single discrete transformation in energy- and angular momentum-space, thereby potentially mitigating any computational expense. We further generalize our formalism to sequences of (unbound) three-body interactions, as occur in dense stellar environments during binary hardening. Finally, we provide a method for dynamically evolving entire populations of binaries via three-body scattering interactions, using a purely analytic formalism. In principle, the techniques presented here are adaptable to other three-body problems that conserve energy and angular momentum.

output.explanation:
In the context of celestial mechanics, complex interactions between three bodies governed by Newton's law of gravity exhibit chaotic behavior. This phenomenon arises from intricate redistributions of energy and angular momentum among particles. A key aspect is that each interaction can be decomposed into discrete transformations in both energy- and angular momentum-space. 

Energy refers to the total motion possessed by an object or system, while angular momentum describes its tendency to rotate around its axis. In this context, a transformation represents a change in state as particles re-distribute their energy and angular momenta. 

The proposed formalism involves constructing schematic diagrams that capture these transformations. These diagrams contain all necessary information to characterize complex interactions through time and space, including the duration of each interaction and its initial and final states. A notable advantage is that it can reduce prolonged excursions of individual particles into a single discrete transformation, potentially mitigating computational costs. 

The formalism has been generalized to sequences of three-body interactions in dense stellar environments where binary hardening occurs. Additionally, an analytic method for dynamically evolving entire populations of binaries via three-body scattering interactions has been developed. The techniques presented are adaptable to other three-body problems that conserve energy and angular momentum.

title: VLA Radio Observations of AR Sco
input: AR Scorpii is unique amongst known white dwarf binaries in showing powerful pulsations extending to radio frequencies. Here we aim to investigate the multi-frequency radio emission of AR Sco in detail, in order to constrain its origin and emission mechanisms. We present interferometric radio frequency imaging of AR Sco at 1.5, 5 and 9 GHz, analysing the total flux and polarization behaviour of this source at high time resolution (10, 3 and 3 s), across a full 3.6 hr orbital period in each band. We find strong modulation of the radio flux on the orbital period and the orbital sideband of the white dwarf's spin period (also known as the "beat" period). This indicates that, like the optical flux, the radio flux arises predominantly from on or near the inner surface of the M-dwarf companion star. The beat-phase pulsations of AR Sco decrease in strength with decreasing frequency. They are strongest at 9 GHz and at an orbital phase ~0.5. Unlike the optical emission from this source, radio emission from AR Sco shows weak linear polarization but very strong circular polarization, reaching ~30% at an orbital phase ~0.8. We infer the probable existence of a non-relativistic cyclotron emission component, which dominates at low radio frequencies. Given the required magnetic fields, this also likely arises from on or near the M-dwarf.

output.explanation:
AR Scorpii is a binary system consisting of a white dwarf and an M-dwarf companion star, which exhibits powerful pulsations extending to radio frequencies.

In this context, cyclotron emission refers to radiation emitted by charged particles when accelerated perpendicular to magnetic field lines. Cyclotron emission is characterized as non-relativistic and occurs at low radio frequencies. The term 'beat period' describes the interaction between the orbital period and white dwarf spin period of a binary system like AR Scorpii.

The beat phase pulsation in AR Scorpii decreases in strength with decreasing frequency, being strongest at 9 GHz and an orbital phase of approximately 0.5. This phenomenon is distinct from optical emission, which shows linear polarization, whereas radio emission exhibits weak linear but very strong circular polarization.
