In this scenario, machine learning, and unsupervised clustering algorithms in particular offer interesting alternatives. The Apache Point Observatory Galactic Evolution Experiment (APOGEE) offers a vast data set of near-infrared stellar spectra which is perfect for testing such alternatives. Apply an unsupervised classification scheme based on -means to the massive APOGEE data set. Explore whether the data are amenable to classification into discrete classes. We apply the -means algorithm to 153,847 high resolution spectra ( ). We discuss the main virtues and weaknesses of the algorithm, as well as our choice of parameters. We show that a classification based on normalised spectra captures the variations in stellar atmospheric parameters, chemical abundances, and rotational velocity, among other factors. The algorithm is able to separate the bulge and halo populations, and distinguish dwarfs, sub-giants, RC and RGB stars. However, a discrete classification in flux space does not result in a neat organisation in the parameters space. Furthermore, the lack of obvious groups in flux space causes the results to be fairly sensitive to the initialisation, and disrupts the efficiency of commonly-used methods to select the optimal number of clusters. Our classification is publicly available, including extensive online material associated with the APOGEE Data Release 12 (DR12). Our description of the APOGEE database can enormously help with the identification of specific types of targets for various applications. We find a lack of obvious groups in flux space, and identify limitations of the -means algorithm in dealing with this kind of data.

output.explanation:
Astronomical surveys are generating vast amounts of data, making traditional spectroscopy analysis techniques impractical due to their computational expense and need for human interaction.

Spectroscopy involves analyzing the light emitted or absorbed by celestial objects to determine properties such as resolution, which is a measure of an instrument's ability to distinguish between closely spaced features. Flux space represents data as intensity values, where flux is a measure of the amount of light emitted or absorbed by an object.

The -means algorithm groups similar data points together based on their characteristics in near-infrared stellar spectra from APOGEE. This process involves normalising spectra to capture variations in stellar atmospheric parameters and chemical abundances. However, discrete classification in flux space does not result in a neat organisation of these parameters due to the lack of obvious groups.

The -means algorithm's sensitivity to initialisation disrupts its efficiency when dealing with this type of data, leading to limitations in distinguishing between bulge and halo populations, as well as dwarfs, sub-giants, RC, and RGB stars. The classification is publicly available for various applications.

title: Torques Induced by Scattered Pebble-flow in Protoplanetary Disks
input: Fast inward migration of planetary cores is a common problem in the current planet formation paradigm. Even though dust is ubiquitous in protoplanetary disks, its dynamical role in the migration history of planetary embryos has not been assessed. In this Letter, we show that the scattered pebble-flow induced by a low-mass planetary embryo leads to an asymmetric dust-density distribution that is able to exert a net torque. By analyzing a large suite of multifluid hydrodynamical simulations addressing the interaction between the disk and a low-mass planet on a fixed circular orbit, and neglecting dust feedback onto the gas, we identify two different regimes, gas- and gravity-dominated, where the scattered pebble-flow results in almost all cases in positive torques. We collect our measurements in a first torque map for dusty disks, which will enable the incorporation of the effect of dust dynamics on migration into population synthesis models. Depending on the dust drift speed, the dust-to-gas mass ratio/distribution and the embryo mass, the dust-induced torque has the potential to halt inward migration or even induce fast outward migration of planetary cores. We thus anticipate that dust-driven migration could play a dominant role during the formation history of planets. Because dust torques scale with disk metallicity, we propose that dust-driven outward migration may enhance the occurrence of distant giant planets in higher-metallicity systems.

output.explanation:
Protoplanetary disks are complex systems where gas and dust interact with planetary embryos, influencing their migration patterns.

The term 'protoplanetary disk' refers to a rotating disk of gas surrounding young stars during the early stages of star formation. Pebble-flow is a phenomenon describing the movement of small particles in these disks, driven by gravitational forces from low-mass planetary embryos. In this context, pebbles are tiny solid objects that can be carried by the gas flow within the disk.

The interaction between pebbles and the gas leads to asymmetric distributions of dust density due to scattering effects. This asymmetry generates a net torque affecting the migration history of planetary embryos. Torque is a measure of rotational force applied to an object, influencing its motion and direction.

Two distinct regimes have been identified: gas-dominated environments where pebble-flow dominates, and gravity-dominated environments where gravitational forces from the embryo prevail. Within these regimes, simulations show that scattered pebbles consistently produce positive torques in almost all cases, potentially halting or reversing inward migration of planetary cores.

title: The odd-isotope fractions of Barium in the strongly r-process enhanced (r-II) stars
input: We determined the \ values, , , , , which correspond to the r-contribution 100\% for four r-II stars, , , \, and , respectively. Our results suggest that almost all of the heavy elements (in the range from Ba to Pb) in r-II stars have a common origin, that is, from a single r-process (the main r-process). We found that the \ has a intrinsic nature, and should keep constant value of about 0.46 in the main r-process yields, which is responsible for the heavy element enhancement of r-II stars and of our Galaxy chemical enhancement. In addition, except the abundance ratio [Ba/Eu] the \ is also an important indicator, which can be used to study the relative contributions of the r- and s-process during the chemical evolution history of the Milky Way and the enhancement mechanism in stars with peculiar abundance of heavy elements.

output.explanation:
The universe's heavy element formation is a complex process, involving various astrophysical mechanisms that shape the chemical composition of stars and galaxies. Key terms like r-process nucleosynthesis refer to the rapid neutron capture process responsible for creating elements from barium to lead through intense nuclear reactions.

R-II stars are characterized by their peculiar abundance patterns, which can be attributed to a single main r-process event. This idea is supported by the discovery that certain abundance ratios have an intrinsic nature and remain relatively constant in specific astrophysical contexts.

The interaction between different nucleosynthetic processes, such as the r- and s-processes, plays a crucial role in shaping the chemical evolution history of galaxies like our own Milky Way. The relative contributions of these processes can be studied through the analysis of abundance ratios in stars with peculiar heavy element patterns.

Almost all heavy elements in R-II stars share a common origin from a single main r-process event, which is responsible for their characteristic abundance enhancement.

title: Reducing the susceptibility of lumped-element KIDs to two-level system effects
input: Arrays of lumped-element kinetic inductance detectors (LEKIDs) optically coupled through an antenna-coupled transmission line are a promising candidate for future cosmic microwave background (CMB) experiments. However, the dielectric materials used for the microstrip architecture are known to degrade the performance of superconducting resonators. In this paper, we investigate the feasibility of microstrip coupling to a LEKID, focusing on a systematic study of the effect of depositing amorphous silicon-nitride on a LEKID. The discrete and spatially-separated inductive and capacitive regions of the LEKID allow us to vary the degree of dielectric coverage and determine the limitations of the microstrip coupling architecture. We show that by careful removal of dielectric from regions of high electric field in the capacitor, there is minimal degradation in dielectric loss tangent of a partially covered lumped-element resonator. We present the effects on the resonant frequency and noise power spectral density and, using the dark responsivity, provide an estimate for the resulting detector sensitivity.

output.explanation:
The cosmic microwave background is a remnant of the Big Bang, emitting radiation that can be detected by sensitive instruments. Arrays of lumped-element kinetic inductance detectors are being developed for future experiments to study this phenomenon. These detectors consist of superconducting resonators with microstrip architectures that use dielectric materials. However, these materials can degrade the performance of the resonators.

The key concept here is the microstrip architecture, which involves a transmission line and an antenna-coupled design. The term 'lumped-element' refers to the discrete inductive and capacitive regions within the detector. These components allow for varying degrees of dielectric coverage, enabling researchers to study its effects on performance.

The mechanism at play is the interaction between the microstrip coupling architecture and the LEKID's dielectric properties. By depositing amorphous silicon-nitride on a LEKID, researchers can control the degree of dielectric coverage and observe its impact on resonant frequency and noise power spectral density. The electric field in the capacitor plays a crucial role, as removing dielectric from high-field regions minimizes degradation.

The claims made are that careful removal of dielectric results in minimal degradation of the dielectric loss tangent for partially covered lumped-element resonators. This leads to negligible effects on resonant frequency and noise power spectral density. Furthermore, using dark responsivity, researchers estimate a detector sensitivity improvement.

title: The Effect of Toroidal Magnetic Fields on Solar Oscillation Frequencies
input: Solar oscillation frequencies change with the level of magnetic activity. Localizing subsurface magnetic field concentrations in the Sun with helioseismology will help us to understand the solar dynamo. Because the magnetic fields are not considered in standard solar models, adding them to the basic equations of stellar structure changes the eigenfunctions and eigenfrequencies. We use quasi-degenerate perturbation theory to calculate the effect of toroidal magnetic fields on solar oscillation mean multiplet frequencies for six field configurations. In our calculations, we consider both the direct effect of the magnetic field, which describes the coupling of modes, and the indirect effect, which accounts for changes in stellar structure due to the magnetic field. We limit our calculations to self-coupling of modes. We find that the magnetic field affects the multiplet frequencies in a way that depends on the location and the geometry of the field inside the Sun. Comparing our theoretical results with observed shifts, we find that strong tachocline fields cannot be responsible for the observed frequency shifts of p modes over the solar cycle. We also find that part of the surface effect in helioseismic oscillation frequencies might be attributed to magnetic fields in the outer layers of the Sun. The theory presented here is also applicable to models of solar-like stars and their oscillation frequencies.

output.explanation:
The Sun's interior is a complex system where magnetic fields interact with its internal dynamics, primarily through convective motions and rotation.

A key concept in understanding this interaction is the solar dynamo, which generates and maintains the Sun's magnetic field by converting kinetic energy into magnetic energy. Toroidal magnetic fields are crucial components of the solar dynamo, shaping the Sun's internal structure and dynamics.

Helioseismology studies subsurface magnetic field concentrations by analyzing oscillation frequencies. The basic equations of stellar structure do not account for magnetic fields, leading to changes in eigenfunctions and eigenfrequencies when they are added. Quasi-degenerate perturbation theory calculates the effect of toroidal magnetic fields on solar oscillation mean multiplet frequencies.

The results indicate that strong tachocline fields cannot be responsible for observed frequency shifts over the solar cycle in p-mode oscillations, but part of the surface effect may be attributed to magnetic fields present in the outer layers. The theory developed here can also apply to models of solar-like stars and their corresponding oscillation frequencies.

title: The co-existence of hot and cold gas in debris discs
input: Debris discs have often been described as gas-poor discs as the gas-to-dust ratio is expected to be considerably lower than in primordial,protoplanetary discs. However, recent observations have confirmed the presence of a non-negligible amount of cold gas in the circumstellar (CS) debris discs around young main-sequence stars.This cold gas has been suggested to be related to the outgassing of planetesimals and cometary-like objects. The aim of the paper is to investigate the presence of hot gas in the surroundings of stars bearing cold-gas debris discs. High-resolution optical spectra of all currently known cold-gas-bearing debris-disc systems, with the exception of Pic and Fomalhaut, have been obtained from different observatories.We have analysed the Ca II H & K and the Na I D lines searching for non-photospheric absorptions of CS origin, usually attributed to cometary-like activity. Narrow, stable Ca II and/or Na I absorption features have been detected superimposed to the photospheric lines in 10 out of the 15 observed cold-gas-bearing debris disc.Features are found at the radial velocity of the stars, or slightly blue- or red-shifted, and/or at the velocity of the local interstellar medium (ISM). Some stars also present transient variable events or absorptions extended towards red wavelengths. These are the first detections of such Ca II features in 7 out of the 15 observed stars. In some of these stars, results suggest that the stable and variable absorptions arise from relatively hot gas located in the CS close-in environment. This hot gas is detected in at least ~80%, of edge-on cold-gas-bearing debris discs, while in only ~10% of the discs seen close to face-on. We interpret this as a geometrical effect, and suggest that the non-detection of hot gas absorptions is due to the disc inclination rather than to the absence of the hot-gas component.

output.explanation:
The universe contains various types of discs, including debris discs that surround young main-sequence stars. These discs are often described as gas-poor environments due to their low gas-to-dust ratio compared to protoplanetary discs.

A key term in this context is 'circumstellar', which refers to the region surrounding a star where various phenomena occur. Another important concept is 'protoplanetary disc', a type of disc that forms around young stars and eventually gives rise to planets. Additionally, 'cometary-like activity' can be understood as the process by which comets release gas and dust into space.

The presence of cold gas in debris discs has been linked to outgassing planetesimals and cometary-like objects. This suggests that these objects are releasing gas into their surroundings, contributing to the observed cold gas content. The interaction between this cold gas and other components in the disc is complex and not yet fully understood.

The analysis of high-resolution optical spectra has revealed narrow, stable absorption features in 10 out of 15 observed debris discs. These features often occur at the radial velocity of the stars or slightly shifted towards blue or red wavelengths. Some systems also exhibit transient variable events or extended absorptions towards red wavelengths. The detection of hot gas in edge-on cold-gas-bearing debris discs is particularly noteworthy, with a significant percentage detected in these cases.

title: EPIC229426032 b and EPIC246067459 b: discovery and characterization of two new transiting hot Jupiters from K2
input: We report the discovery of two hot Jupiters orbiting the stars EPIC229426032 and EPIC246067459. We used photometric data from Campaign 11 and 12 of the Kepler K2 Mission and radial velocity data obtained using the HARPS, FEROS, and CORALIE spectrographs. EPIC229426032 b and EPIC246067459 b have masses of and , radii of and , and are orbiting their host stars in 2.18 and 3.20-day orbits, respectively. The large radius of EPIC229426032 b leads us to conclude that this candidate corresponds to a highly inflated hot Jupiter. EPIC2460674559 b has a radius consistent with theoretical models, considering the high incident flux falling on the planet. We consider EPIC229426032 b to be a excellent system for follow-up studies, since not only is it very inflated, but it also orbits a relatively bright star ( ).

output.explanation:
The universe is home to numerous stars and planets, with some hosting gas giants known as hot Jupiters.

A key term in this context is 'hot Jupiter', which refers to a planet similar in size to Jupiter but orbiting much closer to its star, resulting in extremely high surface temperatures. Inflation of these planets occurs when their radius exceeds expectations based on mass and composition.

The discovery of two hot Jupiters, EPIC229426032 b and EPIC246067459 b, is attributed to the interaction between photometric data from Campaign 11 and 12 of the Kepler K2 Mission and radial velocity data obtained using spectrographs. The large radius of EPIC229426032 b suggests that it is a highly inflated hot Jupiter due to tidal heating caused by its close proximity to its host star.

EPIC246067459 b has a radius consistent with theoretical models, considering the high incident flux falling on the planet. This indicates that it does not experience significant tidal heating. The discovery of these two planets highlights their potential for further study, particularly EPIC229426032 b, which orbits a relatively bright star and offers opportunities for follow-up research.

title: Characterizing the variable dust permeability of planet-induced gaps
input: Aerodynamic theory predicts that dust grains in protoplanetary disks will drift radially inward on comparatively short timescales. In this context, it has long been known that the presence of a gap opened by a planet can alter the dust dynamics significantly. In this paper, we carry out a systematic study employing long-term numerical simulations aimed at characterizing the critical particle-size for retention outside a gap as a function of particle size and for various key parameters defining the protoplanetary disk model. To this end, we perform multifluid hydrodynamical simulations in two dimensions, including different dust species, which we treat as pressureless fluids. We initialize the dust outside of the planet's orbit and study under which conditions dust grains are able to cross the gap carved by the planet. In agreement with previous work, we find that the permeability of the gap depends both on dust dynamical properties and the gas disk structure: while small dust follows the viscously accreting gas through the gap, dust grains approaching a critical size are progressively filtered out. Moreover, we introduce and compute a depletion factor that enables us to quantify the way in which higher viscosity, smaller planet mass, or a more massive disk can shift this critical size to larger values. Our results indicate that gap-opening planets may act to deplete the inner reaches of protoplanetary disks of large dust grains -- potentially limiting the accretion of solids onto forming terrestrial planets.

output.explanation:
Protoplanetary disks are vast, rotating systems of gas and dust that surround newly formed stars.

A key concept in understanding these systems is multifluid hydrodynamics, which treats each component as an individual fluid. In this context, a pressureless fluid refers to a type of fluid where the effects of pressure can be neglected. A protoplanetary disk model defines various parameters that characterize its structure and evolution.

The presence of a planet within these disks creates a gap through gravitational influence, affecting how dust grains move radially inward. Dust species with different properties interact with this environment in distinct ways. The critical particle-size for retention outside the gap depends on both the size of the particles and specific parameters defining the protoplanetary disk model.

In systems where smaller dust grains can pass through the gap due to viscous accretion, larger dust grains approaching a certain threshold are progressively filtered out by the planet's gravitational influence. The depletion factor quantifies how changes in viscosity, planet mass, or disk mass affect this critical size. As a result, planets may deplete protoplanetary disks of large dust grains, potentially limiting solid accretion onto forming terrestrial planets.

title: Circumstellar environment of the M-type AGB star R Dor. APEX spectral scan at GHz
input: Our current insights into the circumstellar chemistry of asymptotic giant branch (AGB) stars are largely based on studies of carbon-rich stars and stars with high mass-loss rates. In order to expand the current molecular inventory of evolved stars we present a spectral scan of the nearby, oxygen-rich star R Dor, a star with a low mass-loss rate ( /yr). We carried out a spectral scan in the frequency ranges 159.0-321.5GHz and 338.5-368.5 GHz (wavelength range 0.8-1.9mm) using the SEPIA/Band-5 and SHeFI instruments on the APEX telescope and we compare it to previous surveys, including one of the oxygen-rich AGB star IK Tau, which has a high mass-loss rate ( /yr). The spectrum of R Dor is dominated by emission lines of SO and the different isotopologues of SiO. We also detect CO, H O, HCN, CN, PO, PN, SO, and tentatively TiO , AlO, and NaCl. Sixteen out of approximately 320 spectral features remain unidentified. Among these is a strong but previously unknown maser at 354.2 GHz, which we suggest could pertain to H SiO, silanone. With the exception of one, none of these unidentified lines are found in a similarly sensitive survey of IK Tau performed with the IRAM 30m telescope. We present radiative transfer models for five isotopologues of SiO ( SiO, SiO, SiO, Si O, Si O), providing constraints on their fractional abundance and radial extent. We derive isotopic ratios for C, O, Si, and S and estimate that R Dor likely had an initial mass in the range 1.3-1.6 , in agreement with earlier findings based on models of H O line emission. From the presence of spectral features recurring in many of the measured thermal and maser emission lines we tentatively identify up to five kinematical components in the outflow of R Dor, indicating deviations from a smooth, spherical wind.

output.explanation:
Asymptotic giant branch (AGB) stars are evolved celestial objects undergoing mass loss and chemical composition changes as they near the end of their life cycle.

The key terms in this context include oxygen-rich and carbon-rich stars, which refer to the dominant element present in their atmospheres. Oxygen-rich stars have a higher abundance of oxygen compared to other elements such as carbon or silicon. Mass-loss rate is another crucial parameter, with low mass-loss rates indicating less intense stellar winds.

The circumstellar chemistry of AGB stars involves complex interactions between the star's atmosphere and its surrounding environment. The study focuses on R Dor, an oxygen-rich star with a low mass-loss rate, which was observed using sensitive instruments to scan its spectrum in specific frequency ranges. This revealed emission lines of various molecules such as SO, SiO isotopologues, CO, H O, HCN, CN, PO, PN, and others.

The presence of these molecular species indicates that R Dor's circumstellar chemistry is influenced by its low mass-loss rate and oxygen-rich composition. The study also presents radiative transfer models for five SiO isotopologues, providing constraints on their fractional abundance and radial extent. Additionally, the analysis yields isotopic ratios for C, O, Si, and S, suggesting that R Dor likely had an initial mass in a specific range.

title: Accelerating -body simulation of self-gravitating systems with limited first-order post-Newtonian approximation
input: In this study, an -body simulation code was developed for self-gravitating systems with a limited first-order post-Newtonian approximation. The code was applied to a special case in which the system consists of one massive object and many low-mass objects. Therefore, the behavior of stars around the massive black hole could be analyzed. A graphics processing unit (GPU) was used to accelerate the code execution, and it could be accelerated by several tens of times compared to a single-core CPU for objects.

output.explanation:
The universe's densest regions are characterized by systems where gravity plays a dominant role in the interactions between objects. In these environments, self-gravitating systems emerge as key features of astrophysical phenomena.

The term 'self-gravitating' refers to systems governed primarily by gravitational forces, while 'post-Newtonian approximation' denotes corrections made to Newton's law of universal gravitation to account for relativistic effects on gravity's behavior. The concept of a massive object surrounded by numerous low-mass objects is fundamental in understanding the dynamics at play.

The code developed employs a limited first-order post-Newtonian approximation, which enables the simulation of complex systems with numerous objects. By leveraging a graphics processing unit (GPU) for accelerated execution, the computation time can be significantly reduced compared to single-core central processing units (CPUs). This optimization allows for more efficient simulations of self-gravitating systems.

The massive object in these systems is typically a black hole, around which stars and other low-mass objects orbit due to gravitational forces. The behavior of these stellar bodies can be analyzed using the developed code, providing valuable insights into their dynamics.

title: The associated absorption features in quasar spectra of the Sload Digital Sky survey .I. \ absorption doublets
input: Using the SDSS spectra of quasars included in the DR7Q or DR12Q catalogs, we search for Mg II narrow absorption doublets in the spectra data around Mg II emission lines. We obtain 17,316 Mg II doublets, within the redshift range of 0.3299<= z_abs <= 2.5663. We find that a velocity offset of v_r < 6000 km/s is a safe boundary to constrain the vast majority of associated Mg II systems, although we find some doublets at v_r > 6000 km/s. If associated Mg II absorbers are defined by v_r < 6000 km/s, ~33.3% of the absorbers supposed to be contaminants of intervening systems. Removing the 33.3% contaminants, ~4.5% of the quasars present at least one associated Mg II system with W_r 2796>=0.2 Å. The fraction of associated Mg II systems with high velocity outflows correlates with the average luminosities of their central quasars, indicating a relationship between outflows and the quasar feedback power. The v_r distribution of the outflow Mg II absorbers is peaked at 1023 km/s, which is smaller than the corresponding value of the outflow C IV absorbers. The redshift number density evolution of absorbers (dn/dz) limited by v_r > -3000 km/s differs from that of absorbers constrained by v_r > 2000 km/s. While, absorbers limited by v_r > 2000 km/s and higher values exhibit similar profile of dn/dz. In addition, the dn/dz is smaller when absorbers are constrained with larger v_r. The distributions of equivalent widths, and the ratio of W_r 2796/W_r 2803 is the same for associated and intervening systems, and independent on quasar luminosity.

output.explanation:
Quasars reside at the centers of galaxies, emitting intense radiation that interacts with surrounding interstellar gas.

Mg II emission lines refer to specific wavelengths where absorption features are observed, while associated absorption systems involve material ejected by quasars themselves. Associated absorbers can be distinguished by velocity offsets, specifically those less than 6000 km/s.

The interaction between quasar radiation and surrounding gas drives outflows from the central engine, which interact with nearby material. The resulting absorption features are a manifestation of this process. Abstract-specific claims indicate that associated Mg II systems with high-velocity outflows correlate with quasar luminosity, suggesting an interplay between these phenomena and quasar feedback power.

The redshift number density evolution of absorbers exhibits distinct patterns depending on the applied velocity constraints, with smaller densities for larger offsets.

title: Searching sub-stellar objects in DR1-TGAS, effectiveness and efficiency of Gaias' astrometry
input: We used 1,477,047 data from DR1-TGAS, in order to analyse the minimum require- ments of accuracy, necessary to detect sub-stellar objects in the astrometric mea- surements of Gaia. We found that the first set of data (DR1) does not have enough accuracy, so sub-stellar objects can not be easily detected. Barely, it would be possible to detect jovian and higher mass objects, with orbital periods over 5 years. We made the calculations of the minimum values of the astrometric angle produced by an or- biting sub-stellar object using a range of different masses. We estimate the efficiency and effectiveness of the DR1-TGAS data in order to detect sub-stellar objects and the minimum accuracy that Gaia would be required to detect these objects using the datasets that the mission will release in the near future.

output.explanation:
The universe contains various types of celestial objects, including stars and sub-stellar entities.

Astrometry refers to the measurement of an object's position and distance from us using various methods. Sub-stellar objects are characterized by masses below a certain threshold, making them distinct from stars that undergo nuclear fusion in their cores.

The astrometric measurements provided by Gaia involve determining the position, distance, and motion of celestial objects. However, these measurements rely on accurate data to detect sub-stellar objects effectively. The DR1-TGAS dataset lacks sufficient accuracy for this purpose but may be useful for identifying jovian and higher mass objects with long orbital periods.

The calculations performed using different masses demonstrate that the minimum values of the astrometric angle produced by an orbiting sub-stellar object are critical in determining its detectability. The efficiency and effectiveness of DR1-TGAS data are evaluated to assess its potential for detecting sub-stellar objects, as well as the required accuracy for Gaia's future datasets.

title: Curvature from strong gravitational lensing: a spatially closed Universe or systematics?
input: Model-independent constraints on the spatial curvature are not only closely related to important problems such as the evolution of the Universe and properties of dark energy, but also provide a test of the validity of the fundamental Copernican principle. In this paper, with the distance sum rule in the Friedmann-Lemaître-Robertson-Walker metric, we achieve model-independent measurements of the spatial curvature from the latest type Ia supernovae and strong gravitational lensing (SGL) observations. We find that a spatially closed Universe is preferred. Moreover, by considering different kinds of velocity dispersion and subsample, we study possible factors which might affect model-independent estimations for the spatial curvature from SGL observations. It is suggested that the combination of observational data from different surveys might cause a systematic bias and the tension between the spatially flat Universe and SGL observations is alleviated when the subsample only from the Sloan Lens ACS Survey is used or a more complex treatment for the density profile of lenses is considered.

output.explanation:
The cosmos is shaped by its spatial curvature, a fundamental aspect of the universe's evolution and dark energy properties. Spatial curvature can be understood as a measure of how much space deviates from flatness. The Friedmann-Lemaître-Robertson-Walker metric provides a framework for describing this curvature using the distance sum rule.

Key terms in cosmology include spatially closed and flat universes, referring to scenarios where spatial curvature is positive or zero, respectively. Spatially flat universes are often considered a default assumption in models of the universe's evolution.

The processes described interact through the Friedmann-Lemaître-Robertson-Walker metric, which combines distance sum rule with observations from type Ia supernovae and strong gravitational lensing data to estimate spatial curvature. The non-relativistic nature of matter within galaxies may suppress certain effects related to spatial curvature.

The analysis suggests that a spatially closed universe is preferred based on SGL observations, but this preference could be influenced by factors such as velocity dispersion within galaxies or the density profile of lenses. Systematic biases introduced by combining data from different surveys might also impact these findings.

title: Hydrodynamics with gas-grain chemistry and radiative transfer: comparing dynamical and static models
input: We quantify if the chemical abundance gradients given by a dynamical model of core collapse including time-dependent changes in density and temperature differ greatly from abundances derived from static models, where the density and temperature structures of the core are kept fixed as the chemistry evolves. For this study we developed a new one-dimensional spherically symmetric hydrodynamics code that couples the hydrodynamics equations with a comprehensive time-dependent gas-grain chemical model, including deuterium and spin-state chemistry, and radiative transfer calculations to derive self-consistent time-dependent chemical abundance gradients. We applied the code to model the collapse of a starless core up to the point when the infall flow becomes supersonic. The abundances predicted by the dynamical and static models are almost identical during the quiescent phase of core evolution, but the results start to diverge after the onset of core collapse, where the static model underestimates abundances at high medium density (inner core) and underestimates them at low density (outer core), and this is clearly reflected in simulated lines. The static model generally overestimates deuteration, which is increasingly evident the more D atoms are substituted in the molecule. We also find that using a limited chemical network, or a limited set of cooling molecules, may lead to an overestimate of the collapse timescale, and in some cases may prevent the collapse altogether. In our model, most of the line cooling near the center of the core is due to HCN, CO, and NO. In conclusion, the use of a static physical model is not a reliable method of simulating chemical abundances in starless cores after the onset of gravitational collapse. The adoption of complex chemistry and a comprehensive set of cooling molecules is necessary to model the collapse adequately.

output.explanation:
The collapse of a starless core is governed by the interplay between gravity and gas dynamics, where density and temperature fluctuations drive chemical evolution.

Key terms in this context include hydrodynamics, which describes fluid motion under various forces; gas-grain chemistry, referring to interactions between gas molecules and solid particles; deuterium, an isotope of hydrogen with a neutron in its nucleus; and spin-state chemistry, the behavior of atoms or molecules based on their rotational energy levels.

The collapse process involves dynamic changes in density and temperature, leading to variations in chemical composition. As the infall flow becomes supersonic, the static model diverges from the dynamical one, underestimating abundances at high medium density and low-density regions within the core. This discrepancy is particularly evident in deuteration levels.

The use of a limited chemical network or cooling molecules can lead to an overestimate of collapse timescales, potentially preventing collapse altogether. In our model, HCN, CO, and NO molecules are primary contributors to line cooling near the center of the core.

title: Dirichlet Process Gaussian-mixture model: An application to localizing coalescing binary neutron stars with gravitational-wave observations
input: We reconstruct posterior distributions for the position (sky area and distance) of a simulated set of binary neutron-star gravitational-waves signals observed with Advanced LIGO and Advanced Virgo. We use a Dirichlet Process Gaussian-mixture model, a fully Bayesian non-parametric method that can be used to estimate probability density functions with a flexible set of assumptions. The ability to reliably reconstruct the source position is important for multimessenger astronomy, as recently demonstrated with GW170817. We show that for detector networks comparable to the early operation of Advanced LIGO and Advanced Virgo, typical localization volumes are -- corresponding to -- potential host galaxies. The localization volume is a strong function of the network signal-to-noise ratio, scaling roughly . Fractional localizations improve with the addition of further detectors to the network. Our Dirichlet Process Gaussian-mixture model can be adopted for localizing events detected during future gravitational-wave observing runs, and used to facilitate prompt multimessenger follow-up.

output.explanation:
The universe's gravitational waves are ripples in spacetime produced by massive cosmic events, such as the collision of neutron stars and black holes. These waves carry information about their sources' positions in the sky area and distance from Earth. A Dirichlet Process Gaussian-mixture model is a statistical tool used to estimate probability density functions for source positions with flexible assumptions.

The key terms involved are: Bayesian non-parametric method - a type of statistical analysis that doesn't assume a specific form for the data; Dirichlet Process - a mathematical concept used in Bayesian statistics to represent uncertainty; Gaussian-mixture model - a statistical tool used to estimate probability density functions by combining multiple distributions.

The mechanism behind this process involves using gravitational waves detected by Advanced LIGO and Advanced Virgo to infer the position of binary neutron-star mergers. The Dirichlet Process Gaussian-mixture model is applied to these detections, allowing for reliable reconstruction of source positions in the sky area and distance from Earth.

For detector networks comparable to those used during the early operation of Advanced LIGO and Advanced Virgo, typical localization volumes are large enough to correspond to potential host galaxies. The size of these volumes depends on the network's signal-to-noise ratio, which scales roughly linearly with it.

title: Precision big bang nucleosynthesis with improved Helium-4 predictions
input: Primordial nucleosynthesis is one of the three historical evidences for the big bang model, together with the expansion of the universe and the cosmic microwave background. Now that the number of neutrino families and the baryonic densities have been fixed by laboratory measurements or CMB observations, the model has no free parameter and its predictions are rigid. Departure from its predictions could provide hints or constraints on new physics or astrophysics in the early universe. Precision on primordial abundances deduced from observations have recently been drastically improved and reach the percent level for both deuterium and helium-4. Accordingly, the BBN predictions should reach the same level of precision. For most isotopes, the dominant sources of uncertainty come from those on the laboratory thermonuclear reactions. This article focuses on helium-4 whose predicted primordial abundance depends essentially on weak interactions which control the neutron-proton ratio. The rates of the various weak interaction processes depend on the experimentally measured neutron lifetime, but also includes numerous corrections that we thoroughly investigate here. They are the radiative, zero-temperature, corrections, finite nucleon mass corrections, finite temperature radiative corrections, weak-magnetism, and QED plasma effects, which are for the first time all included and calculated in a self consistent way, allowing to take into account the correlations between them, and verifying that all satisfy detailed balance. The helium-4 predicted mass fraction is . In addition, we provide a Mathematica code (PRIMAT) that incorporates, not only these corrections but also a full network of reactions, using the best available thermonuclear reaction rates, allowing the predictions of primordial abundances up to the CNO region.

output.explanation:
The universe's early stages are characterized by the formation of light elements through a process known as primordial nucleosynthesis.

Primordial nucleosynthesis involves the creation of elements from protons and neutrons via weak interactions, which control the neutron-proton ratio. The term 'weak interaction' refers to processes that involve the exchange of particles carrying the weak nuclear force. Neutron lifetime is a critical factor in determining these rates.

The corrections to the weak interaction rates include radiative corrections, zero-temperature corrections, finite nucleon mass corrections, and QED plasma effects. These corrections are calculated in a self-consistent manner to account for their correlations and ensure they satisfy detailed balance.

The predicted helium-4 abundance is determined through Big Bang Nucleosynthesis (BBN) predictions, which have reached the same level of precision as observed primordial abundances.

title: Erratum: "Determining neutron star masses and radii using energy-resolved waveforms of X-ray burst oscillations" (ApJ, 776, 19 [2013])
input: This erratum addresses an error in the text of Lo et al. (2013) and more importantly corrects a computational error that was made in all previously published relativistic computations of absolute pulse waveform fluxes produced by hot spots on rotating stars that followed the radiation forward in time from the star to the observer. These computations used an incorrect expression for the differential emitting area on the stellar surface, as measured in the comoving frame. This erratum explains this error, lists all the published papers that contain results affected by this error, and summarizes in a general way why and how the results in Lo et al. (2013) were affected by this error, in a way that makes clear why and how the results in the other papers were affected. The idealized radiation spectra, beaming patterns, and spot shapes assumed in many of the previously reported computations of pulse waveforms very likely introduced systematic errors that are much larger than the relatively small errors introduced by using an incorrect expression for the differential emitting area. This erratum also corrects an error in the caption of Figure 5, an error in the text on page 19, and an incomplete description of our results on page 24.

output.explanation:
Rotating stars with hot spots on their surfaces emit radiation that can be observed from a distance, and the flux of this radiation varies over time due to the star's rotation. The comoving frame is a reference system where an observer at rest with respect to the stellar surface measures the differential emitting area - a key concept in relativistic computations. 

The term 'comoving frame' refers to a coordinate system that moves along with an object or region of space, allowing for more accurate calculations when dealing with relativistic effects. Relativistic computations involve taking into account special relativity's impact on the radiation emitted by stars. The differential emitting area plays a crucial role in determining the flux observed from a distance. 

The mechanism behind pulse waveforms involves the interaction between rotating stars and their hot spots, where the differential emitting area is essential for accurate calculations. An incorrect expression for this area led to systematic errors that are likely much larger than small errors introduced by using an incorrect formula. 

The corrected relativistic computations now accurately account for special relativity's effects on radiation emitted by hot spots on rotating stars, providing a more reliable understanding of these astrophysical phenomena.

title: Insights into the effects of indicators on knowledge production in Astronomy
input: Nine interviews were conducted with astronomers from Leiden University, and a document analysis was performed on relevant institutional (self-) evaluation documents, annual reports, and CVs of the interviewees. The aim was to perform a qualitative study about the relationship between the research behaviour of astronomers and how their science is being evaluated. This study encompassed the funding and publication system as well as the indicators used to measure the scientific output, its quality and the research performance. This report sheds light on how astronomers define high-quality research and how they think that creating knowledge of value is encouraged or hampered by the evaluation processes. We found that astronomers are realists who define scientific quality on the basis of "truth" and are driven by curiosity. These two factors make up their intrinsic values and motivation to perform Astronomy. Publication pressure, arising from the requirements of "the system", creates an extrinsic motivation to perform. This results in premature publications, low readability and replicability, risk aversion and a focus on quantity rather than quality. Hence, indicators do not merely represent quality, but also co-constitute what counts as good research. While we observe such constitutive effects of indicator use on research behaviour and content, we do not see that the astronomer's intrinsic values are co-constituted. This gives rise to a discrepancy between what is being measured by indicators and what astronomers define as scientific quality; the so-called "evaluation gap". Findings on constitutive effects and the evaluation gap in Astronomy lays out the conceptual groundwork for further empirical research and for policy advice on alternative evaluation practices and innovative indicators with the aim of bridging the "evaluation gap".

output.explanation:
Astronomers are embedded in a system where their pursuit of knowledge is influenced by both internal and external factors.

Key terms such as intrinsic motivation, driven by curiosity and the desire for truth, and extrinsic motivation, stemming from publication pressure, require clarification. Intrinsic motivation refers to the drive to uncover scientific truths, while extrinsic motivation arises from external requirements.

The interplay between these motivations shapes research behavior, leading to a focus on quantity over quality due to premature publications, low readability, and replicability issues. This phenomenon is exacerbated by risk aversion and the emphasis on meeting system demands.

As a result, indicators used in evaluation processes not only measure scientific output but also co-constitute what counts as good research, creating an 'evaluation gap' between measured quality and astronomers' definitions of scientific excellence.

title: Exploring the dusty star-formation in the early Universe using intensity mapping
input: In the last decade, it has become clear that the dust-enshrouded star formation contributes significantly to early galaxy evolution. Detection of dust is therefore essential in determining the properties of galaxies in the high-redshift universe. This requires observations at the (sub-)millimeter wavelengths. Unfortunately, sensitivity and background confusion of single dish observations on the one hand, and mapping efficiency of interferometers on the other hand, pose unique challenges to observers. One promising route to overcome these difficulties is intensity mapping of fluctuations which exploits the confusion-limited regime and measures the collective light emission from all sources, including unresolved faint galaxies. We discuss in this contribution how 2D and 3D intensity mapping can measure the dusty star formation at high redshift, through the Cosmic Infrared Background (2D) and [CII] fine structure transition (3D) anisotropies.

output.explanation:
The universe at high redshift is marked by the presence of galaxies shrouded in dust, which plays a significant role in early galaxy evolution.

Dusty star formation refers to the process where stars form within clouds of gas and dust. In astrophysics, this term encompasses both primordial and astrophysical processes that lead to the creation of new stars.

Intensity mapping exploits the confusion-limited regime by measuring collective light emission from all sources, including unresolved faint galaxies. This approach can be applied in two dimensions through the Cosmic Infrared Background anisotropies or three-dimensionally via [CII] fine structure transition anisotropies.

The dusty star formation at high redshift can be measured using 2D and 3D intensity mapping, which provides a promising route to overcome the challenges posed by single dish observations and interferometers. The Cosmic Infrared Background (2D) and [CII] fine structure transition (3D) anisotropies are essential for this measurement.

title: The simplest origin of the big bounce and inflation
input: Torsion is a geometrical object, required by quantum mechanics in curved spacetime, which may naturally solve fundamental problems of general theory of relativity and cosmology. The black-hole cosmology, resulting from torsion, could be a scenario uniting the ideas of the big bounce and inflation, which were the subject of a recent debate of renowned cosmologists.

output.explanation:
In the realm of spacetime, where gravity warps and curves, a fundamental concept emerges: torsion. This geometrical object is an inherent requirement in quantum mechanics, where it may hold the key to resolving long-standing issues within general theory of relativity and cosmology.

Torsion can be understood as a measure of the rotation or twist of spacetime around itself. In this context, curvature refers to the bending of spacetime due to massive objects, while torsion describes its intrinsic spin-like property.

The presence of torsion in curved spacetime gives rise to black-hole cosmologies that could potentially bridge two prominent ideas: the big bounce and inflation. These concepts have been at the center of a recent debate among renowned cosmologists.

In this scenario, the interplay between curvature and torsion may naturally solve fundamental problems within general theory of relativity and cosmology.

title: Studying G-axion Inflation model in light of PLANCK
input: With the Planck 2015 result, most of the well known canonical large field inflation models turned out to be strongly disfavored. Axion inflation is one of such models which is becoming marginalized with the increasing precession of CMB data. In this paper, we have shown that with a simple Galileon type modification to the marginally favored axion model calling G-axion, we can turn them into one of the most favored models with its detectable prediction of and within its PLANCK range for a wide range of parameters. Interestingly it is this modification which plays the important role in turning the inflationary predictions to be independent of the explicit value of axion decay constant . However, dynamics after the inflation turned out to have a non-trivial dependence on . For each G-axion model there exists a critical value of such that for we have the oscillating phase after inflation and for we have non-oscillatory phase. Therefore, we obtained a range of sub-Planckian value of model parameters which give rise to consistent inflation. However for sub-Planckian axion decay constant the inflaton field configuration appeared to be singular after the end of inflation. To reheat the universe we, therefore, employ the instant preheating mechanism at the instant of first zero crossing of the inflaton. To our surprise, the instant preheating mechanism turned out to be inefficient as opposed to usual non-oscillatory quintessence model. For another class of G-axion model with super-Planckian axion decay constant, we performed in detail the reheating constraints analysis considering the latest PLANCK result.

output.explanation:
The universe underwent a period of rapid expansion in the early cosmos, known as inflation. This process is driven by a scalar field called the inflaton. Axion inflation models rely on the axion decay constant f_a, but these models have been largely disfavored following Planck 2015 results.

Inflationary predictions can be modified using Galileon type modifications, resulting in G-axion models with more favorable predictions within the PLANCK range for various parameters. The critical role of this modification lies in rendering inflationary predictions independent of f_a's explicit value.

The inflaton field configuration exhibits a non-trivial dependence on f_a after inflation. Each G-axion model features a critical value of f_a, below which the phase is oscillatory and above which it is non-oscillatory. Sub-Planckian values of model parameters yield consistent inflationary scenarios.

For sub-Planckian axion decay constants, singularities emerge in the inflaton field configuration following the end of inflation. Instant preheating mechanisms are employed at the first zero crossing of the inflaton but prove inefficient compared to non-oscillatory quintessence models. G-axion models with super-Planckian axion decay constants undergo a detailed reheating constraints analysis in accordance with the latest PLANCK results.

title: Regularity of high energy photon events from gamma ray bursts
input: The effect of Quantum Gravity (QG) may bring a tiny light speed variation as , where is the photon energy and is a Lorentz violation scale. A remarkable regularity was suggested in previous studies to look for the light speed variation from high energy photon events of Gamma Ray Bursts (GRBs). We provide a general analysis on the data of 25 bright GRBs observed by the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope (FGST). Such method allows a completed scan over all possibilities in a more clean and impartial way without any bias compared to previous intuitive analysis. The results show that with the increase in the intrinsic energies of photons, such regularity truly emerges and gradually becomes significant. For photons with intrinsic energies higher than 40~GeV, the regularity exists at a significance of 3-5~ with determined by the GRB data.

output.explanation:
The universe's fundamental structure is shaped by Quantum Gravity (QG), which may lead to a minute variation in light speed. This phenomenon can be described using the equation , where represents photon energy and is a measure of Lorentz violation scale, a key concept that defines how much QG affects light propagation.

The intrinsic energy of photons refers to their energy as they travel through space without external influences. The analysis focuses on high-energy events from Gamma Ray Bursts (GRBs), incredibly powerful explosions releasing enormous amounts of energy, including gamma rays.

The mechanism behind this phenomenon involves the interaction between QG and light propagation. As photon energies increase, a remarkable regularity emerges in the data from GRB observations by the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope (FGST). This regularity becomes significant at a confidence level of 3-5 sigma for photons with intrinsic energies above 40 GeV, as determined by analyzing the data from GRBs.

The results indicate that this phenomenon is more pronounced in high-energy photon events, suggesting a potential link between QG and light speed variation.

title: Current and future constraints on extended Bekenstein-type models for a varying fine-structure constant
input: There is a growing interest in astrophysical tests of the stability of dimensionless fundamental couplings, such as the fine-structure constant , as an optimal probe of new physics. The imminent arrival of the ESPRESSO spectrograph will soon enable significant gains in the precision and accuracy of these tests and widen the range of theoretical models that can be tightly constrained. Here we illustrate this by studying proposed extensions of the Bekenstein-type models for the evolution of that allow different couplings of the scalar field to both dark matter and dark energy. We use a combination of current astrophysical and local laboratory data (from tests with atomic clocks) to show that these couplings are constrained to parts per million level, with the constraints being dominated by the atomic clocks. We also quantify the expected improvements from ESPRESSO and other future spectrographs, and briefly discuss possible observational strategies, showing that these facilities can improve current constraints by more than an order of magnitude.

output.explanation:
The universe's fundamental nature is governed by dimensionless couplings, such as the fine-structure constant , which are crucial for understanding new physics phenomena. These couplings can be probed through astrophysical tests, and upcoming spectrographs like ESPRESSO will significantly enhance precision and accuracy in these measurements. Theoretical models of evolution involving scalar fields interacting with dark matter and dark energy can be constrained using a combination of current astrophysical data and laboratory experiments with atomic clocks. 

The fine-structure constant is the ratio of an electron's magnetic moment to its Bohr magneton, while dark matter refers to unseen mass in the universe that affects galaxy rotation curves. Dark energy represents a mysterious component driving cosmic acceleration. The scalar field is a hypothetical entity mediating interactions between these components. 

In astrophysical settings, dimensionless couplings can be constrained by comparing theoretical models with observational data from various sources. These constraints are often limited by the precision of available measurements and the range of applicable models. 

The proposed extensions of Bekenstein-type models involve different couplings between the scalar field and dark matter or dark energy. This allows for a more nuanced understanding of their interactions, which can be constrained using current data from astrophysical observations and laboratory experiments.

title: The mid-plane of the Main Asteroid Belt
input: We measure the mid-plane of the main asteroid belt by using the observational data of a nearly complete and unbiased sample of asteroids, and find that it has inclination degrees and longitude of ascending node degrees (in J2000 ecliptic-equinox coordinate system). This plane differs significantly from previously published measurements, and it is also distinctly different than the solar system's invariable plane as well as Jupiter's orbit plane. The mid-plane of the asteroid belt is theoretically expected to be a slightly warped sheet whose local normal is controlled by the gravity of the major planets. Specifically, its inclination and longitude of ascending node varies with semi-major axis and time (on secular timescales), and is defined by the forced solution of secular perturbation theory; the nodal secular resonance is predicted to cause a significant warp of the mid-plane in the inner asteroid belt. We test the secular theory by measuring the current location of the asteroids' mid-plane in finer semi-major axis bins. We find that the measured mid-plane in the middle and outer asteroid belt is consistent, within 3-- confidence level, with the prediction of secular perturbation theory, but a notable discrepancy is present in the inner asteroid belt near AU.

output.explanation:
The solar system's main asteroid belt is a vast region of space where many small rocky bodies orbit the Sun, and its mid-plane can be thought of as an imaginary flat surface that slices through this collection of asteroids at their average orbital positions.

Inclination degrees refer to how tilted this plane is relative to our solar system's invariable plane. The longitude of ascending node describes an object's orientation within a 3D space, specifically the angle between its orbit and a reference direction. A slightly warped sheet implies that the mid-plane's normal vector varies locally due to major planet gravity.

The gravitational interactions between planets and asteroids cause variations in the inclination and longitude of ascending node with semi-major axis and time on secular timescales. Secular perturbation theory predicts these variations based on these gravitational interactions, which are expected to warp the mid-plane significantly in certain regions.

Measurements show that the measured mid-plane location is consistent within 3-- confidence level with predictions for the middle and outer asteroid belt but exhibits notable discrepancies near AU in the inner region.

title: Reticuli binary system: A puzzling chromospheric activity pattern
input: We perform, for the first time, a detailed long-term activity study of the binary system Ret. We use all available HARPS spectra obtained between the years 2003 and 2016. We built a time series of the Mount Wilson index for both stars, then we analyse these series by using Lomb-Scargle periodograms. The components Ret and Ret that belong to this binary system are physically very similar to each other and also similar to our Sun, which makes it a remarkable system. We detect in the solar-analogue star Ret a long-term activity cycle with a period of 10 yr, similar to the solar one ( 11 yr). It is worthwhile to mention that this object satisfies previous criteria for a flat star and for a cycling star simultaneously. Another interesting feature of this binary system, is a high 0.220 dex difference between the averages log( ) activity levels of both stars. Our study clearly shows that Ret is significantly more active than Ret. In addition, Ret shows an erratic variability in its stellar activity. In this work, we explore different scenarios trying to explain this rare behaviour in a pair of coeval stars, which could help to explain the difference in this and other binary systems. From these results, we also warn that for the development of activity-age calibrations (which commonly use binary systems and/or stellar clusters as calibrators) it should be taken into account the whole history of activity available of the stars involved.

output.explanation:
The universe contains numerous binary systems, consisting of two stars gravitationally bound together. In the context of these systems, stellar activity refers to phenomena such as sunspots and solar flares that occur on a star's surface.

A key concept in understanding stellar activity is the Mount Wilson index, which measures the level of activity exhibited by a star. This index is used to quantify the amount of magnetic field present on a star's surface, with higher values indicating greater levels of activity.

The binary system Ret consists of two stars that are physically similar to each other and to our Sun. These stars exhibit distinct long-term activity patterns, with one star displaying a 10-year cycle akin to that observed in our solar system. This phenomenon is particularly noteworthy given the rarity of such cycles among binary systems.

A notable difference exists between the average activity levels of the two stars in Ret, with one star exhibiting significantly higher values than its companion. The erratic variability in this star's stellar activity presents an intriguing challenge for astronomers seeking to explain this behavior within the context of coeval star pairs.

title: Massive star winds interacting with magnetic fields on various scales
input: One of the defining processes which govern massive star evolution is their continuous mass loss via dense, supersonic line-driven winds. In the case of those OB stars which also host a surface magnetic field, the interaction between that field and the ionized outflow leads to complex circumstellar structures known as magnetospheres. In this contribution, we review recent developments in the field of massive star magnetospheres, including current efforts to characterize the largest magnetosphere surrounding an O star: that of NGC 1624-2. We also discuss the potential of the `analytic dynamical magnetosphere' (ADM) model to interpret multi-wavelength observations. Finally, we examine the possible effects of -- heretofore undetected -- small-scale magnetic fields on massive star winds and compare their hypothetical consequences to existing, unexplained observations.

output.explanation:
Massive stars are characterized by intense radiation that drives supersonic winds, leading to the formation of circumstellar structures known as magnetospheres when a surface magnetic field is present.

The term 'magnetosphere' refers to the region where the stellar wind interacts with the magnetic field lines. Magnetization describes how the magnetic field influences the flow of charged particles in this context. A supersonic line-driven wind is driven by intense radiation, and magnetospheres form when a surface magnetic field is present.

The interaction between the magnetic field and ionized outflow leads to complex circumstellar structures known as magnetospheres surrounding OB stars. The strength of the magnetic field plays a crucial role in shaping these structures. Magnetization influences how charged particles flow within this region.

Magnetospheres exhibit suppression due to their non-relativistic nature, and small-scale magnetic fields may have undetectable effects on massive star winds. These hypothetical consequences are compared to existing unexplained observations.

title: The Search for Dark Matter
input: The dark matter problem is almost a century old. Since the 1930s evidence has been growing that our cosmos is dominated by a new form of non-baryonic matter, that holds galaxies and clusters together and influences cosmic structures up to the largest observed scales. At the microscopic level, we still do not know the composition of this dark, or invisible matter, which does not interact directly with light. The simplest assumption is that it is made of new particles that interact with gravity and at most weakly with known elementary particles. I will discuss searches for such new particles, both space- and Earth-bound including those placed in deep underground laboratories. While a dark matter particle hasn't been yet identified, even after decades of concerted efforts, new technological developments and experiments have reached sensitivities where a discovery might be imminent, albeit certainly not guaranteed.

output.explanation:
The universe is composed of various forms of matter and energy, with dark matter being a dominant force in shaping the cosmos on large scales. Dark matter refers to an invisible form that does not interact directly with light. 

 In this context, 'non-baryonic' describes matter that doesn't consist of baryons (subatomic particles like protons and neutrons), while 'new particles' implies entities beyond our current understanding of the elementary particle spectrum. These new particles are hypothesized to interact with gravity and possibly weakly with known particles. 

 The gravitational interaction between dark matter particles allows them to accumulate in regions of high density, such as galaxy clusters. This accumulation enables the formation of large-scale cosmic structures. However, despite decades of research and technological advancements, a conclusive discovery remains elusive due to undetectability at current sensitivities. 

 Searches for these new particles are ongoing, both space- and Earth-bound, including those placed in deep underground laboratories. The sensitivity of these experiments has reached a point where a discovery might be imminent, albeit not guaranteed.

title: Efficient common-envelope ejection through dust-driven winds
input: Common-envelope evolution (CEE) is the short-lived phase in the life of an interacting binary-system during which two stars orbit inside a single shared envelope. Such evolution is thought to lead to the inspiral of the binary, the ejection of the extended envelope and the formation of a remnant short-period binary. However, detailed hydrodynamical models of CEE encounter major difficulties. They show that following the inspiral most of the envelope is not ejected; though it expands to larger separations, it remains bound to the binary. Here we propose that dust-driven winds can be produced following the CEE. These can evaporate the envelope following similar processes operating in the ejection of the envelopes of AGB stars. Pulsations in an AGB-star drives the expansion of its envelope, allowing the material to cool down to low temperatures thus enabling dust condensation. Radiation pressure on the dust accelerates it, and through its coupling to the gas it drives winds which eventually completely erode the envelope. We show that the inspiral phase in CE-binaries can effectively replace the role of stellar pulsation and drive the CE expansion to scales comparable with those of AGB stars, and give rise to efficient mass-loss through dust-driven winds.

output.explanation:
In the universe, binary systems consisting of two stars are a common occurrence. Binary systems can be classified based on their evolutionary stage into various types such as main-sequence binaries and post-main sequence binaries like asymptotic giant branch (AGB) stars which have envelopes that expand due to pulsations allowing material to cool down to low temperatures thus enabling dust condensation.

The term 'dust formation' refers to the process where gas in a star's envelope cools down sufficiently for it to condense into solid particles. This phenomenon is crucial in understanding various astrophysical processes including common-envelope evolution (CEE).

During CEE, radiation pressure on dust plays a pivotal role as it accelerates the dust and drives winds that can strip away the shared envelope of the binary system. The inspiral phase within this context can be seen as analogous to stellar pulsations driving the expansion of the shared envelope.

The process described in the previous paragraph leads to efficient mass loss through dust-driven winds, effectively replacing the role of stellar pulsation and driving CE expansion to scales comparable with those found in AGB stars. This outcome is a result of radiation pressure on dust accelerating it and expelling material from the system.

title: Analysis of the Yukawa gravitational potential in gravity II: relativistic periastron advance
input: Alternative theories of gravity may serve to overcame several shortcomings of the standard cosmological model but, in their weak field limit, General Relativity must be recovered so as to match the tight constraints at the Solar System scale. Therefore, testing such alternative models at scales of stellar systems could give a unique opportunity to confirm or rule them out. One of the most straightforward modifications is represented by analytical -gravity models that introduce a Yukawa-like modification to the Newtonian potential thus modifying the dynamics of particles. Using the geodesics equations, we have illustrated the amplitude of these modifications. First, we have integrated numerically the equations of motion showing the orbital precession of a particle around a massive object. Second, we have computed an analytic expression for the periastron advance of systems having their semi-major axis much shorter than the Yukawa-scale length. Finally, we have extended our results to the case of a binary system composed of two massive objects. Our analysis provides a powerful tool to obtain constraints on the underlying theory of gravity using current and forthcoming datasets.

output.explanation:
The cosmos is governed by gravity, shaping the motion of celestial bodies in vast systems like our Solar System. Gravity's influence warps spacetime around massive objects, affecting nearby particles' paths. In this context, General Relativity accurately describes these phenomena at small scales. However, alternative theories propose modifications to this framework, which must be consistent with observations.

Key terms such as the Newtonian potential and geodesics equations are crucial in understanding gravity's effects on particle dynamics. The Newtonian potential represents the gravitational field around a massive object, while geodesics equations describe how particles move under gravity's influence. A Yukawa-like term is introduced to modify the Newtonian potential, effectively altering particle dynamics.

This modification leads to observable effects such as orbital precession and periastron advance in systems with semi-major axes shorter than the Yukawa-scale length. The amplitude of these modifications depends on the scale length of the Yukawa correction. In binary systems composed of two massive objects, similar effects are observed, providing a means to constrain alternative theories using observational data.

The analysis provides constraints on the underlying theory of gravity by comparing predictions with current and forthcoming datasets.

title: An ALMA view of star formation efficiency suppression in early-type galaxies after gas-rich minor mergers
input: Gas-rich minor mergers contribute significantly to the gas reservoir of early-type galaxies (ETGs) at low redshift, yet the star formation efficiency (SFE; the star formation rate divided by the molecular gas mass) appears to be strongly suppressed following some of these events, in contrast to the more well-known merger-driven starbursts. We present observations with the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) of six ETGs, which have each recently undergone a gas-rich minor merger, as evidenced by their disturbed stellar morphologies. These galaxies were selected because they exhibit extremely low SFEs. We use the resolving power of ALMA to study the morphology and kinematics of the molecular gas. The majority of our galaxies exhibit spatial and kinematical irregularities, such as detached gas clouds, warps, and other asymmetries. These asymmetries support the interpretation that the suppression of the SFE is caused by dynamical effects stabilizing the gas against gravitational collapse. Through kinematic modelling we derive high velocity dispersions and Toomre Q stability parameters for the gas, but caution that such measurements in edge-on galaxies suffer from degeneracies. We estimate merger ages to be about 100~Myr based on the observed disturbances in the gas distribution. Furthermore, we determine that these galaxies lie, on average, two orders of magnitude below the Kennicutt-Schmidt relation for star-forming galaxies as well as below the relation for relaxed ETGs. We discuss potential dynamical processes responsible for this strong suppression of star formation surface density at fixed molecular gas surface density.

output.explanation:
Early-type galaxies at low redshift are often formed through the merger of smaller gas-rich systems, contributing significantly to their gas reservoirs.

The star formation efficiency (SFE) is a key concept in understanding galaxy evolution; it's defined as the rate at which stars form divided by the mass of available molecular gas. In contrast, early-type galaxies have lower SFEs and often exhibit relaxed morphologies.

Dynamical effects play a crucial role in stabilizing the gas against gravitational collapse, preventing its collapse into dense regions where stars could form. This stabilization is supported by observations revealing spatial and kinematical irregularities in six ETGs following a recent gas-rich minor merger.

These galaxies exhibit high velocity dispersions and Toomre Q stability parameters for the gas, but caution is advised when interpreting these measurements due to degeneracies inherent in edge-on galaxy observations. The strong suppression of star formation surface density at fixed molecular gas surface density can be attributed to dynamical processes that stabilize the gas against gravitational collapse.

title: Enrichment of Zinc in galactic chemodynamical evolution models
input: The heaviest iron-peak element, Zn has been used as an important tracer of cosmic chemical evolution. Spectroscopic observations of the metal-poor stars in Local Group galaxies show that an increasing trend of [Zn/Fe] ratios toward lower metallicity. However, enrichment of Zn in galaxies is not well understood due to the poor knowledge of astrophysical sites of Zn as well as metal mixing in galaxies. Here we show possible explanations for the observed trend by taking into account electron-capture supernovae (ECSNe) as one of the sources of Zn in our chemodynamical simulations of dwarf galaxies. We find that the ejecta from ECSNe contribute to stars with [Zn/Fe] 0.5. We also find that scatters of [Zn/Fe] in higher metallicity originate from the ejecta of type Ia supernovae. On the other hand, it appears difficult to explain the observed trends if we do not consider ECSNe as a source of Zn. These results come from inhomogeneous spatial metallicity distribution due to the inefficiency of metal mixing. We find that the optimal value of scaling factor for metal diffusion coefficient is 0.01 in the shear-based metal mixing model in smoothed particle hydrodynamics simulations. These results suggest that ECSNe can be one of the contributors to the enrichment of Zn in galaxies.

output.explanation:
The universe's chemical evolution is a complex process influenced by various astrophysical sites and metal mixing in galaxies.

Metallicity refers to the abundance of elements within stars, while electron-capture supernovae (ECSNe) are a type of explosive event that occurs at the end of a star's life. Type Ia supernovae, on the other hand, are thought to result from the explosion of white dwarf stars.
