To ensure stability over astronomical time scale of a { realistic} planetary system -- in which planets have masses comparable to those of planets in the solar system -- the motion must be quasi-periodic. A dynamical mechanism is proposed which naturally evolves a planetary system to a quasi-periodic state from an arbitrary initial condition. A planetary self-organization predicted by the theory is similar to the one found in our solar system. %

output.explanation:
Planetary systems exist within a vast, dynamic cosmos where celestial bodies interact through gravity. This gravitational force governs the motion of planets and other objects in space.

Gravitational interactions can be chaotic, leading to unpredictable outcomes such as collisions or ejections from the system. Chaotic dynamics refer to complex, seemingly random behavior that arises from the intricate web of gravitational forces between celestial bodies. Arnold diffusion is a specific phenomenon where energy is transferred among these bodies, further destabilizing their orbits.

Key terms in this context include chaotic dynamics and quasi-periodic motion. Chaotic dynamics describe systems where small changes can lead to drastically different outcomes, while quasi-periodic motion refers to predictable patterns of movement that repeat over time. These concepts are essential for understanding the behavior of planetary systems.

The stability of a planetary system relies on its ability to transition from an arbitrary initial condition to a state of quasi-periodic motion. This process is facilitated by a dynamical mechanism that naturally evolves the system towards greater order and predictability, similar to what is observed in our own solar system.

title: Evidence For The Magnetic Breakout Model in an Equatorial Coronal-Hole Jet
input: Small, impulsive jets commonly occur throughout the solar corona, but are especially visible in coronal holes. Evidence is mounting that jets are part of a continuum of eruptions that extends to much larger coronal mass ejections and eruptive flares. Because coronal-hole jets originate in relatively simple magnetic structures, they offer an ideal testbed for theories of energy buildup and release in the full range of solar eruptions. We analyzed an equatorial coronal-hole jet observed by SDO/AIA on 09 January 2014, in which the magnetic-field structure was consistent with the embedded-bipole topology that we identified and modeled previously as an origin of coronal jets. In addition, this event contained a mini-filament, which led to important insights into the energy storage and release mechanisms. SDO/HMI magnetograms revealed footpoint motions in the primary minority-polarity region at the eruption site, but show negligible flux emergence or cancellation for at least 16 hours before the eruption. Therefore, the free energy powering this jet probably came from magnetic shear concentrated at the polarity inversion line within the embedded bipole. We find that the observed activity sequence and its interpretation closely match the predictions of the breakout jet model, strongly supporting the hypothesis that the breakout model can explain solar eruptions on a wide range of scales.

output.explanation:
The solar corona is a region of intense magnetic activity, where small-scale eruptions frequently occur, particularly in coronal holes. These events are thought to be part of a continuum that extends to larger scale phenomena. Coronal-hole jets originate from relatively simple magnetic structures, making them an ideal testing ground for theories on energy buildup and release across the full range of solar eruptions.

The embedded-bipole topology is characterized by its polarity inversion lines, where opposite magnetic polarities meet. Magnetic shear occurs when these polarities are twisted together at a polarity inversion line, creating free energy that can be released through eruptions. This concept is crucial in understanding coronal-hole jets and their relationship to larger scale phenomena.

The interaction between the embedded-bipole topology and the surrounding magnetic field leads to the buildup of free energy. When this energy becomes unstable, it is released as a jet, driven by magnetic shear concentrated at the polarity inversion line within the embedded bipole. The observed activity sequence closely matches predictions of the breakout jet model.

The findings suggest that solar eruptions on various scales can be explained by the same underlying mechanism: magnetic shear concentrated at polarity inversion lines within embedded bipoles.

title: Stellar Bar evolution in the absence of dark matter halo
input: We study the stellar bar growth in high resolution numerical galaxy models with and without dark matter halos. In all models the galactic disk is exponential and the halos are rigid or live Plummer spheres. More specifically, when there is no dark matter halo, we modify the gravitational force between point particles. To do so we use the weak field limit of an alternative theory of dark matter known as MOG in the literature. The galaxy model in MOG has the same initial conditions as in galaxy models with dark matter halo. On the other hand, the initial random velocities and the Toomre's local stability parameter are the same for all the models. We show that the evolution and growth of the bar in MOG is substantially different from the standard cases including dark matter halo. More importantly, we find that the bar growth rate and its final magnitude is smaller in MOG. On the other hand, the maximum value of the bar in MOG is smaller than the Newtonian models. It is shown that although the live dark matter halo may support the bar instability, MOG has stabilizing effects. Furthermore, we show that MOG supports fast pattern speeds, and unlike in the dark matter halo models pattern speed does not decrease with time. Theses differences, combined with the relevant observations, may help to distinguish between dark matter an modified gravity in galactic scales.

output.explanation:
Galaxies are complex systems consisting of a central bulge surrounded by a disk of stars and other matter, which rotates around the galactic center.

A Plummer sphere is a model for dark matter halos that surrounds galaxies, representing either rigid or dynamic structures. The Toomre's local stability parameter quantifies the likelihood of bar instability in these systems. MOG stands for Modified Gravity theory, an alternative to Newtonian gravity describing gravitational force between particles at large scales.

The interaction between modified gravity and galactic disk dynamics leads to distinct differences in stellar bar growth patterns compared to traditional models with dark matter halos. The simulations demonstrate that the gravitational force modification affects how particles interact within the galactic disk, influencing stability and ultimately affecting bar growth rates.

MOG supports slower bar growth rates, smaller final magnitudes than standard Newtonian models, and faster pattern speeds that remain constant over time, whereas these speeds decrease in live dark matter halo models.

title: First Cosmological Constraint on the Effective Theory of Dark Matter-Proton Interactions
input: We obtain the first cosmological constraints on interactions between dark matter and protons within the formalism of nonrelativistic effective field theory developed for direct detection. For each interaction operator in the effective theory, parametrized by different powers of the relative velocity of the incoming particles, we use the Planck 2015 cosmic microwave background (CMB) temperature, polarization, and lensing anisotropy to set upper limits on the scattering cross section for all dark matter masses above 15 keV. We find that for interactions associated with a stronger dependence on velocity, dark matter and baryons stay thermally coupled for longer, but the interaction strengths are suppressed at the low temperatures relevant for Planck observations and are thus less constrained. At the same time, cross sections with stronger velocity dependencies are more constrained in the limit of small dark matter mass. In all cases, the effect of dark matter-proton scattering is most prominent on small scales in the CMB power spectra and in the matter power spectrum, and we thus expect substantial improvement over the current limits with data from ground-based CMB experiments and galaxy surveys.

output.explanation:
The universe's evolution is shaped by the presence of dark matter, a type of matter that does not interact with light.

Dark matter-proton interactions are governed by nonrelativistic effective field theory, which describes how particles move at low speeds relative to each other. Key terms in this context include thermal coupling and scattering cross section.

Thermal coupling refers to the process where dark matter and baryons (normal matter) exchange energy due to their interactions. The strength of these interactions depends on the velocity between incoming particles, with stronger dependencies leading to longer-lasting couplings but suppressed interaction strengths at low temperatures.

The effect of dark matter-proton scattering is most prominent in small-scale structures within the cosmic microwave background and galaxy distributions. In particular, cross sections with stronger velocity dependencies are more constrained for smaller dark matter masses.

title: Absolute dimensions and evolutionary status of the semi-detached Algol W Ursae Minoris
input: Double-lined eclipsing binaries allow accurate and direct determination of fundamental parameters such as mass and radius for each component, and they provide important constraints on the stellar structure and evolution models. In this study, we aim to determine a unique set of binary parameters for the Algol system W UMi and to examine its evolutionary status. New high-resolution time-series spectroscopic observations were carried out during 14 nights from April 2008 to March 2011, and a total of 37 spectra were obtained using the Bohyunsan Optical Echelle Spectrograph. We measured the radial velocities (RVs) for both components, and the effective temperature of the primary star was found to be = 9310 90 K by a comparison of the observed spectra and the Kurucz models. The physical parameters of W UMi were derived by an analysis of our RV data together with the multi-band light curves of Devinney et al. (1970). The individual masses, radii, and luminosities of both components are = 3.68 0.10 M and = 1.47 0.04 M , = 3.88 0.03 R and = 3.13 0.03 R , and = 102 1 L and = 7.3 0.1 L , respectively. A comparison of these parameters with theoretical stellar models showed that the primary component lies in the main-sequence band, while the less massive secondary is noticeably evolved. The results indicate that the initially more massive star became the present secondary by losing most of its own mass via mass transfer to the companion (present primary).

output.explanation:
Stellar systems like W UMi, consisting of two stars in close orbit, allow for precise measurements of their fundamental properties.

The term 'radial velocity' refers to the speed at which a star moves towards or away from an observer along its line of sight, while effective temperature defines the surface temperature of a star. In this context, radial velocities are used as a proxy for measuring mass by analyzing Doppler shifts in spectral lines.

When two stars orbit each other closely, their interactions can lead to significant changes in their physical properties. Mass transfer from one star to its companion can cause the more massive star to lose most of its own mass, resulting in a change of roles between the initially more and less massive stars.

The analysis of W UMi's binary parameters revealed that the primary component is currently on the main-sequence band, while its less massive companion has undergone significant evolution due to mass transfer. The individual masses, radii, and luminosities of both components were derived through an analysis of radial velocity data combined with multi-band light curves.

title: Constraining the early universe with primordial black holes
input: In this thesis, the effect of non-Gaussianity upon the abundance of primordial black holes (PBHs), and the implications of such an effect are considered. It is shown that even small non-Gaussianity parameters can have a large effect on the constraints that can be placed on the primordial curvature perturbation power spectrum - which can become stronger or weaker by an order of magnitude. The effects of super-horizon curvature perturbation modes at the time of PBH formation are considered, and it is shown that these have little effect on the formation of a PBH, but can have an indirect effect on the abundance of PBHs due to modal coupling to horizon-scale modes in the presence of non-Gaussianity. By taking into account the effect of modal coupling to CMB-scale modes, many models can be ruled out as a mechanism to produce enough PBHs to constitute dark matter.

output.explanation:
The universe's early stages involve the formation of primordial black holes (PBHs), which can potentially constitute dark matter.

Primordial curvature perturbations are a measure of density fluctuations in the cosmos, and they play a crucial role in this process. Non-Gaussianity refers to deviations from Gaussian distributions, while PBHs are formed through gravitational collapse. The primordial curvature perturbation power spectrum is sensitive to non-Gaussian parameters.

When super-horizon modes of curvature perturbations interact with horizon-scale modes due to modal coupling and the presence of non-Gaussianity, they can indirectly influence PBH abundance. This interaction affects the constraints on the primordial curvature perturbation power spectrum.

Even small values of non-Gaussian parameters can lead to an order-of-magnitude change in these constraints, ruling out many models as viable mechanisms for producing sufficient PBHs to account for dark matter.

title: Fully kinetic large scale simulations of the collisionless Magnetorotational instability
input: We present two-dimensional particle-in-cell (PIC) simulations of the fully kinetic collisionless magnetorotational instability (MRI) in weakly magnetized (high ) pair plasma. The central result of this numerical analysis is the emergence of a self-induced turbulent regime in the saturation state of the collisionless MRI, which can only be captured for large enough simulation domains. One of the underlying mechanisms for the development of this turbulent state is the drift-kink instability (DKI) of the current sheets resulting from the nonlinear evolution of the channel modes. The onset of the DKI can only be observed for simulation domain sizes exceeding several linear MRI wavelengths. The DKI, together with ensuing magnetic reconnection, activate the turbulent motion of the plasma in the late stage of the nonlinear evolution of the MRI. At steady state, the magnetic energy has an MHD-like spectrum with a slope of for and for sub-Larmor scale ( ). We also examine the role of the collisionless MRI and associated magnetic reconnection in the development of pressure anisotropy. We study the stability of the system due to this pressure anisotropy, observing the development of mirror instability during the early-stage of the MRI. We further discuss the importance of magnetic reconnection for particle acceleration during the turbulence regime. In particular, consistent with reconnection studies, we show that at late times the kinetic energy presents a characteristic slope of in the high-energy region.

output.explanation:
The fully kinetic collisionless magnetorotational instability (MRI) occurs in weakly magnetized pair plasma, where the magnetic field is relatively strong compared to the thermal energy of the particles. The MRI leads to the formation of current sheets through the nonlinear evolution of channel modes. 

The drift-kink instability (DKI) emerges as a key mechanism for developing turbulent states within these current sheets. This requires simulation domains that are several linear MRI wavelengths in size, allowing the DKI to be observed and its effects on magnetic reconnection to unfold. The resulting turbulence activates plasma motion in the late stages of MRI evolution. 

The system's behavior is characterized by a magnetic energy spectrum with two distinct regimes: for scales larger than the Larmor scale ( ), and for sub-Larmor scales ( ). This MHD-like spectrum indicates that the system has reached a state where macroscopic fluid dynamics dominate over kinetic effects. 

Pressure anisotropy also plays a crucial role, as it can lead to mirror instability during the early stages of MRI evolution. Magnetic reconnection is essential for particle acceleration within this turbulent regime, with late-time kinetic energy exhibiting a characteristic slope in the high-energy region.

title: Models for the Unusual Supernova iPTF14hls
input: Supernova iPTF14hls maintained a bright, variable luminosity for more than 600 days, while lines of hydrogen and iron in its spectrum had different speeds, but showed little evolution. Here several varieties of models are explored for iPTF14hls-like events. They are based upon circumstellar medium (CSM) interaction in an ordinary supernova, pulsational pair-instability supernovae (PPISN), and magnetar formation. Each is able to explain the enduring emission and brightness of iPTF14hls, but has shortcomings when confronted with other observed characteristics. The PPISN model can, in some cases, produce a presupernova transient like the one observed at the site of iPTF14hls in 1954. It also offers a clear path to providing the necessary half solar mass of material at cm for CSM interaction to work, and can give an irregular light curve without invoking additional assumptions. It explains the 4000 km s seen in the iron lines, but without additional energy input, strains to explain the nearly constant 8000 km s velocity seen in H . Magnetar models can also explain many of the observed features, but give a smooth light curve and may require an evolving magnetic field strength. Their dynamics may be difficult to reconcile with the observation of slow-moving hydrogen at late times. The various models predict different spectral characteristics and a remnant that, today, could be a black hole, magnetar, or even a star. Further observations and calculations of radiation transport will narrow the range of possibilities.

output.explanation:
Supernovae occur in the vast expanses of interstellar space where gas and dust are dispersed among stars.

The circumstellar medium (CSM) is a region surrounding a star with ejected material, while pulsational pair-instability supernovae (PPISN) models propose that these events arise from massive stars undergoing pulsations before exploding. Magnetar formation models also suggest the involvement of massive stars but focus on magnetic field dynamics.

A presupernova transient refers to an event occurring just before a star's explosion, while CSM interaction involves material ejected by stars into their surroundings. The PPISN model can produce such transients and provide necessary material for CSM interaction, yielding irregular light curves without additional assumptions.

The various models forecast different spectral characteristics and remnant possibilities: a black hole, magnetar, or even a star.

title: Identifying two groups of massive stars aligned in the Galactic direction
input: Context: Recent near-infrared data have contributed to unveil massive and obscured stellar populations in both new and previously known clusters in our Galaxy. These discoveries lead us to view the Milky Way as an active star-forming machine. Aims: We look for young massive cluster candidates as over-densities of OB-type stars. The first search, focused on the Galactic direction , resulted in the detection of two objects with a remarkable population of OB-type star candidates. Methods: With a modified version of the friends-of-friends algorithm AUTOPOP and using 2MASS and UKIDSS-GPS near-infrared ( , , and ) photometry for one of our cluster candidates (named Masgomas-6) we selected 30 stars for multi-object and long-slit - and -spectroscopy. With the spectral classification and the near-infrared photometric data, we derive individual distance, extinction and radial velocity. Results: Of the 30 spectroscopically observed stars, 20 are classified as massive stars, including OB-types (dwarfs, giants and supergiants), two red supergiants, two Wolf-Rayet (WR122-11 and the new WR122-16), and one transitional object (the LBV candidate IRAS 18576+0341). The individual distances and radial velocities do not agree with a single cluster, indicating that we are observing two populations of massive stars in the same line-of-sight: Masgomas-6a and Masgomas-6b. The first group of massive stars, located at 3.9 kpc, contains both Wolf-Rayets and most of the OB-dwarfs, and Masgomas-6b, at kpc, hosts the LBV candidate and an evolved population of supergiants. We are able to identify massive stars at two Galactic arms, but we can not clearly identify whether these massive stars form clusters or associations.

output.explanation:
The Milky Way is a vast, dynamic system where star-forming regions emerge and evolve over time. In this context, young massive clusters are of particular interest due to their potential for harboring OB-type stars. These luminous objects are key indicators of recent star formation.

OB-type refers to massive stars primarily composed of hydrogen and helium. They can be classified into dwarfs, giants, or supergiants based on their luminosity and surface temperature. Wolf-Rayet (WR) stars, such as WR122-11 and the newly identified WR122-16, are characterized by intense radiation and strong stellar winds.

The analysis of spectroscopic data revealed two populations of massive stars in the same line-of-sight: Masgomas-6a and Masgomas-6b. The first group is located at 3.9 kpc, containing both Wolf-Rayets and most OB-dwarfs. In contrast, the second population hosts an LBV candidate and evolved supergiants.

The discovery of these two populations suggests that massive star formation in our Galaxy may be more complex than previously thought. The individual distances and radial velocities do not agree with a single cluster, indicating that we are observing multiple populations of massive stars.

title: Adsorption energies of carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen atoms on the low-temperature amorphous water ice: A systematic estimation from quantum chemistry calculations
input: We propose a new simple computational model to estimate adsorption energies of atoms and molecules to low-temperature amorphous water ice, and we present the adsorption energies of carbon (3P), nitrogen (4S), and oxygen (3P) atoms based on quantum chemistry calculations. The adsorption energies were estimated to be 14100 +- 420 K for carbon, 400 +- 30 K for nitrogen, and 1440 +-160 K for oxygen. The adsorption energy of oxygen is well consistent with experimentally reported value. We found that the binding of a nitrogen atom is purely physisorption, while that of a carbon atom is chemisorption in which a chemical bond to an O atom of a water molecule is formed. That of an oxygen atom has a dual character both physisorption and chemisorption. The chemisorption of atomic carbon also implies a possibility of further chemical reactions to produce molecules bearing a C-O bond, while it may hinder the formation of methane on water ice via sequential hydrogenation of carbon atoms. These would be of a large impact to the chemical evolution of carbon species in interstellar environments. We also investigated effects of the newly calculated adsorption energies onto chemical compositions of cold dense molecular clouds with the aid of gas-ice astrochemical simulations. We found that abundances of major nitrogen-bearing molecules, such as N2 and NH3, are significantly altered by applying the calculated adsorption energy, because nitrogen atoms can thermally diffuse on surfaces even at 10 K.

output.explanation:
Low-temperature amorphous water ice exists in interstellar environments, where atoms and molecules can adsorb to its surface. Adsorption energies are a measure of the strength of these interactions.

Physisorption refers to weak van der Waals forces holding an atom or molecule to the surface, while chemisorption involves a strong chemical bond between the atom or molecule and an oxygen atom of a water molecule. The adsorption energy quantifies this binding interaction.

When atoms interact with amorphous water ice, physisorption occurs through weak van der Waals forces, whereas chemisorption forms a strong chemical bond. For instance, carbon atoms exhibit chemisorption with an estimated adsorption energy of 14100 ± 420 K, indicating a strong binding interaction. In contrast, nitrogen atoms undergo purely physisorption.

The implications of these findings are significant for the chemical evolution of carbon species in interstellar environments. Specifically, the chemisorption of atomic carbon may hinder methane formation via sequential hydrogenation of carbon atoms.

title: Updating a simple model of lunar recession
input: A classical model of lunar recession is reviewed and updated, where input parameters are taken or inferred from earlier astronomical computation of insolation quantities on Earth back to 0.25 Gyr. Free parameters are (i) the transition age, where mean lunar recession is suddenly lowered, and (ii) the merging age, where Earth-Moon distance (EMD), drops to zero. Predicted mean EMD and length of day (LOD) slightly overstimate their counterparts from the above mentioned astronomical computation. Predicted LOD, where the effect of atmospheric tides and nontidal processes is considered and supposed to be time independent, slightly understimates a linear interpolation from paleontological data related to Phanerozoic, inferred in earlier investigations. If short-period ( Gyr) EMD fluctuations ( ), resulting from the above mentioned astronomical computation back to 0.25 Gyr, occur along the whole evolution of Earth-Moon system (EMS), then the predicted mean EMD is consistent with values inferred from three well studied paleontological data sets: Elatina-Reynella (ER), Big Cottonwood (BC), Weeli Wolli (WW), for a suitable choice of input parameters. The same holds for LOD where, in addition, computed values are consistent with a linear interpolation from paleontological data related to Proterozoic, inferred in earlier investigations. The effect of atmospheric tides and nontidal processes is also discussed. In conclusion, the current model can be considered as a useful zeroth-order approximation to the evaluation of lunar recession and LOD. More accurate paleontological data, expecially in connection with error evaluation, would be desirable in view of improved results and further constraints involving both Astronomy and Paleontology.

output.explanation:
The Earth-Moon system is a complex celestial environment where gravitational forces shape the evolution of our planet and its satellite.

Insolation quantities describe the amount of solar energy received by Earth, which has been computed for various time periods, including 0.25 Gyr ago. A classical model of lunar recession relies on these computations, with two key parameters: transition age and merging age. The transition age marks a sudden decrease in mean lunar recession, while the merging age represents the point at which Earth-Moon distance drops to zero.

The process of lunar recession is influenced by gravitational forces between Earth and Moon. Insolation quantities play a crucial role in shaping this interaction. Atmospheric tides and nontidal processes also impact the length of day (LOD) and mean Earth-Moon distance (EMD).

Predicted values for EMD and LOD are compared to earlier astronomical computations and paleontological data, showing slight overestimation or underestimation depending on the consideration of atmospheric tides. However, if short-period EMD fluctuations occur throughout the EMS evolution, predicted mean EMD is consistent with inferred values from three well-studied paleontological datasets: Elatina-Reynella, Big Cottonwood, and Weeli Wolli. Similarly, computed LOD values are consistent with linear interpolations from Proterozoic paleontological data.

title: A combined multiwavelength VLA/ALMA/Chandra study unveils the complex magnetosphere of the B-type star HR5907
input: We present new radio/millimeter measurements of the hot magnetic star HR5907 obtained with the VLA and ALMA interferometers. We find that HR5907 is the most radio luminous early type star in the cm-mm band among those presently known. Its multi-wavelength radio light curves are strongly variable with an amplitude that increases with radio frequency. The radio emission can be explained by the populations of the non-thermal electrons accelerated in the current sheets on the outer border of the magnetosphere of this fast rotating magnetic star. We classify HR5907 as another member of the growing class of strongly magnetic fast rotating hot stars where the gyro-synchrotron emission mechanism efficiently operates in their magnetospheres. The new radio observations of HR5907 are combined with archival X-ray data to study the physical condition of its magnetosphere. The X-ray spectra of HR5907 show tentative evidence for the presence of non-thermal spectral component. We suggest that non-thermal X-rays originate a stellar X-ray aurora due to streams of non-thermal electrons impacting on the stellar surface. Taking advantage of the relation between the spectral indices of the X-ray power-law spectrum and the non-thermal electron energy distributions, we perform 3-D modeling of the radio emission for HR5907. The wavelength-dependent radio light-curves probe magnetospheric layers at different heights above the stellar surface. A detailed comparison between simulated and observed radio light-curves leads us to conclude that the stellar magnetic field of HR5907 is likely non-dipolar, providing further indirect evidence of the complex magnetic field topology of HR5907.

output.explanation:
The universe is home to a variety of stars, including hot magnetic ones like HR5907.

A magnetosphere is the region around a star where its magnetic field dominates, and it's here that non-thermal electrons are accelerated in current sheets on the outer border. This process is known as gyro-synchrotron emission, which generates radio waves by accelerating charged particles within a magnetic field.

Gyro-synchrotron emission relies on the concept of synchrotron radiation, where charged particles emit electromagnetic radiation when moving at high speeds within a magnetic field. The energy distribution of non-thermal electrons is crucial in determining the spectral indices of X-ray power-law spectra.

The radio light curves of HR5907 exhibit strong variability with increasing amplitude across different frequencies, suggesting that its magnetosphere contains layers at various heights above the stellar surface. This variability can be attributed to the populations of accelerated non-thermal electrons, and 3-D modeling indicates that HR5907's magnetic field is likely non-dipolar.

title: Oceanic tides from Earth-like to ocean planets
input: Oceanic tides are a major source of tidal dissipation. They drive the evolution of planetary systems and the rotational dynamics of planets. However, 2D models commonly used for the Earth cannot be applied to extrasolar telluric planets hosting potentially deep oceans because they ignore the three-dimensional effects related to the ocean vertical structure. Our goal is to investigate in a consistant way the importance of the contribution of internal gravity waves in the oceanic tidal response and to propose a modeling allowing to treat a wide range of cases from shallow to deep oceans. A 3D ab initio model is developed to study the dynamics of a global planetary ocean. This model takes into account compressibility, stratification and sphericity terms, which are usually ignored in 2D approaches. An analytic solution is computed and used to study the dependence of the tidal response on the tidal frequency and on the ocean depth and stratification. In the 2D asymptotic limit, we recover the frequency-resonant behaviour due to surface inertial-gravity waves identified by early studies. As the ocean depth and Brunt-Väisälä frequency increase, the contribution of internal gravity waves grows in importance and the tidal response become three-dimensional. In the case of deep oceans, the stable stratification induces resonances that can increase the tidal dissipation rate by several orders of magnitude. It is thus able to affect significantly the evolution time scale of the planetary rotation.

output.explanation:
Planetary systems are influenced by the gravitational interaction between a planet and its surrounding environment, including oceans. The Earth's oceanic tides play a significant role in this process, driving the evolution of planetary systems and rotational dynamics.

The Brunt-Väisälä frequency is a measure of stratified layer stability, while compressibility refers to changes in fluid density under pressure. Sphericity terms account for the curvature of the planet's surface.

Internal gravity waves arise from ocean currents interacting with the planet's rotation, leading to three-dimensional dynamics. These waves become increasingly important as ocean depth and stratification increase, eventually dominating tidal responses in deep oceans.

In stable stratified layers, resonances can amplify tidal dissipation rates by several orders of magnitude, significantly affecting planetary rotation timescales.

title: FBQS J1644+2619: multiwavelength properties and its place in the class of gamma-ray emitting Narrow Line Seyfert 1s
input: A small fraction of Narrow Line Seyfert 1s (NLSy1s) are observed to be gamma-ray emitters. Understanding the properties of these sources is of interest since the majority of NLSy1s are very different from typical blazars. Here, we present a multi-frequency analysis of FBQS J1644+2619, one of the most recently discovered gamma-ray emitting NLSy1s. We analyse an ~80 ks XMM-Newton observation obtained in 2017, as well as quasi-simultaneous multi-wavelength observations covering the radio - gamma-ray range. The spectral energy distribution of the source is similar to the other gamma-ray NLSy1s, confirming its blazar-like nature. The X-ray spectrum is characterised by a hard photon index (Gamma = 1.66) above 2 keV and a soft excess at lower energies.The hard photon index provides clear evidence that inverse Compton emission from the jet dominates the spectrum, while the soft excess can be explained by a contribution from the underlying Seyfert emission. This contribution can be fitted by reflection of emission from the base of the jet, as well as by Comptonisation in a warm, optically thick corona. We discuss our results in the context of the other gamma-ray NLSy1s and note that the majority of them have similar X-ray spectra, with properties intermediate between blazars and radio-quiet NLSy1s.

output.explanation:
Astronomers study a rare class of galaxies called Narrow Line Seyfert 1s, which occasionally emit gamma rays. These sources differ significantly from typical blazars. In this research, the properties of FBQS J1644+2619 are analyzed using XMM-Newton observations and multi-wavelength data covering radio to gamma-ray frequencies. The source's energy distribution is similar to other gamma-ray emitting NLSy1s, indicating a blazar-like nature.

The analysis reveals that high-energy photons in the galaxy's jet dominate its spectrum, while lower-energy radiation can be attributed to either reflected emission from the base of the jet or Comptonization within an optically thick corona. Key terms include inverse Compton scattering and Comptonization, which describe processes where energetic particles interact with surrounding matter.

The interaction between high-energy photons in the galaxy's jet and lower-energy radiation is a crucial aspect of this phenomenon. The hard photon index (Gamma = 1.66) above 2 keV indicates that inverse Compton emission dominates the spectrum, while the soft excess at lower energies can be explained by reflection or Comptonization.

The X-ray spectra of these galaxies are characterized by a mix of blazar-like and radio-quiet properties, suggesting an intermediate nature between typical blazars and NLSy1s.

title: Galaxy Formation Efficiency and the Multiverse Explanation of the Cosmological Constant with EAGLE Simulations
input: Models of the very early universe, including inflationary models, are argued to produce varying universe domains with different values of fundamental constants and cosmic parameters. Using the cosmological hydrodynamical simulation code from the eagle collaboration, we investigate the effect of the cosmological constant on the formation of galaxies and stars. We simulate universes with values of the cosmological constant ranging from Lambda = 0 to Lambda_0 = 300, where Lambda_0 is the value of the cosmological constant in our Universe. Because the global star formation rate in our Universe peaks at t = 3.5 Gyr, before the onset of accelerating expansion, increases in Lambda of even an order of magnitude have only a small effect on the star formation history and efficiency of the universe. We use our simulations to predict the observed value of the cosmological constant, given a measure of the multiverse. Whether the cosmological constant is successfully predicted depends crucially on the measure. The impact of the cosmological constant on the formation of structure in the universe does not seem to be a sharp enough function of Lambda to explain its observed value alone.

output.explanation:
The universe is thought to be composed of distinct domains with varying fundamental constants and cosmic parameters, a concept supported by inflationary models.

In this context, the cosmological constant Lambda plays a crucial role in shaping the formation of galaxies and stars. To understand its impact, it's essential to define key terms: the cosmological constant is a measure of the universe's energy density, while galaxy formation refers to the process by which gas and dust coalesce into celestial bodies.

The interaction between these processes can be understood through the lens of hydrodynamics, where the motion of fluids and gases drives the formation of structure in the universe. In this framework, the cosmological constant influences the rate at which galaxies form by affecting the expansion history of the universe.

According to simulations conducted using the eagle collaboration's code, even significant increases in Lambda have a minimal effect on star formation rates, given that this process peaks before the onset of accelerated expansion. Furthermore, predicting the observed value of Lambda relies heavily on how one measures the multiverse, and the relationship between Lambda and structure formation is not sharp enough to explain its observed value alone.

title: Saltation under Martian Gravity and its Influence on the Global Dust Distribution
input: Dust and sand motion are a common sight on Mars. Understanding the interaction of atmosphere and Martian soil is fundamental to describe the planet's weather, climate and surface morphology. We set up a wind tunnel to study the lift of a mixture between very fine sand and dust in a Mars simulant soil. The experiments were carried out under Martian gravity in a parabolic flight. The reduced gravity was provided by a centrifuge under external microgravity. The onset of saltation was measured for a fluid threshold shear velocity of 0.82 0.04 m/s. This is considerably lower than found under Earth gravity. In addition to a reduction in weight, this low threshold can be attributed to gravity dependent cohesive forces within the sand bed, which drop by 2/3 under Martian gravity. The new threshold for saltation leads to a simulation of the annual dust cycle with a Mars GCM that is in agreement with observations.

output.explanation:
Mars' environment is characterized by low gravity, which affects the behavior of dust and sand particles. Key terms include 'saltation,' referring to the process where air flow lifts grains from a surface, causing them to bounce or jump along the terrain, and 'cohesive forces,' attractive forces holding particles together within the sand bed. In Martian conditions, cohesive forces decrease when transitioning from Earth's gravity.

Saltation is influenced by airflow and reduced gravity, which affects the behavior of dust and sand particles. The mechanism involves air flow lifting grains from a surface, causing them to bounce or jump along the terrain.

The interaction between atmosphere and soil plays a crucial role in shaping Mars' weather, climate, and surface morphology. Saltation occurs at lower fluid threshold shear velocities on Mars compared to Earth due to reduced gravity-dependent cohesive forces within the sand bed. Specifically, this phenomenon was observed for a fluid threshold shear velocity of 0.82 m/s.

The new understanding of saltation enables accurate simulation of the annual dust cycle using a Mars General Circulation Model (GCM), aligning with observations.

title: H2O MegaMasers: a RadioAstron success story
input: The RadioAstron space-VLBI mission has successfully detected extragalactic H2O MegaMaser emission regions at very long Earth to space baselines ranging between 1.4 and 26.7 Earth Diameters (ED). The preliminary results for two galaxies, NGC3079 and NGC4258, at baselines longer than one ED indicate masering environments and excitation conditions in these galaxies that are distinctly different. Further observations of NGC4258 at longer baselines will reveal more of the physics of individual emission regions.

output.explanation:
The RadioAstron space-VLBI mission has enabled the detection of extragalactic H2O MegaMaser emission regions at very long Earth to space baselines spanning from 1.4 to 26.7 Earth Diameters. This range encompasses a vast physical setting, where astronomical objects are observed in extreme conditions.

The term 'VLBI' refers to Very Long Baseline Interferometry, a technique used to combine the signals of multiple radio telescopes separated by large distances. MegaMaser emission regions are characterized by intense water vapor maser activity, which is thought to be triggered by specific physical processes within galaxies.

To understand these phenomena, it's essential to define key terms: 'masering environment' refers to the conditions under which masers form and operate; 'excitation conditions' describe the physical mechanisms that energize the water vapor molecules responsible for the emission. In this context, distinct differences in masering environments and excitation conditions have been observed between two galaxies, NGC3079 and NGC4258.

The interaction of these galaxies with their surroundings likely plays a crucial role in shaping their masering environments. The varying baseline lengths used by RadioAstron allow for the exploration of different physical regimes within each galaxy. By analyzing observations at longer baselines, researchers can gain insights into the individual emission regions and uncover more about the underlying physics.

title: Dust Coagulation Regulated by Turbulent Clustering in Protoplanetary Disks
input: The coagulation of dust particles is a key process in planetesimal formation. However, the radial drift and bouncing barriers are not completely resolved, especially for silicate dust. Since the collision velocities of dust particles are regulated by turbulence in a protoplanetary disk, the turbulent clustering should be properly treated. To that end, direct numerical simulations (DNSs) of the Navier Stokes equations are requisite. In a series of papers, Pan & Padoan used a DNS with the Reynolds number Re~1000. Here, we perform DNSs with up to Re=16100, which allow us to track the motion of particles with Stokes numbers of 0.01<~St<~0.2 in the inertial range. By the DNSs, we confirm that the rms relative velocity of particle pairs is smaller by more than a factor of two, compared to those by Ormel & Cuzzi (2007). The distributions of the radial relative velocities are highly non-Gaussian. The results are almost consistent with those by Pan & Padoan or Pan et al. at low-Re. Also, we find that the sticking rates for equal-sized particles are much higher than those for different-sized particles. Even in the strong-turbulence case with alpha-viscosity of 10^{-2}, the sticking rates are as high as >~50% and the bouncing probabilities are as low as ~10% for equal-sized particles of St<~0.01. Thus, the turbulent clustering plays a significant role for the growth of cm-sized compact aggregates (pebbles) and also enhances the solid abundance, which may lead to the streaming instability in a disk.

output.explanation:
The formation of planets in protoplanetary disks is a complex process involving the coagulation of dust particles.

Key terms include Stokes number St, which measures particle inertia relative to fluid flow; Reynolds number Re, characterizing fluid turbulence intensity; and Navier-Stokes equations describing fluid motion. Direct numerical simulations (DNSs) are essential for understanding how these systems behave under different conditions.

Turbulent clustering plays a crucial role in regulating collision velocities between dust particles, which is driven by the interaction of fluid flow with particle motion. This process determines how particles interact and grow into larger aggregates called planetesimals. The reduced relative velocities between particles compared to previous estimates are attributed to this mechanism.

The distributions of radial relative velocities exhibit non-Gaussian behavior, consistent with earlier studies at lower Re values. Additionally, equal-sized particles tend to stick together more frequently than differently sized ones, even in highly turbulent environments where sticking rates can be high and bouncing probabilities low.

title: New universal attractor in nonmininally coupled gravity: Linear inflation
input: Once quantum corrections are taken into account, the strong coupling limit of the -attractor models (in metric gravity) might depart from the usual Starobinsky solution and move into linear inflation. Furthermore, it is well known that the metric and Palatini formulations of gravity lead to different inflationary predictions in presence of non-minimally couplings between gravity and the inflaton. In this letter we show that for a certain class of non-minimally coupled models, loop corrections will lead to a linear inflation attractor regardless of the adopted gravity formulation.

output.explanation:
The universe's early stages are characterized by rapid expansion, a phenomenon known as inflation.

Inflationary models rely on the concept of an inflaton field, which drives cosmic growth. Key terms include -attractor models and non-minimal couplings between gravity and the inflaton. Non-minimally coupled models describe scenarios where gravity interacts with the inflaton in ways that deviate from standard gravitational behavior.

The mechanism driving inflation involves complex interactions between gravity and matter fields, specifically the inflaton field. Loop corrections arising from quantum fluctuations within non-minimally coupled models can significantly impact predictions, potentially leading to a linear inflation attractor.

In this context, -attractor models exhibit a unique property: regardless of whether metric or Palatini gravity formulations are employed, loop corrections will lead to a linear inflation attractor. This result holds for certain classes of non-minimally coupled models.

title: Gamma-ray spectral modulations of Galactic pulsars caused by photon-ALPs mixing
input: Well-motivated extensions of the standard model predict ultra-light and fundamental pseudo-scalar particles (e.g., axions or axion-like particles: ALPs). Similarly to the Primakoff-effect for axions, ALPs can mix with photons and consequently be searched for in laboratory experiments and with astrophysical observations. Here, we search for energy-dependent modulations of high-energy gamma-ray spectra that are tell-tale signatures of photon-ALPs mixing. To this end, we analyze the data recorded with the Fermi -LAT from Galactic pulsars selected to have a line of sight crossing spiral arms at a large pitch angle. The large-scale Galactic magnetic field traces the shape of spiral arms, such that a sizable photon-ALP conversion probability is expected for the sources considered. In nine years of Fermi -LAT data, we detect significant spectral features in the selected source-sample consistent with photon-ALPs oscillation with a combined statistical significance of 5.52 σ . Notably, sources with neighboring lines of sight share similar spectral features. From a common fit to all sources, we determine the most-likely parameters for mass and coupling to be neV and GeV . In the error budget, we consider instrumental effects, scaling of the adopted Galactic magnetic field model ( ), and uncertainties on the distance of individual sources. We note that an astrophysical interpretation of the detected modulation is not obvious.

output.explanation:
The universe's magnetic fields play a crucial role in shaping the structure of galaxies, including our own Milky Way.

A key concept in this research is the Primakoff effect, which refers to the interaction between a nucleus and a virtual photon that can produce axions or axion-like particles (ALPs). ALPs are hypothetical particles with properties similar to those predicted for axions. In the context of this study, they are expected to mix with photons.

The large-scale Galactic magnetic field plays a crucial role in facilitating this mixing process by tracing the shape of spiral arms. This allows researchers to analyze data from pulsars located near these regions and search for energy-dependent modulations in high-energy gamma-ray spectra that could be indicative of photon-ALP oscillations.

Researchers have detected significant spectral features consistent with photon-ALPs oscillation, suggesting a mass of approximately neV and a coupling strength of GeV . However, the error budget includes instrumental effects, uncertainties on source distances, and scaling of the adopted Galactic magnetic field model. Further investigation is needed to confirm these results.

title: The dynamical connection between Phaethon and Pallas
input: Phaethon (3200) is an active Near Earth Asteroid classified as a B-type object and a suspected former member of the Pallas family. In this article, we search for sources of Phaethon-like orbits originating from the two strongest resonances in the region of the Pallas family; namely, the 5:2 and 8:3 mean motion resonances with Jupiter, located at AU and AU, respectively. The probability for this dynamical connection observed in was close to per cent. Using sophisticated numerical methods, we found a highly efficient dynamical flow between Pallas and Phaethon. As many as per cent of test particles placed in the 5:2 resonance were able to reach the orbit of Phaethon; whereas, for the 8:3 resonance, this percentage was per cent.

output.explanation:
The solar system's outer region is characterized by complex gravitational interactions between celestial bodies, including asteroids and planets like Jupiter.

A key concept in understanding these dynamics is a mean motion resonance, where the gravitational pull of one body causes another to oscillate due to their synchronized orbital periods. In this context, a B-type object known as Phaethon (3200) has been identified as an active Near Earth Asteroid with its orbit potentially linked to that of Pallas through gravitational interactions.

Phenomena like mean motion resonances can be described using terms such as 'B-type object', referring to the asteroid's composition and spectral characteristics, and 'mean motion resonance', describing the synchronized orbital periods between celestial bodies. Additionally, a Near Earth Asteroid (NEA) is an asteroid whose orbit brings it relatively close to the Sun.

The 5:2 and 8:3 mean motion resonances with Jupiter are crucial in understanding Phaethon's dynamics, as they create zones where test particles can be trapped or escape. The results indicate that nearly a significant percentage of test particles in these resonance zones were able to reach Phaethon's orbit.

title: A better communicator is always a better scientist, or the reason why every PhD student should engage in science outreach
input: The ability to communicate with all audiences is a skill that is rapidly becoming a must-have for any future scientist. As more physicists engage in communicating science to non-expert audiences, research shows that this experience helps them to get a better understanding of their own research and the impact on society, improves the perception of science by lay audiences and can also become an area of personal growth as a citizen. A recent deployment of a PhD student to the Amundsen Scott South Pole Station, as part of the IceCube Collaboration, provided a ready opportunity to spark interest. We present results of the efforts made by the Université libre de Bruxelles (ULB), the Vrije Universiteit Brussel (VUB) and the Interuniversity Institute for High Energies, IIHE (ULB-VUB), to introduce Belgian students and citizens to science and the life of a scientist. The essential parts of this program will be identified to show why the contributions of a PhD student to the organization of these activities are beneficial to the development of new skills as a scientist, but also to broaden the audiences and the impact of the local university and/or the specific research outreach program.

output.explanation:
Scientific communication is a vital skill for future scientists to possess, enabling them to effectively convey their research to diverse audiences. This ability not only enhances the scientist's understanding of their work but also fosters a positive perception of science among non-experts. 

The IceCube Collaboration at the Amundsen Scott South Pole Station provided an ideal opportunity to engage students and citizens in scientific activities. The Université libre de Bruxelles (ULB), Vrije Universiteit Brussel (VUB), and Interuniversity Institute for High Energies, IIHE (ULB-VUB) collaborated to introduce Belgian students and citizens to science through outreach programs. 

The key terms in this context include 'outreach program,' which refers to initiatives that promote scientific awareness among the general public, and 'impact,' denoting the influence of these efforts on society. Additionally, 'personal growth' alludes to the benefits scientists experience when engaging with diverse audiences. 

In this scenario, a PhD student's contributions to organizing outreach activities are crucial in developing essential skills for effective scientific communication. By participating in such programs, students can broaden their audience reach and enhance the visibility of local universities or research institutions.

title: Refinement of Parameters of Six Selected Galactic Potential Models
input: This paper is devoted to the refinement of the parameters of the six three-component (bulge, disk, halo) axisymmetric Galactic gravitational potential models on the basis of modern data on circular velocities of Galactic objects located at distances up to 200 kpc from the Galactic center. In all models the bulge and disk are described by the Miyamoto--Nagai expressions. To describe the halo, the models of Allen-Santillán (I), Wilkinson-Evans (II), Navarro-Frenk-White (III), Binney (IV), Plummer (V), and Hernquist (VI) are used. The sought-for parameters of potential models are determined by fitting the model rotation curves to the measured velocities, taking into account restrictions on the local dynamical matter density pc and the vertical force pc . A comparative analysis of the refined potential models is made and for each of the models the estimates of a number of the Galactic characteristics are presented.

output.explanation:
The Galaxy is modeled as a three-component system consisting of a bulge, disk, and halo. The bulge and disk are described by the Miyamoto-Nagai expressions, which define their spatial distributions.

The halo's structure varies across six different models: Allen-Santillán, Wilkinson-Evans, Navarro-Frenk-White, Binney, Plummer, and Hernquist. These models differ in how they describe the halo's density distribution.

The key terms here are axisymmetric gravitational potential models, which describe the Galaxy's mass distribution, and Miyamoto-Nagai expressions, a mathematical representation of the bulge and disk's spatial distributions. Axisymmetry implies rotational symmetry around a central axis. The Miyamoto-Nagai expression is a parametric equation that describes the density profile of the bulge and disk.

The Galaxy's potential models are refined by fitting them to measured circular velocities at distances up to 200 kpc from the center, while considering constraints on local dynamical matter density and vertical force.

title: Marked clustering statistics in gravity cosmologies
input: We analyse the two-point and marked correlation functions of haloes and galaxies in three variants of the chameleon gravity model using N-body simulations, and compare to a fiducial CDM model based on general relativity (GR). Using a halo occupation distribution prescription (HOD) we populate dark matter haloes with galaxies, where the HOD parameters have been tuned such that the galaxy number densities and the real-space galaxy two-point correlation functions in the modified gravity models match those in GR to within . We test the idea that since the behaviour of gravity is dependent on environment, marked correlation functions may display a measurable difference between the models. For this we test marks based on the density field and the Newtonian gravitational potential. We find that the galaxy marked correlation function shows significant differences measured in different models on scales smaller than Mpc. Guided by simulations to identify a suitable mark, this approach could be used as a new probe of the accelerated expansion of the Universe.

output.explanation:
The universe's large-scale structure is shaped by gravitational forces, which can be described using general relativity or alternative theories like chameleon gravity.

Key terms in this scenario include halo occupation distribution (HOD), a prescription that populates dark matter haloes with galaxies based on specific parameters. Dark matter refers to an invisible form of matter that makes up a significant portion of the universe's mass-energy density, while HOD parameters have been fine-tuned to match galaxy number densities and real-space correlation functions between chameleon gravity models and general relativity.

The gravitational force's dependence on environment is a crucial aspect of chameleon gravity. This theory proposes that gravity behaves differently in various environments, leading to differences in the distribution of galaxies within dark matter haloes. Marked correlation functions are used to study this distribution by identifying specific properties such as density or Newtonian potential.

The analysis reveals significant discrepancies in galaxy marked correlation functions on scales smaller than Mpc, indicating a potential new probe for understanding the universe's accelerated expansion and suggesting that environment-dependent gravity could be tested using these correlations.

title: Cosmic ray production in supernovae
input: We give a brief review of the origin and acceleration of cosmic rays (CRs), emphasizing the production of CRs at different stages of supernova evolution by the first-order Fermi shock acceleration mechanism. We suggest that supernovae with trans-relativistic outflows, despite being rather rare, may accelerate CRs to energies above 10 eV over the first year of their evolution. Supernovae in young compact clusters of massive stars, and interaction powered superluminous supernovae, may accelerate CRs well above the PeV regime. We discuss the acceleration of the bulk of the galactic CRs in isolated supernova remnants and re-acceleration of escaped CRs by the multiple shocks present in superbubbles produced by associations of OB stars. The effects of magnetic field amplification by CR driven instabilities, as well as superdiffusive CR transport, are discussed for nonthermal radiation produced by nonlinear shocks of all speeds including trans-relativistic ones.

output.explanation:
The universe is home to high-energy phenomena such as supernovae explosions and other energetic events that produce cosmic rays (CRs). Supernova outflows can accelerate charged particles through the first-order Fermi shock acceleration mechanism, which involves repeated collisions between charged particles and magnetic fields causing them to gain energy. Key terms include: trans-relativistic outflows, referring to extremely fast-moving supernovae; PeV regime, a scale of energy above 10 eV; superbubbles are large structures formed by the interaction of multiple stars.

Fermi shock acceleration relies on the transfer of energy from supernova outflows to CRs through repeated collisions with magnetic fields. This process can occur in various environments, including young compact clusters of massive stars and interaction-powered superluminous supernovae. Magnetic field amplification due to CR-driven instabilities plays a crucial role.

The acceleration of galactic CRs occurs through multiple shocks present in superbubbles produced by associations of OB stars. These structures play a key role in accelerating the bulk of galactic CRs, while supernovae with trans-relativistic outflows may produce CRs above 10 eV within a year of their evolution.

The effects of magnetic field amplification and superdiffusive transport on nonthermal radiation from nonlinear shocks across all speeds are discussed. This includes acceleration to energies exceeding PeV scales in certain types of supernovae.

title: Thermal desorption of formamide and methylamine from graphite and amorphous water ice surfaces
input: Formamide (NH2CHO) and methylamine (CH3NH2) are known to be the most abundant amine-containing molecules in many astrophysical environments. The presence of these molecules in the gas phase may result from thermal desorption of interstellar ices. The aim of this work is to determine the values of the desorption energies of formamide and methylamine from analogues of interstellar dust grain surfaces and to understand their interaction with water ice. TPD experiments of formamide and methylamine ices were performed in the submonolayer and monolayer regimes on graphite (HOPG) and non-porous amorphous solid water ice surfaces at 40-240 K. The desorption energy distributions of these two molecules were calculated from TPD measurements using a set of independent Polanyi-Wigner equations. The maximum of the desorption of formamide from both graphite and ASW ice surfaces occurs at 176 K after the desorption of H2O molecules, whereas the desorption profile of methylamine depends strongly on the substrate. Solid methylamine starts to desorb below 100 K from the graphite surface. Its desorption from the water ice surface occurs after 120 K and stops during the water ice sublimation around 150 K. It continues to desorb from the graphite surface at temperatures higher than 160 K. More than 95 % of NH2CHO diffuses through the water ice surface towards the graphitic substrate and is released into the gas phase with a desorption energy distribution (7460-9380 K), which is measured with the best-fit pre-exponential factor A=10^18 s-1. However, the desorption energy distribution of methylamine from the np-ASW ice surface (3850-8420 K) is measured with the best-fit pre-exponential factor A=10^12 s-1. A fraction of solid methylamine monolayer of roughly 0.15 diffuses through the water ice surface towards the HOPG substrate. This small amount desorbs later with higher binding energies (5050-8420 K).

output.explanation:
Astrophysical environments are characterized by the presence of various molecules, including amine-containing compounds like formamide and methylamine. These molecules can be found in many astrophysical settings.

Key terms to understand this phenomenon include thermal desorption, which refers to the process where molecules escape from a surface due to increased temperature; Polanyi-Wigner equations, used to calculate the probability of molecular desorption based on energy barriers; and pre-exponential factors, describing the frequency of molecular collisions. Thermal desorption is often associated with interstellar ices.

The interaction between formamide, methylamine, and water ice plays a crucial role in their release into the gas phase. The process involves the diffusion of these molecules through water ice towards dust grain surfaces. This phenomenon can be influenced by various factors, including temperature and substrate properties.

Formamide desorbs at 176 K after water ice sublimation from both graphite and ASW ice surfaces. Methylamine's desorption profile varies depending on the substrate, with solid methylamine starting to desorb below 100 K from graphite but only after 120 K from ASW ice. More than a certain percentage of formamide diffuses through water ice and is released into the gas phase with a specific energy distribution.

title: A new relativistic component of the accretion disk wind in PDS 456
input: Past X-ray observations of the nearby luminous quasar PDS 456 (at ) have revealed a wide angle accretion disk wind (Nardini et al. 2015), with an outflow velocity of . Here we unveil a new, relativistic component of the wind through hard X-ray observations with NuSTAR and XMM-Newton, obtained in March 2017 when the quasar was in a low flux state. This very fast wind component, with an outflow velocity of , is detected in the iron K band, in addition to the wind zone. The relativistic component may arise from the innermost disk wind, launched from close to the black hole at radius of gravitational radii. The opacity of the fast wind also increases during a possible obscuration event lasting for 50 ks. We suggest that the very fast wind may only be apparent during the lowest X-ray flux states of PDS 456, becoming overly ionized as the luminosity increases. Overall, the total wind power may even approach the Eddington value.

output.explanation:
Active galactic nuclei, like PDS 456, are characterized by supermassive black holes surrounded by accretion disks and outflows. 

The term 'accretion disk wind' refers to a flow of hot gas ejected from the vicinity of the black hole into the surrounding interstellar medium. The relativistic component is described as phenomena occurring at speeds approaching or exceeding light speed, in this context referring to the very fast component of the outflow. 

The interaction between the hot gas and strong gravitational field near the black hole drives the accretion disk wind mechanism. The innermost part of the disk launches a relativistic wind detectable in hard X-rays, potentially arising from close to the event horizon at radii measured in units of gravitational radii. 

The very fast component has an outflow velocity and is only apparent during low flux states of PDS 456, with total wind power possibly approaching the Eddington value.

title: Antarctic Surface Reflectivity Calculations and Measurements from the ANITA-4 and HiCal-2 Experiments
input: The balloon-borne HiCal radio-frequency (RF) transmitter, in concert with the ANITA radio-frequency receiver array, is designed to measure the Antarctic surface reflectivity in the RF wavelength regime. The amplitude of surface-reflected transmissions from HiCal, registered as triggered events by ANITA, can be compared with the direct transmissions preceding them by O(10) microseconds, to infer the surface power reflection coefficient . The first HiCal mission (HiCal-1, Jan. 2015) yielded a sample of 100 such pairs, resulting in estimates of at highly-glancing angles (i.e., zenith angles approaching ), with measured reflectivity for those events which exceeded extant calculations. The HiCal-2 experiment, flying from Dec., 2016-Jan., 2017, provided an improvement by nearly two orders of magnitude in our event statistics, allowing a considerably more precise mapping of the reflectivity over a wider range of incidence angles. We find general agreement between the HiCal-2 reflectivity results and those obtained with the earlier HiCal-1 mission, as well as estimates from Solar reflections in the radio-frequency regime. In parallel, our calculations of expected reflectivity have matured; herein, we use a plane-wave expansion to estimate the reflectivity R from both a flat, smooth surface (and, in so doing, recover the Fresnel reflectivity equations) and also a curved surface. Multiplying our flat-smooth reflectivity by improved Earth curvature and surface roughness corrections now provides significantly better agreement between theory and the HiCal 2a/2b measurements.

output.explanation:
The Antarctic surface plays a crucial role in radio-frequency (RF) propagation, acting as a vast reflector of RF waves. The Earth's surface is dynamic and complex, with various mechanisms influencing the interaction between incoming RF radiation and the surface.

Incidence angle refers to the angle at which incoming RF radiation hits the surface, while power reflection coefficient represents the ratio of reflected to incident energy. These terms are essential in understanding radio-frequency reflectivity.

The amplitude of surface-reflected transmissions can be compared with direct transmissions to infer this coefficient. In reality, surfaces are curved and rough, introducing corrections necessary for accurate calculations. The HiCal-2 experiment provided significantly more precise measurements than its predecessor, allowing for a detailed mapping of reflectivity over various incidence angles.

Calculations using plane-wave expansions have been refined to account for both flat-smooth and curved surfaces. By incorporating improved curvature and surface roughness corrections into these estimates, the agreement between theory and HiCal 2a/2b measurements has substantially increased.

title: Iterative map-making with two-level preconditioning for polarized Cosmic Microwave Background data sets
input: An estimation of the sky signal from streams of Time Ordered Data (TOD) acquired by Cosmic Microwave Background ( ) experiments is one of the most important steps in the context of data analysis referred to as the map-making problem. The continuously growing data sets render the map-making problem more challenging in terms of computational cost and memory in particular in the context of ground based experiments. In this context, we study a novel class of the Preconditioned Conjugate Gradient (PCG) solvers which invoke two-level preconditioners. We compare them against PCG solvers commonly used in the map-making context considering their precision and time-to-solution. We compare these new methods on realistic, simulated data sets reflecting the characteristics of current and forthcoming ground-based experiment. We develop an embarrassingly parallel implementation of the approach where each processor performs a sequential map-making for a subset of the TOD. We find that considering the map level residuals the new class of solvers permits achieving tolerance of up to 3 orders of magnitude better than the standard approach, where the residual level often saturates before convergence is reached. This corresponds to an important improvement in the precision of recovered power spectra in particular on the largest angular scales. The new method also typically requires fewer iterations to reach a required precision and thus shorter runtimes for a single map-making solution. However, the construction of an appropriate two-level preconditioner can be as costly as a single standard map-making run. Nevertheless, if the same problem needs to be solved multiple times, e.g., as in Monte Carlo simulations, this cost has to be incurred only once, and the method should be competitive not only as far as its precision but also its performance is concerned.

output.explanation:
The analysis of Cosmic Microwave Background data involves creating maps from Time Ordered Data, a task that is becoming increasingly challenging due to the growing size of these datasets.

Time Ordered Data refers to ordered sequences of time-stamped measurements, while Preconditioned Conjugate Gradient solvers are algorithms used for efficient map-making. Two-level preconditioners are a type of optimization technique employed by PCG solvers to improve their performance.

The new class of two-level preconditioner-based PCG solvers works by leveraging the properties of these optimizers to reduce computational costs and memory requirements. This is achieved through an embarrassingly parallel implementation, where each processor handles a subset of the Time Ordered Data in sequence.

Considering map level residuals, this novel approach permits achieving tolerance up to 3 orders of magnitude better than traditional methods, leading to improved precision in recovered power spectra on large angular scales. Additionally, it requires fewer iterations and shorter runtimes for single map-making solutions.

title: Precision mass measurements on neutron-rich rare-earth isotopes at JYFLTRAP - reduced neutron pairing and implications for the -process calculations
input: The rare-earth peak in the -process abundance pattern depends sensitively on both the astrophysical conditions and subtle changes in nuclear structure in the region. This work takes an important step elucidating the nuclear structure and reducing the uncertainties in -process calculations via precise atomic mass measurements at the JYFLTRAP double Penning trap. Nd, Pm, Sm, and Gd have been measured for the first time and the precisions for Nd, Pm, Eu, Gd, and Tb have been improved considerably. Nuclear structure has been probed via two-neutron separation energies and neutron pairing energy metrics . The data do not support the existence of a subshell closure at . Neutron pairing has been found to be weaker than predicted by theoretical mass models. The impact on the calculated -process abundances has been studied. Substantial changes resulting in a smoother abundance distribution and a better agreement with the solar -process abundances are observed.

output.explanation:
The universe's rare-earth peak is formed through astrophysical processes and nuclear reactions within a specific region of the cosmos. Key to understanding these processes are atomic masses, which can be measured with high precision using instruments like the JYFLTRAP double Penning trap.

Two-neutron separation energies and neutron pairing energy metrics are essential indicators of nuclear structure. A subshell closure is a theoretical concept where certain nucleons occupy specific energy levels; however, data suggest that this phenomenon does not occur at .

Neutron pairing refers to the interaction between neutrons in an atomic nucleus, which affects its stability. Theoretical models predict stronger neutron pairing than observed in experimental measurements.

The precise measurement of atomic masses has a significant impact on calculated -process abundances. Substantial changes have been made to these calculations, resulting in a smoother abundance distribution and improved agreement with solar rare-earth process abundances.

title: -Process Nucleosynthesis from Three-dimensional Jet-driven Core-Collapse Supernovae with Magnetic Misalignments
input: We investigate -process nucleosynthesis in three-dimensional general relativistic magnetohydrodynamic simulations of jet-driven supernovae resulting from rapidly rotating, strongly magnetized core-collapse. We explore the effect of misaligning the pre-collapse magnetic field with respect to the rotation axis by performing four simulations: one aligned model and models with 15, 30, and 45 degree misalignments. The simulations we present employ a microphysical finite-temperature equation of state and a leakage scheme that captures the overall energetics and lepton number exchange due to post-bounce neutrino emission and absorption. We track the thermodynamic properties of the ejected material with Lagrangian tracer particles and analyse its composition with the nuclear reaction network SkyNet. By using different neutrino luminosities in post-processing the tracer data with SkyNet, we constrain the impact of uncertainties in neutrino luminosities. We find that, for the aligned model considered here, the use of an approximate leakage scheme results in neutrino luminosity uncertainties corresponding to a factor of 100-1000 uncertainty in the abundance of third peak -process elements. Our results show that for misalignments of 30 degrees or less, -process elements are robustly produced as long as neutrino luminosities are reasonably low ( erg s ). For a more extreme misalignment of 45 degrees, we find the production of -process elements beyond the second peak significantly reduced. We conclude that robust -process nucleosynthesis in magnetorotational supernovae requires a progenitor stellar core with a large poloidal magnetic field component that is at least moderately (within degrees) aligned with the rotation axis.

output.explanation:
Core-collapse supernovae involve the catastrophic implosion of massive stars, releasing enormous amounts of energy and expelling material at relativistic speeds.

Key terms include magnetohydrodynamics (MHD), which describes fluid motion interacting with magnetic forces; a microphysical finite-temperature equation of state, used to model thermodynamic properties; and Lagrangian tracer particles, employed to track the ejected material's composition. Additionally, -process nucleosynthesis refers to nuclear reactions forming certain elements within these materials.

In magnetorotational supernovae, misalignments between pre-collapse magnetic fields and rotational axes can significantly impact MHD simulations. The interaction between fluid motion and magnetic forces affects neutrino emission and absorption patterns, influencing the efficiency of -process nucleosynthesis. Misalignment alters the balance between these processes, leading to variations in element production.

Robust production of third peak -process elements requires reasonably low neutrino luminosities ( erg s ), particularly for aligned models with moderate misalignments (30 degrees or less). In contrast, extreme misalignments can significantly reduce the production of elements beyond the second peak.

title: Improving Weak Lensing Mass Map Reconstructions using Gaussian and Sparsity Priors: Application to DES SV
