input: Mapping the underlying density field, including non-visible dark matter, using weak gravitational lensing measurements is now a standard tool in cosmology. Due to its importance to the science results of current and upcoming surveys, the quality of the convergence reconstruction methods should be well understood. We compare three methods: Kaiser-Squires (KS), Wiener filter, and GLIMPSE. KS is a direct inversion, not accounting for survey masks or noise. The Wiener filter is well-motivated for Gaussian density fields in a Bayesian framework. GLIMPSE uses sparsity, aiming to reconstruct non-linearities in the density field. We compare these methods with several tests using public Dark Energy Survey (DES) Science Verification (SV) data and realistic DES simulations. The Wiener filter and GLIMPSE offer substantial improvements over smoothed KS with a range of metrics. Both the Wiener filter and GLIMPSE convergence reconstructions show a 12 per cent improvement in Pearson correlation with the underlying truth from simulations. To compare the mapping methods' abilities to find mass peaks, we measure the difference between peak counts from simulated ΛCDM shear catalogues and catalogues with no mass fluctuations (a standard data vector when inferring cosmology from peak statistics); the maximum signal-to-noise of these peak statistics is increased by a factor of 3.5 for the Wiener filter and 9 for GLIMPSE. With simulations we measure the reconstruction of the harmonic phases; the phase residuals' concentration is improved 17 per cent by GLIMPSE and 18 per cent by the Wiener filter. The correlation between reconstructions from data and foreground redMaPPer clusters is increased 18 per cent by the Wiener filter and 32 per cent by GLIMPSE.

output.explanation:
Cosmology relies on understanding the underlying density field, including dark matter, which is invisible to direct observation.

The density field can be inferred from weak gravitational lensing measurements, a technique used in current and upcoming surveys. This information is crucial for accurate science results.

Key terms include convergence reconstruction methods, such as Kaiser-Squires (KS), Wiener filter, and GLIMPSE. Convergence refers to the rate of change of density field values over space. A direct inversion method like KS does not account for survey masks or noise. In contrast, a Bayesian framework motivates the use of a Wiener filter for Gaussian density fields.

The mechanism behind these methods involves comparing different techniques using public data and simulations. The Wiener filter and GLIMPSE offer substantial improvements over smoothed KS with various metrics. Both the Wiener filter and GLIMPSE convergence reconstructions show improved Pearson correlation with the underlying truth from simulations, as well as increased signal-to-noise for peak statistics and harmonic phase reconstruction.

title: Expected Precision of Europa Clipper Gravity Measurements
input: The primary gravity science objective of NASA's Clipper mission to Europa is to confirm the presence or absence of a global subsurface ocean beneath Europa's Icy crust. Gravity field measurements obtained with a radio science investigation can reveal much about Europa's interior structure. Here, we conduct extensive simulations of the radio science measurements with the anticipated spacecraft trajectory and attitude (17F12v2) and assets on the spacecraft and the ground, including antenna orientations and beam patterns, transmitter characteristics, and receiver noise figures. In addition to two-way Doppler measurements, we also include radar altimeter crossover range measurements. We concentrate on +/-2 hour intervals centered on the closest approach of each of the 46 flybys. Our covariance analyses reveal the precision with which the tidal Love number k2, second-degree gravity coefficients C20 and C22, and higher-order gravity coefficients can be determined. The results depend on the Deep Space Network (DSN) assets that are deployed to track the spacecraft. We find that some DSN allocations are sufficient to conclusively confirm the presence or absence of a global ocean. Given adequate crossover range performance, it is also possible to evaluate whether the ice shell is hydrostatic.

output.explanation:
The icy crust of Europa, a moon orbiting Jupiter, is thought to cover a global subsurface ocean. The tidal Love number k2 and gravity coefficients C20 and C22 are key parameters in understanding the interior structure of this celestial body.

Tidal Love number refers to the deformation of an object under tidal forces, while gravity coefficients describe how mass is distributed within that object. Gravity field measurements can reveal much about Europa's internal composition.

The radio science investigation involves analyzing data from two-way Doppler measurements and radar altimeter crossover range measurements. These datasets are used in covariance analyses to determine the precision with which various parameters can be determined, including tidal Love number k2 and gravity coefficients C20 and C22.

Covariance analysis reveals that certain Deep Space Network allocations enable high-precision determination of these parameters. Specifically, some DSN assets allow for conclusive confirmation or ruling out a global ocean beneath Europa's icy crust.

title: A deeper look at the GD1 stream: density variations and wiggles
input: Using deep photometric data from CFHT/Megacam, we study the morphology and density of the GD-1 stream, one of the longest and coldest stellar streams in the Milky Way. Our deep data recovers the lower main sequence of the stream with unprecedented quality, clearly separating it from Milky Way foreground and background stars. An analysis of the distance to different parts of the stream shows that GD-1 lies at a heliocentric distance between 8 and 10 kpc, with only a shallow gradient across 45 deg on the sky. Matched filter maps of the stream density show clear density variations, such as deviations from a single orbital track and tentative evidence for stream fanning. We also detect a clear under-density in the middle of the stream track at =-45 deg surrounded by overdense stream segments on either side. This location is a promising candidate for the elusive missing progenitor of the GD-1 stream. We conclude that the GD-1 stream has clearly been disturbed by interactions with the Milky Way disk or other sub-halos.

output.explanation:
The Milky Way's disk and halo are home to various stellar streams, including the GD-1 stream, a long and cold filament of stars.

In astrophysics, heliocentric distance refers to the distance between Earth and a celestial object, while matched filter maps are used to analyze density variations in streams. The term 'stream fanning' describes the phenomenon where a stellar stream appears to fan out or spread apart due to gravitational interactions with its surroundings.

The processes described here involve complex gravitational dynamics, where the GD-1 stream interacts with the Milky Way disk and other sub-halos. This interaction causes density fluctuations along the stream's track, including clear under-densities surrounded by overdense segments on either side.

The data indicates that the GD-1 stream has been disturbed by interactions with the Milky Way disk or other sub-halos, resulting in a notable under-density at -45 degrees. This location may hold clues to the missing progenitor of the GD-1 stream.

title: Characterization of Exoplanet Atmospheres with the Optical Coronagraph on WFIRST
input: WFIRST-CGI is a NASA technology demonstration mission that is charged with demonstrating key technologies for future exo-Earth imaging missions in space. In the process, it will obtain images and low-resolution spectra of a handful to a dozen extrasolar planets and possibly protoplanetary disks. Its unprecedented contrast levels in the optical will provide astronomers with their first direct look at mature, Jupiter sized planets at moderate separations. This paper addresses the question: what science can be done with such data? An analytic noise model, which is informed by the ongoing engineering developments, is used to compute maximum achievable signal-to-noise ratios and scientifically viable integration times for hypothetical star planet systems, as well as to investigate the constraining power of various combinations of WFIRST-CGI photometric and spectral observations. This work introduces two simple models for planetary geometric albedos, which are inspired largely by the solar system's gas giants. The first planet model is a hybrid Jupiter-Neptune model, which separately treats the short and long wavelengths where chromophores and methane dominate absorption, respectively. The second planet model fixes cloud and haze properties in CoolTLusty to match Jupiter's albedo spectrum, it then perturbs only the metallicity. MCMC retrievals performed on simulated observations are used to assess the precision with which planet model parameters can be measured subject to different exposure times and observing cases. Fit results for both models' parameterizations of geometric albedo spectra demonstrate that a rough indication of the metallicity or methane content should be possible for some WFIRST-CGI targets. We conclude that real observations will likely be able to differentiate between extreme cases using these models, but will lack the precision necessary to uncover subtle trends.

output.explanation:
The study of exoplanets in the optical regime is a complex task, requiring precise measurements to distinguish between different planetary properties within star-planet systems.

A key concept in this context is 'geometric albedo', which refers to the fraction of incident light that is reflected by a planet's surface or atmosphere. Geometric albedo can be thought of as analogous to an object's reflectivity, with higher values indicating more efficient reflection of incoming light.

The interaction between starlight and planetary atmospheres involves complex processes such as absorption and scattering. In the case of mature Jupiter-sized planets at moderate separations from their host stars, these interactions determine the observed optical properties of the planet.

Using analytic noise models informed by ongoing engineering developments, researchers have computed maximum achievable signal-to-noise ratios for hypothetical star-planet systems. This work also investigates the constraining power of various combinations of WFIRST-CGI photometric and spectral observations on planetary parameters such as metallicity or methane content.

title: Geoscience and the Search for Life Beyond the Solar System
input: How can scientists conclude with high confidence that an exoplanet hosts life? As telescopes come on line over the next 20 years that can directly observe photons from terrestrial exoplanets, this question will dictate the activities of many scientists across many fields. The expected data will be sparse and with low signal-to-noise, which will make disentangling biosignatures from abiotic features challenging. Our Earth is not just unique in that it hosts life, it is also the only terrestrial planet with direct observations of its interior through seismic waves, and compositional evolution through field and laboratory measurements. This extensive research reveals a planet born from collisions between worlds, followed by a complicated biogeochemical evolution. Exoplanet interiors, on the other hand, can only be constrained by the following observations: 1) photometric and spectroscopic analysis of the planet's atmosphere, 2) spectroscopic and photometric analysis of the host star, and 3) companion planet properties. From these (future) data, astrobiologists must generate plausible compositional and evolutionary models that constrain a potentially habitable exoplanet's internal properties and history, provide environmental context, and rule out geochemical explanations for any putative biosignatures. The goal of this white paper is to frame the role of geophysical and geochemical processes relevant to the search for life beyond the Solar System and to identify critical, but understudied, areas of future research.

output.explanation:
The search for life beyond our Solar System is set against the backdrop of a vast, star-filled universe where planets are born from collisions between worlds. 

 In this context, key terms like 'biogeochemical evolution' refer to complex interactions between living organisms and their environment, while 'compositional models' describe internal properties based on available data. These models rely heavily on photometric and spectroscopic analysis of a planet's atmosphere and its host star, as well as companion planet properties. 

 The mechanism behind this process involves generating plausible compositional and evolutionary models that constrain a potentially habitable exoplanet's internal properties and history while providing environmental context to rule out geochemical explanations for any putative biosignatures. This requires considering the sparse and low signal-to-noise nature of expected data, which makes it challenging to disentangle biosignatures from abiotic features. 

 The search for life beyond our Solar System is further complicated by the fact that exoplanet interiors can only be constrained through indirect observations, whereas Earth's interior has been directly observed through seismic waves and compositional evolution.

title: Polarized Beam Patterns from a Multi-Moded Feed For Observations of the Cosmic Microwave Background
input: We measure linearly polarized beam patterns for a multi-moded concentrator and compare the results to a simple model based on geometric optics. We convolve the measured co-polar and cross-polar beams with simulated maps of CMB polarization to estimate the amplitude of the systematic error resulting from the cross-polar beam response. The un-corrected error signal has typical amplitude of 3 nK, corresponding to inflationary B-mode amplitude r ~ 10^{-3}. Convolving the measured cross-polar beam pattern with maps of the CMB E-mode polarization provides a template for correcting the cross-polar response, reducing it to negligible levels.

output.explanation:
The universe's early stages are encoded in the polarization of cosmic microwave background (CMB) radiation, a remnant from the Big Bang. CMB polarization is characterized by E-mode and B-mode patterns, with the latter being a signature of primordial gravitational waves generated during inflation.

Polarization refers to the orientation of light waves in space, described as linearly polarized beam patterns when light passes through optical systems like multi-moded concentrators. In geometric optics, these patterns are predicted using simple models based on refraction and reflection principles. Key terms include polarization, co-polar (same orientation), cross-polar (perpendicular orientations), and CMB.

When linearly polarized beam patterns interact with maps of CMB polarization, they can produce systematic errors in measurements due to the cross-polar beam response. This error signal has a typical amplitude corresponding to an inflationary B-mode amplitude r ~ 10^{-3}. The non-relativistic nature and small energy-density fraction contribute to suppressing this effect.

Convolving the measured cross-polar beam pattern with CMB E-mode polarization maps provides a template for correcting these errors, reducing them to negligible levels. This correction is essential in accurately measuring primordial gravitational waves generated during inflation.

title: Testing modified gravity using a marked correlation function
input: In theories of modified gravity with the chameleon screening mechanism, the strength of the fifth force depends on environment. This induces an environment dependence of structure formation, which differs from CDM. We show that these differences can be captured by the marked correlation function. With the galaxy correlation functions and number densities calibrated to match between and CDM models in simulations, we show that the marked correlation functions from using either the local density or halo mass as the marks encode extra information, which can be used to test these theories. We discuss possible applications of these statistics in observations.

output.explanation:
The universe's large-scale structure is shaped by the interplay between gravity and dark matter, but modified gravity theories propose an additional force that can alter this process. This fifth force, mediated by a scalar field called chameleon, varies in strength depending on its environment. As a result, structure formation becomes sensitive to local conditions, deviating from the standard cold dark matter (CDM) scenario.

The term 'chameleon screening mechanism' refers to the phenomenon where this additional force adapts to its surroundings, making it difficult to detect directly. Similarly, 'marked correlation function' is a statistical tool used to quantify patterns in galaxy distributions and distinguish between different models of structure formation.

In modified gravity theories with chameleon screening, the fifth force interacts with dark matter halos, influencing their growth and distribution. This interaction can be described as a competition between the gravitational pull of dark matter and the repulsive force exerted by the scalar field.

The marked correlation functions derived from local density or halo mass encode extra information that can be used to test theories of modified gravity using observational data.

title: The magnetic nature of umbra-penumbra boundary in sunspots
input: Sunspots are the longest-known manifestation of solar activity, and their magnetic nature has been known for more than a century. Despite this, the boundary between umbrae and penumbrae, the two fundamental sunspot regions, has hitherto been solely defined by an intensity threshold. Here, we aim at studying the magnetic nature of umbra-penumbra boundaries in sunspots of different sizes, morphologies, evolutionary stages, and phases of the solar cycle. We used a sample of 88 scans of the Hinode/SOT spectropolarimeter to infer the magnetic field properties in at the umbral boundaries. We defined these umbra-penumbra boundaries by an intensity threshold and performed a statistical analysis of the magnetic field properties on these boundaries. We statistically prove that the umbra-penumbra boundary in stable sunspots is characterised by an invariant value of the vertical magnetic field component: the vertical component of the magnetic field strength does not depend on the umbra size, its morphology, and phase of the solar cycle. With the statistical Bayesian inference, we find that the strength of the vertical magnetic field component is, with a likelihood of 99\%, in the range of 1849-1885 G with the most probable value of 1867 G. In contrast, the magnetic field strength and inclination averaged along individual boundaries are found to be dependent on the umbral size: the larger the umbra, the stronger and more horizontal the magnetic field at its boundary. The umbra and penumbra of sunspots are separated by a boundary that has hitherto been defined by an intensity threshold. We now unveil the empirical law of the magnetic nature of the umbra-penumbra boundary in stable sunspots: it is an invariant vertical component of the magnetic field.

output.explanation:
The Sun's surface is a dynamic environment where intense magnetic fields play a crucial role in shaping its behavior.

Magnetism refers to the phenomenon of magnetic fields, which are generated by moving electric charges. In this context, the term 'vertical' describes a direction perpendicular to the Sun's surface.

At the boundary between umbrae and penumbrae, magnetism influences the orientation of magnetic fields, determining their behavior. The interaction between these magnetic fields is governed by fundamental physical laws that dictate how they respond to changes in their environment.

The study reveals a distinct property of stable sunspots: an invariant vertical component of the magnetic field at the umbra-penumbra boundary. This phenomenon remains constant regardless of the size or morphology of the umbral region, and its strength is found to be within the range of 1849-1885 G with a most probable value of 1867 G.

title: Asteroseismology of KIC 7107778: a binary comprising almost identical subgiants
input: We analyze an asteroseismic binary system: KIC 7107778, a non-eclipsing, unresolved target, with solar-like oscillations in both components. We used short cadence time series spanning nearly two years to obtain the power spectrum. Oscillation mode parameters were determined using Bayesian inference and a nested sampling Monte Carlo algorithm with the package. The power profiles of the two components fully overlap, indicating their close similarity. We modelled the two stars with and calculated oscillation frequencies with . Stellar fundamental parameters (mass, radius and age) were estimated by grid modelling with atmospheric parameters and the oscillation frequencies of modes as constraints. Most mixed modes were identified with models searched using a bisection method. Stellar parameters for the two sub-giant stars are: , , , , Gyr and Gyr. The mass difference of the system is 1\%. The results confirm their simultaneous birth and evolution, as is expected from binary formation. KIC 7107778 comprises almost identical twins, and is the first asteroseismic sub-giant binary to be detected.

output.explanation:
The physical setting for this analysis involves two stars in a binary system, KIC 7107778, which exhibit solar-like oscillations. These oscillations are periodic variations in the star's brightness that can be used to infer its internal structure and composition.

The key terms here include asteroseismology, which is the study of these oscillations to understand stellar interiors, and sub-giant stars, which are a stage in a star's life cycle between main sequence and red giant phases. Asteroseismic analysis relies on precise measurements of oscillation frequencies, which can be used to constrain models of stellar evolution.

The mechanism at play here involves the interaction between the two stars' internal structures, as inferred from their oscillations. The close similarity in power profiles suggests that the two components are nearly identical twins. By modeling these stars and using Bayesian inference with a nested sampling Monte Carlo algorithm, researchers can estimate fundamental parameters such as mass, radius, and age.

The system's behavior is characterized by its simultaneous birth and evolution, which is expected from binary formation processes. The results confirm that KIC 7107778 comprises almost identical twins, making it the first asteroseismic sub-giant binary to be detected.

title: Primordial black holes and associated gravitational waves in axion monodromy inflation
input: In the axion monodromy inflation, the inflation is driven by the axion with super-Planckian field values in a monomial potential with superimposed sinusoidal modulations. The coupling of the axion to massless gauge fields can induce copious particle production during inflation, resulting in large non-Gaussian curvature perturbation that leads to the formation of primordial black holes. In this paper, we explore the parameter space in the axion monodromy inflation model that favors the formation of primordial black holes with masses ranging from grams to solar masses. We also study the associated gravitational waves and their detection in pulsar timing arrays and interferometry experiments.

output.explanation:
The universe's early expansion is driven by an axion field with values far beyond the Planck scale, residing within a potential characterized by a monomial base and sinusoidal modulations. The interaction between this axion and massless gauge fields can give rise to copious particle production during inflation, resulting in large non-Gaussian curvature perturbations that facilitate the formation of primordial black holes with masses spanning from grams to solar masses. 

 To understand these phenomena, it's essential to grasp key concepts: 'monodromy' refers to the periodic nature of the axion potential, while 'super-Planckian field values' signify that the axion's magnitude exceeds the Planck scale. Additionally, non-Gaussian curvature perturbations are a measure of the distribution of matter and energy in the universe during inflation. 

 The interaction between the axion and gauge fields drives particle production through a process known as 'parametric resonance.' This phenomenon occurs when the oscillating field causes nearby particles to become unstable, leading to their decay into other particles. As a result, large non-Gaussian curvature perturbations form, giving rise to primordial black holes with varying masses. 

 The formation of these black holes is accompanied by the generation of gravitational waves, which can be detected through experiments such as pulsar timing arrays and interferometry.

title: BANYAN. XI. The BANYAN multivariate Bayesian algorithm to identify members of young associations within 150 pc
input: BANYAN is a new Bayesian algorithm to identify members of young stellar associations within 150 pc of the Sun. It includes 27 young associations with ages in the range ~1-800 Myr, modelled with multivariate Gaussians in 6-dimensional XYZUVW space. It is the first such multi-association classification tool to include the nearest sub-groups of the Sco-Cen OB star-forming region, the IC 2602, IC 2391, Pleiades and Platais 8 clusters, and the Ophiuchi, Corona Australis, and Taurus star-formation regions. A model of field stars is built from a mixture of multivariate Gaussians based on the Besançon Galactic model. The algorithm can derive membership probabilities for objects with only sky coordinates and proper motion, but can also include parallax and radial velocity measurements, as well as spectrophotometric distance constraints from sequences in color-magnitude or spectral type-magnitude diagrams. BANYAN benefits from an analytical solution to the Bayesian marginalization integrals that makes it more accurate and significantly faster than its predecessor BANYAN II. A contamination versus hit rate analysis is presented and demonstrates that BANYAN achieves a better classification performance than other moving group classification tools, especially in terms of cross-contamination between young associations. An updated list of bona fide members in the 27 young associations, augmented by the Gaia-DR1 release, are presented. This new tool will make it possible to analyze large data sets such as the upcoming Gaia-DR2 to identify new young stars. IDL and Python versions of BANYAN are made available with this publication. (shortened)

output.explanation:
The Sun's vicinity is home to numerous young stellar associations, each with distinct ages and spatial distributions. These groups are characterized by their shared age and kinematic properties. A key challenge in identifying association members lies in distinguishing them from field stars, which have diverse origins and motions.

To address this issue, the concept of multivariate Gaussians is employed to model young associations in 6-dimensional space, incorporating XYZUVW coordinates. This approach allows for a nuanced representation of each group's age and kinematic properties. The Besançon Galactic model serves as a foundation for constructing a field star model, comprising a mixture of multivariate Gaussians.

The BANYAN algorithm leverages an analytical solution to Bayesian marginalization integrals, enhancing its accuracy and speed compared to previous tools like BANYAN II. By incorporating various data types, including sky coordinates, proper motion, parallax, radial velocity measurements, and spectrophotometric distance constraints, BANYAN can derive membership probabilities for objects within these young associations.

A critical evaluation of contamination versus hit rate demonstrates that BANYAN outperforms other moving group classification tools in terms of cross-contamination between young associations. This improved performance enables the identification of bona fide members within each association.

title: Pinpointing astrophysical bursts of low-energy neutrinos embedded into the noise
input: We propose a novel method to increase the probability of identifying impulsive astrophysical bursts of low-energy neutrinos. The proposed approach exploits the temporal structure differences between astrophysical bursts and background fluctuations and it allows us to pinpoint weak signals otherwise unlikely to be detected. With respect to previous search strategies, this method strongly reduces the misidentification probability, e.g. for Super Kamiokande this reduction is a factor of within a distance of kpc without decreasing the detection efficiency. In addition, we extend the proposed method to a network of different detectors and we show that the Kamland LVD background reduction is improved by a factor up to an horizon of kpc.

output.explanation:
Astrophysical environments are characterized by intense energy releases, such as supernovae or neutron star mergers. These events produce bursts of low-energy neutrinos that can be detected through their arrival times and energies.

The term 'temporal structure' refers to the pattern of signal arrivals in time, while 'background reduction' denotes a decrease in random fluctuations within detectors.

Astrophysical bursts have distinct temporal structures compared to background fluctuations. The proposed method exploits these differences to enhance detection efficiency by pinpointing weak signals that would otherwise be undetected. This approach reduces misidentification probability without compromising detection efficiency.

Within a distance of kpc, the reduction in misidentification probability is significant for Super Kamiokande, and extending this method to multiple detectors improves background reduction up to an horizon of kpc as seen with Kamland LVD.

title: Fast cosmic web simulations with generative adversarial networks
input: Dark matter in the universe evolves through gravity to form a complex network of halos, filaments, sheets and voids, that is known as the cosmic web. Computational models of the underlying physical processes, such as classical N-body simulations, are extremely resource intensive, as they track the action of gravity in an expanding universe using billions of particles as tracers of the cosmic matter distribution. Therefore, upcoming cosmology experiments will face a computational bottleneck that may limit the exploitation of their full scientific potential. To address this challenge, we demonstrate the application of a machine learning technique called Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN) to learn models that can efficiently generate new, physically realistic realizations of the cosmic web. Our training set is a small, representative sample of 2D image snapshots from N-body simulations of size 500 and 100 Mpc. We show that the GAN-generated samples are qualitatively and quantitatively very similar to the originals. For the larger boxes of size 500 Mpc, it is very difficult to distinguish them visually. The agreement of the power spectrum is 1-2\% for most of the range, between and . An important advantage of generating cosmic web realizations with a GAN is the considerable gains in terms of computation time. Each new sample generated by a GAN takes a fraction of a second, compared to the many hours needed by traditional N-body techniques. We anticipate that the use of generative models such as GANs will therefore play an important role in providing extremely fast and precise simulations of cosmic web in the era of large cosmological surveys, such as Euclid and Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST).

output.explanation:
The universe's cosmic web is a complex network of dark matter structures formed through gravity-driven evolution, comprising halos, filaments, sheets, and voids.

Key terms such as 'cosmic web' refer to this intricate structure, while 'N-body simulations' describe computational modeling techniques used to track the action of gravity in an expanding universe with billions of particles. In these models, each particle represents a tracer of cosmic matter distribution.

The gravitational interactions between particles drive the formation and evolution of dark matter structures within the cosmic web. Machine learning techniques like Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN) can efficiently generate new realizations of this complex network by learning from existing samples.

GAN-generated samples are found to be very similar to originals, with an agreement in power spectrum for most of the range between certain values. This is particularly evident in larger boxes where it becomes difficult to visually distinguish between original and generated samples. The use of GANs offers significant gains in computation time, allowing each new sample to be generated quickly compared to traditional N-body techniques.

title: Orbital radius during the grazing envelope evolution
input: We use the binary module of the MESA code to study the evolution of an evolved binary system where we assume that a main sequence companion removes the outskirts of the envelope of an asymptotic giant branch (AGB) star by launching jets, and explore the characteristics of this grazing envelope evolution (GEE). We base our assumption that jets launched by the secondary star remove a substantial fraction of the outskirts of the envelope of an AGB star on earlier hydrodynamical simulations. We find that in many cases that we study, but not in all cases, the binary system experiences the GEE rather than entering the common envelope phase, under our assumptions of jet-driven mass removal. To prevent the common envelope phase, we assume the secondary star may accrete a large amount of mass in a short time while avoiding rapid inflation, the feasibility of which requires further study. Because of our simplifying assumptions we cannot yet present the parameter space for the GEE. Although the incorporation of the GEE into population synthesis numerical codes requires further studies of the GEE, we conclude that analyses of population synthesis studies of evolved binary stars should include the GEE.

output.explanation:
Binary star systems are complex entities that can undergo various evolutionary processes, including the interaction between stars in close proximity to each other.

The term 'asymptotic giant branch' (AGB) refers to a stage in a star's life cycle where it has exhausted its fuel and is expanding into a red supergiant. The envelope of an AGB star is its outer layer, composed of gas and dust that surrounds the core.

The concept of 'jet-driven mass removal' involves high-speed streams of gas ejected from one star interacting with another star's envelope, potentially stripping away material. This process relies on earlier hydrodynamical simulations for support. A jet is a stream of gas accelerated to high speeds by an astrophysical object such as a star or black hole.

The interaction between the jets and the AGB star's envelope can lead to grazing envelope evolution (GEE), where material from the envelope is gradually stripped away, potentially preventing the common envelope phase under certain assumptions about jet-driven mass removal. However, this process requires careful consideration of factors like accretion rates and inflationary processes.

title: Identification of multiple hard X-ray sources in solar flares: A Bayesian analysis of the February 20 2002 event
input: The hard X-ray emission in a solar flare is typically characterized by a number of discrete sources, each with its own spectral, temporal, and spatial variability. Establishing the relationship amongst these sources is critical to determine the role of each in the energy release and transport processes that occur within the flare. In this paper we present a novel method to identify and characterize each source of hard X-ray emission. The method permits a quantitative determination of the most likely number of subsources present, and of the relative probabilities that the hard X-ray emission in a given subregion of the flare is represented by a complicated multiple source structure or by a simpler single source. We apply the method to a well-studied flare on 2002~February~20 in order to assess competing claims as to the number of chromospheric footpoint sources present, and hence to the complexity of the underlying magnetic geometry/toplogy. Contrary to previous claims of the need for multiple sources to account for the chromospheric hard X-ray emission at different locations and times, we find that a simple two-footpoint-plus-coronal-source model is the most probable explanation for the data. We also find that one of the footpoint sources moves quite rapidly throughout the event, a factor that presumably complicated previous analyses. The inferred velocity of the footpoint corresponds to a very high induced electric field, compatible with those in thin reconnecting current sheets.

output.explanation:
Solar flares are intense events in the Sun's atmosphere, characterized by hard X-ray emission from multiple discrete sources with unique properties that vary spectrally, temporally, and spatially.

Key terms include subsources, which refer to individual components within each source, and relative probabilities, describing the likelihood of observing different types of source configurations. Subsources can be thought of as distinct entities within a larger source structure.

In solar flares, energy release and transport processes occur due to magnetic reconnection events in the corona, where complex interactions between subsources contribute to overall variability. The movement of footpoint sources throughout an event complicates our understanding of underlying magnetic geometry/topology.

A simple two-footpoint-plus-coronal-source model is found to be the most probable explanation for hard X-ray emission in a well-studied flare on February 20, contradicting previous claims suggesting multiple sources were necessary. The inferred velocity of one footpoint source corresponds to a high induced electric field, consistent with those in thin reconnecting current sheets.

title: Different is More: The Value of Finding an Inhabited Planet that is Far From Earth 2.0
input: The search for an inhabited planet, other than our own, is a driver of planetary exploration in our solar system and beyond. Using information from our own planet to inform search strategies allows for a targeted search. It is, however, worth considering some span in the strategy and in a priori expectation. An inhabited Earth-like planet is one that would be similar to Earth in ways that extend beyond having biota. To facilitate analysis, we introduce a metric that extends from zero, for an inhabited planet that is like Earth in all other regards (i.e., zero differences), toward positive or negative values for planets that differ from Earth. The analysis shows how assessment of life potential in our galaxy changes more significantly if we find an inhabited planet that is less Earth-like (i.e., it quantifies how probability assessments improve with deviations from Earth-likeness). Discovering such planets could also provide a test of the strong form of the Gaia hypothesis - a test that has proved difficult using only the Earth as a laboratory. Lastly, we discuss how an Earth2.0 narrative, that has been presented to the public as a search strategy, comes with nostalgia-laden philosophical baggage that does not best serve exploration.

output.explanation:
The search for an inhabited planet is a driving force behind planetary exploration in our solar system and beyond. This pursuit relies on understanding the characteristics of Earth, which serves as a reference point for identifying potential life-bearing planets. An Earth-like planet extends beyond having biota; it must also share similarities with Earth in terms such as atmospheric composition, temperature range, and geological activity.

To quantify these differences, we introduce a metric that ranges from zero to positive or negative values, depending on how closely a planet resembles Earth. This approach allows for the assessment of life potential in our galaxy to be reevaluated based on deviations from Earth-likeness. The analysis reveals that discovering an inhabited planet with distinct characteristics could significantly impact probability assessments.

The strong form of the Gaia hypothesis proposes that life influences its environment, and finding a less Earth-like inhabited planet would provide a unique opportunity to test this concept. This discovery would also serve as a more robust laboratory for studying the relationship between life and its surroundings compared to relying solely on Earth.

An alternative search strategy, often referred to as an 'Earth2.0' narrative, has been presented to the public but carries nostalgia-laden philosophical connotations that may not be conducive to exploration.

title: Deep Water Cycling and Delayed Onset Cooling of the Earth
input: Changes that occur on our planet can be tracked back to one of two energy sources: the sun and the Earth's internal energy. The motion of tectonic plates, volcanism, mountain building and the reshaping of our planet's surface over geologic time depend on the Earth's internal energy. Tectonic activity is driven by internal energy and affects the rate at which energy is tapped, i.e., the cooling rate of our planet. Petrologic data indicate that cooling did not occur at a constant rate over geologic history. Interior cooling was mild until ~2.5 billion years ago and then increased (Figure 1). As the Earth cools, it cycles water between its rocky interior (crust and mantle) and its surface. Water affects the viscosity of mantle rock, which affects the pace of tectonics and, by association, Earth cooling. We present suites of thermal-tectonic history models, coupled to deep water cycling, to show that the petrologically constrained change in the Earth's cooling rate can be accounted for by variations in deep water cycling over geologic time. The change in cooling rate does not require a change in the global tectonic mode of the Earth. It can be accounted for by a change in the balance of water cycling between the Earth's interior and its surface envelopes. The nature and timing of that water cycling change can be correlated to a change in the nature of continental crust and an associated rise of atmospheric oxygen. The prediction that the rise of oxygen should then be correlated, in time, to the change in the Earth's cooling rate is consistent with data constraints.

output.explanation:
The Earth's surface is shaped by internal heat and solar energy, driving geological processes that reshape the planet over time. Key terms: Petrology refers to the study of rocks; Viscosity measures a fluid's resistance to flow; Tectonics involves the movement of large sections of the Earth's crust.

The interaction between tectonic activity and water cycling is critical in understanding changes in the Earth's cooling rate. As the planet cools, it cycles water through its rocky interior and surface envelopes, influencing mantle rock viscosity and tectonic pace. This process affects how quickly the Earth loses heat.

The coupling of thermal-tectonic history models with deep water cycling explains variations in the Earth's cooling rate without requiring a change in global tectonics. Instead, changes in water cycling balance account for this phenomenon by influencing continental crust nature and rising atmospheric oxygen levels. The prediction that oxygen rise should correlate with cooling rate changes is consistent with data constraints.

The Earth's internal energy drives tectonic activity, which affects the planet's cooling rate through water cycling between its interior and surface.

title: Wavelet theory applied to the study of spectra of trans-Neptunian objects
input: Reflection spectroscopy in the Near Infrared (NIR) is used to investigate the surface composition of Trans-Neptunian objects (TNOs). In general, these spectra are difficult to interpret due to the low apparent brightness of the TNOs, causing low signal-to-noise ratio even in spectra obtained with the largest telescopes available on the Earth, making necessary to use filtering techniques to analyze and interpret them. The purpose of this paper is to present a methodology to analyze the spectra of TNOs. Specifically, we aim at filtering these spectra in the best possible way: maximizing the remotion of noise, while minimizing the loss of signal. We use wavelets to filter the spectra. The wavelets are a mathematical tool that decomposes the signal into its constituent parts, allowing to analyze the data in different areas of frequencies with the resolution of each component tied to its scale. To check the reliability of our method, we compare the filtered spectra with spectra of water and methanol ices to identify some common structures between them. Of the 50 TNOs of our sample, we identify traces of the presence of water ices and methanol in the spectra of several of them, some with previous reports, while for other objects there were no previous reports. We conclude that the wavelet technique is successful in filtering spectra of TNOs.

output.explanation:
The vast, icy expanse of the Trans-Neptunian region is home to small bodies known as Trans-Neptunian objects (TNOs).

The term wavelet refers to a mathematical tool used for signal decomposition into constituent parts, allowing analysis in different frequency ranges with resolution tied to their scale. Wavelets are particularly useful when dealing with signals that have varying frequencies and amplitudes.

Wavelet filtering is an effective method for decomposing Near Infrared (NIR) spectra of TNOs, enabling a precise understanding of spectral features. By applying this technique to 50 TNOs, researchers have identified common structures between water and methanol ices in the NIR spectra of several objects. These findings suggest that some TNOs contain traces of water ices and methanol, which is consistent with previous reports for certain objects.

The wavelet method is successful in filtering spectra of TNOs, allowing researchers to extract valuable information from low-quality data obtained using even the largest telescopes available on Earth.

title: A Pulsar Wind Nebula Model Applied to Short GRB 050724
input: A subset of short gamma-ray bursts (sGRBs) have been found to be characterized by near-infrared/optical bumps at days, some of which exhibit almost concurrent X-ray flares. Although the near-infrared/optical bumps may be a signature of kilonovae, the X-ray flares are not consistent with kilonovae. It is widely believed that sGRBs are produced by the mergers of double compact objects, during which sub-relativistic ejecta are launched. In this paper we propose that the above optical/X-ray features are indicative of the formation of long-lived magnetars following the mergers of double neutron stars. Observations and theoretical works imply that the spin-down power of the magnetars is injected into the ejecta as ultra-relativistic electron-positron pairs, i.e. pulsar wind nebulae (PWNe). Here we suggest such a PWN model and find that the optical bump and X-ray flare observed in GRB 050724 can be well understood in this PWN model. We show that the optical bump and X-ray flare may have different origins. Our results strengthen the evidence for the formation of magnetars in double neutron star mergers and justify the validity of the PWN model.

output.explanation:
Gamma-ray bursts originating from the mergers of double compact objects are characterized by intense radiation across various wavelengths, including near-infrared and optical signals that appear as bumps at days after the event.

A key concept in understanding these features is the definition of a magnetar: a type of neutron star with an extremely strong magnetic field. Magnetars can emit intense radiation as they spin down, injecting energy into their surroundings through pulsar wind nebulae (PWNe).

The interaction between the magnetars and the surrounding ejecta leads to the formation of PWNe, where ultra-relativistic electron-positron pairs are produced. This process is thought to be responsible for the observed optical bumps in some sGRBs.

The PWN model suggests that these features may have different origins: the optical bump resulting from the magnetar's spin-down power and potentially other processes giving rise to X-ray flares, which do not appear consistent with kilonovae.

title: Toward an understanding of GRB prompt emission mechanism: II. Patterns of peak energy evolution and their connection to spectral lags
input: The prompt emission phase of gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) exhibits two distinct patterns of the peak-energy ( ) evolution, i.e., time-resolved spectral analyses of spectra of broad pulses reveal (1) "hard-to-soft" and (2) "flux-tracking" patterns of evolution in time, the physical origin of which still remains not well understood. We show here that these two patterns can be successfully reproduced within a simple physical model invoking synchrotron radiation in a bulk-accelerating emission region. We show further that the evolution patterns of the peak energy have, in fact, direct connections to the existence of two different (positive or negative) types of spectral lags, seen in the broad pulses. In particular, we predict that (1) only the positive type of spectral lags is possible for the hard-to-soft evolution of the peak energy, (2) both the positive and negative type of spectral lags can occur in the case of flux-tracking pattern of the peak energy, (3) for the flux-tracking pattern, the peak location of the flux light curve slightly lags behind the peak of the evolution with time if the spectral lags are positive, and (4) in the case of flux-tracking pattern, double-peaked broad pulses can appear in the light curves, the shape of which is energy-dependent.

output.explanation:
Gamma-ray bursts occur in the universe, producing intense radiation across a broad spectrum of energies. Synchrotron radiation is a key process involved in this phenomenon, where charged particles emit photons as they accelerate through magnetic fields. This type of radiation has frequency dependence and polarization properties.

The hard-to-soft evolution pattern refers to the decrease of peak energy over time, while flux-tracking involves a more complex relationship between peak energy and total flux. These patterns are linked to different types of spectral lags, which describe delays in high-energy photon arrival times relative to low-energy ones.

In gamma-ray bursts, charged particles interact with magnetic fields within an accelerating emission region. This interaction leads to synchrotron radiation, exhibiting complex frequency dependence and polarization properties. The resulting patterns of peak-energy evolution are a result of this process.

The hard-to-soft pattern is associated with positive spectral lags, while flux-tracking can exhibit both types of lags. In cases where spectral lags are positive, the peak location of the flux light curve will lag behind the energy evolution over time.

title: Fast Standing Modes in Transversely Nonuniform Solar Coronal Slabs: Effects of a Finite Plasma Beta
input: We examine the dispersive properties of linear fast standing modes in transversely nonuniform solar coronal slabs with finite gas pressure, or, equivalently, finite plasma beta. We derive a generic dispersion relation governing fast waves in coronal slabs for which the continuous transverse distributions of the physical parameters comprise a uniform core, a uniform external medium, and a transition layer (TL) in between. The profiles in the TL are allowed to be essentially arbitrary. Restricting ourselves to the first several branches of fast modes, which are of most interest from the observational standpoint, we find that a finite plasma beta plays an at most marginal role in influencing the periods ( ), damping times ( ), and critical longitudinal wavenumbers ( ), when both and are measured in units of the transverse fast time. However, these parameters are in general significantly affected by how the TL profiles are described. We conclude that, for typical coronal structures, the dispersive properties of the first several branches of fast standing modes can be evaluated with the much simpler theory for cold slabs provided that the transverse profiles are properly addressed and the transverse Alfvén time in cold MHD is replaced with the transverse fast time.

output.explanation:
The solar corona is a region of intense magnetic activity, where fast waves play a crucial role in the dynamics of plasma flows.

Plasma beta refers to the ratio of gas pressure to magnetic field strength, while transverse fast time represents a characteristic timescale for wave propagation across the slab's width. Alfvén time, on the other hand, is related to MHD and serves as a reference point for understanding wave behavior in cold plasmas.

In systems with finite plasma beta, the interaction between distinct regions of the coronal slab - including its uniform core, external medium, and transition layer (TL) - gives rise to complex dispersive properties. The TL's arbitrary profiles allow for diverse physical behavior, influencing how fast waves propagate through these structures.

The periods, damping times, and critical longitudinal wavenumbers of these waves are significantly affected by the TL profiles when measured in units of the transverse fast time. However, finite plasma beta has only a marginal effect on these parameters.

title: Nobeyama 45m Cygnus-X CO survey I: photodissociation of molecules revealed by the unbiased large-scale CN and C O maps
input: We present an unbiased large-scale (9 deg ) CN ( =1-0) and C O ( =1-0) survey of Cygnus-X conducted with the Nobeyama 45m Cygnus-X CO survey. CN and C O are detected in various objects towards the Cygnus-X North and South (e.g., DR17, DR18, DR21, DR22, DR23, and W75N). We find that CN/C O integrated intensity ratios are systematically different from region to region, and are especially enhanced in DR17 and DR18 which are irradiated by the nearby OB stars. This result suggests that CN/C O ratios are enhanced via photodissociation reactions. We investigate the relation between the CN/C O ratio and strength of the UV radiation field. As a result, we find that CN/C O ratios correlate with the far-UV intensities, . We also find that CN/C O ratios decrease inside molecular clouds, where the interstellar UV radiation is reduced due to the interstellar dust extinction. We conclude that the CN/C O ratio is controlled by the UV radiation, and is a good probe of photon-dominated regions.

output.explanation:
The interstellar medium in the Cygnus-X region is a complex environment where various objects interact with each other through radiation and gas dynamics. Key terms to understand this context include photodissociation reactions, which are chemical processes that break down molecules into atoms under the influence of ultraviolet (UV) radiation. Photodissociation can enhance the abundance of certain species relative to others in a region. 

The Cygnus-X North and South regions contain various objects such as DR17, DR18, DR21, DR22, DR23, and W75N, where CN and CO molecules are detected. The integrated intensity ratios of CN/CO vary systematically across these regions, with enhanced values observed in DR17 and DR18 due to their proximity to nearby OB stars that emit intense UV radiation. 

The relationship between the CN/CO ratio and the strength of the UV radiation field is investigated, revealing a correlation between the two quantities. Specifically, it is found that the CN/CO ratio increases with far-UV intensity. Additionally, within molecular clouds where interstellar dust extinction reduces the UV radiation, the CN/CO ratios decrease. 

The observed behavior suggests that the CN/CO ratio serves as an indicator of photon-dominated regions and is controlled by the UV radiation field.

title: Constant-roll tachyon inflation and observational constraints
input: For the constant-roll tachyon inflation, we derive the analytical expressions for the scalar and tensor power spectra, the scalar and tensor spectral tilts and the tensor to scalar ratio up to the first order by using the method of Bessel function approximation. The derived results for the constant-roll inflation are also compared with the observations, we find that only one constant-roll inflation is consistent with the observations and observations constrain the constant-roll inflation to be slow-roll inflation. The tachyon potential is also reconstructed for the constant-roll inflation which is consistent with the observations.

output.explanation:
In the realm of cosmology, tachyon inflation represents a type of cosmic expansion driven by hypothetical fields called tachyons. The constant-roll scenario assumes that these fields' potential energies are slowly varying over time.

Key terms in this context include slow-roll inflation, which describes a regime where the universe expands slowly due to the tachyon field's potential energy; and Bessel function approximation, a mathematical technique used for simplifying complex expressions. Additionally, scalar power spectra refer to fluctuations in matter density on large scales, while tensor modes represent gravitational waves.

The mechanism at play involves the interaction between the tachyon field, its potential energy, and the universe's expansion history. The constant-roll condition implies that this interaction occurs slowly over time, with a gradual roll of the tachyon field's potential energy.

According to analytical expressions derived using Bessel function approximation, only one type of constant-roll inflation is consistent with observational data. Observations also constrain constant-roll inflation to be slow-roll in nature.

title: Observations of excitation and damping of transversal oscillation in coronal loops by AIA/SDO
input: The excitation and damping of transversal coronal loop oscillations and quantitative relation between damping time, damping quality (damping time per period), oscillation amplitude, dissipation mechanism and the wake phenomena are investigated. The observed time series data with the (AIA) telescope on NASA's (SDO) satellite on 2015 March 2, consisting of 400 consecutive images with 12 seconds cadence in the 171 pass band is analyzed for evidence of transversal oscillations along the coronal loops by Lomb-Scargle periodgram. In this analysis signatures of transversal coronal loop oscillations that are damped rapidly were found with dominant oscillation periods in the range of minutes. Also, damping times and damping qualities of transversal coronal loop oscillations at dominant oscillation periods are estimated in the range of minutes and , respectively. The observational results of this analysis show that damping qualities decrease slowly with increasing the amplitude of oscillation, but periods of oscillations are not sensitive function of amplitude of oscillations. The order of magnitude of the damping qualities and damping times are in good agreement with previous findings and the theoretical prediction for damping of kink mode oscillations by dissipation mechanism. Furthermore, oscillation of loop segments attenuate with time roughly as that magnitude values of for 30 different segments change from 0.51 to 0.75.

output.explanation:
Solar coronal loops are dynamic structures that can exhibit oscillatory behavior in the solar atmosphere, where hot plasma is confined by magnetic fields. Key terms include transversal motion, which refers to back-and-forth movement along a loop's length, and kink mode, describing specific wave propagation in magnetized plasmas with restoring forces provided by magnetic tension.

Dissipation mechanism involves processes that convert energy from one form to another, such as heat or radiation, leading to oscillation damping. In this context, dissipation can be caused by interactions between the plasma and its surroundings.

The interaction between rapidly damped transversal coronal loop oscillations and their surroundings is complex. The plasma's back-and-forth motion along the loop's length can be influenced by various factors, including magnetic tension and energy dissipation. As a result, the oscillation amplitude affects damping quality, but not the period.

The observed attenuation of loop segment oscillations with time suggests that these phenomena are subject to certain limits. The magnitude values for 30 different segments change from 0.51 to 0.75 over time, indicating a gradual decrease in oscillatory energy.

title: Analysis of a Failed Eclipse Plasma Ejection Using EUV Observations
input: The photometry of eclipse white-light (W-L) images showing a moving blob is interpreted for the first time together with observations from space with the PRoject for On Board Autonomy (PROBA-2) mission (ESA). An off-limb event seen with great details in W-L was analyzed with the SWAP imager (Sun Watcher using Active pixel system detector and image Processing) working in the EUV near 174 A. It is an elongated plasma blob structure of 25 Mm diameter moving above the E-limb with coronal loops under. Summed and co-aligned SWAP images are evaluated using a 20 hours sequence, in addition to the July 11, 2010 eclipse W-L images taken from several sites. The Atmospheric Imaging Assembly (AIA) instruments on board the Solar Dynamical Observatory (SDO) recorded the event suggesting a magnetic reconnection near a high neutral point; accordingly, we also call it a magnetic plasmoid. The measured proper motion of the blob shows a velocity up to 12 km s^-1. Electron densities of the isolated condensation (cloud or blob or plasmoid) is photometrically evaluated. The typical value is 10^8 cm^-3 at r=1.7 R, superposed on a background corona of 10^7 cm^-3 density. The mass of the cloud near its maximum brightness is found to be 1.6x10^13 gr which is typically 0.6x10^-4 of the overall mass of the corona. From the extrapolated magnetic field the cloud evolves inside a rather broad open region but decelerates, after reaching its maximum brightness. The influence of such small events for supplying material to the ubiquitous slow wind is noticed. A precise evaluation of the EUV photometric data after accurately removing the stray light, suggests an interpretation of the weak 174 A radiation of the cloud as due to resonance scattering in the Fe IX/X lines.

output.explanation:
The sun's outer atmosphere, the corona, is a dynamic region where magnetic fields and plasma interact.

Key terms in this context include EUV - extreme ultraviolet radiation, which can be detected by specialized instruments like the SWAP imager working near 174 A; coronal loops - twisted structures that connect the sun's surface to its corona; and magnetic reconnection - a process where magnetic field lines break and reform. Another important concept is plasma blob structure.

The interaction between magnetic fields, plasma, and EUV radiation leads to the formation of moving blobs in the solar corona. This phenomenon involves reconnection at high neutral points, resulting in rapidly moving structures with velocities up to 12 km s^-1. The electron density within these blobs was found to be around 10^8 cm^-3 at r=1.7 R.

The mass of the cloud near its maximum brightness is approximately 0.6x10^-4 of the overall mass of the corona, and it evolves inside a broad open region before decelerating.

title: γ Doradus stars as test of angular momentum transport models
input: Helioseismology and asteroseismology of red giant stars have shown that the distribution of angular momentum in stellar interiors, and its evolution with time remains an open issue in stellar physics. Owing to the unprecedented quality of Kepler photometry, we are able to seismically infer internal rotation rates in γDoradus stars, which provide the MS counterpart to the red-giants puzzle. We confront these internal rotation rates to stellar evolution models with rotationally induced transport of angular momentum, in order to test angular momentum transport mechanisms. We used a stellar model-independent method developed by Christophe et al. in order to obtain seismically inferred, buoyancy radii and near-core rotation for 37 γDoradus stars observed by Kepler. We show that the buoyancy radius can be used as a reliable evolution indicator for field stars on the MS. We computed rotating evolutionary models including transport of angular momentum in radiative zones, following Zahn and Maeder, with the CESTAM code. This code calculates the rotational history of stars from the birth line to the tip of the RGB. The initial angular momentum content has to be set initially, which is done by fitting rotation periods in young stellar clusters. We show a clear disagreement between the near-core rotation rates measured in the sample and the rotation rates obtained from evolutionary models including rotationally induced transport following Zahn (1992). These results show a disagreement similar to that of the Sun and red giant stars. This suggests the existence of missing mechanisms responsible for the braking of the core before and along the MS. The efficiency of the missing mechanisms is investigated. The transport of angular momentum as formalized by Zahn and Maeder cannot explain the measurements of near-core rotation in main-sequence intermediate-mass stars we have at hand.

output.explanation:
The interior of stars, particularly those on the main sequence and red giants, is characterized by a complex interplay between internal rotation rates and angular momentum transport mechanisms.

Angular momentum refers to the tendency of rotating objects to maintain their rotational velocity due to conservation laws. In stars, this manifests as the rate at which material rotates around the axis passing through its center. Buoyancy radius is a measure used to infer internal rotation rates and can serve as a reliable indicator for field stars on the main sequence.

Radiative zones are regions within stars where energy transport occurs primarily through radiation rather than convection. The CESTAM code calculates rotational histories of stars from birth to red giant branch tip, assuming initial angular momentum content based on fitting rotation periods in young stellar clusters. However, a clear disagreement exists between measured near-core rotation rates and those obtained from evolutionary models incorporating Zahn's transport mechanism.

This suggests the presence of missing mechanisms responsible for core braking before and during main-sequence evolution.

title: Polarity imbalance of the photospheric magnetic field
input: Polarity imbalance of the photospheric magnetic field was studied using synoptic maps of NSO Kitt Peak (1976-2016). Imbalance of positive and negative fluxes was considered for the fields with strength B>50 G in the sunspot zone (5 deg - 40 deg) and for the fields with strength B<50 G at higher latitudes (40 deg - 90 deg). The 22-year periodicity in the imbalance of positive and negative fields was found which maintained itself during four solar cycles. While for the sunspot zone the sign of the imbalance always coincides with the northern hemisphere polarity, for the high latitudes the sign of the imbalance always coincides with the southern hemisphere polarity. Good correspondence of the flux imbalance with the quadrupole moment (g20) of the potential-field source-surface (PFSS) model was observed. The polarity imbalance of the sunspot zone correlates, on one hand, with the asymmetry of the magnetic field of the Sun-as-a-star and, on the other hand, with the sector structure of the interplanetary magnetic field. The obtained results show the close connection of the magnetic fields in active regions with the Sun's polar magnetic field. The weakest fields B<5 G represent quite a special group with the magnetic flux developing in antiphase to the fluxes of the stronger fields.

output.explanation:
The sun's magnetic field is a complex system influenced by its photospheric layer, where the visible light is emitted. The term 'photosphere' refers to this outermost layer of the sun's atmosphere.

The potential-field source-surface model represents the mathematical framework used to understand the structure and behavior of the solar magnetic field. This model helps in identifying key characteristics such as the quadrupole moment (g20).

The interaction between strong and weak magnetic fields plays a crucial role in shaping the sun's overall magnetic landscape. The 22-year periodicity observed in the imbalance of positive and negative fluxes indicates a persistent pattern in the sunspot zone, closely linked to the northern hemisphere's polarity. In contrast, higher latitudes exhibit an opposing pattern where the sign of the imbalance coincides with the southern hemisphere's polarity.

The results demonstrate that the weakest magnetic fields (B<5 G) develop their flux in antiphase to stronger fields, highlighting a unique characteristic within this group.

title: SEURAT: SPH scheme extended with ultraviolet line radiative transfer
input: We present a novel Lyman alpha (Ly ) radiative transfer code, SEURAT, where line scatterings are solved adaptively with the resolution of the smoothed particle hydrodynamics (SPH). The radiative transfer method implemented in SEURAT is based on a Monte Carlo algorithm in which the scattering and absorption by dust are also incorporated. We perform standard test calculations to verify the validity of the code; (i) emergent spectra from a static uniform sphere, (ii) emergent spectra from an expanding uniform sphere, and (iii) escape fraction from a dusty slab. Thereby we demonstrate that our code solves the Ly radiative transfer with sufficient accuracy. We emphasise that SEURAT can treat the transfer of Ly photons even in highly complex systems that have significantly inhomogeneous density fields. The high adaptivity of SEURAT is desirable to solve the propagation of Ly photons in the interstellar medium of young star-forming galaxies like Ly emitters (LAEs). Thus, SEURAT provides a powerful tool to model the emergent spectra of Ly emission, which can be compared to the observations of LAEs.

output.explanation:
The interstellar medium of young star-forming galaxies, such as those emitting Lyman alpha radiation, is a complex environment with inhomogeneous density fields. In this context, the propagation of Ly photons plays a crucial role.

The code SEURAT solves radiative transfer problems using an adaptive Monte Carlo algorithm that incorporates scattering and absorption by dust. This approach allows for high accuracy in solving line scatterings within smoothed particle hydrodynamics (SPH) resolution.

Key to understanding this is the concept of Lyman alpha radiation, which involves a specific wavelength of light emitted during the recombination of hydrogen atoms after star formation. The term 'smoothed particle hydrodynamics' refers to a numerical method for simulating fluid dynamics using particles rather than grid cells.

The SEURAT code's adaptivity is essential in treating complex systems like those found in young galaxies, where density fields are significantly inhomogeneous. This enables the accurate modeling of emergent spectra from Ly emission, which can be compared to observations.

title: Constraining Primordial non-Gaussianity with Bispectrum and Power Spectum from Upcoming Optical and Radio Surveys
input: We forecast constraints on primordial non-Gaussianity (PNG) and bias parameters from measurements of galaxy power spectrum and bispectrum in future radio continuum and optical surveys. In the galaxy bispectrum, we consider a comprehensive list of effects, including the bias expansion for non-Gaussian initial conditions up to second order, redshift space distortions, redshift uncertainties and theoretical errors. These effects are all combined in a single PNG forecast for the first time. Moreover, we improve the bispectrum modelling over previous forecasts, by accounting for trispectrum contributions. All effects have an impact on final predicted bounds, which varies with the type of survey. We find that the bispectrum can lead to improvements up to a factor over bounds based on the power spectrum alone, leading to significantly better constraints for local-type PNG, with respect to current limits from . Future radio and photometric surveys could obtain a measurement error of . In the case of equilateral PNG, galaxy bispectrum can improve upon present bounds only if significant improvements in the redshift determinations of future, large volume, photometric or radio surveys could be achieved. For orthogonal non-Gaussianity, expected constraints are generally comparable to current ones.

output.explanation:
The universe's large-scale structure is shaped by the distribution of galaxies, which can be influenced by primordial non-Gaussianity (PNG). PNG arises from deviations in the initial conditions of the universe, causing variations in galaxy distributions. The bias expansion for non-Gaussian initial conditions up to second order refers to how these deviations affect the relationship between galaxy and matter distributions.

The redshift space distortions occur when light from galaxies is shifted due to the expansion of the universe, while redshift uncertainties arise from imprecise measurements of a galaxy's distance. Theoretical errors stem from limitations in our understanding of the underlying physics. These effects are combined to forecast constraints on PNG parameters using future radio continuum and optical surveys.

The bispectrum describes how galaxies cluster together, influenced by bias expansion, redshift space distortions, and theoretical errors. This complex interplay affects the accuracy of predicted bounds, which vary depending on the type of survey conducted.

Galaxy bispectrum measurements can improve upon power spectrum analysis by up to a factor for local-type PNG, leading to better constraints than current limits. However, this approach depends on significant improvements in redshift determinations for future surveys.

title: ALMA spectral line and imaging survey of a low and a high mass-loss rate AGB star between 335 and 362 GHz
input: A spectral line and imaging survey of the low mass-loss rate AGB star R Dor (Mdot ~ 1e-7 Msun/yr) and the high mass-loss rate AGB star IK Tau (Mdot ~5e-6 Msun/yr) was made with ALMA between 335 and 362 GHz at a spatial resolution of ~150 mas, corresponding to the locus of the main dust formation region of both targets. Some 200 spectral features from 15 molecules (and their isotopologues) were observed, including rotational lines in both the ground and vibrationally excited states. Detected species include the gaseous precursors of dust grains such as SiO, AlO, AlOH, TiO, and TiO2. We present a spectral atlas for both stars and the parameters of all detected spectral features. A clear dichotomy for the sulphur chemistry is seen: while CS, SiS, SO, and SO2 are abundantly present in IK Tau, only SO and SO2 are detected in R Dor. Also other species such as NaCl, NS, AlO, and AlOH display a completely different behaviour. From some selected species, the minor isotopologues can be used to assess the isotopic ratios. The channel maps of many species prove that both large and small-scale inhomogeneities persist in the inner wind of both stars in the form of blobs, arcs, and/or a disk. The high sensitivity of ALMA allows us to spot the impact of these correlated density structures in the spectral line profiles. The spectral lines often display a half width at zero intensity much larger than expected from the terminal velocity, v_inf, previously derived for both objects (36 km/s versus v_inf ~17.7 km/s for IK Tau and 23 km/s versus v_inf ~5.5 km/s for R Dor). Both a more complex 3D morphology and a more forceful wind acceleration of the (underlying) isotropic wind can explain this trend. The formation of fractal grains in the region beyond ~400 mas can potentially account for the latter scenario. From the continuum map, we deduce a dust mass of ~3.7e-7 Msun for IK Tau and ~2e-8 Msun for R Dor.

output.explanation:
Stars like R Dor and IK Tau undergo significant mass loss due to strong stellar winds, a phenomenon known as Asymptotic Giant Branch (AGB) evolution.

Key terms include: AGB stars, which are characterized by their low or high mass-loss rates; dust grain formation from gaseous precursors such as SiO. These molecules can be in rotational lines of both the ground and vibrationally excited states. Dust grains form when gas condenses into solid particles.

The process of dust grain formation involves complex interactions between gas and dust particles, including the presence of blobs, arcs, or a disk within the inner wind of these stars. In this context, a dichotomy is observed in sulphur chemistry: while certain species are abundant in IK Tau, others display different behavior in R Dor.

The spectral lines often display half widths at zero intensity larger than expected from terminal velocities v_inf, which can be attributed to variations in the wind acceleration and 3D morphology of these stars. The formation of fractal grains beyond ~400 mas may also contribute to this trend.

title: Constraints on metal oxide and metal hydroxide abundances in the winds of AGB stars - Potential detection of FeO in R Dor
input: Using ALMA, we observed the stellar wind of two oxygen-rich Asymptotic Giant Branch (AGB) stars, IK Tau and R Dor, between 335 and 362 GHz. One aim was to detect metal oxides and metal hydroxides (AlO, AlOH, FeO, MgO, MgOH), some of which are thought to be direct precursors of dust nucleation and growth. We report on the potential first detection of FeO (v=0, Omega=4, J=11-10) in RDor (mass-loss rate, Mdot, ~1e-7 Msun/yr). The presence of FeO in IK Tau (Mdot~5e-6 Msun/yr) cannot be confirmed due to a blend with 29SiS, a molecule that is absent in R Dor. The detection of AlO in R Dor and of AlOH in IK Tau was reported earlier by Decin et al. (2017). All other metal oxides and hydroxides, as well as MgS, remain undetected. We derive a column density N(FeO) of 1.1+/-0.9e15 cm^{-2} in R Dor, or a fractional abundance [FeO/H]~1.5e-8 accounting for non-LTE effects. The derived fractional abundance [FeO/H] is a factor ~20 larger than conventional gas-phase chemical kinetic predictions. This discrepancy may be partly accounted for by the role of vibrationally excited OH in oxidizing Fe, or may be evidence for other currently unrecognised chemical pathways producing FeO. Assuming a constant fractional abundance w.r.t. H_2, the upper limits for the other metals are [MgO/H_2] <5.5e-10 (R Dor) and <7e-11 (IK Tau), [MgOH/H_2] <9e-9 (R Dor) and <1e-9 (IK Tau), [CaO/H_2] <2.5e-9 (R Dor) and <1e-10 (IK Tau), [CaOH/H_2] <6.5e-9 (R Dor) and <9e-10 (IK Tau), and [MgS/H_$] <4.5e-10 (R Dor) and <6e-11 (IK Tau).
